HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Paychecks Rise Only 2.7%, The Lowest Rate in Years
The economic growth that has propelled stocks to record levels has not done the same for the paychecks of American workers, whose earnings rose 2.7 percent in the last 12 months, the smallest amount in the 13 years that records have been kept, the Labor Department said. Inflation was 2.5 percent, and the economy grew 3.5 percent. The amount business spent on health benefits fell by one-tenth of 1 percent; as recently as 1988, the spending was rising 14 percent a year. [Page A1.]
 
Canadian Markets Rally
Investors cheered the vote rejecting sovereignty for Quebec, even though the margin was paper-thin. The Canadian dollar rose sharply, stocks advanced in Toronto, and the Canadian central bank lowered a lending rate. [A8.]
 
Stocks Give Up Big Gain
Stock prices dipped late in the day as traders took profits. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up 42 points on upbeat economic reports and lower interest rates, ended down 1.09 points, at 4,755.48. Broader averages also fell a bit. [D8.]
 
Nabisco Rejects Icahn Proposal
RJR Nabisco rebuffed Carl C. Icahn and Bennett S. LeBow, who have called for an immediate spinoff of its food business from its tobacco operations. It rejected their call for a referendum on the matter. [D4.]
 
New Home Sales Increase
New-home sales recovered in September, lifted by low mortgage rates, the Commerce Department said. The 3.3 percent rise followed an 11.1 percent plunge in August. Consumer confidence weakened slightly. [D2.]
 
Softkey Shares Weaken Again
Softkey International shares fell for the second consecutive day. Investors feared its two takeover offers would dilute its earnings per share. Softkey shares are nearly 40 percent below their 52-week high. Market Place. [D8.]
 
High-Level Meeting on Debt Ceiling
President Clinton plans to meet today with Republican Congressional leaders to discuss an extension of the debt limit, but both sides disagreed about the meeting's agenda. [A19.]
 
Cloud Over Dow Chemical
Dow Chemical finds itself heading down the treacherous path traveled by several implant makers. The company had kept its distance from the suits directed at Dow Corning, half of which it owns. But this week, a Nevada jury ordered Dow Chemical to pay $14.1 million to a woman who said she had been injured by breast implants. [D2.]
 
Digital Takes the Offensive
Digital Equipment is starting a high-energy ad campaign that boasts that the company is past its problems. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Regency Passengers in Turmoil
Regency Cruises threw its passengers into turmoil when it halted operations last weekend. Analysts suggested that new ships and intense competition were hurting other lines, as well. [D5.]
 
New York Sues H & R Block
New York City sued H. & R. Block for deceptive advertising of its electronic filing of taxes and rapid-refund service. [B2.]
 
Development Bank for Middle East
A conference of business and Government leaders in Jordan supported a proposed Middle East Development Bank, with paid-in working funds of $1.25 billion. [A7.]

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Up 3.3% Aided by Lower Loan Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Lower mortgage rates helped generate a recovery in sales of new homes in September, the Commerce Department said yesterday, providing more evidence of steady, moderate growth.
Sales rose 3.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 727,000 units, after a revised 11.1 percent plunge in August to 704,000. 
 September was the fourth consecutive month in which sales of new homes exceeded 700,000 a year -- a level of sales activity not seen in nearly two years, since the four months from September through December 1993.
In another indicator of resurgent economic activity, Chicago purchasing managers said their Chicagoland Business Barometer posted a solid rise in October with big gains in production and orders.
The measure rose to a seasonally adjusted 53.4 in October from 49 in September -- the first monthly gain after four consecutive months of decline -- with any measure above 50 pointing to an expanding manufacturing economy.
But a separate report showed consumers slightly more pessimistic about the economy. The Conference Board, a New York-based business research group, said its consumer confidence index was 97 in October, down from 97.3 in September.
Still, the index was higher from a year ago, when it was 89.1. The index, based on a sample from 5,000 households, works over a 1985 base of 100.
Although the view of the current situation by consumers dimmed, easing to 105.3 in October from 110 in September, they grew more optimistic about the future. The index measuring their sense of future economic conditions rose to 91.5 in October from 88.8 in September.
"This month's readings continue to suggest healthy economic growth ahead." said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
The housing sales report followed a report last week that showed an increase in sales of existing homes as well. The National Association of Realtors reported that sales of existing homes rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September -- the fifth consecutive monthly increase -- to an annual rate of 4.15 million units.
"Tumbling mortgage rates do wonders for the housing market and they certainly have done so during the third quarter," said David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
But sales in the Northeast fell 12 percent in September to a rate of 44,000 a year. That was the lowest rate for the region since sales were running at 38,000 a year in August 1982, the Commerce Department said.
Sales of new homes in the Midwest rose 12.7 percent, to a rate of 151,000 a year, and were up 6.9 percent in the West to 231,000. Sales in the South were down by seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 302,000.

HEADLINE: Some Tobacco Growers Diversify, a Study Finds

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
A new study of tobacco farmers in the United States shows a significant generation gap in the farmers' concern for their economic future and the need to diversify their crops.
The research, believed to be the first comprehensive assessment of American tobacco farmers' attitudes, found that farmers have a strong and continuing economic dependence on tobacco as a crop, and showed that many farmers powerfully identify their interests with those of tobacco companies. 
 But the study also found that younger and more educated farmers were more eager to supplement tobacco income with other ventures and were more concerned about the long-term uncertainties of tobacco agriculture.
Furthermore, 80 percent of tobacco farmers of all ages said that the purchase of foreign tobacco by American manufacturers was a grave threat to their future.
The research, called the United States Tobacco Farmers' Opinion Study, was financed by a $98,000 grant from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The foundation and the organizations that conducted the survey said they had no connection to tobacco companies or anti-tobacco groups.
Telephone interviews with 992 tobacco farmers in six states were conducted in March by researchers from the Bowman Gray School of Medicine of Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., and the Center for Sustainable Systems in Berea, Ky. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
About 37 percent of the growers said they depended on tobacco revenues for more than half of their net family income, and 69 percent said they received at least a quarter of their family income from tobacco.
Two-thirds of the farmers under the age of 45 said they had discovered profitable ventures to supplement tobacco growing.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
Balkan Leaders Face an Hour for Painful Choices

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, once remarked that choosing between President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia was like chosing between "leukemia and a brain tumor."
For all three Presidents, however, the hour of painful choices has now come. After four years of war, the loss of quarter of a million lives, the dispersal of three million refugees and the destruction of their once-shared Yugoslav state, they have been summoned to a bleak American air base near Dayton to confront each other and their responsibilities in talks that start on Wednesday. 
 There will be no joy in their hearts at this prospect. They are used to playing the endless halls of mirrors that constitute Balkan politics, and they are unaccustomed to looking each other in the eye and certainly deeply reluctant to do so.
Even Mr. Tudjman and Mr. Izetbegovic, nominal allies in Bosnia's Muslim-Croat federation, dislike each other with a peculiar intensity. "If only Izetbegovic would sit down and have a drink like a civilized human being, we could do business with him," the Croatian President is fond of telling American visitors. The Bosnian President, a devout Muslim, shuns alcohol.
To Mr. Milosevic, an independent Bosnia was a ludicrous invention -- as much a state, he once suggested, as Caligula's horse was a consul. As for Mr. Tudjman, who has a pronounced taste for creamy, medal-bedecked military uniforms, the dour Serbian President often dismisses him as a buffoon.
"This is a complete snake pit," said a senior American official who will be present at the talks. "But we're ready to play the big snake."
Only after countless aborted agreements and resolutions, culminating with the recent Serbian massacre of several thousand Muslims from the United Nations-designated "safe area" of Srebrenica, has the West backed up its pronouncements with credible threats of force.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American mediator, understands this need for strong measures. He has progressed to this point by thrusting American power squarely in the face of his interlocutors. Till now, this kind of diplomacy has worked.
The Assistant Secretary of State has warned Mr. Izetbegovic that NATO will not be his air force, threatened Mr. Tudjman with economic sanctions if he makes a wrong move, and left Mr. Milosevic with no doubt that the international acceptance he craves will not come without major Serbian concessions.
The method has gradually revealed the weaknesses of the three: Mr. Izetbegovic's difficulty with decision-making and tendency to agree with the last person he has talked to; Mr. Tudjman's pomposity and inflated notion of his refurbished army's prowess; Mr. Milosevic's fear of continued international isolation.
But if American officials now know how to deal with the three men, they are scarcely any closer to bridging the enormous differences that separate them.
All the issues that caused the wars of Yugoslavia's disintegration -- the status of Sarajevo, the territorial claims of Serbian minorities in Bosnia and Croatia, the governance of Bosnia -- remain unresolved. Some atrocities -- the killing of Muslims in northwestern Bosnia this month and Muslims in Srebrenica in August -- are still raw in the minds and hearts of the Bosnian delegation.
Conspicuously absent from the meetings will be the two main Bosnian Serb leaders. Radovan Karadzic, the political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the army chief have been indicted for war crimes by the international tribunal in The Hague and both risk arrest if they leave their territory. In the Dayton talks, Mr. Milosevic and other Bosnian Serb officials are representing that side.
But still, Mr. Izetbegovic will be negotiating with men who, at the very best, turned a blind eye to the incarceration of tens of thousands of Muslim civilians in bestial concentration camps by Serbian forces throughout Bosnia in 1992 and the imprisonment of thousands more in similar camps by Croatian troops around Mostar in 1993.
Moreover, he is aware that the objective that led Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Tudjman to condone, or perhaps approve, such methods -- a carve-up of Bosnia along ethnic lines that would leave the Muslims with very little -- may well persist just beneath the surface of the more measured official policies the two Presidents now espouse publicly.
Decision-making in Ohio will not be easy for Mr. Izetbegovic. More at home in philosophical discussions than political realities, the mild-mannered Bosnian leader has zigzagged this way and that.
At times it has appeared that two spells in prison -- in 1946 and again in 1983 -- stemming from his identification with Muslim movements contested by Yugoslavia's Communist authorities -- imbued Mr. Izetbegovic with a patience and otherworldliness ill-suited to politics.
He did little to prepare for war, although it was clear to almost everyone that the Bosnian independence he sought in 1992 would provoke a violent reaction from the Serbian minority of Bosnia, strongly backed by the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army. On April 4, 1992, two days before the fighting broke out, he declared: "Citizens of Sarajevo, sleep peacefully, there will be no war."
He says now that he has no regrets. "In history there are no experiments," he said in a recent interview. "We don't know what would have happened if we had stayed. But after the destruction of Vukovar, would you have stayed with Yugoslavia and Milosevic? We had to choose, and the aggressors committed crimes we never predicted. I never could have predicted such enormous crimes."
The slaughter of Muslims by Serbs in 1992 initially disoriented Mr. Izetbegovic. Under immense military pressure, he repeatedly entertained thoughts of a Muslim mini-state in some part of Bosnia, an idea attractive to some radical members of the Muslim nationalist Party of Democratic Action that he founded. But in the end, he always discarded it.
Now, at the age of 70, this lawyer has grown in stature, bolstered by the emergence of a credible Bosnian Army which, backed by the Croats, has won significant victories this year. His standing has also been reinforced by the fact that, despite obvious pressure from an influential minority of Islamic radicals in Bosnia and from military supporters including Iran, Mr. Izetbegovic has never abandoned the basic civility and tolerance that has allowed Muslims, Croats and Serbs to go on living together in Sarajevo through four years of war. This stance has amounted to the best rebuff of repeated Serbian charges that he is a "fundamentalist" and Croatian claims that Mr. Izetbegovic and his people need education in civilized European mores.
The Serbian charges have used as ammunition a document called "The Islamic Declaration" published by Mr. Izetbegovic in 1973.
While it contains inflammatory passages -- suggesting, for example, the coexistence of Islam and "non-Islamic social and political institutions" may be impossible -- it amounts essentially to a meditation on how to reconcile Islam with the modern world.
Whatever his past convictions, Mr. Izetbegovic's current goals now seem clear. He wants a settlement that offers a real chance that Bosnia will remain whole, either through the central, democratic institutions established under a peace plan, or -- if that fails, Bosnian leaders say -- by securing the land, the money and military training that would open the way for some future military push.
Thus he wants the line that the United States proposes to draw through Bosnia -- dividing the country roughly in half between the Serbs and the federation -- to be a faint one, a temporary division rather than a permanent frontier.
Mr. Izetbegovic wants Sarajevo, the soul of Bosnia, undivided. He seeks a land link between Sarajevo and Gorazde, the remaining eastern Muslim enclave. He will request a huge economic aid package. And he insists on the departure, through popular vote or arraignment, of Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic.
"With democracy and freedom, it will become irrelevant which side controls a town," Mr. Izetbegovic said. "If reasonable people come to power, all problems can be solved."
Western diplomats look to Mr. Milosevic as the best hope for peace because he is desperate to get international economic sanctions on Serbia lifted and, at 54, looks forward to a less rocky future as president for another decade or two.
He is therefore ready to make compromises. He has made clear that he cares little about Sarajevo, even less about the fate of Mr. Karadzic, whom he loathes, and General Mladic, whom he now sees as a liability. But his room for maneuver may be limited.
He heads a delegation that includes Bosnian Serbs who care passionately about securing Serbian rule over part of Sarajevo. Indeed a Sarajevo divided along ethnic lines has been a fundamental war aim of the Bosnian Serbs.
Moreover, he has refrained from ousting either man up to now, apparently because he is not entirely sure of his power base in the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army.
The army is keeping watch on eastern Slavonia, a sliver of rich land that abuts Serbia and is the one remaining Serbian-occupied area of Croatia.
It is particularly unstable because Mr. Tudjman remains a volatile character, enamored of his army, who has repeatedly been underestimated by American officials.
Flanked by a Defense Minister, Gojko Susak, whom officials close to Mr. Holbrooke call "the tough cookie of the Balkans," Mr. Tudjman has shown that he can successfully use force, including sometimes barbaric methods, while skirting international ostracism or stricture.
He is not a natural ally for the United States, but he has emerged as one because he was needed to balance initial Serbian military superiority and provide an arms pipeline to the Bosnians. From comments in the 1990 Croatian election campaign that he was pleased not to be married to "a Serb or a Jew" to more recent reflections on the need for Croats to show Bosnian Muslims what European civilization is about, Mr. Tudjman has shown a streak of thinly veiled bigotry.
Despite these traits, Mr. Tudjman has retained American support as he recovered all but 3 percent of Croatia from the secessionist Serbs. He also helped himself to more than 20 percent of Bosnia.
In so doing, he has virtually cleansed Croatia of its 13 percent Serbian minority. "Croatia is now rid of its historical cross," he declared after the victorious August attack on the Krajina region that sent about 170,000 Serbs into flight.
"We knew all along that Tudjman wanted a small, humble, contrite, quiet and second-class Serb minority," said one State Department official. "But we needed him, so we closed our eyes."
The policy culminated with the Clinton Administration's effective green light to the Krajina campaign, a triumph that cemented Mr. Tudjman's vision of himself.
Mr. Tudjman's conversion to nationalism came at a relatively late age. As a young man, he joined Tito's Communist Partisan movement and fought the Croatian Ustashe, Nazi puppets whose slaughter of Serbs during World War II provided one of the highly charged historical themes that have fed the current conflict.
After the war, he rose quickly to become, before the age of 40, Tito's youngest general. But a move from the army to historical study then led to a radical conversion from Communism to Croatian Nationalism.
His writings now suggest that Ustashe crimes were exaggerated and the number of Serbian and Jewish dead inflated. He became a leading figure in the "Croatian Spring" of 1971, a flowering of national and liberal resistance to Tito's autocratic rule. The movement was quashed by Tito and Mr. Tudjman imprisoned.
He emerged, as Communism collapsed in Europe, to lead Croatia's march to independence as the head of the Croatian Democratic Union Party. The march suffered setbacks, but it now looks victorious, and Mr. Tudjman, at this stage, is the big winner from the latest Balkan war.
Mr. Holbrooke is now determined to curtail Mr. Tudjman's triumphalism. He wants to head off any attack on eastern Slavonia, and he wants to make real multiculturalism in Bosnia the price for Mr. Tudjman's ticket to acceptance in the West and eventually the European Union.
"His ticket to the West is compliance on these issues," said one American official. "No use of force in eastern Slavonia. Work with the Muslims in Bosnia."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Strong Demand Propels Copper, And Corn Hits a 7-Month High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices rallied yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York on signs of surprisingly strong industrial demand.
On other commodity markets, corn prices rose to a seven-month high. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.24 point, to 242.22. 
 Copper for December delivery climbed 1.10 cents yesterday, to $1.2475 a pound.
Availability of copper, an essential component for construction projects and many manufactured products, remains relatively tight despite increased warehouse stocks, analysts said.
"The market appears to be saying, 'We don't think there is going to be enough copper around for the fourth quarter,' " said Richard Hirsch, a vice president of Deutsche Sharps Pixley Metals Inc. in New York.
Traders in New York took their cues mainly from the London Metal Exchange, where copper for delivery in three months rose $21 a metric ton despite an increase in visible stocks. A metric ton is 2,205 pounds.
Copper in exchange-registered warehouses rose by 2,500 metric tons last week to 193,450, the London exchange said.
"In spite of all the worldwide recession fears, we're seeing strong manufacturing and industrial demand," Mr. Hirsch said.
Visible American stocks of copper remain low. Commodity warehouse stocks were unchanged at 6,107 tons, the exchange said in a daily report after the close of trading yesterday.
"You certainly have a tight situation in the U.S.," David Rinehimer, an analyst with Smith Barney, said.
Corn and soybean prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly as a result of farmers' reluctance to sell newly harvested crops at current prices.
The advance also reflected traders' expectations that the Agriculture Department would further reduce its 1995 corn and soybean production estimates in a Nov. 9 crop report, said Dan Cekander, a grain analyst with Fimat Futures USA Inc. in Chicago. "I think people are starting to get a little nervous going into the crop report," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Developments in U.S. Neighbors Cause Dollar to Rise, Then Dip

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended little changed against most leading currencies yesterday. It initially rose to a five-week high against the yen as traders assessed the United States impact of the vote in Quebec that narrowly rejected secession from Canada, but the dollar then slipped back after the Mexican peso weakened.
"Canada helped the dollar, and Mexico held it back," said Jay Westheimer, senior currency trader with Banco di Sicilia in New York. 
 Concern that a Quebec vote for independence would roil Canadian financial markets made market participants wary of holding too many United States or Canadian dollars during the last few days. After the slim vote against separation, Canadian and United States markets surged yesterday morning, driving both currencies higher.
"Investors are feeling a little more comfortable about investing in North America, hence the dollar is benefiting," Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York, said during morning trading.
That comfort, however, did not last long. The Mexican peso fell because of continued concern that Mexico's economy will be slow to emerge from recession. The peso's decline hurt the dollar because of the close ties between Mexico and the United States. Mexico is the United States' third-largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 101.96 Japanese yen from 101.95 yen on Monday. The dollar slipped to 1.4070 German marks from 1.4089 marks and to 1.1353 Swiss francs from 1.1369 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5810 from $1.5779.
In other trading, the Canadian dollar settled at 74.33 United States cents, up from 73.34 cents on Monday. The United States dollar rose to 7.0750 Mexican pesos, up from 6.925 pesos on Monday.
The gain in the Canadian dollar yesterday was tempered by the narrow margin by which secession was rejected, market participants said.
By a vote of 50.6 percent to 49.4 percent, Quebec voters turned down the provincial government's request for a mandate to negotiate separation from Canada .
"No one can believe this issue is resolved," said Graham Broyd, manager of currency sales at National Westminster Bank in New York. "It will be with us for a while to come and may result in another vote during the next couple of years. The risk premium Canada has to pay for Quebec is still there."

HEADLINE: Steps Taken On Welfare In Michigan

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

 BODY:
In another month or two, most women on welfare in Michigan will probably have to be working within six weeks of having a child or they will lose their benefits.
New welfare recipients there who do not obtain jobs, paid or unpaid, are likely to become ineligible for benefits in two months. Michigan fathers would lose their driver's and professional licenses for not supporting their children. And welfare recipients would be docked 10 percent of their payments to reimburse their landlords for damage to housing. 
 In an apparent effort to outpace other states and show the nation how to make welfare recipients go to work, the Republican Governor of Michigan, John Engler, proposed these and other changes yesterday in a state welfare program that already leads the nation in steering recipients into jobs, with about 30 percent of its 190,000 welfare recipients working -- three times the national average.
With Congress on the last lap of writing legislation to hand most of the control over welfare to the states, most likely in December, Mr. Engler submitted his proposals yesterday to a supportive State Legislature. He wants his own program, an expansion of one he established three years ago, to take effect immediately afterward. He would then begin spending the lump-sum payments, or block grants, that Congress is expected to allocate to all states for largely unrestricted use on welfare, replacing a system now controlled by Washington.
If, as widely expected, the overhaul of the welfare system is approved by the full Congress and is signed into law by President Clinton, states are likely to begin a stampede to re-invent welfare in ways most suitable to them. Michigan made a point yesterday of being the first out of the gate.
"We want to be ready to go as soon as the legislation is passed in Washington," said Gerald H. Miller, director of the Michigan Department of Social Services. The Governor's spokesman, John Truscott, said: "We want to be the first state. We want to be the model for the rest of the nation."
In Michigan, welfare would be redefined. Mr. Miller's department would become the Family Independence Agency, which would oversee a Family Independence Program. The principal Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, would become Family Independence Assistance.
The state's welfare system would be greatly simplified, too, Mr. Miller said. The standard form applicants fill out would be cut to 5 pages from 25. Many reporting requirements would be eliminated, and layers of the welfare bureaucracy would shrink, with most of the work assumed by the caseworker, who would be called a family independence specialist.
But Michigan's rush to be first stuns people who argue that the changes the Governor has already made have yet to be proven, especially in a recession, when jobs, now abundant in Michigan, disappear. State welfare spending could soar as the state tries to fulfill its promise to support people who seek to find work and fail.
"From our standpoint, the speed with which they are moving is just appalling," said Sharon Parks, senior research associate at the Michigan League for Human Services, a research and advocacy organization.
Mr. Truscott acknowledged the problems arising from a recession. But he said that starting with the first block grant, the state would set aside a contingency fund, although how much of the grants would go to that was undecided. He also said he would expect Congress to help out with emergency aid.
"Congress can always revisit this," he said, "if it gets to the point where staters cannot handle it." But Congress has made no such provision for a bailout.
At a news conference today and in an outline of a bill he plans to submit to the State Senate and House, Mr. Engler said he would deny welfare to mothers under 18 and provide coverage for them only when living under adult supervision, trying in that way discourage young women from using a baby and a welfare check as a means of leaving home.
The new program would be at once tougher on people who refuse to work and gentler on those who make an effort. Instead of food stamps, for example, many people who do find jobs but remain on welfare would be freed of the stigma of using food stamps and be given cash for food instead.

HEADLINE: An Intricate Senate Procedure Lends a Hand to Welfare Recipients

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
With one clean swipe just before midnight Friday, the Democratic minority in the Senate knocked out of the big budget bill many of the harshest policies involving welfare.
No longer would the bill force families off welfare after they had been on relief for five years. 
 No longer would it allow states to deny welfare benefits to unwed mothers younger than 18 or to children born into families already on welfare.
No longer would the bill provide a bonus to states if their rate of out-of-wedlock births fell.
The Democrats did not succeed because they mustered a majority vote for their position -- the 46 Democratic senators voted to delete the provisions in question, while the 53 Republicans voted to retain them -- but because of an arcane procedure known as the Byrd rule.
The Senate's use of the rule raises some question about whether comprehensive welfare legislation, approved by both houses and favored in some form by President Clinton, can become law this year.
Under this Senate rule, named for its author, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, provisions in budget bill can be successfully challenged on a point of order if they produce no change in revenue or spending or if such changes are "merely incidental" to the fiscal items. It takes a three-fifths majority, or 60 votes if all senators are present, to waive the rule.
The rule does not apply directly to the House, whose budget bill clamps down more on the poor than does the Senate's. But it will apply to any matter approved by a conference committee before the Senate.
So the rule is likely to complicate the work of the conference committee that this week is beginning to try to work out the differences between budget bills approved last week by the Senate and the House.
These are among the elements of the House bill, but not the Senate bill, that may not meet the test of the Byrd rule:
*Abolition of the Commerce Department.
*Merger of the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency into the State Department.
*Repeal of Federal nursing home standards.
*Overturning new Government regulations on livestock grazing on Federal land.
*Tightening of the United States embargo on Cuba.
*Revision of the Endangered Species Act.
None of these go to the heart of the budget measure, which is supposed to balance the budget in seven years, cut the taxes of middle- and upper-income taxpayers and shift control of most social programs from the Federal Government to the states.
But many are important to conservative Republicans in the House, where freshmen have no experience with the strange ways of the Senate. The party leaders may have to twist a good many arms to get these conservatives to vote for the compromise measure that comes out of the conference without these provisions.
The rule also complicates the politics of welfare legislation, which is going through Congress along two separate tracks.
The Senate and House have passed separate welfare bills almost identical to the welfare provisions in the budget bills. The notion of overhauling welfare is popular politically, and President Clinton has said he would sign a bill with welfare measures like those in the Senate bill.
The Republicans who control Congress decided to include the welfare provisions in the budget bill so they could blame Mr. Clinton for vetoing the popular legislation if, as is almost certain to happen, he vetoes the budget bill.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said he was reluctant, as a political matter, to give the President the opportunity to sign the former and veto the latter.
Then there is the question of a Senate filibuster. Under the rules, budget bills cannot be filibustered. But a separate welfare bill could be. The welfare bill was approved in the Senate last month by an overwhelming 87-to-12 vote. But many Democrats who voted for it might jump ship if they thought they could sustain a filibuster.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, the leading opponent of the welfare measure in the Senate, said tonight that he thought most Democrats who voted for the measure last month would join a filibuster if President Clinton drops the word.
Senator Byrd, who was the Democratic leader from 1977 until 1989 and who sees himself as the guardian of the prerogatives of the Senate, first got his budget rule approved by the Senate in 1985. It cannot be changed without a three-fifths majority in the Senate.
The rule was meant to counter the fact that under law only 20 hours of debate are permitted on the huge budget measures known as reconciliation bills. Before the Byrd rule was imposed, dozens of extraneous elements often managed to sneak into such bills without debate or the knowledge of many senators.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday.
The market, traders and analysts said yesterday, is being pulled in two directions: by market participants hoping that a budget deal will be reached in Washington and by those looking at economic reports for signs of inflationary growth. 
 The two opposing forces were reflected in trading yesterday. Despite reports showing a growing economy, there were enough buyers betting that a budget deal would prompt the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates again this year.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 107 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.33 percent, from 6.35 percent on Monday. The prices of intermediate-term notes were mixed or little changed. Bill rates rose a few basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Several reports released yesterday showed strength in the economy. The Chicago Purchasing Management Association said yesterday that its index of business activity rose to 53.4 last month from 49 in September. A reading above 50 denotes expansion in the manufacturing sector. Analysts had expected an increase to 50.8. The prices paid component in the index also increased to 59.5, from 54.9 in September.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said new-home sales rose in September to an annual rate of 727,000 from the trade estimate of 725,000 and from the August downward revision to 704,000. And the Conference Board's consumer confidence survey fell slightly, to 97 in October from 97.3 the previous month.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research, Boston, said the December bond futures contract fell after the release of the data, But prices were also under pressure from some end-of-the-month squaring-up of positions, highlighted by some short-covering, traders said.
"The reality is that the market is still bullish," Ms. Mesch said. "The bulls are technically well ahead in this market rally, but complacency about the rally being in the bag would be a mistake."
The December contract rose as high as 117 10/32 yesterday, with the low at 116 16/32, before closing at 117 1/32.
"The economy is at a point of being either very good or very terrible," said Carroll J. Delaney, director of research for Stires, O'Donnell & Company, "with the market sitting very comfortably in between."
"But for the market to dismiss the last G.D.P. figure of a 4.2 percent gain for the third quarter is really stretching it," he added. "Bottom line, the market is ignoring all the data, concentrating instead on the budget negotiations in Washington and fixed on the idea that when the issue is resolved we will get a corresponding action of an easing by the Federal Reserve."
Despite the battle in Washington, the Treasury was still planning to announce plans this afternoon to sell bills and notes to raise money it needs to pay Government expenses in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Manhattan tally: Charles Jourdan returns and a currency trader stays, as do Tiffany's offices.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
CHARLES JOURDAN is returning to Manhattan retailing.
The company, which closed its Madison Avenue and Trump Tower stores more than two years ago, has signed a lease for 1,700 square feet of selling space at 655 Madison, at 60th Street. The upscale shoe store is to open Nov. 20. 
 The space is being sublet from Bogner, the ski wear company, which is moving its shop to a five-story 1880 brick row house at 821 Madison, between 68th and 69th Streets.
Faith H. Consolo of the Garrick-Aug retail brokerage, which handled the Jourdan deal for Bogner, said the sublet was for two years -- the time left on the Bogner lease -- for an annual rent of "less than $150 a square foot."
"Comparable space for that corner today would be $275 a square foot and up," Ms. Consolo said.
Max Imgruth, Charles Jourdan's president and chief executive, said the two earlier stores, at Madison and 66th and in Trump Tower at Fifth and 57th, had been closed because the new Jourdan owners, who took over three years ago, felt that business was eroding on Madison and "decided to redirect the company and rethink strategies."
In addition, Mr. Imgruth said, "both deals were made in the 80's, and the Trump Tower rent, including common area charges, was $1.92 million a year."
"Even though we did $6 million in shoe sales, we made no profit," he said.
The time was now right to reopen, he said, and the sublease provided "an opportunity."
"The rent," he said, "is intelligent. Sometimes you take something even if it is for a relatively short period of time."
 
Currency Trader Stays Put
 Tullett & Tokyo Forex Inc., a London-based currency trading company, has signed a 15-year, $35 million lease to keep its North American headquarters, with 550 employees, at 80 Pine Street in lower Manhattan.
The company agreed in June to remain in New York City in exchange for a $2.2 million, 16-year tax incentive from New York City. But it had waited to sign the lease until the State Legislature approved a package of tax benefits designed by the Giuliani administration to encourage residential conversion and commercial renovation downtown, said Bruce Surry, a senior managing director of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company, who handled the deal for Tullett & Tokyo. The legislation was signed into law by Gov. George E. Pataki on Sunday.
The company's decision to stay in Manhattan was a victory for the city, which has lost several currency-trading concerns to Jersey City in recent years. Noonan, Astley & Pearce has moved to 10 Exchange Place across the Hudson; two other companies, Bierbaum Martin and Fulton Prebon Yamane, are now at 101 Hudson Street there.
At 80 Pine, a 38-story building at Maiden Lane, Tullett & Tokyo will expand from about 46,000 square feet to 62,680 square feet, Mr. Sully said. He added that the landlord, the Rudin family, had been "particularly aggressive in helping to keep this tenant."
William C. Rudin, president of Rudin Management, said "the Mayor's downtown plan was a key component of Tullett & Tokyo's decision to stay."
Rudin Management has been particularly aggressive in trying to revitalize downtown. It is renovating 55 Broad Street, a 31-story office building at the corner of Beaver Street with 400,000 square feet of empty space, and making it a center for information and telecommunications companies.
Mr. Rudin said that 55 Broad would open at the end of the month. "There are three floors committed," he said, "and we're working on three or four more floors of deals."
 
Tiffany Offices Also Stay
 Also staying in Manhattan and expanding are the operations offices of Tiffany & Company, at 600 Madison Avenue, a 26-story building at 58th Street, two blocks from the flagship store at 57th and Fifth.
Tiffany has about 63,000 square feet on four floors at 600 Madison, on various leases that were to expire in from three and a half to five years. It will have about 84,000 square feet and one more floor under one new lease that has been "restructured and extended on economically favorable" terms for the next 15 years, said Mitchell Steir, executive vice president of the Julien J. Studley agency. Mr. Steir, who brokered the deal for Tiffany, declined to disclose the terms of the lease. Arthur J. Draznin of Harper-Lawrence Inc. was leasing agent for the building.
"The business group could have relocated outside New York but felt it was best to be at 600 Madison," Mr. Steir said.
 
2 Companies, 1 Office
 The trend to consolidation continues. Two companies with common ownership that occupy space in two midtown office buildings are moving to one.
Vitt Media International, a media planning and buying company with 36,000 square feet at 1114 Avenue of the Americas, at 42d Street, and Sawyer Ferguson Walker Inc., a seller of national advertising for many major newspapers, which has 17,000 square feet in the Chrysler Building, are moving to about 35,000 square feet on the 10th floor of 90 Park Avenue, a 41-story building at 39th Street.
Charles Lowenstein and Scott Pudalov of the Edward S. Gordon company handled the deal for the companies. The lease is for 10 years, with an aggregate rent of $15 million.

HEADLINE: Arab-Israeli Conference Agrees on Mideast Development Bank

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A three-day conference of business and Government leaders intended to broaden economic bonds between Israel and the Arab world ended today with the announcement that an American-backed proposal for a Middle East Development Bank would move forward.
The conference passed a resolution calling for establishment of the bank, to be capitalized at $5 billion with paid-in working fund of $1.25 billion. Officials said they will negotiate in the coming months to determine who the shareholders will be and how much each will contribute. 
 The bank has been championed by the United States, Israel, Jordan and Egypt but opposed by the European Union, which says that the bank will eclipse European development programs, and by Persian Gulf countries that are supposed to provide a substantial part of its financing.
The gathering was declared a success that "exceeded all expectations," by Joan Spero, Under Secretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs.
Foundations were laid for deals between Arabs and Israelis that may bear fruit in the future. But the three days of meetings also were marked by inter-Arab rivalries, European-American competition for influence and the legacy of 50 years of Arab-Israeli conflict.
During the conference, Israel announced it had signed an agreement to enter into negotiations with Enron Corporation, an American energy company, to buy liquified natural gas produced by the company in Qatar.
In addition to the regional development bank, which will have its headquarters in Cairo, the meeting also approved plans to establish regional tourism and business boards, a permanent secretariat for the economic conference in Rabat, Morocco, and a committee in Amman to organize future conferences.
"I still am an optimist, and I believe we are heading for the best of times," said Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan, the chairman of the gathering, officially called the Middle East/ North Africa Economic Summit. The first regional economic meeting that included large Israeli participation was held a year ago in Casablanca with King Hassan II of Morocco as chairman. Organizers said the next conference will be in Cairo and the following one in Qatar.
On the whole, the meeting of more than 1,000 businessmen and delegations of officials was more subdued than the Morocco gathering. Syria and Lebanon refused to attend the meeting, and Iran, Iraq and Libya were not invited.
Time after time, discussions were interrupted by Palestinians who complained that Israel is falling behind schedule in granting them autonomy or by Arabs calling upon other Arabs to slow down their "rush" to peace until Israel makes peace with Lebanon and Syria.
On the development bank proposal, European Union officials argued that it is an American attempt to diminish Europe's role in the Middle East.
Saudi Arabia's Commerce Minister, Ussama Al Faqih, said in a speech on Sunday that his country would not contribute to capitalize the bank, and Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain have taken the same position.
Until these disputes are resolved, a number of experts here said, the bank remains merely "an announcement to establish" with nothing more than a location in Cairo.
The agreement to negotiate for the sale of $20 billion in natural gas falls short of being a direct business transaction between an Arab country and Israel, but it would be the first such deal by a Persian Gulf Arab oil-producing nation to supply energy to Israel.

HEADLINE: Canadian Dollar Buoyed by Quebec Vote

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Relief at the rejection of separatism by a paper-thin majority of Quebecers rippled through Canada's economy today, driving up the depressed Canadian dollar and the Toronto stock market and offering investors a respite after weeks of uncertainty about the country's future.
"It's not just positive, it's exuberant," Warren Jestin, the chief economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia, said of the market's reaction to Quebec voters' decision to remain a part of Canada. 
 Even a thin 52,000-vote margin of victory, Mr. Jestin and other Canadian economists said, has dissipated the fog of confusion over Quebec's future that had obscured Canada's economic strengths.
They include an enviably low inflation rate, profitable exports of raw materials such as oil and forestry products and signs that the federal and most provincial governments are serious about trimming back Canada's staggering debt burden.
John McCallum, the chief economist at the Royal Bank of Canada, compared the financial markets before the referendum to a metal spring wound up so tightly that Quebecers' approval of secession could have sent them flying off in uncharted directions. Even the slim rejection of the referendum sufficed to wind down the tension.
"It's kind of a reprieve and a wake-up call" for Canadians to find a place for Quebecers in their country, Mr. McCallum said of the referendum result. But, he added, "We're now on a sustainable path."
The most conspicuous indicator was the rising Canadian dollar, in which trading had virtually stopped last Friday as trepidation grew about the outcome of the referendum.
The Canadian dollar closed today at 74.35 cents, up .77 cents from Monday's close. Foreign currency speculators began buying once the referendum results swung last night in favor of those who wanted to stay a part of Canada.
The benchmark Toronto Stock Exchange's composite index of 300 stocks rose 130 points soon after trading opened, dropped in modest profit taking and resumed its climb to close at 4,459 points, up just over 79 points from Monday's close. The stock markets in Montreal and Vancouver also registered gains.
The Bank of Canada fueled the optimism by lowering its bank lending rate sharply today, to 6.18 percent, compared to 7.65 percent last week. Canadian bonds rose earlier in anticipation of the cut, which could stimulate consumer spending by Canadians, who owe proportionately more money than Americans.
The rally extended to Quebec, where the Montreal brokerage firm Levesque Beaubien reported substantial buy orders for Quebec provincial bonds. Many investors were previously scared off by the prospect of political instability in the province. But as Sherry Cooper, the chief economist for Nesbitt Burns, observed, "It is still too early to definitely suggest that investors will commit sizable long-term capital to the Quebec economy."
Not all economists shared the euphoria. While the immediate crisis was over, a few noted, the impasse over Quebec was still unresolved and could distract Prime Minister Jean Chretien's Government from the spending cuts needed to place the economy on a sounder footing. Economic growth flattened out in the first half of the year, they said.
Jeff Rubin, the chief economist of Wood Gundy Inc. in Toronto, said the referendum result was much narrower than the markets had expected and had not really reduced the political risk of investing in Canada.
"It shows that Quebec has the political capacity to say 'yes' " to separation from Canada, Mr. Rubin said of the narrowness of the vote.
David Rosenberg, a senior economist with Nesbitt Burns in Toronto, reported a "temperate enthusiasm from a market point of view." He too said the 1.2 percent margin of victory was much too close to warrant unbridled optimism.
But, Mr. Rosenberg added, "With the vote out of the way, there is room for investors to focus on underlying positives" in the Canadian economy.
Though Canada carries one of the highest ratios of debt to gross national product in the Western industrial world, it also has one of the lowest rates of inflation -- currently just over 2 percent a year.
It is also running a record trade surplus with the United States, its foremost trading partner, of 15.2 billion Canadian dollars a year. And the Canadian Government looks like it will meet or exceed its target of cutting 32.7 billion Canadian dollars from the annual budget deficit this year.
The threat of Quebec separatism has obscured much of this for foreign investors and other observers, economists said.
Ted Carmichael, the chief economist for J.P. Morgan in Toronto, compared Canada-watching to a three-ring circus, with investors variously preoccupied by the fundamentals of the Canadian economy, the Government's progress toward deficit and debt reduction and political developments like the Quebec referendum.
"Like in any circus, the spotlight tends to shift from ring to ring," Mr. Carmichael said, with Quebec commanding recent attention.

HEADLINE: An Intricate Senate Procedure Lends a Hand to Welfare Recipients

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
With one clean swipe just before midnight Friday, the Democratic minority in the Senate knocked out of the big budget bill many of the harshest policies involving welfare.
No longer would the bill force families off welfare after they had been on relief for five years. 
 No longer would it allow states to deny welfare benefits to unwed mothers younger than 18 or to children born into families already on welfare.
No longer would the bill provide a bonus to states if their rate of out-of-wedlock births fell.
The Democrats did not succeed because they mustered a majority vote for their position -- the 46 Democratic senators voted to delete the provisions in question, while the 53 Republicans voted to retain them -- but because of an arcane procedure known as the Byrd rule.
The Senate's use of the rule raises some question about whether comprehensive welfare legislation, approved by both houses and favored in some form by President Clinton, can become law this year.
Under this Senate rule, named for its author, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, provisions in budget bill can be successfully challenged on a point of order if they produce no change in revenue or spending or if such changes are "merely incidental" to the fiscal items. It takes a three-fifths majority, or 60 votes if all senators are present, to waive the rule.
The rule does not apply directly to the House, whose budget bill clamps down more on the poor than does the Senate's. But it will apply to any matter approved by a conference committee before the Senate.
So the rule is likely to complicate the work of the conference committee that this week is beginning to try to work out the differences between budget bills approved last week by the Senate and the House.
These are among the elements of the House bill, but not the Senate bill, that may not meet the test of the Byrd rule:
*Abolition of the Commerce Department.
*Merger of the Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency into the State Department.
*Repeal of Federal nursing home standards.
*Overturning new Government regulations on livestock grazing on Federal land.
*Tightening of the United States embargo on Cuba.
*Revision of the Endangered Species Act.
None of these go to the heart of the budget measure, which is supposed to balance the budget in seven years, cut the taxes of middle- and upper-income taxpayers and shift control of most social programs from the Federal Government to the states.
But many are important to conservative Republicans in the House, where freshmen have no experience with the strange ways of the Senate. The party leaders may have to twist a good many arms to get these conservatives to vote for the compromise measure that comes out of the conference without these provisions.
The rule also complicates the politics of welfare legislation, which is going through Congress along two separate tracks.
The Senate and House have passed separate welfare bills almost identical to the welfare provisions in the budget bills. The notion of overhauling welfare is popular politically, and President Clinton has said he would sign a bill with welfare measures like those in the Senate bill.
The Republicans who control Congress decided to include the welfare provisions in the budget bill so they could blame Mr. Clinton for vetoing the popular legislation if, as is almost certain to happen, he vetoes the budget bill.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said he was reluctant, as a political matter, to give the President the opportunity to sign the former and veto the latter.
Then there is the question of a Senate filibuster. Under the rules, budget bills cannot be filibustered. But a separate welfare bill could be. The welfare bill was approved in the Senate last month by an overwhelming 87-to-12 vote. But many Democrats who voted for it might jump ship if they thought they could sustain a filibuster.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, the leading opponent of the welfare measure in the Senate, said tonight that he thought most Democrats who voted for the measure last month would join a filibuster if President Clinton drops the word.
Senator Byrd, who was the Democratic leader from 1977 until 1989 and who sees himself as the guardian of the prerogatives of the Senate, first got his budget rule approved by the Senate in 1985. It cannot be changed without a three-fifths majority in the Senate.
The rule was meant to counter the fact that under law only 20 hours of debate are permitted on the huge budget measures known as reconciliation bills. Before the Byrd rule was imposed, dozens of extraneous elements often managed to sneak into such bills without debate or the knowledge of many senators.

HEADLINE: At Co-ops, Entrenched Arrogance

SERIES: THE HOUSE RULES: Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
When a group of Japanese urban planners visited New York recently as part of an exchange program, they were struck by any number of the city's singular quirks. Nothing, however, bemused them more than the discovery that every co-op building had its own peculiar array of rules, dictating all kinds of things, from who can live there to how fat their dogs can be.
Co-ops don't exist in Tokyo, and all condominiums there are subject to a uniform set of bylaws established by the city government. "What really boggled their minds was that a bunch of people get together here and set up their own rules," said Michael Kwartler, an urban planner with the New School. 
 Curiously, while New York has probably the most comprehensive law regulating the creation of co-op buildings, virtually nothing addresses the internal workings of a co-op once it is formed. That has meant that the strengths of co-ops are increasingly their points of friction. Owners may like that they have absolute control over their neighbors, but they don't seem to like that their neighbors have absolute control over them.
So while no one imagines that co-ops will wither and vanish, many agree that some issues need resolution if co-ops are to maintain their allure.
Increasingly, it is the co-ops' governing boards, which operate with great power and virtually no oversight, that are the focus of attention and discontent. The deficiencies of some boards have been newly defined by a corruption scandal involving managing agents and by shareholder irritation with some boards' furtive and overbearing ways.
In the wake of that scandal, people have begun calling for the licensing of managing agents. Whether that actually happens, boards feel they need to be more conscientious about whom they hire, and some are turning to consultants to advise them.
At the same time, said Clark Halstead, the head of Halstead Properties, more buildings are choosing to dismiss their agents and manage their affairs themselves, though then they must grapple with their own inexperience.
To some people, the scandal, and the way some boards have tried to compensate by exerting greater control, points directly to one of the system's most disquieting issues: the existence of a certain number of deeply entrenched, highly secretive boards that no longer represent their shareholders.
Many people advocate restricting tenures of board members. Assemblyman Alexander B. Pete Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who lives in a rental building, has for a decade promoted a co-op bill of rights because complaints about co-ops from his constituents. "It's become a very imperial life style," he said.
His bill would require greater disclosure of information to shareholders and applicants, including the reasons behind all board decisions. But while the bill has regularly passed the Assembly, the Senate has refused to consider it, largely because of opposition by real estate interests.
Many people say that the system works well enough unencumbered. In any event, given the cost of regulation, coupled with the forces aligned against it, few people seriously think that many new rules fundamentally altering the system will ever be imposed.
"That's good news and bad news," said Walter Goldsmith, a real estate lawyer who once worked on co-op matters at the State Attorney General's office. "The good news is co-op owners will be able to do it themselves. The bad news is they will be able to do it themselves."
His point is that while owners may cherish the freedom, they are going to find the work ever more complex and onerous. Squabbling will persist.
Norman Schreiber is a 54-year-old freelance writer who lives in a Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, co-op, where he has served on the board for seven or eight terms. He is writing a murder mystery set in a co-op, and is voluble on the behavioral sociology of the institution.
"Theoretically, a co-op is an excellent experience on two levels," he said. "There's the sense of ownership that does make a difference in how you think and live and plan with each other. There's the notion of sharing. Economically, it makes sense, because the landlord -- you -- doesn't have a profit incentive.
"In real life, however, those issues sometimes get forgotten. People with very different ideas of how the world works come into conflict. There is the run-the-building-like-a-business approach. I often wonder, what business? Penn Central? Then there are those who want to run it like a social organization. It just doesn't work."
As a housing choice, the co-op seems unlikely to grow in prevalence, but neither is it likely to shrink. The reasons have to do with the sour promises for the local economy as well as the quirky nature of New Yorkers.
In the stagnant market of the 1990's, few buildings have converted to co-ops, and developers doubt that there will be more co-ops soon. All new buildings tailored for home ownership are condominiums, since they are easier to sell and sublet.
Yet no one foresees co-ops vanishing, or even being eclipsed by condominiums anytime in the 21st century. New Yorkers, it is often remarked, gain sustenance from irritation. Too much happiness seems to make them edgy. So the co-op system should weather any amount of defilement.
Indeed, if the always cyclical real estate market gathers momentum again, real estate people think more co-op conversions will occur. Mr. Kwartler, the urban planner, said that as the boundaries between where people live and work narrow, more people will desire the rigid control over neighbors that co-ops permit.
What is becoming another significant issue is the large number of co-op apartments not occupied by their owners. Many buildings have 70 to 80 percent of their stock in the hands of people who continue to rent them from the buildings' original sponsors. These hybrid buildings are especially difficult to manage, since renters often care less about the building, but also because owners frequently resent renters.
"Everyone anticipated sponsors would be there for a while," said Abbey Goldstein, a real estate lawyer. "But no one envisioned them being there forever. And there is tremendous abuse in regard to sponsors improperly keeping control of boards."
At least one case dealing with the right of investors to rent co-op apartments indefinitely is before the State Supreme Court.
It is true that some recent court decisions have gone against co-op boards, but none have significantly sapped their basic powers. In April, a court ruled that a woman could have a freezer in her co-op, in violation of house rules, after she established that she suffered from panic disorder and was unable to leave her apartment often enough to shop for food. In June, a court ruled that a co-op can't charge sublet fees unless that right is expressed in the lease and bylaws. Lawyers hurriedly began advising boards to spell out fines and restrictions in their bylaws.
Greater harmony may have to come in ad hoc ways. In many buildings, annual parties are held so people at least meet one another. In-house newsletters are distributed to strengthen communication.
Many promote arbitration and mediation to resolve co-op disputes. This would prevent cases like the recent one in which $130,000 in legal fees were exhausted to decide who should pay for window bars costing $924.
Lela Love, who directs a mediation clinic at the Cardozo Law School and has mediated many co-op cases, recalls the two warring couples in a Brooklyn co-op. For years, they fought over the banging noise that one couple's infant made at meals in his highchair. Not until the aggrieved couple tried to bring criminal charges of harassment against the other couple did they turn to mediation. A solution emerged: wrap the metal parts of the high chair in towels and put a carpet beneath the legs.
Just as they argue over whether to allow pianos, or dogs weighing more than 15 pounds, co-op owners find themselves divided over what they want.
A long-time co-op resident, after lamenting the constrained nature of the co-op system, was asked if she might prefer a condo. She gave a withering look and said: "Oh, no. Then anyone can move in."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Norman Schreiber, a freelance writer who lives in a Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, co-op, is writing a murder mystery set in a co-op. "There's the sense of ownership that does make a difference in how you think and live and plan with each other," he said. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: 'Yes' for New York Debt Reform

 BODY:
It took many years of profligate borrowing, shaky budgets and fiscal gimmickry for New York to sink to one of the lowest state credit ratings in the country. The state's poor standing is not simply an embarrassment. It costs taxpayers millions of dollars a year in extra debt service payments.
The best hope for improving the state's shoddy borrowing habits is an important, if little discussed, proposal to amend the State Constitution on the ballot Nov. 7. We strongly urge a "yes" vote on Ballot Proposal No. 3. 
 On paper, the New York State Constitution already imposes stringent controls on government borrowing. Bond issues must be approved by the voters, in theory, and the voters have been increasingly reluctant to do so. But since the days of Gov. Nelson Rockefeller, state governments have circumvented voter resistance to bond issues by finding stealthy devices to issue debt without referendum approval. The principal means was the creation of state agencies that issued their own bonds, backed by the stated intention of the Legislature to make appropriations every year to retire them. Despite aggressive legal challenges, this form of backdoor indebtedness has been upheld by the state's highest court as legal because it was not considered the kind of debt barred by the State Constitution.
Today New York State has only $5 billion worth of bonds authorized by the voters -- and $23 billion worth issued by state agencies without voter approval.
Proposal No. 3 would amend the Constitution and outlaw such backdoor debt, except in a few instances. It would, however, enable the Legislature to authorize the issuing of bonds backed by specific revenues without approval by the voters, as long as their total does not exceed a cap pegged to a fixed amount of the total personal income reported by the state's residents. The measure will not necessarily cut down on New York's debts. But it will prohibit borrowing for day-to-day expenses, and make most future debt a direct obligation of the state.
Under the proposed amendment, the state would also be required to produce a long-range capital investment plan, subject to public hearings, so that citizens for the first time would be able to see its priorities clearly. The measure would also allow several bond issues to be proposed for approval at the same time, enabling voters to pick and choose which purposes they would like to support. Until now, only one big grab-bag bond issue was allowed for each election.
By far the biggest advantage is that the measure would make more clear the purposes of future debt and the revenues that will be available to pay it off. Once and for all it would forbid such practices as the selling of the state prison at Attica to the Urban Development Corporation, and then renting it back for a quick infusion of cash to meet expenses.
Ultimately, the most effective brake on borrowing will be pressure from the voters and the credit agencies. But everyone will benefit by making the process more open and based more on long-term planning than short-term expediencies.
Three other proposed constitutional amendments will be on the ballot:
* Proposal No. 1 would increase the maximum amount of money in damages that can be sought in lawsuits before the Civil Court of New York City or the District Court in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, from $25,000 to $50,000. We endorse this proposal as a reasonable adjustment to the impact of inflation on lawsuits that may be filed in the state's lower courts.
* We also recommend a "yes" vote for Proposal No. 2, which would make it clear that if a registered voter moves within the same county or within New York City, he or she does not need to re-register. The measure also incorporates several changes to make state law conform with Federal law.
* Proposal No. 4 would authorize the state to let the upstate town of Keene, near Lake Placid, acquire 12 acres from Adirondack State Park for a cemetery. In return the town would give 144 acres surrounding a nearby trout stream to the state. Environmentalists support the measure as a net gain for the park. We recommend a "yes" vote.

HEADLINE: For Fare Increase, M.T.A. Owes Us a Giveback

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since the Metropolitan Transportation Authority breached the $1 fare barrier on New York City buses and subways some years ago, I have found it more difficult to use this public service without the necessity of rationalizing whether or not each use was economically justified. O.K., call me a penny pincher, but I support a wife and two children. 
 With the fare increasing by 20 percent this time to a substantial $1.50, local transportation cost is going to become a household expense to weigh just like groceries.
Beginning Nov. 12, when the four of us decide to spend a weekend afternoon in Central Park or shopping for school shoes, as we recently did, the $12 round-trip transit fare will have to be factored in to our planned expenses. To us, $12 is not an insignificant amount of money.
Using the most conservative calculations, my family's minimum bus and subway fare expenses over a year will be $2,748. That is $229 a month. I could almost lease a car for that, and maybe I should, forgetting the nice idealism of helping to preserve the environment by relying on mass transit.
Assuming that a fare increase is justified and that all appropriate efficiency measures have been taken in management of the system, let us think of a way for the M.T.A. to give something back to the ridership and perhaps increase ridership as well.
Over the years the agency has tried half-fare programs. What I would like to see is a half-fare program at night and on weekends. This would place the burden on the commuter (I am one) and encourage use during off-peak hours. The mechanisms are already in place because it would be an extension of the seniors' half-fare program. How about it, M.T.A.?
 
WILLIAM H. WORK
New York, Oct. 25, 1995

HEADLINE: Who Put Ethics on Labor's New Agenda

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Labor Wakes Up" (editorial, Oct. 26) speaks to the hopes of many workers that a revitalized labor movement can grow again to improve economic and social conditions for all American workers. But one error is apparent to any knowledgeable observer of labor's debates over the past four or five months. 
 You credit supporters of the newly elected A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, John J. Sweeney, with the effort of the labor movement to "police itself vigilantly."
Although I supported Tom Donahue's re-election, I have no desire to reopen the campaign, and I am committed to doing what I can to help the new administration succeed. I firmly believe that Mr. Sweeney will attempt to pursue an ethical practices code and hope that you will be vigilant in reporting its successes.
However, the resolution to update an ethical practices code and to provide an enforcement mechanism was part of Mr. Donahue's campaign for re-election, not Mr. Sweeney's.
Mr. Donahue introduced this subject in his inaugural address on Aug. 1, pursued it over the objections of several Sweeney supporters, included it in his campaign literature (it never appeared in Mr. Sweeney's literature) and insured its adoption as the last piece of convention business over which he presided.
Tom Donahue has always deeply believed that labor needs to insure that no hint of corruption engaged in by a few individuals be allowed to taint the dedicated work of so many honest, hard-working trade union leaders.
 
ALBERT SHANKER
President
American Federation of Teachers
Washington, Oct. 27, 1995

HEADLINE: Kate Ericson, 39, Installation Artist

 BODY:
Kate Witte Ericson, an artist who collaborated with her husband, Mel Ziegler, on indoor and outdoor installation works noted for their beauty, complexity and social awareness, died on Sunday at her home in Milanville, Pa. She was 39 and also had a home in Manhattan.
The cause was brain cancer, her husband said. 
 Ms. Ericson was born in Manhattan in 1955. She earned a bachelor of fine arts degree from the Kansas City Art Institute in 1978 and a master's from the California Institute of the Arts in 1982. She and Mr. Ziegler met as undergraduates and began working together in 1978, developing a style that featured provocative accumulations of materials and ideas, many of them involved with architecture, American history and the economy.
One of their first solo shows, at the Los Angeles Institute of Contemporary Art in 1986, consisted of a display of all the wood necessary to raise a house, with each piece carved with a phrase or adage about house or home. At the end of the exhibition, the wood was sold and used in the construction of a house.
Ms. Ericson and Mr. Ziegler exhibited their work in many shows in the United States and abroad, including the 1989 Whitney Biennial. Their most recent New York exhibition was in 1993 at the Michael Klein Gallery in SoHo.
In addition to her husband, Ms. Ericson is survived by her parents, H. A. and Alma Ericson, of Norwalk, Conn., and a brother, Scott, of Arlington, Tex.
