HEADLINE: Mike Figgis Reconsiders His Divorce From Hollywood

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Mike Figgis has no illusions about the limited appeal of his new film, "Leaving Las Vegas." After all, it has no car chases and no explosions. It doesn't even have a serial killer, the trend of the moment in Hollywood.
"I really have no high expectations for the box office," said Mr. Figgis, a British director whose relationship with Hollywood can be characterized only as veering between ambivalence and despair. "I don't feel my life is on the line. Besides, it's already exceeded my expectations." 
 "Leaving Las Vegas" opened last week in New York and Los Angeles. Little or no fanfare preceded it, but it received some of the best reviews of the year. In the film, which expands around the nation this week, Ben, an alcoholic played by Nicolas Cage, goes to Las Vegas to end his life in a final binge. He meets and falls in love with a prostitute played by Elisabeth Shue; their bond seems mysterious, tender and desperate. "This small, searing film watches transfixingly as Ben plays out his final hand," Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.
The movie is based on a semi-autobiographical novel by a screenwriter, John O'Brien, who killed himself two weeks after learning the book was to be made into a movie. O'Brien left no suicide note, but his father, Bill, said the book, also called "Leaving Las Vegas," served the same purpose. "The family came to the set one day, and I found it almost unbearably sad," Mr. Figgis said.
For the 45-year-old London-based director, whose past films include "Stormy Monday," "Internal Affairs" and "Mr. Jones," it is something of a personal vindication that the movie was made at all. It hardly surprised him that most of the major studios rejected it as too uncommercial; less expected were rejections from Miramax, Gramercy and Sony Classics, companies that are normally sympathetic to this kind of film. It is being released in the United States by MGM/UA.
"A year ago I was almost unemployable," Mr. Figgis said over breakfast at his hotel the other morning. "Frankly, I'm broke. But I feel optimistic. However bad the studio system is, the American film industry will always surprise you by taking a film like this and saying, 'We really like it.' It's true; you're only as good as your last picture."
By most accounts, including his own, Mr. Figgis's last Hollywood picture, "Mr. Jones," was not very good. In fact, he describes the experience as a nightmare.
The 1993 movie, which starred Richard Gere as a manic-depressive who falls in love with his psychiatrist (Lena Olin), was controlled by a revolving group of studio executives at Tri-Star, and producers whom Mr. Figgis despised.
"I've never in my life experienced anything that was so degrading, so humiliating, so completely lacking in respect," Mr. Figgis said. "Had it been anywhere but a film studio, people would have been on the floor bleeding."
The major source of disagreement on "Mr. Jones," according to the director, was the insistence of the producers and the studio that it be more upbeat. "They felt the film was too dark and wanted it more glamorous," Mr. Figgis said. "I thought it was a ludicrous idea. Manic-depression isn't something to dismiss lightly."
"You either learn from that kind of experience, or you turn very bitter," said Mr. Figgis, whose roots are in experimental theater and music, and who writes the scores for his movies. "And then this book turned up. I saw it as a symbol of something. The choice was to make a film or to try to make more money. Actually it was no choice."
Executives at Tri-Star disagreed strongly with the director's account, saying that "Mr. Jones" was always intended to be a love story and that Mr. Figgis failed to follow the script and instead asked the actors to improvise their lines. They said that the ending presented by Mr. Figgis was incoherent and that the studio took over the final editing.
The final outcome was a critical and financial failure that all parties would now like to forget.
It was while Mr. Figgis was involved in post-production work on "Mr. Jones" that Stuart Regan, a friend of his who runs an art gallery in Santa Monica, found the O'Brien novel in a secondhand bookstore, read it and brought it to Mr. Figgis's attention. "It was such a profoundly dark story," Mr. Figgis said. "And it was like a breath of fresh air to me, because it came along at not a very good time." (Mr. Regan is executive producer.)
Mr. Figgis took only a week to write the first draft, and immediately called Mr. Cage, whom he had met casually. "The book is brutal and very 90's, but there was a kind of old-fashioned charm and dignity to this man -- and Nicolas was the one actor I thought of."
Ms. Shue, who has played ingenue roles in such movies as "Adventures in Baby-Sitting" and "The Karate Kid," was cast partly because she seemed so wholesome. "I wanted the girl next door," said Mr. Figgis, who met Ms. Shue years ago when she read for a project and convinced him that she had talents untapped by studios.
With the help of his agent, Robert Newman at International Creative Management, Mr. Figgis raised the bulk of the film's cost, $3.5 million, from Lumiere Films, a French production, financing and distribution company. The actors and Mr. Figgis took virtually no money, and shooting was done on Super 16 film, normally used in documentaries, instead of 35 millimeter.
"It was lighter, it was cheaper, it was grittier, and it was a little more impressionistic," Mr. Figgis said. Sting, a friend of Mr. Figgis's since they worked together in 1988 on "Stormy Monday," volunteered to sing on the soundtrack.
The story has a deeply personal resonance for Mr. Figgis, who is married and has three children. "My parents were alcoholics," he said. "On weekends they would drink themselves into stupors, be out of control, irresponsible." (His father died of cancer; his mother is ailing.) The director spent his childhood in Nairobi, Kenya, in the fading days of British colonial rule.
"We lived in the lap of luxury with no money whatsoever," he said. For a while his mother worked as a secretary to Ernest Hemingway. He describes his father as "a charming, dashing Irishman" who held a succession of jobs, but mainly "he drank."
"We were always broke," Mr. Figgis recalled, "but we lived like kings."
As for the connection between the film and his parents, Mr. Figgis said, "A psychiatrist would say you associate yourself with the thing you would like to heal in yourself."
After the family relocated to northern England, Mr. Figgis began playing in rock-and-roll bands and later immersed himself in London's avant-garde theater world. His first major feature film, "Stormy Monday," set in Newcastle's steamy jazz world, and starring Tommy Lee Jones, Sting and Melanie Griffith, received strong reviews and caught the attention of Hollywood. His American directorial debut, "Internal Affairs," a police thriller with Richard Gere and Andy Garcia, made Mr. Figgis one of the more provocative and sought-after directors in town.
But the films that followed -- "Liebestraum," a thriller that brought Kim Novak out of retirement; "The Browning Version," starring Albert Finney and Greta Scacchi; and "Mr. Jones" -- were either critical or financial disappointments. With "Leaving Las Vegas," could Mr. Figgis's stormy relationship with Hollywood be on the upswing? He's not sure.
He would like to make a movie version of Strindberg's "Miss Julie," starring Juliette Binoche, late next year. In the meantime he's enjoying the reaction to his new film -- and waiting for offers.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
The Search for Peace in the Balkans: A Primer

 BODY:
After four years of war that followed the disintegration of Communist Yugoslavia - and added "ethnic cleansing" to the world's vocabulary of shame - the leaders of Bosnia, Serbia and Croatia are meeting at an Air Force base in Ohio today to begin hammering out a peace settlement. If progress is made, the parties will move to Paris for continued negotiations. NATO has pledged to send 60,000 troops to enforce a peace.
 
THE PLAYERS
 
Slobodian Milosevic
President of Serbia
 The 54-year-old Communist turned nationalist has been blamed more than anyone else for the violence that has wracked the Balkans. In search of a Greater Serbia, his army or his proxies attacked Croatia and led a rebellion against the Muslim-dominated government of Bosnia. Squeezed by a United Nations economic embargo, his territorial holdings rolled back by force, he has recently brought the Bosnian Serbs to heel and sought a settlement. He is negotiating on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs.
 
Alija Izetbegovic
President of Bosnia
 The founder in 1990 of the Muslim nationalist party in Bosnia, Mr. Izetbegovic, 70, had served in prison for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Communists. A lawyer and a devout man, he has been accused by the Serbs of "fundamentalism," but he says he stands for tolerance. Elected president in 1990, he led his country to independence in 1992, arguing that the alternative was oppressive Serbian rule. But this helped set off a war for which the government was unprepared.
 
Franjo Tudjman
President of Croatia
 A one-time Communist official who was jailed by Tito for his ardent Croatian nationalism, Mr. Tudjman, 73, has made little secret of his desire to bring Croatians in Bosnia into the orbit of the motherland. But he relied on tacit American support for a military build-up to counterbalance Serbia and, under Western pressure, says he supports the integrity of Bosnia.
 
THE MAJOR ISSUES
 
TERRITORY
 Each side now controls an area roughly equal to what it would get ina settlement. But each has other areas it wants for security or historic reasons. The Serbs, for example, want a more secure corridor linking up their lands, while the Bosnians want a clear path to the surrounded enclave of Gorazde. Any trading of hard-won ground is certain to be wrenching.
 
ENDING HOSTILITIES
 Beyond the current cease-fire, the parties will have to agree on how far back to pull their armies, how to monitor troops and arms, whether military reductions will occur and how peacekeeping forces will be interposed. The Americans also seek to equialize forces by reducing Serb arms or increasing the government's.
 
CONSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS
 How much power will the central government have? How will elections be organized and monitored? The details will determine whether Bosnia survives as a genuine country or a fiction, with its Serbian and Croatian areas effectively annexed by neighbors. The rights of displaced people to regain their homes will also be discussed.
 
EASTERN SLAVONIA
 Negotiators will try to set a timetable for the return of this Serb-held region to Croatia, and the protection of Serbs who remain as displaced Croats flood back in. The Croatian president has set a deadline to the end of November before conducting a military attack.
 
SARAJEVO
The future of Sarajevo, the symbolic heart of a multi-ethnic Bosnia, is in dispute. The government wants an open, shared city under its control; the Serbs want to keep the areas they control as part of their new republic.
 
WHAT'S BEEN DECIDED
 In previous meetings in Geneva and New York, the warring parties agreed on general priniciples. Bosnia is to remain a single country but it will be divided into two republics: one governed by the Bosnian-Croat federation, which will have about 51 percent of the territory and one by the Bosnian Serbs, which will have about 49 percent. Each can develop special ties to neighboring countries.
 The principles call for free, internationally monitored elections to select a collective national presidency, with two-thirds of its members from the Bosnian-Croat federation and one-third from the Serbvs, and a parliament divided along the same lines.
 
The Bosnian Serbs
 
Serbian leaders in Bosnia say their people fear life under Muslim domination, and had looked to Serbia for support for their rebellion, but are new reduced to seeking a semi-autonomous region. The political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and the military leader, Ratko Mladic, have both been indicted for war crimes and have lost Serbia's support for their war aims.
 
Croatia
 
Mainly Roman Catholic, with a population of nearly 5 million, Croatia has fought to regain its territory, with support from the West, which sees it as a counter-balance to Serbia. Now in an uneasy alliance with theBosnian government, its main immediate goal is to secure the return of eastern Slovania, seized by Serbs in 1991.
 
Bosnian and Herzegovina
 
When it broke from Yugoslavia in 1992, Bosnia's population of 4.6 million was about one-half Muslim - mainly Slavic people who adopted Islam under Ottoman rule - one-third Serb and one-fifth Croat. The government, dominated by Muslims, says it is committed to a pluralistic society, and it now hopes that international backing will preserve its borders.
 
Bosnian-Croat Federation
 
At American urging, Bosnian Croats and government forces stopped fighting each other in 1994 and forged an alliance to battle the Bosnian Serbs. The federation is to govern about half of Bosnia under the peace settlement, but the government is alarmed by indications that local Croats are deepending their ties to Croatia.
 
Serbia
 
A majority of Serbia's 10 million people are Orthodox Christian Serbs, but te country also includes restive Albanian and Hungarian minorities. At first the undisputed powerhouse of the region, Serbia and Montenegro retained the name of Yugoslavia, an entity not widely recognized by other countries. President Milosovic fanned the flames of nationalism, but the dream of a Greater Serbia has wilted.
 
Four Tortuous Years of Talk, Broken Promises and War
 
1991
 
JUNE -- Croatia and Slovenia declare independence. In Slovenia, the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army agrees to withdraw after 10 days of fighting. In Croatia, the Krajina region is seized by local Serbs.
 
SEPTEMBER -- United Nations imposes an arms embargo on the former Yugoslav republics. Serbs take over eastern Slavonia region of Croatia, destroying city ov Vukovar.
 
OCTOBER -- Serbs begin seige of Dubrovnik.
 
1992
 
FEBRUARY -- Bosnian Croats and muslims vote overwhelmingly for independence; most Serbs boycott the vote. Tensions intensify as Serbs establish autonomous regions, saying they fear Muslim domination. U.N. votes to send peacekeepers to monitor Croatian-Serbian cease-fire.
 
APRIL -- European Community and United States recognize Bosnia. Serbian siege of Sarajevo begins. A vicious Serbian campaign to evict or kill Muslims in scores of towns and villages throughout Bosnia begins.
 
MAY -- U.N. imposes an economic embargo on Serbia and Montenegro after a shell kills more than a dozen people lined up for bread in Sarajevo.
 
MAY-OCTOBER -- Serbs engage in widespread and brutal "ethnic cleansing" of areas they conquer, ejecting Muslims. Tens of thousands of Muslim men are put in detention camps and widespread rape of Muslim women is reported.
 
OCTOBER -- U.N. imposes a 'no-flight zone' over Bosnia to deter Serb attacks (not enforced until April '93).
 
1993
 
JANUARY -- Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen announce a peace proposal to divide Bosnia into 10 provinces. Plan falls apart after rejection by Bosnian Serb assembly in May.
 
APRIL -- War erupts between Bosnian Muslims andCroats over territory. Croats in the Mostar region throw Muslims into camps similar to those run by the Serbs.
 
MAY -- Serbia, squeezed by economic sanctions, says it is cutting off aid to the Bosnian Serbs, though some supplies continue.
 
1994
 
FEBRUARY -- A Serbian shell at the Sarajevo marketplace kills 69 people and prompts NATO to set an ultimatum for the withdrawal of Serbian artillery around the city. Most guns remain in place but are monitored by the U.N.
 As Bosnian Serbs make large gains in eastern Bosnia, United Nations declares several "safe areas" and threatens NATO air strikes to maintain them.
 United States sponsors uneasy federation between Muslims and Croats.
 
APRIL -- First NATO air strikes, on Serbian forces around Gorazde, triggered by Bosnian Serb attack on this "safe area." Serbs take U.N. peacekeepers hostage, and pinprick air attacks stop.
 
1995
 
MAY -- Situation in Sarajevo deteriorates as Serbs resume using heavy guns. NATO air strikes near Pale are followed by the seizure of over 400 United Nations hostages by the Serbs. Air strikes are halted.
 
JULY -- Serbs overrun Srebenica and Zepa and expel Muslims, including these women and children, and massare thousands of Muslim men, causing world outrage. NATO threatens extensive air strikes if Gorazde is attacked.
 The War Crimes Tribunal at the Hague indicts Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, and Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander, bringing the number of indictments to nearly 50.
 
AUGUST -- After a deadly mortar attack on a Sarajevo market, NATO begins a 2-week bombing campaign designed to break the siege of the city and force the Serbs to negotiate.
 
AUGUST-SEPTEMBER -- Croatian forces retake the Krajina, sending more than 170,000 Serbs fleeing.
 
SEPTEMBER -- U.S.-brokered talks lead Bosnians, Croats and Serbs to agree on basic principles for a settlement, preserving one country with two republics.
 
OCTOBER -- As Bosnian and Croat offensives recapture large areas of eastern Bosnia, the three warring sides agree to a cease-fire and to hold preliminary talks in the United States.

HEADLINE: U.S. Wages Up 2.7% in Year, A Record Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The expanding economy that has propelled stock prices to record levels has not spilled over to the paychecks of American workers, whose earnings rose by 2.7 percent in the last 12 months, the smallest amount on record, the Labor Department reported today.
In the year that ended in September, wages and salaries rose by 2.8 percent and benefits rose by 2.2 percent, resulting in the calculation of a 2.7 percent overall rise in earnings. Inflation for the same period was 2.5 percent, while economic growth was 3.5 percent. 
 The figures also showed that business was succeeding in its effort to bring down the cost of health care. The amount spent on health benefits fell by one-tenth of 1 percent, the first decline since the Government began tracking these costs in 1981. As recently as 1988, health spending was going up 14 percent a year.
Since the mid-1980's, the incomes of middle-class households have stagnated. But today's figures underscore the view that even in a year with a solidly expanding economy, a roaring stock market and strong corporate profits, many American workers cannot find perceptible improvements in their earnings.
The frustration and insecurity that have resulted are expected to play a major role in shaping next year's Presidential race as politicians of both parties try to portray themselves as the best choice to provide economic growth that will benefit the middle class.
President Clinton has already found it hard to get political credit for the strong economy, and stagnant paychecks will make it harder for him to contend that he has helped the average worker. But the results also hold out little joy for the Republicans as they try to deal with public skepticism about many of the Federal spending cuts they plan to enact in such areas as education and Medicare.
"There is something wrong with rising profits, rising productivity and a soaring stock market but employee compensation heading nowhere," Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich said today.
Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, a senior member of the Banking Committee, said today that the figures were a result of broad changes in the structure of the American economy. "It's not the fault of either party or budget problems," she said. "It's the fundamental changes in the technological base and employment patterns."
But, she added, "If we don't get the budget deficit down and we don't reorder our savings and tax policies, we'll never be able to tackle this."
While economic growth has been steady, Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, contends that it has not been high enough to drive up wages. Faster growth will not occur without lower interest rates from the Federal Reserve and more Government support for exports, he said.
"If we are concerned about wages and workers' standard of living, we ought to focus more on doing all we can to raise growth," he said. Many analysts do expect the Federal Reserve will lower short-term interest rates one more time this year.
The hope that higher growth will lift compensation may be of scant comfort to workers worried about keeping their jobs. Even as economic growth remains steady, companies continue to announce plans to shed jobs, the latest being an announcement today that W. R. Grace & Company would cut 800 jobs by the end of next year.
The job insecurity bred by such cutbacks was cited this month by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, as a major factor in the slowdown in labor compensation. "That fear has doubtless played a significant role in the slowdown in the growth of labor compensation as workers have in effect sought to preserve their jobs by accepting lesser increases in wages," he said.
Today's figures, however, offered hope that incomes could be about to grow somewhat faster.
"We are getting health costs under control," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "That leaves more room for wages to increase."
While some analysts remain skeptical that reductions in benefit costs can be sustained, there is a growing sense that some significant portion will be shared with workers as well as with stockholders.
Specialists say that most of the savings so far have come not from a shrinking of benefits or a shifting of costs to workers but from companies using their leverage to bargain harder with hospitals, clinics and other providers of health care.
"Employers have become a lot smarter in using their leverage to negotiate and providers are doing all they can to keep their share of the market," said Charles Kerby, an official at William M. Mercer Inc., a consulting firm based in New York.
Today's report showed that total compensation costs rose just six-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, matching the first quarter of this year for the smallest increase since the series began in 1982.
Wages and salaries were up seven-tenths of 1 percent for a 12-month total of 2.8 percent, while benefit costs were up four-tenths of 1 percent for a 2.2 percent yearly rise.
For workers in private industry, employment costs rose six-tenths of 1 percent, or 2.6 percent over 12 months. That, according to economists at Merrill Lynch, is probably the smallest rise in at least 40 years.
Wayne Shelly of the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, noting the decades of minimal gains in benefits, said the Merrill Lynch assessment sounded "reasonable."
The figures for health costs were not published separately from benefits as a whole, which also encompass vacation, holidays, sick leave, shift differentials, life insurance, retirement benefits, unemployment insurance and severance pay.
But Mr. Shelly said health costs eased one-tenth of 1 percent in the latest 12 months, the first time they had shown such a retreat.
As gauged by the Consumer Price Index, inflation in medical care has moderated significantly in recent years but still ran at 4.4 percent for the 12 months through September. The decline in employers' costs implies that some hard bargaining was done by corporate America.
For the 12 months through September, today's report showed, workers in service industries posted compensation gains of 2.9 percent compared with 2.1 percent for those in goods-producing industries. This was markedly different from the year ended September 1994 when the increases of both groups were separated by just one-tenth of a point, straddling 3.25 percent.
White-collar workers had bigger gains than blue-collar workers, 2.8 percent to 2.3 percent, while non-union workers, up 2.7 percent, did a bit better than union workers, up 2.4 percent, the report also found.
One of the biggest gains came for workers at colleges and universities, where pay and benefits rose 4.7 percent. Machine operators, assemblers and inspectors, on the other hand, gained just 1.8 percent.
By region, compensation increases for the 12 months were 2.7 percent in the Northeast, 2.8 percent in the South, 2.5 percent in the Midwest and 2.1 percent in the West. Workers in metropolitan areas gained 2.7 percent, with those in other areas up 2.4 percent.
In a separate report today, the department said collective-bargaining settlements reached by private industry in the third quarter called for smaller increases than the contracts they replaced, the 12th consecutive period this had occurred. The average increases were 3.2 percent in both the first year and over the term of the contract, compared with increases of 3.8 percent and 3.3 percent, respectively, in the contracts being replaced. Most of those older contracts were negotiated in 1992.
Last week, the department reported that median weekly earnings of wage-and-salary workers climbed 3.7 percent over the latest 12 months. After adjustment for inflation, the real gain was 1 percent.

As the article stated, they rose 2.8 percent, not 2.7 percent. Earnings, consisting of wages, salaries and benefits, rose 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Turning Rockers Into High Rollers

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
With his baseball cap turned backward and a silver earring bobbing as he strummed a few chords on an air guitar, 29-year-old Philip Weck was not your typical casino customer. But then again, this was not your typical Vegas hot spot: music by Pearl Jam pumped through the sound system and an electronic board above a bank of slot machines counted the diminishing number of acres of rain forest left on mother earth.
"It's more like a party than a casino," Mr. Weck observed, taking a break from a post-midnight romp at the roulette table in the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino here. "It's more familiar to people like me than the Strip." 
 You say you want a revolution? By most standards, the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino, which opened with high-decibel pomp last spring, is less than radical. An affiliate of the Hard Rock Cafes, it bills itself as the spot in Las Vegas for people who do not like Las Vegas, but it is ultimately a place to eat, drink and gamble, with plenty of buxom cocktail waitresses.
When it opened, there was only a hope that a younger crowd would discover Vegas, and that if it did, the newcomers would spend freely. Now there are answers to both questions. The hotel says that it turns away as many as 300 people seeking reservations every weekend, and that the Hard Rock's revenues are running more than 50 percent ahead of projections.
With tens of thousands of young customers like Mr. Weck attracted by the slick rock-and-roll aura, this may prove a hint of things to come in Las Vegas, which has been experimenting for several years with ways of reinvigorating its time-tested, if slightly tired, formula of glitz, schlock and the lure of easy money.
The Hard Rock is also showing the way for what will undoubtedly be forays by other entertainment-oriented companies -- from Planet Hollywood, which is working with Caesars Palace, to the leading movie studios -- into the enormously profitable gambling business.
The top executives of the Sony Corporation, for instance, have been given tours of the Hard Rock by its chairman, Peter Morton, and even the Walt Disney Company, which has denied rumors that it is considering opening a casino, has said it may test the waters by putting slot machines on cruise ships it is building.
The initial success of the Hard Rock is a sign of the new marketing strategies being employed in the $40 billion gambling industry as it overcomes old moral and legal restraints and makes its way into America's mainstream.
For instance, many casino operators here have sought to shed the old image of mob-infiltrated dens of sin filled with an aging tour-bus crowd by appealing to clean-cut families. They have added amusement parks and hotels built around themes like pirates or ancient Egypt.
But the Hard Rock is looking beyond that clientele, which has a median age of 46. Mr. Morton said the median age of a Hard Rock customer was 35, and was better educated and more well-to-do than the industry average.
"I'm not sure you can even call this a yuppie crowd," said Barbara Hein, a 39-year-old dealer in the Hard Rock casino, as she surveyed its youthful mix of customers. "They're younger than that."
She added: "I don't know where they get it all, but they sure do have money to spend. I can't believe it."
Neither can Mr. Morton, co-founder of the Hard Rock empire and 60 percent owner of the hotel and casino.
"We knew they'd come, but people are betting a lot more than we thought," he said. "There are yuppies out there who'll really play blackjack. I mean, they play with real money. It's amazing."
The remaining 40 percent of the hotel and casino is owned by Harvey's Casino Resorts. The operation is private and does not release financial figures. Mr. Morton said, however, that it would produce revenues of about $100 million in the first year, compared with initial projections of $60 million.
One of the greatest surprises is the 2,000-square-foot retail store, which sells an array of Hard Rock paraphernalia, from T-shirts to caps for children -- all of which bear the Hard Rock insignia and are thus free advertising. Sales from the store are 75 percent ahead of budget, Mr. Morton said.
Young gamblers are also walking away with thousands of the casino's $25 playing chips, which carry an image of Jimi Hendrix. Each chip costs the Hard Rock a little more than 50 cents.
All that is why seven months after the opening of the 340-room hotel, Mr. Morton is thinking of doubling its size, with construction perhaps starting next year.
"What it proves so far is that there is real strong demand for that kind of product in the casino industry," said Mark Manson, a gambling analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It is hard to get that younger group. But this works."
The flood of revenues is not being matched by profits, though. The hotel and casino, a short way from the Strip, the site of the biggest casinos (many with more than 2,000 rooms), overran its initial construction budget of $78 million and ended up costing $102 million.
And, at least so far, the Hard Rock has cost more to run than anticipated as the hotel and casino fine-tune their formulas. Salomon Brothers estimated that the Hard Rock contributed $400,000 to Harvey's net income in the third quarter, about a third of what the securities firm had expected.
"There were some costs that ran over a bit and we did some experimentation, so costs exceeded our expectations," said Charles W. Scharer, chief financial officer of Harvey's. "But the property is very strong."
The Hard Rock is a study in details. From the 82-foot Gibson guitar out front to the guitar-shaped slot machine handles, Red Hot Chili Pepper chips, saxophone chandelier and vintage Harley-Davidson motorcycle mounted above the tables, the place oozes hip ostentation. The nightclub, called the Joint, has featured acts from Bob Dylan to Melissa Etheridge and the Eagles.
The Do Not Disturb signs for the hotel rooms -- which begin at $75 for a double during the week and $135 on weekends -- read, "I hear Ya' Knockin' But Ya' Can't Come In." And the hotel room art, rather than the usual prints of anonymous seaside villages, consists of photos of rock greats like B.B. King and the Beatles. The rock music played at the pool, which has a sandy beach, is also broadcast underwater.
In short, it is a marketing laboratory, an attempt to remake an old product with new packaging.
"We've become what we wanted to be: the alternative to Caesars Palace," said Stephen L. Cavallaro, the Hard Rock's general manager. "Our cards asking people how they liked staying here say, 'Did you dig it or was it bogus?' More than 8 out of 10 rate us as awesome. Now that just blows me away."
Mr. Morton, of course, understands the marketing edge he has created.
"People sit around the pool, on the beach, and I love it when they say, 'I don't feel this is really Las Vegas,' " he said. "But economically I always look at it as Las Vegas."
One thing the formula misses are the high rollers, who create an aura that many other customers find attractive.
"This is real nice for a change, but these are real small players," said Margaret Thurston, a 50-something woman who works at a nearby hotel as a concierge and who was playing the Hard Rock's slot machines. "This place isn't in the same league as the other casinos with the high rollers."
A benefit of the younger crowd, however, is that they are more inclined to play the table games, which tend to be more profitable for the casino. That reverses a longtime trend at the nation's casinos, which have seen an increasing share of their earnings come from slot machines. They now reap a little more than half their revenues from the slots.
"One lesson we're learning is that the younger customers like more interactive activities," Mr. Cavallaro said. "Craps is more interactive than the slots. That's where they go."
For Mr. Morton, this is clearly just a first step away from the burgers-and-oldies formula of his cafes, as he seeks to find more ways to cash in on the brand name he has created. Casinos in other cities are a possibility, he said, as well as hotels and resorts with other partners. He also acknowledged that he had considered taking the Hard Rock empire public.
"I don't need to bring more lawyers and more accountants into my life," he insisted. "I have enough already. I don't need the money. But I've run my company in such a way that it could go public like . . . " And he snapped his fingers.
For now, he has demonstrated that someone who might not have favored gambling before can be attracted by the right atmosphere.
"Whoooaa!" said Tony Zaldivar, a 30-year-old auto restorer from Chicago, when asked why he had come to the Hard Rock.
"I always meet cool people here," said Mr. Zaldivar, who was sporting two earrings in his left ear, long black hair, a goatee and a sleeveless sweatshirt. "It's more my kind of people, my kind of music. You know?"
He added: "It's just a cool scene. Are you really a reporter, in Vegas?"

HEADLINE: Farewell to the Steam Table

BYLINE: By ALFRED GINGOLD and HELEN ROGAN 

 BODY:
AT Bertelsmann, employees can nibble fresh sushi in a sleek dining room overlooking the Great White Way. At Pfizer, they can pre-order their children's birthday cakes and pick them up on the way home. On request (not before), the server at Mount Sinai's Kosher Corner will prepare a serious pastrami sandwich garnished with the sort of sour pickle seldom experienced north of Delancey Street. Hungry lawyers at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler can choose between Chilean sea bass with peppers, mango and pineapple or a soft-shell crab sandwich with curry mayonnaise.
New York's company cafeterias are not what they used to be. 
 Gone from most places are the tired sandwiches, the soggy fries, the mystery-meat stews gently decomposing on the steam table. Nowadays, while there is still no such thing as a free lunch (except at very few places) the lunchtime living can be easy indeed.
There are, of course, some exceptions. At glitzy Conde Nast, a small uninspiring cafeteria dishes out mayonnaise-laden salads and hot foods off the steam table. The lissome editorial assistants merely race in for a "bialy, no butter," endless iced coffee, Dannon Light and (daringly) an egg white omelet on dry toast.
Companies have spruced up their cafeterias because in the 90's it makes business sense. A good meal at a reasonable price (less than $5 in most places, including beverage) in pleasant surroundings is a hefty benefit, generating good will and increasing productivity. The estimated 300 to 400 employee dining rooms are economical if they draw 80 percent of the employees at least once a day.
Most of the new cafeterias are in the hands of food service specialists, often subsidiaries of giant multinational corporations, which run them for profit or for a fee. Subsidized cafeterias remain popular, especially at law firms.
"It's not uncommon for people to be working through the night," said Mike Bailey of Compass International, the parent company of Flik International, which feeds many lawyers. "You'd better make sure you feed 'em well for that $3 billion deal."
What the new cafeterias have in common is more striking than their differences. To begin with, please do not call them "cafeterias"; those in charge prefer "employee dining facilities." Most are intended to be peaceful: cool colors, flowers, blond wood, carpets and tables far enough apart for privacy.
At Scholastic Inc.'s main offices in a renovated SoHo loft, the whole 12th floor was designed as the cafeteria. Outside, there is a terrace with sculpture, a stage, arbors, Adirondack furniture and spectacular views; inside, a room full of light, greenery, Fiestaware, exposed pipes and ducts painted in soft pastels and a jukebox stocked with classics like "Goodbye Cruel World [I'm Off to Join the Circus.]"
Even when the physical plant is unpromising, a soothing effect can be created. The cafeteria at Metropolitan Life, run by Aramark, is on a basement floor, but the look is of an indoor courtyard, with hanging plants, indirect lighting and thick white pillars.
Numerous extras win employee allegiance: At Scholastic, managed by Good Food, a small company in New York, there is free biscotti with your cappuccino, a daffodil or chocolate covered strawberry on the first day of spring and an employees' birthday breakfast every month. Kaye, Scholer, which handles its own cafeteria, offers free lunch on snowy days, cooking classes and an "appreciation day" for each employee, with a free lunch or candlelight dinner.
Most cafeterias have few lines. Instead, separate stations bearing names like the Kettle or Itsa Pizza or Varieties offer everything from tacos to Thai. At serving stations, warmed up with quasi-rustic touches, Restaurant Associates cafeterias display fruit and baked goods in baskets on farmhouse tables; at Restaura's operations at Paine Webber and Nynex, dishes are showcased on wrought-iron bakers' racks, and at Saatchi & Saatchi, Flik uses white crocks instead of the dreaded stainless steel.
So how is the food? Well, all pretty good. At Nynex, the chicken is lemony and light, and the arugula gritless; at Rockefeller University, the European sandwiches are served on bread from Eli's and the Tom Cat Bakery as well as the ubiquitous Fink; at Mount Sinai's cafeteria, run by Marriott International, diners can sample four salad vinegars.
And all of them offer serious coffee. While espresso and cappuccino are still big among media and financial types, others have moved on to flavored (often weirdly flavored) coffee; at Nynex, for example, it was butter pecan.
All the emphasis is on fresh preparation. In each of the dozen cafeterias visited, a cheerful person in a chef's hat was sharpening knives a la Benihana, tossing the elements of a stir fry or saucing pasta. These so-called boredom breakers keep the customers coming back.
Because the trend of the moment is lighter eating, salad bars have been overhauled and now offer fish or grilled chicken, perfectly cooked asparagus, hearts of palm, roasted vegetables and grains of many lands. The refrigerators teem with diet sodas and designer water. "Sure, people are diet-conscious when it comes to drinks," said Roy Elvove, Flik's man at Saatchi.
The food services all offer selections with names like Healthy Choice, Spa Menu and Living Right. Signs bearing little red apples or heart-shaped toothpicks stuck in the healthy stuff guide diners to make good dietary choices.
Although people are eating turkeyburgers and pasta more than before, they are easily discouraged. That is why, said Michael Kowalczyk, the chef at Kaye, Scholer, "We offer a low-fat lunch, which is a cold plate, but we don't give calorie amounts; people aren't ready to face the truth and look at two ounces of steamed salmon."
In small ways, every cafeteria comes to reflect the corporate culture enveloping it. At Metropolitan Life, a smiling woman dishes out hefty yellow cupcakes with brown icing in honor of the Preference Plus Account Variable Annuity Fifth Birthday.
At Rockefeller University, seasonal decorations are frowned upon. "They don't want to trash the place up," said John Harding of Restaurant Associates, looking around at the high-ceilinged airy room with its breathtaking views of the East River. Saatchi offers bright little bags for those who eat at their desks, while Ogilvy & Mather's cafeteria, a Gardner Merchant operation, tries to use as many client-sponsored products as possible, like Hershey chocolate and Birds Eye vegetables. It even has an after-hours bar.
One of the most idiosyncratic cafeterias in New York has to be the one done by Restaurant Associates for the performers at the Metropolitan Opera, where during the season you can see up to 1,600 people, many in costume, wolfing down cheeseburgers. (Placido Domingo is often there, while Pavarotti has everything brought to his dressing room, including mint tea and the Wellbred carrot cake, to which he is so devoted that the standing order is doubled when he is appearing.)
But the strangest cafeteria of all is at the United Nations, where Restaurant Associates serves a population of 7,000 people. Since the U.N. is not subject to American laws, the first thing anyone notices is the blue haze of cigarette smoke hanging over the premises. There is wine by the checkout, no diet soda to speak of, a perfunctory salad bar, and a person who makes espresso so well that world citizens line up for it. The menus are established after tortuous deliberations of a special committee; there are no seasonal observances, since no one wants to risk an international incident.
To give people what they want, cafeteria managers test new dishes and hold focus groups. "Don't add fancy herbs to good soup," one Bertelsmann employee said, while another complained of garlic overload. (To which the chef replied, "I am French and I feel I must do it.")
Despite the changes, all the managers emphasized that the modern cafeteria could not subsist on salad and low-fat yogurt. Saatchi's dessert station always includes big bowls of Jell-O, chocolate and rice pudding and whipped cream; at Ogilvy, the most popular dish is meat loaf; at Mount Sinai, fried chicken is very big. Even at Rockefeller University, where the fat gene was isolated, there are plenty of burgers and fries -- all the standard artery cloggers that even intellectuals, it seems, crave.

HEADLINE: Justices Consider Limit on Liquor Ads

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
A Supreme Court argument today on whether a state may constitutionally ban the advertising of liquor prices presented an interesting mix of free-speech principles and economic theory. If advertising is a form of constitutionally protected speech -- as the Court has held for 20 years -- can the state restrict truthful advertising about a lawful product to reduce consumer demand?
Lurking on the edges of the argument, never explicitly acknowledged but clearly on the Justices' minds, were the potential consequences of whatever answer they might give for Government regulation of advertising for other products, including cigarettes. 
 "Is your product special, or would the Court also be saying that the state can stop price advertising across the board" for products that can reasonably be described as harmful, Justice Stephen G. Breyer asked Rebecca T. Partington, a Special Assistant Attorney General from Rhode Island, who was asking the Court to uphold her state's restriction on liquor advertising.
"Alcohol stands in a unique position," Mrs. Partington replied. She cited the social problems caused by excessive drinking as well as the long history of Government regulation of liquor, including the 21st Amendment, which repealed Prohibition while leaving considerable regulatory power to the states.
But some Justices appeared to doubt the Court could decide the case in a way that would not have effects, perhaps unanticipated, on the regulation of products beyond liquor, especially given a 1986 Supreme Court decision that permitted limits on advertising by gambling casinos. It would be difficult to claim a unique position for alcohol on a list that already includes gambling, Justice David H. Souter suggested.
Justice Anthony M. Kennedy asked whether states could limit advertising about firearms, prompting Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg to ask: "You ask about guns -- what about butter?" Justice Antonin Scalia added: "Some states may hate red meat."
Rhode Island's law, which dates to 1956, prohibits liquor advertisements that include not only prices but suggestive words like sale or wow. Two liquor stores challenged the law in Federal District Court in Providence in 1992 and won a ruling that the statute was an unconstitutional restriction on commercial speech.
But the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, overturned that ruling and upheld the law last year. The state did not have to prove its theory that the advertising restriction would translate into lower liquor consumption, the appeals court said, noting that all that was required was for the state's rationale to be reasonable.
Arguing today for the liquor stores, Evan T. Lawson said the state should not be permitted to restrict speech when it could achieve its regulatory goal of lowering consumption by increasing the state tax on liquor or by setting minimum prices.
Mr. Lawson acknowledged that states are free under the 21st Amendment to ban liquor sales entirely. "But you can't say that because you have the power to ban something, you have the power to ban speech about something you're not banning," he said. Mr. Lawson said the state had failed to provide even minimal proof that the advertising restriction reduced consumption, adding that liquor consumption in Rhode Island was relatively high compared to that of other states.
"Isn't there a certain latitude allowed to a state to indulge a common-sense presumption?" Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist asked.
In her argument on behalf of the state, Mrs. Partington said "generally accepted economic principles" support the reasonableness of the state's view that the advertising restriction will lead to generally higher prices that in turn lead to reduced consumption, serving the state's goal of curbing alcohol abuse and "promoting temperance."
Ten other states, including Connecticut, prohibit or restrict the advertising of liquor prices.
In an advertising restriction that extends beyond price, the city of Baltimore has banned billboards and other outdoor advertising of alcoholic beverages in some locations. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, dismissed a constitutional challenge to the Baltimore ordinance earlier this year. Last week, Anheuser-Busch appealed that ruling to the Supreme Court.
The case before the Court today, 44 Liquormart v. Rhode Island, No. 94-1140, attracted wide attention, with the liquor stores receiving support from organizations not usually found on the same side of constitutional debates. The American Civil Liberties Union filed a brief describing the state law as a restriction on truthful information that should receive the most strict constitutional scrutiny. A conservative public interest law firm, the Institute for Justice, filed a brief describing the law as economic protectionism that intrudes on the normal operation of the market for liquor.
Many of these groups are also carefully watching the evolution of national policy on cigarette advertising. In August, President Clinton proposed Federal regulations to curb smoking among teen-agers by limiting cigarette advertising in magazines with young readerships, prohibiting outdoor advertising of cigarettes within 1,000 feet of schools and playgrounds and limiting promotions and store displays. Tobacco manufacturers promptly filed suit, as did a coalition of advertisers and advertising agencies and the Magazine Publishers of America.
The fact that the Justices posed hypothetical questions today about so many products other than cigarettes may have reflected their assumption that they will soon have to address restrictions on cigarette advertising in the context of a real case.
In a second case today, the Court heard arguments in an employee-benefit dispute that could determine the legal obligation of employers who administer health and welfare plans to make sure employees understand any weaknesses in the plan or any limitations on their eventual right to benefits.
The case is an appeal by the Varity Corporation, a Buffalo-based manufacturer of industrial machinery. Varity, faced in 1986 with serious weaknesses in some product lines, spun those products off into a new company, the Massey Combines Corporation, and persuaded thousands of employees to transfer to the new company by telling them that its prospects were bright and their benefits would not be changed. Retired Varity employees were simply transferred into the new company's benefits plan without being told.
In fact, Massey Combines had a negative net worth when it was formed and went into receivership within two years. Current and retired workers lost their health benefits and brought a successful lawsuit under a Federal law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, usually known as Erisa.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Sells Its Companies, but Buyers Are Few

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Almost a year ago, Washington eagerly promoted a Ukrainian plan to sell 8,000 state companies and pledged tens of millions of dollars and squads of Western consultants to help accomplish the task quickly.
The transfer of the enterprises to private hands was to be the centerpiece of an ambitious billion-dollar post-cold-war aid program to bolster a financially ravaged and politically precarious Ukraine into a stable buffer between Russia and Eastern Europe. 
 Since early last year, after Ukraine finally agreed to dismantle its nuclear weapons, Washington has increased its total aid package to $900 million for 1994-95, including the privatization program. This makes Ukraine the fourth largest recipient of American foreign aid, behind Israel, Egypt and Russia.
But the showcase privatization program, which Washington expected to be a key to a market economy, has run into deep trouble.
American and Ukrainian officials say Washington pushed ahead on the plan despite grave doubts about its effectiveness, and knowing that Ukraine's powerful directors of state companies were resistant.
In the last year, nearly $67 million has been spent on privatization by the United States Agency for International Development and the companies it hired to carry out the program, A.I.D. officials here say.
But only 300 of the 8,000 companies have been sold, and fewer than half the eligible Ukrainians have bothered to pick up the free certificates that entitle them to be shareholders in privatized companies, the officials added. In a comparable time Russia, which also received substantial A.I.D. money for privatization, has accomplished much of its program.
The A.I.D. director here, Gregory F. Huger, said in September in a sharply worded letter to Prime Minister Yevhen Marchuk, "The program is now at risk of collapse."
Mr. Huger, whose letter was also signed by top officials from the European Union and the World Bank, warned that Ukraine's entire economic reform program was in jeopardy because of the slow pace of privatization.
To try to rescue the program, Mr. Huger urged the Government to take a number of quick steps, including lowering share prices. But the Government went in the opposite direction: in early October, Parliament barred privatization of half the 8,000 companies, and Mr. Marchuk presented an economic program that gave short shrift to privatization.
For most Ukrainians, privatization seems to be unfathomable, or at the very best a dubious offer.
Vesker Ihorovych, a director at the South Building Construction Company in Kiev, has been trying to interest his 1,700 employees in picking up their certificates and investing them in their company. But he is concerned, despite his campaign, that the company will remain unsold.
"Everyone asks: 'Concretely, what am I going to get out of this?' " he said. "For me to say in these hard times that if you get your share, you will get your dividends tomorrow, and then put a smile on my face -- -- it's a tough sell."
The desultory pace of privatization is clearly visible in Donetsk, the most populous province in Ukraine.
The newly opened privatization center, which is managed by Price Waterhouse, the main company hired by A.I.D., is in an unmarked out-of-the-way office building. The cramped, poorly lighted office is staffed by a young Ukrainian and a Peace Corps volunteer, one of six hired by Price Waterhouse to keep down costs on the firm's $26 million contract.
But on one recent morning, the volunteer, Richard Chitwood, did not speak enough Russian or Ukrainian to deal with his first visitor, a local plant manager. After a translator helped Mr. Chitwood, a recent graduate of business management school in Texas with no practical experience, the manager left in disgust.
"Before delivering lectures here, the American guy should learn the laws," said the manager, Igor Shinkorenko, stuffing the paper Mr. Chitwood gave him into his pocket. "It's not the U.S. Congress that delivers laws here, but the Parliament of Ukraine."
Down the street, at the State Property Fund, Vladimir Altinnik, a former Communist Party secretary who selects state companies for privatization, was equally miffed as he sat at a desk littered with the business cards of foreign consultants.
"I tell the foreigners, 'Let's define the goals, and I'll give you my opinions on how to reach this goal,' " Mr. Altinnik said, dismissing an inch-thick manual on privatizing that had been prepared by Price Waterhouse. "But they never ask for my opinions. They say, 'You must solve the task the way we say.' Why should we have American experts when there are Ukrainian experts?"
More than 60 foreign consultants who live in Kiev and scores of others who fly in and out work for the eight private companies hired by A.I.D. for the privatization effort; the agency has 30 foreign employees of its own in Kiev.
These Americans have been involved in setting up 26 regional centers like the one in Donetsk and equipping them with computers and staff members to collect information on companies as they go through the sale process. They have run a public education campaign and have started to open share registries, establish a capital system and give advice to new Ukrainian investment funds.
But the program has failed to take off largely because of in-built flaws that Washington knew about but decided not to rectify before spending the money, those involved in the program said.
"We inherited a very complicated process," said John R. Johnson, the director of Price Waterhouse in Kiev. "If it's complicated for the consultants, it's complicated for the Ukrainian public.
Among the problems Mr. Johnson listed are these:
*Unlike the certificates used in Russia, those given to Ukrainians are not transferable and do not operate like proper shares.
*The companies put up for sale at monthly auctions are overpriced.
*Managers and officials like Mr. Altinnik have been reluctant to allow companies to be sold. Only four companies in Donetsk, for example, were up for auction in October.
"U.S.A.I.D. said to themselves: 'Do we wait until the Government agrees to the ideal program, or do we proceed with the less optimal program?' " Mr. Johnson said. "They decided to go ahead with the compromises, and that is one of the big reasons for the delays."
An American official involved in the program agreed that Washington rushed. After a reformist President, Leonid Kuchma, took office last year, there was pressure in Washington to seize the opportunity and get privatization going.
"Ukraine was a high priority for us, and we wanted to get reform started," the official said. "We knew there would be problems with their program, but we thought we would go the extra effort and hope they'd come along with us."
Officials said Washington made gestures like bowing to a Ukrainian demand to have the certificates printed in Washington rather than in Ukraine, for better security, even though it was much more expensive.
Other Washington officials said A.I.D. could have been stricter in overseeing the work done by its contractors, which in addition to Price Waterhouse include Burson Marsteller ($6.6 million for public education), the Center for Financial Engineering and Development ($5.5 million for bus-company privatization) and Booz Allen & Hamilton Inc. ($3.2 million for regulation of investment funds).
Even on the simplest elements like television commercials, billboards and leaflets to educate Ukrainians about privatization, the message is often misguided.
One television advertisement shows an elderly Ukrainian woman in a rocking chair, sitting in a large empty room; she says a privatization certificate will solve her financial woes.
But several Ukrainians said they found the advertisement mystifying: rocking chairs are unknown in Ukraine, and Ukrainian rooms are usually small and crammed with furniture.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.B.I. Seeks Huge System For National Wiretapping
The F.B.I. has proposed a national wiretapping system on a huge scale that would allow law enforcement officials to monitor 1 percent of the phone lines in some high-crime areas of the country, far exceeding the recent annual average of less than 1 in 174,000 lines.
The plan, which depends on Congressional financing, would still require a court warrant for wiretaps. Both phone-industry executives and privacy-rights advocates see the specter of a Big Brother capability and ask why the F.B.I. needs such broad access. [Page A1.]
 
G.M. and Chrysler Limit Sales Drop
General Motors and Chrysler surprised analysts with smaller-than-expected declines in October sales. G.M.'s sales dropped 2.7 percent from October 1994, compared with forecasts as high as 6 percent, while Chrysler's sales fell 2.8 percent, compared with an expected 5 percent. [D4.]
 
Chrysler's production appeared threatened by a U.A.W. strike at a Detroit plant that produces most of the auto maker's windshields. [D4.]

Peco Energy Halts Bid for PP&L
Peco Energy called off its effort to buy PP&L Resources, a rival Pennsylvania utility that rejected a sweetened $4.3 billion bid. [D4.]
 
Big Gold Mine Loses Insurance
The U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation has canceled $100 million in political risk insurance for a huge Indonesian gold-mining project. [D6.]
 
Chemical Outlines Lending Plans
Chemical and Chase said they would lend $18 billion to small businesses, nonprofit organizations and low- to moderate-income homeowners in the five years after their merger. That represents a 5 percent increase from the current pace of investment. [D5.]
 
Budget Talks at an Impasse
Budget talks were conducted at the White House, but President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders said that nothing had been accomplished. The first moment of crisis -- when the Government runs out of money -- is not expected for nearly two weeks. [B10.]
 
Treasury Securities Rally
Prices of Treasury securities surged after a report showed unexpected weakness in manufacturing. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 107 25/32 , sending its yield down 4 basis points, to 6.29 percent. [D10.]
 
Stocks rose moderately, with the Dow industrials closing up 11.20, at 4,766.68. [D12.]
 
S.E.C. Negotiates With N.A.S.D.
The S.E.C. may be willing to drop its inquiry into the securities dealers' group, if it agrees to a tougher disciplinary process. [D12.]
 
Intel Upgrades the Pentium
Intel introduced an upgraded Pentium chip, with stronger performance and a lower price than expected. But the new chip is not likely to have much immediate impact, because it runs best on newer, more advanced systems. In some cases, its performance is comparable to that of work stations. [D2.]
 
Advertising Suit at Supreme Court
The court heard arguments on whether a state can ban some liquor advertising. The case could affect cigarette ads. [B14.]
 
 
Ukraine Privatization Falters
Ukraine's privatization program is in deep trouble. Washington has promoted the program as the key to a market economy. But only 300 of 8,000 state companies have been sold, and fewer than half the eligible Ukrainians have picked up the free certificates that entitle them to be shareholders in privatized companies. [A1.]
 
Mexico Spurring Savings
Mexico took steps to increase savings by overhauling its social security system. President Ernesto Zedillo said that individual retirement accounts would generate savings to help Mexico in its economic crisis. [A15.]

HEADLINE: Chase and Chemical Pledge $18 Billion in Community Loans

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that they would lend $18 billion to small businesses, nonprofit organizations and low- to moderate-income homeowners in the five years after their proposed merger.
That nationwide commitment represents about a 5 percent increase from the current pace of their combined investment in those areas. 
 It is in the banks' interest to come up with an impressive figure because their merger could be blocked if the Government found they were not meeting their obligations under the Community Reinvestment Act, which requires banks to lend in areas where they do business.
To reach $18 billion, the banks included a wide range of activities, including all their small-business lending, whether to urban grocery stores or suburban antique dealers. The largest category is loans to first-time home buyers under programs sponsored by the Federal Housing Administration, the Veterans Administration and other agencies.
A much smaller category is cash grants to nonprofit organizations, which will increase from $12 million this year to an average of $14 million in each of the next five years.
Despite the banks' plans for a 5 percent overall increase, some community activists criticized the total for being too low, though others praised the banks' long-term records. But bank executives said their announcement was meant to reassure the communities they serve that despite the job cutbacks and branch closings that would result from the merger, the new bank's commitment to community development would be undiminished.
"We tried to pick a number that is realistic, not one that would be impressive," said Mark Willis, head of Chase's community development unit. "If there is $20 billion worth of business out there, we will do it."
The bulk of the planned lending includes $13.5 billion in mortgage loans to low- and moderate-income home buyers. That amount represents a continuation of lending at current levels, not an increase.
"The mortgage market is very unpredictable," said Carol Parry, head of Chemical's community development group. "We think even saying we will maintain our effort is an aggressive commitment."
This explanation did not appease those activists who have criticized Chase for shunning low-income and minority mortgage customers outside the New York area.
"If we felt that Chemical and Chase's performances were adequate, then a commitment to stay at the level would be all right," said Matthew Lee, director of Inner City Press/Community on the Move, a Bronx group that has been in a long battle with Chase over its national mortgage lending. "But we don't think that Chase's performance has been anywhere near adequate."
While Chase has defended its record, the commitment yesterday included a promise to create mortgage counseling programs in 21 cities. The bank also said it would open a branch in the South Bronx, one of Mr. Lee's longstanding demands. That branch, however, would have cash machines and customer service officers, but no tellers.
The main change in the banks' commitment is a promise to increase their $500 million a year in small-business lending by 10 percent annually. About 30 percent of this lending will be in low-income areas.
To achieve this growth, the merged bank plans to open an office to assist small businesses in Brooklyn and will create a program to offer Government-subsidized loans to small retailers in low-income neighborhoods.
The banks promised to invest $1.2 billion in housing and economic development projects in the four states where they have branches: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Texas.

HEADLINE: Nongdao Journal;
Far From the Mad Whirl, China's Ageless Rhythm

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: NONGDAO, China

 BODY:
In parts of China, women from a certain generation do not have an identity separate from their husbands. Thus the only way to introduce the old couple living on the dirt path leading into this village in southwestern China is to say: Meet Man Han, age 77, and Man Han's wife, 70.
While millions of Chinese are frenetically trying to get rich, Mr. and Mrs. Man live in a house under a banyan tree on the remote and rural sidelines of China's economic transformation. 
 And, seemingly, they couldn't care less.
"Before about five years ago, we had never seen a car," Mr. Man frankly admitted.
"Now," Mrs. Man added cheerfully, "wherever you go you can take a bus. Before that, you had to walk."
They have raised six children, brought in more than 100 rice and wheat harvests with their neighbors over the decades, and survived the Japanese occupation and the civil war between the Communists and Nationalists that followed Japan's defeat. Now, they spend much of their days on the dirt stoop in front of their straw-mat house chatting with neighbors and whoever happens by.
"All the kids are grown up," Mr. Man said. "I don't have a lot to worry about. I guess I'm pretty contented and I'm lucky because I haven't lost any of my teeth."
Sitting on a stool, Mr. Man pulled up his pants leg to reveal an extraordinary tattoo covering most of his right thigh in a blue-black lace pattern.
"During the anti-Japanese war, we all got tattoos to show that we are of the Dai people and not Han Chinese so the Japanese would not kill us," Mr. Man said. The Han are China's dominant ethnic group, representing 95 percent of the population of 1.2 billion, while 56 minorities make up the rest.
Why people of China's Dai minority thought the tattoos would protect them from slaughter by Japanese troops is not clear, but on the strength of rumor, thousands of them endured the painful embroidery more than 50 years ago.
"I got this tattoo in 1944 because all the other people did and, besides, it looks pretty nice," Mr. Man said.
Asked her opinion, Mrs. Man seemed unwilling to countenance her husband's display of self-satisfaction.
"He thinks it's pretty nice," she said, "but when he had it done, he had to go through all kinds of pain. But he still wanted to do it." Her tone indicated that this subject had been well discussed over the years.
But Mr. Man was on to another topic.
"Japanese forces occupied this place 53 years ago after the Americans built an airplane factory over there," he said, vaguely pointing over his shoulder.
Several times, Mr. Man referred to a road that was the object of so much attention during World War II. In the Dai dialect, it came out sounding like "sze-te-er-wa" road, known in English as the Burma Road or, to the people here, the Stilwell Road, named for Joseph W. Stilwell, the American general who was doing all he could to build and protect a supply line to the Nationalist forces of Chiang Kai-shek.
"When the Americans were here, it was pretty peaceful," Mr. Man said. "For a while, we used American money. I remember because American coins were so big."
The war made a greater impression on Mr. Man than anything that has happened since, including more than 45 years of Communism. The tumultuous political campaigns of the Great Leap Forward and the Great Proletarian Revolution under Mao Zedong were not as devastating in some of China's most remote border regions, like this one.
The greatest rhythm in life here is that of the agricultural seasons, especially the harvest.
As the Mans chatted on, most of the able-bodied men and women of this Dai village were in the fields with Meng Zai, the 34-year-old village chief, who had organized the day's rice harvesting.
It is a 10-minute walk across the paddies and past a dozen water buffalo to the concrete threshing ground. There, Mr. Meng was leaning against a haystack as about 25 villagers separated rice husks from their stalks in a motorized variant of the traditional way.
First, a tractor was driven, in reverse, in fast and furious circles over the dried rice stalks. The process resembled a dangerous rodeo stunt as the tractor bounded over 5- and 6-foot piles of rice stalks, narrowly missing farmhands, women and children who pushed and pulled at the straw to insure that all of it got run over several times.
The crazy dance of the tractor caused most of the rice grains still inside the husks to separate from the stalks. The peasants then bundled and beat the stalks against the side of a wooden box, collecting as many grains as they could. The stalks were then built into stacks, which would be burned to fertilize the fields.
The rice grains were left on the concrete slab mixed with the debris of the stalks. After a few more hours of raking and hurling the debris into the air, the rice was finally separated from the chaff and the harvest was bagged for storage.
The rice was carefully separated on the threshing surface because the day's harvest belonged to two families. The other villagers came to help because that is the tradition: each family that needs help for the harvest lends a hand with another's harvest.
Mr. Meng speculated that this year's harvest would exceed 900 pounds per mu, a measure of land that equals about one-fifth of an acre. "Our best year was 1,000 pounds, so this is not bad," he said.
As he adjusted his sarong, a now familiar lace tattoo was visible on his right thigh. Mr. Meng is far too young to have marked himself in this way to avoid Japanese bayonets.
"When we saw it on the old people," he said, using the plural to refer to the men of his generation, "we thought it was very handsome, so we got it also."
Rural life, he chuckled, is not without its vanities.

The tattoo on his thigh is from World War II, and thereby hangs a story. (Photographs by Patrick E. Tyler/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks Post Modest Gains Despite Surge in Bonds and Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks picked up only moderate gains yesterday, even though bonds and the dollar rallied strongly.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 11.20 points, at 4,766.68, after trading in a narrow 26-point range all day. 
 Broader market indicators were also higher, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 2.72 points, to 584.22. Volume was moderately heavy on the New York Stock Exchange, with 378.1 million shares traded, little changed from Tuesday.
Stocks pulled back after an initial surge yesterday, and some traders attributed the market's uncertainty to the unresolved Federal budget negotiations in Washington. But Barry Berman, head stock trader at Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, said concerns about the budget talks were an "excuse to try to do as little as possible between now and year-end."
Many investors who have seen huge gains in their stock portfolios all year are likely to sit out the last two months, "as long as there isn't anything in the news to force people into action," Mr. Berman said.
Stock investors showed little lasting reaction to a substantial run-up in bond prices. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , while its yield fell to 6.29 percent from 6.33 percent. They also sloughed off a rally in the dollar that pushed it up 1.36 Japanese yen, to 103.32 yen.
The bond market surged yesterday after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity dropped to 46.8 percent in October from 48.3 percent in September.
The purchasers' report reinforced a Commerce Department report that the Government's main forecasting gauge of future economic activity fell one-tenth of a percentage point in September, its second decline in the last three months.
The slowing economy could encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates before the end of the year.
But Ricky Harrington, a technical analyst at Interstate-Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C., said the sluggish economic data might ultimately be be a negative for stocks. "There are more concerns that the slowing economy could affect earnings before long," Mr. Harrington said.
The concern about earnings was particularly noticeable in economically sensitive issues, including some technology stocks, which tend to respond sharply to changes in economic outlook. International Business Machines fell 3/8, to 96 7/8, and Micron Technology lost 2 1/2, to 68. In Nasdaq trading, Microsoft fell 1 5/8, to 98 3/8.
Bucking the downdraft in technology shares was Intel, which rose 15/16 , to 7013/16 , on heavy Nasdaq volume after the company introduced its new Pentium Pro computer chip. Also on the Nasdaq, America Online rose 6 1/4, to 86 1/4, after the company declared a 2-for-1 stock split. And Sierra Semiconductor, rose 1 1/2, to 19 3/8.
The Nasdaq composite index, which is weighted with technology stocks, gained 4.44 points, to 1,040.50.
Transportation stocks, which are viewed as vulnerable to swings in the economy, fell. The Dow Jones transportation index dropped 11.24 points, or 0.58 percent, to 1,924.88. Shares of Norfolk Southern fell 1 3/4, to 74 7/8.
Financial services stocks and utility stocks, which u8, to 67 1/4.
The Dow Jones utility average rose 1.85 points, or 0.86 percent, to 216.39, led by Peco Energy, up 5/8, to 29 7/8. PP&L Resources Inc. rejected a sweetened $4 billion buyout offer from Peco, prompting the neighboring utility to drop its takeover attempt. PP&L's shares eased 1/8, to 22 3/8.
Among other issues, Federated Department Stores rose 1 1/8, to 26 1/2. The stock is being added to the S.& P. 500 index.
Humana rose 1 5/8, to 22 3/4, after the health care company reported favorable third-quarter results.
Boeing rose 2 1/2, to 68, after it received an $800 million order from Japan Airlines.
Chiron fell 6, to 85, after the biotechnology company reported disappointing earnings late Tuesday.
Advancing issues led declining ones by about 7 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange. The Big Board's composite index was up 1.41, to 311.02, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index was up 0.97, to 522.64.

HEADLINE: Peco Drops $4.3 Billion Bid For PP&L Resources Utility

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Peco Energy Company yesterday abandoned an effort to buy PP&L Resources Inc. after it rejected a sweetened $4.3 billion bid from Peco, its Pennsylvania rival.
PP&L, based in Allentown, Pa., said it spurned one of the utility industry's largest hostile offers because the combined company would have increased its exposure to nuclear-plant liabilities that might not be covered by future revenue. PP&L also said that a deal with Peco, based in Philadelphia, would give its shareholders a dividend payout that was 4 percent lower and would increase rates for PP&L customers. 
 "The board has concluded that Peco's revised proposal is not in the best interests of PP&L Resources and its shareowners, customers, employees or the communities it serves," PP&L said in a statement.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, shares of PP&L fell 12.5 cents, to $22.375, while Peco shares rose 62.5 cents, to $29.875.
"This wasn't exactly a surprise," said Bert Kramer, an analyst with Paine Webber.
On Oct. 23, Peco raised its bid to $27.50 a share after its original $24-a-share proposal was turned down. While Peco's August offer was a 28 percent premium on PP&L's share price of $18.75 at that time, PP&L has since won a 4.5 percent rate increase from the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission that made its stock more valuable, Mr. Kramer said.
Peco's buyout offer is one of a flurry of mergers in the utility industry this year. The deal-making has been spurred by a drive to cut costs as utilities brace for deregulated markets and increasing competition.
PP&L said yesterday that it was taking steps to prepare for competition, including job cuts and reduction in capital expenditures, and that combining with Peco would have made it less competitive.
"Before the rate case came in, there was an economic reason for PP&L merging," Mr. Kramer said. "There's still an economic reason for everyone to merge, to lower costs, but the compelling reason for PP&L is gone."
Shareholders may not be happy with PP&L's decision. Analysts said a higher bid from another utility was unlikely.
"The chairman of PP&L will have to justify to shareholders why he turned down $27.50 a share for a stock that was at $18 before the offer came," said Thomas Hamlin, a utilities analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond. "It's a tough spot to be in."
