HEADLINE: Economy Is Slowing, but Fed Isn't Expected to Cut Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The American economy has slowed this autumn, several new reports showed today, but Federal Reserve officials said in interviews that the signs so far did not appear likely to lead them to lower short-term interest rates at their next meeting on Nov. 15.
After expanding at an ebullient annual pace of 4.2 percent in the third quarter, the economy lost momentum in recent weeks, the new reports showed. 
 Together, they portrayed a fairly consistent picture of a gradually slowing economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of growth in manufacturing had dropped for the third consecutive month. The Commerce Department said that its index of leading economic indicators dropped by one-tenth of a percentage point in September. And in a review of the economy's health that comes out only eight times a year, the Federal Reserve said that a pause in retail sales appeared to be braking growth.
The bond market rallied on the reports, with prices rising and the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 6.29 percent from 6.33 percent. Stocks were also up, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 11.20 points, to 4,766.68.
But the Federal Reserve may wait for progress in the budget debate and further evidence of economic slowing before reducing the short-term interest rates again, senior Fed officials have suggested in interviews today and over the last week.
The gradual slowing of inflation "gives us room to ease in the future," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve Board governor. "I think as long as the inflation picture continues to be favorable and as we resolve uncertainties about the fiscal position -- assuming they are resolved in a favorable way -- ease might be appropriate."
If Fed officials do not reduce interest rates on Nov. 15, their next meeting is scheduled for Dec. 19 and they might cut rates then.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has long been known to distrust a single month of evidence that the economy is slowing after a quarter of strong economic performance. And in a series of little-noticed hints in his Congressional testimony earlier this year, he expressed a desire to wait for financial market reaction to any budget deal before deciding whether to reduce interest rates. Congress is still at least two weeks away from sending President Clinton a bill, and since all sides expect him to veto the bill when he gets it, negotiations could drag on to the end of the year.
A sharp drop in interest rates in the financial markets right after a budget deal would indicate that most investors accepted the accord as a credible sign of Congressional determination to reduce deficit spending. That would provide political cover for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further without risking criticism that it was rewarding a Republican pledge that might not be fulfilled to balance the budget over seven years.
Still, several economic indicators due out in the next couple of weeks could alter Federal Reserve officials' impressions of the economy and persuade them that a quick cut in interest rates was appropriate. The most important indicator is likely to be the Labor Department's release on Friday of unemployment patterns during November. And a slew of data will be coming out on the morning that the Fed officials meet, including the November figures for consumer prices, industrial production and business inventories.
But today's economic reports were mostly subdued in tone. "Reports from the 12 Federal Reserve districts suggest that moderate growth in economic activity continued in early fall, although perhaps at a slower pace than at the time of the previous set of reports," said the Federal Reserve report, known as the beige book for the color of its cover.
Prices for paper and other industrial materials showed the largest drop in 15 years, a sign of weak demand for raw materials in the nation's manufacturing sector. The falling prices dragged down the index of leading economic indicators, which most economists had expected to show a slight rise.
The exception to the string of soft numbers today was the Commerce Department's report on construction spending in September, which rose by 1.2 percent, or slightly more than expected. Home builders and construction companies with Government contracts are doing particularly well.
But manufacturers and retailers appear to be in worse shape. Auto sales are weak, shipping costs are declining for lack of demand, and many store chains are beginning to struggle.
"There's a definite loss of thrust and momentum entering the fourth quarter -- it's showing up in retail sales, auto sales, and I think it's showing up in capital goods spending," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "What's unknown is how consumers will behave at Christmas."
The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates seven times during a 12-month period beginning in February 1994 for fear that very strong economic growth would lead to inflation. When growth slowed briefly early last summer, the Fed's top officials trimmed the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Battle Ahead: Can Mexico's Social Security Net Be Tightened?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo today announced a sweeping overhaul of Mexico's 52-year-old social security system with the goal of improving medical services and increasing the sagging rate of domestic savings.
Mr. Zedillo said the social security system was inefficient and the health system in danger of financial collapse. He also said that allowing Mexicans to establish individual retirement accounts, a central feature of both the social security plan and the economic recovery program announced on Sunday, would generate millions of dollars in domestic savings to help the country in its current economic crisis. 
 Pension savings could be used to encourage investment and replace some of the $29 billion in short-term foreign capital that has left Mexico since last year's disastrous devaluation. The domestic savings rate has fallen below 16 percent of the gross domestic product, from a high of 22 percent in 1988.
"More domestic savings will mean more investment and more growth," Mr. Zedillo said. "That economic growth will mean more jobs, and more jobs will mean more security for society."
But Mr. Zedillo is likely to face a difficult political battle in trying to take apart something as sacred as social security. Unlike Social Security in the United States, the Mexican system does a lot more than provide retirement benefits. The huge system also runs nearly all of Mexico's clinics and hospitals, and 455 day-care centers.
Over the years, the system has also taken over management of 149 discount stores, 38 theaters, 4 recreation resorts and 16 funeral parlors.
Although business and labor leaders support the reforms, social security workers have already launched an aggressive campaign to keep the system from being dismantled. The workers argue that giving private managers a chance to handle the national pension fund, which they say is worth about $4.25 billion, is an invitation to corruption.
"We believe with all certainty," the workers said in advertisements in Mexico City newspapers, "that if Congress authorizes these initiatives, inefficiency and ineptitude will be rewarded, and that will have negative repercussions for most Mexicans."
Under the plan, which Mr. Zedillo plans to send to Congress in the current session, workers would be allowed to choose between the existing pension system and individual retirement accounts. The accounts would offer a higher rate of return than the current system, and thus encourage workers to save more.
The entire social security system would be broadened to expand medical coverage and lower costs. Today about 39 million Mexicans with salaried jobs have coverage. Most of the other 53 million Mexicans -- most of them self-employed -- are not covered.
Social security contributions now come from employers, workers and the Government, and are considered high in comparison with other countries. The reforms would try to end the practice of subsidizing money-losing parts parts of the system, like the day-care centers and the theaters.
To improve the medical care, which is widely criticized as insensitive and inadequate, patients would be allowed to select their own doctors at health maintenance groups.
The number of social security employees would be reduced, an implicit suggestion that operations like the discount stores or resorts would have to be able to stand on their own or be dropped.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Sluggishness At Factories Lifts Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday after a report showed unexpected weakness in manufacturing.
But the rally lost some of its steam late in the session as traders locked in profits with an eye toward tomorrow's report on employment in October. Still, yesterday's data bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would reduce short-term interest rates again, although few analysts expect the Fed to do so at its Nov. 15 policy-making meeting. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , to 10725/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, fell to 6.29 percent, just above the 6.27 percent low for the session and below Tuesday's close of 6.33 percent.
The prices of Treasury securities rallied after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing strength had fallen to 46.8 points in October from 48.3 in September. Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, a market research and analysis concern, said the report showed that "the manufacturing sector is still mired in mud and not moving very quickly."
"Weak exports and a flat auto sector are holding it back," he said.
The market's positive reaction to the weak news sparked some short- covering activity, in which market participants who sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices and pocket the difference, are forced to buy back securities in a rising market to limit their losses.
Other data released yesterday portrayed an economy slowing steadily from its strong growth in the third quarter. The Federal Reserve's survey of business conditions around the country showed only modest growth. The Commerce Department said that its index of leading economic indicators dropped by one-tenth of a percentage point in September, a slightly weaker result than expected.
Although construction spending rose strongly in September, by 1.2 percent, Mr. Palash of MCM Moneywatch noted that housing was continuing to benefit from low interest rates.
"In balance, the mixed numbers represent a favorable background for bonds," Mr. Palash said, "in that growth is moderate enough to keep inflation down and keep open the door for a Fed easing at some point." The timing of the Fed move, he said, will depend on the negotiations in Washington on the Federal budget. "At this point, my best guess is that the Fed will ease in the first quarter of next year," he said.
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said the signs of moderate growth "have led many to expect a Fed ease sometime down the road, with the bond market already pricing it in."
The bond market had little reaction to the Treasury's announcement yesterday of tentative plans for its quarterly refunding. The Treasury plans to sell $18 billion in three-year notes on Tuesday and $13.5 billion, up from an expected $13 billion, in 10-year notes on Wednesday.
But the Treasury also said the sales would go ahead only if Congress raised the national debt limit from the current $4.9 trillion.
The possibility of canceled auctions did not appear to alarm traders and investors yesterday.
But the uncertainty prevented the start of activity in securities traded on a when-issued basis. By late in the day the cash market's current three-year note was trading at a price of 100 25/32 , to yield 5.56 percent, and the 10-year note was trading at 10328/32 , to yield 5.97 percent.
Today, the Treasury plans to sell $6 billion in 48-day cash management bills and $8 billion in 83-day cash management bills. Mr. Palash said these auctions were designed to get the Treasury past temporary cash shortages.
In futures trading yesterday, the December bond contract set another high, 11731/32 , with the low at 11621/32 . It closed the session at 11716/32.

HEADLINE: Sterling Forest Pledges to Maintain Open Space

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 23 editorial on a potential acquisition of Sterling Forest in New York State leaves the reader confused about Sterling Forest Corporation's commitment to maintaining open space in the forest and willingness to sell the property to the public. We have been willing to sell all or part of the forest to the public at a fair market price as long as negotiations are fair and timely. 
 However, no willing buyer with committed financing has presented an offer to purchase the property, and, as you reveal, the prospects for government funding of an acquisition grow uncertain.
Consequently, we must continue the process for gaining the necessary approvals for our plan. Even if the public does not acquire any of the property, we are committed to maintaining open space in the forest at no cost to taxpayers.
For the past six years we have pursued a balanced, environmentally sensitive plan for our land. We have worked with top planning experts to insure that our plan's environmental and economic features balance open space preservation with the growth facing our region.
As a result, the plan permanently sets aside 76 percent of the forest for protection as open space at no cost to taxpayers. We remain committed to preservation of open space and welcome public or private support to reach that goal.
 
LOUIS HEIMBACH
Chairman, Sterling Forest Corp.
Tuxedo, N.Y., Oct. 27, 1995

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Athletics And Tigers Courting Showalter

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
While Yankee executives met in Tampa, Fla., yesterday to discuss who their next manager should be, Buck Showalter, their former manager, started his life without the Yankees feeling very wanted. Showalter was immediately courted by the Detroit Tigers and the Oakland Athletics about their manager positions and will interview with both teams on the West Coast this weekend.
Even though Showalter is looking forward to the interviews, a part of him still wondered about his negotiations with George Steinbrenner and why he is no longer the Yankee manager. Except for the 22 days he spent unemployed after being dismissed as the third-base coach before becoming the manager on Oct. 29, 1991, yesterday marked the first day Showalter was not a Yankee since 1977. 
 "I would have listened to him if George had called me last night," said Showalter, regret in his voice. "It's a little bit disappointing. I called him last and I rejected the offer as it was stated to me. Maybe we could have gotten something done."
Joe Torre is expected to replace Showalter sometime soon; General Manager Bob Watson told officials he wanted to select a manager by tomorrow. Watson met with Steinbrenner and Gene Michael, the former general manager, for several hours about Showalter's successor and said they trimmed "a short list even shorter." Even though Watson claimed there are three or four candidates and said interviews will be conducted today, Torre is still believed to be the front-runner.
"We want to get the right guy," said Watson, who refused to divulge the names of any candidates, even Torre. "That's so important to us. We had a negative situation with the last manager who was here. We want to move on and think about winning."
Meanwhile, Showalter bit his tongue whenever he was asked about the ugliness that has enveloped his departure from the Yankees after four seasons. Steinbrenner and Showalter have refused to call each other since last Thursday, when the manager turned down a two-year, $1.05 million contract offer that included the provision that the batting coach, Rick Down, be dismissed. Several of Steinbrenner's employees have criticized Down, one of Showalter's closest friends, and the manager ever since.
"I'm just disappointed in it all," said Showalter, who has insisted that he never resigned, contrary to Steinbrenner's opinion. "I'm disappointed in so many things that happened. Just disappointed. Just write disappointed. I'm trying not to say anything else."
Asked if he thought that his disagreement with Steinbrenner could cease long enough for him to miraculously return as manager, Showalter said, "I doubt it."
Detroit General Manager Randy Smith said he will interview the Cleveland infield coach Buddy Bell today and the Texas third-base coach Jerry Narron on Saturday, so he is likely to interview Showalter tomorrow. Smith, the former Padres general manager, has a home in San Diego, and Showalter already planned to venture to Oakland to be interviewed Saturday.
Oakland General Manager Sandy Alderson said Showalter is one of many candidates for the spot vacated when Tony La Russa left for St. Louis. Alderson interviewed Gary Jones and Dick Scott, Oakland's Class AAA and AA managers, yesterday and will interview Jim Lefebvre, the A's hitting instructor and the former manager of the Cubs and Mariners, and Davey Lopes, San Diego's first-base coach, today.
"I think Buck's record and his credibility and his reputation stand for themselves," Smith said. "We've got several guys who are candidates, but the one thing that Buck has over them is he's got a track record at the major league level."
Showalter is more interested in the Tigers because they have a new general manager, will eventually have a new stadium and have emphasized that they will overhaul their team with the hopes of contending by 1998. The A's are in the middle of severe budget cuts and are not as appealing.
"I feel like someone is interested in something I have to offer and that's pretty flattering," Showalter said.
Smith hoped to name Sparky Anderson's successor within the next month, but he could make a decision sooner. While Showalter has been called the leading candidate, Smith declined to rank the candidates.
"I think he knows he's in demand," Smith said of Showalter. "I don't think we were even the first team to contact him. I think he knows he has options and he has more than two."
Since Smith said Showalter has more than two opportunities and the 39-year-old is only interested in managing, there could be a third team prepared to erase a manager and pounce on the available Showalter. Showalter distanced himself from this ticklish theory. He looked to the future without forgetting the past.
"I don't think anything is going to taint the times I had with the Yankees and the things that I hold dear," Showalter said. "If I end up with another organization, I'll always feel good about being a Yankee."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Yankees received a one-day extension on DARRYL STRAWBERRY's $1.8 million contract option so they must make a decision by today. . . . Pitcher SCOTT KAMIENIECKI had surgery to remove bone spurs from his right elbow and second baseman PAT KELLY had shoulder surgery to repair a torn labrum. The injuries will surely impact how the Yankees feel about the players for 1996. Both were operated on by Dr. FRANK JOBE in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: G.M. and Chrysler's October Sales Better Than Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation surprised analysts today with smaller-than-expected declines in October sales.
At General Motors, total sales fell 2.7 percent from October last year, while Chrysler's sales fell 2.8 percent. Analysts had anticipated a drop of 5 percent for Chrysler, while some analysts saw G.M. sales dropping as much as 6 percent. 
 "They were a little better than expected," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company, who on Tuesday cut his fourth-quarter earnings estimate for Chrysler on concerns that its car sales would be off by 15 percent.
Chrysler's car sales were down 10 percent, to 52,222. Its truck sales, led by brisk movement of its popular Dodge Ram trucks and mini-vans, were up 2 percent, to 113,487 vehicles.
Strong car sales, however, were evident at G.M. Sales rose 6.6 percent for the month to 272,830 cars, partly offsetting a sharp drop in truck sales.
"We don't expect any grandiose numbers, just decent numbers, and that's what we're getting," said Michael Schmall, director of auto supplier forecasting for J. D. Power & Associates, a consulting firm in Troy, Mich.
October sales are closely watched because it typically is the strongest month in the fourth quarter. An overall decline was expected, as cautious consumers worried about job security and the direction of the economy.
Analysts are projecting an annualized industry selling rate of about 15.1 million vehicles this month, compared with last October's strong rate of 15.3 million.
G.M. released its results after the stock market closed, and Chrysler released its sales just before. Shares of all three American auto makers fell on the New York Stock Exchange today. G.M. shares fell 37.5 cents, to $43.375, and Chrysler's stock fell 75 cents, to $50.75. Shares of the Ford Motor Company fell 25 cents, to $28.50.
Ford is expected to report its October sales on Friday.
G.M.'s October truck sales dropped 16 percent, to 147,578 vehicles, much lower than expected. The company recorded its sharpest decline in truck sales in at least five years, the company said, because shipments to dealers were hobbled by a strike against a unit of Ryder, the principal vehicle hauler for General Motors.
Though the strike ended Oct. 7, shipments of cars and trucks are still backlogged. For instance, about 20,000 Blazers are stacked up at G.M.'s plant in Moraine, Ohio.
"I dispatched a couple of drivers to go down there this morning" and get some Blazers, said Mark Worthington, sales manager of Jack Cauley Chevrolet in West Bloomfield, Mich.
"My customers are getting anxious and I was afraid I'd lose them. My drivers tell me there were tons of people down there picking up vehicles."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Yen As Maturing Debt Leaves Japan

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a six-week high against the yen yesterday, bolstered by optimism that Japanese investors had sold domestic investments and sent money overseas.
About $4 billion of Japanese debt matured at the end of October, and some analysts estimated that as much as 10 percent of those funds were being reinvested in higher-yielding Australian, German, Swiss and United States bond markets. 
 "A lot of domestic instruments matured," said Marc Chandler, currency analyst at Deutsche Bank. "Some of those funds are believed to be finding higher yields abroad."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 103.32 yen -- its highest since Sept. 20, when it touched 104.65 yen -- from 101.96 yen on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 1.4177 German marks from 1.4070 marks and to 1.1355 Swiss francs from 1.1353 francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5783 from $1.5810.
Weaker European currencies, benefiting from thinner trading than ususual, regained some ground against the mark yesterday, leading to a more optimistic climate for the dollar. Trading was light because of holidays in France, Belgium, Italy, Hong Kong and other countries.
The Quebec referendum, in which a razor-thin majority of voters chose to remain within Canada, was a positive factor for the dollar after the resignation of Premier Jacques Parizeau of Quebec, a leader of the separatist Parti Quebecois.
"Europe and North America are no longer in quite such turmoil," said Kevin Harris, international economist at MCM Currency Watch. "Whatever gyrations Canada has to go through to get over the referendum, the worst is over."
Currency traders also bet that the battle to balance the United States budget would eventually be resolved, and any prospective debt default averted.
"The underlying feeling" is that it "will be resolved," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney. "Both sides are fighting for pretty good changes."
The dollar's upward momentum managed to overcome renewed pressure on the Mexican peso, which fell below 7.35 to the dollar before recovering to 7.265 to the dollar.
Weakness in the Mexican peso typically hurts the dollar because of the close economic ties between the two countries. The speculative selling of the peso came a day before a national holiday in Mexico, when financial markets will be closed.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
German Socialists Question The Single-Money Canon

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Can Europe's nations fuse so intimately that they become a kind of United States? No, say Europeans like Chancellor Helmut Kohl, especially if they cling to their currencies -- as if Texans used dollars and New Yorkers used rubles.
Thus, the notion of creating a common European currency to supersede the national coin and forge monetary union has become something close to dogma in Germany,and the Chancellor preaches it with the same sense of infallibility as theologians ascribe to the Pope. 
 Imagine, thus, the fuss when leading members of the opposition Social Democratic Party said the other day that monetary union might be no more than "some idea or other" that should become a major issue in Germany's next national elections in 1998.
"Cheap populism," countered Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of the Free Democratic Party, the junior coalition partner in Mr. Kohl's Government.
"Playing with fire," said an editorial in the daily Suddeutsche Zeitung on Tuesday.
Beyond such debate language, though, lay one of the puzzles of Europe's integration: if Germany's will to create a single currency is weakened by domestic pressures, who else will raise the banner of monetary union? And, if the drive to integration stalls, will Europe revert to a splintered and troubled past?
In economic terms, the introduction of a single European currency would represent a revolution in the way Europeans transact business.
Without monetary union, Suddeutsche Zeitung said darkly, "Europe will go backward and Germany will again become a problem for its neighbors."
The preparations for a common currency are supposed to be completed by 1999 with the creation of common standards of fiscal management throughout the European Union. At present, only Germany and Luxembourg meet those standards.
Last weekend, however, Rudolf Scharping, the beleaguered leader of the ailing Social Democrats, voiced what opinion surveys say is the majority view among Germans. "I would regard it as wrong," he said, "to give up the German mark in return for some idea or other that in the end produces neither economic nor monetary stability."
Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democratic state premier of Lower Saxony, forecast a "huge controversy" at the 1998 elections and declared that at last the Social Democrats had discovered "a national theme" on which to campaign.
The Social Democrats' bid to rewrite the national agenda obviously annoys Chancellor Kohl and his allies.
"No one can play political games with an issue like the European currency that is vital to the nation's future," said Friedrich Bohl, a senior aide to the Chancellor. Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister, accused the Social Democrats of misusing the issue to "divert attention from their own squabbles."
If that was the plan, though, it has backfired. Even in Mr. Scharping's ranks, his latest utterances drew criticism.
"Neither the timetable nor the criteria for entering the European monetary union may now be brought into doubt," said Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, Mr. Scharping's own deputy leader.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Welfare time limits raise the specter of more street dwellers.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
NEWT GINGRICH and Bill Clinton agree: the time for time limits on welfare has come. But what happens when the welfare checks stop? "Not a lot of people have thought about it," says LaDonna Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute.
They will soon have to. A dozen states have already received Federal waivers to set time limits. The others will probably not even have to ask: both the House and Senate welfare bills would drop any requirement to provide monthly stipends. But researchers who watched the states cope in haphazard fashion with rising caseloads in the early 1990's are not sanguine about the consequences. 
 At best, they say, time limits on cash benefits will force the dependent poor and the bureaucrats who serve them to focus on finding work for the able-bodied. Those who cannot find work on their own will be shunted into public service jobs that teach the value of work and help to break the cycle of dependence.
But it is also possible that welfare will become meaner as well as leaner. Tens of thousands now live on the streets. Perhaps Americans will learn to turn their backs on tens of thousands more.
The idea of time limits was part of what Judy Gueron, president of the nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, calls "the liberal-conservative consensus" that dominated thinking about welfare for much of the last decade. From this perspective, public assistance was a right -- but only as long as those who needed it did their best to get off it.
Society would never abandon the irredeemably dependent. But the notion of a fixed limit on cash grants meshed with the new emphasis on "workfare." Some, it was assumed, would find jobs before the time limit. The rest would earn their welfare checks raking leaves, helping in child-care centers or cleaning storm drains.
The catch, well known to policy specialists if not to taxpayers, is that workfare is very expensive unless a high percentage of chronic welfare recipients find jobs. For even if public service jobs pay little, the cost of providing day care and administering the programs would far exceed the cost of welfare as usual. Indeed, it was fear of the price tag that stood in the way of welfare reform on the workfare model during the Bush and early Clinton years.
But the liberal-conservative consensus is gone, victim to the priorities of the new Republican majority in Congress. If the Republicans have their way, there will be no new money for public service jobs. Indeed, there will be $100 billion less for welfare over the next seven years. What's more, states will be free to spend fixed block grants any way they please.
How they please will almost certainly include time limits: 24 states have already applied for waivers to set limits. And while a few are committed to workfare, the link between time limits and jobs of last resort is fraying and will likely be severed once state legislatures understand that Federal aid is no longer linked to the ambitions of state welfare programs.
Everyone expects deadlines to create "a sense of urgency" among welfare recipients, says David Butler, a policy analyst at the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation and the co-author of the organization's first study of time-limited welfare. But just how far will a kick in the pants move the welfare system?
The typical user of welfare is off the dole within two years. But the majority of those on welfare at any one time are there to stay: Ms. Pavetti estimates that three-quarters of four million to five million adults currently on welfare will remain dependent for at least five years. And she is skeptical that a large proportion of them can soon be bullied or cajoled into private-sector jobs.
Even if they could, it is far from clear that the bitterly competitive market for unskilled labor would make room for them. Sheila and Sheldon Danziger of the University of Michigan found that just one-third of the nonelderly adults without children forced off Michigan's "general assistance" welfare roles in 1992 snagged full-time jobs within two years. And those were years of falling unemployment. "All bets are off for recessions," Mr. Danziger concludes.
So what happens to the losers? Those who subscribe to the old workfare consensus hope that the prospect of poor families living on the streets will force Americans to face up to the reality that reducing dependence is a time-consuming and expensive business.
But Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution is skeptical it will come to that. More likely, extreme poverty will be driven underground, as families stripped of welfare grants get by on a combination of temporary work, food stamps, Medicaid, charity and help from relatives.
"We shouldn't kid ourselves that time limits will make most recipients' lives better," he said.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Jim Lehrer Carries On In the Post-MacNeil Era

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The deliverers of television news occupy a significant place in many a family's routine. The main network news programs signal the end of the workday and lead into tube time; whether it be Peter or Tom or Dan, millions have grown accustomed to their space. And that must be even more emphatically the feeling of the fewer but no less loyal viewers who have come to dote on "The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour."
Whatever your comfort level with the network anchors, after all, they supply pretty much the same goods. If one of them decided to go on to more challenging work, fans might miss their favorite for a while, but they could switch channels and be assured of finding a reasonable facsimile. Robert MacNeil, by contrast, has come to represent something special for television, so his recent departure from the distinctive and distinguished program that was marked by his style as well as his name may give his fans the shakes. 
 A look at life after MacNeil, then, is in order. With the caution that "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" is still young, still settling into a post-MacNeil mode, here is how matters appear so far.
The most conspicuous loss, it seems to me, is an authoritative voice. Mr. Lehrer's down-home address remains easy to take, easier perhaps than Mr. MacNeil's stiffer, more buttoned-up style (maybe that is why the two played off each other so well) but the MacNeil persona carried decidedly more weight. Even when he was away for a day or two, the center did not hold quite as firmly.
Still, I don't want to make too much of that. The program's considerable strengths, developed over the years, reside less in its estimable on-screen presences than in its serious attitude toward the news and the time it accords to major doings. Last week, for a not untypical example, on an evening when the three network news programs led off with a story about a school-bus accident, "The Newshour" gave more minutes to a report and a discussion about the budget battle in Congress than the networks gave to all the day's events put together. On Monday, Charlayne Hunter-Gault, the MacNeil-Lehrer veteran, did a useful 15-minute interview with Richard Holbrooke, the American negotiator on Bosnia.
The general rule of civility in interviews, particularly welcome given the commotion that substitutes for discussion on shows like "the McLaughlin Group," also seems to be safe. In one of "The Newshour" 's series of talks with Presidential hopefuls last week, Margaret Warner, businesslike but not adversarial, pressed Pat Buchanan about his notions of "economic nationalism" and allowed him to reveal himself as an old-fashioned isolationist.
The problem with civility is that it can easily edge into hospitality, which is what happened that same evening in Elizabeth Farnsworth's encounter with Yasir Arafat. It was a sort of tea party, with Ms. Farnsworth courteously allowing herself to be led by her guest and even helping him to a few answers. She seemed too genteel to handle this practiced performer and was notably more comfortable on Monday in the pleasanter job of encouraging Doris Kearns Goodwin to rhapsodize about baseball.
"The Newshour" has often been chided for concentrating on Beltway biggies. That is no crime. Particularly when Washington is being moved and shaken as it is these days, you want to hear from the movers and shakers. And they usually have more pertinent things to say than the just-folks around the country whom the producers, perhaps hoping to shed their elitist reputation, have taken to assembling periodically as the Voice of the People.
But the habit of bringing on the pols can turn silly, as it did on Friday, when Thomas Foley, Democrat and former Speaker of the House, and Robert Michel, the former Republican minority leader, as unstimulating a pair as Washington could yield, were hauled in to talk about Congressional tactics. It was a desperate tactic for producers seeking a fresh approach to an aging story, a parody of a "Newshour" interview.
That sort of mishap occurred on Mr. MacNeil's watch too. It also occurs with fair frequency on the Sunday morning network interview programs; Washington veterans being even more skilled at evading than Washington journalists are at inquiring, time wasting is probably inherent in the form.
What redeems "The Newshour" from the occasional longueur is the guarantee of its steady attention on what matters, be it the budget or race, Bosnia or the Middle East. If the program is not noted for scoops, that may be because of its concentration on substance, giving healthy chunks of time even to unglamorous subjects like the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. When it gets the story in focus, as it usually does, it has little competition.
With Mr. MacNeil's departure, "The Newshour" has also lost its New York City connection. Not that the program has ever shown any particular devotion to New York, but at moments the city's spirit, so unlike that of Washington, where the program is now being produced, did manage to make itself felt. Maybe one of the essayists, say, Roger Rosenblatt, that confessed New Yorker, can sneak some big-city smarts into the show.
So I think Mr. MacNeil is already missed, probably by Mr. Lehrer more than anyone, and he does not seem readily replaceable. But let's not overdo the television cult of personality. The real tribute to the departed will be if the program he did much to craft stays true to its mission and, with the support of viewers like you and me, goes on being an important part of the television day.

HEADLINE: In Bridgeport, Not Only Bettors Eye Hounds With Hope

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Years of intense, expensive lobbying to expand gambling here and to create jobs in this ailing industrial city yielded their first results tonight as dogs began running at a greyhound race track, the Shoreline Star.
Overshadowed by the battle to bring a $500 million casino with 9,000 jobs to Bridgeport's harbor, just blocks away, the $30 million dog track, employing 600 people, nevertheless is the largest development to be built in the city in years. 
 While animal-rights demonstrators outside the track protested the racing industry's treatment of greyhounds tonight, inside the track, below an elevated section of the Connecticut Turnpike, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim praised the track and its owner, A. Robert Zeff, for bringing new jobs and revenue to the city.
"This is the largest investment in this city in decades," Mr. Ganim said. "This is a first-class, A-1 dog track here in Bridgeport, open today, but it's also jobs and the beginning of revitalization for the city."
The arrival of hounds in the heart of Bridgeport's manufacturing district, one small step in the city's pursuit of gambling as the only industry interested in redeveloping its waterfront, illustrates the opportunities and hazards for communities as gambling spreads rapidly.
Elsewhere in the nation, including in eastern Connecticut, the opening of casinos with slot machines has pushed dog tracks and other slower-paced forms of betting to the brink of bankruptcy.
Some of the kennels racing greyhounds here, in fact, came from Kansas City, Kan., where a seven-year-old dog and horse track, the Woodlands, is failing because of competition from riverboat casinos in Missouri. The track's owners are lobbying Kansas legislators to allow slot machines in race tracks.
In Bridgeport, a casino would open just across the turnpike from the dog track if Connecticut legislators authorize the Mashantucket Pequot tribe to build here. And no one knows whether that would help or harm the track.
The track's general manager, James S. Gartland, who also came to Bridgeport from Kansas City, shrugs when asked about the effect of a casino.
"When I hired on, I told Mr. Zeff that regardless of a casino, there was enough population for a track to do all right," Mr. Gartland said. But, he added, "You can't compete against what I call the mindless gaming of pulling a slot-machine handle."
Mr. Zeff, who made his fortune as a trial lawyer in Detroit before opening a jai alai fronton on Kossuth Street here in 1976, has done his best to offer customers constant action. The fronton, which operated only six months a year, has been converted into an off-track betting parlor televising dog and horse races from around the country.
Across the parking lot, the track's clubhouse, with a capacity of 2,900, has 230 television sets for bettors to watch between the greyhound races, which are run every 15 minutes but are over in less than 35 seconds.
Mr. Zeff has also hedged his investment in other ways.
Original plans, projected to cost $76 million, were scaled back, creating a smaller clubhouse that should be easier to fill, especially since there is not another dog track between Bridgeport and West Virginia.
When Donald Trump proposed a casino in Bridgeport and began looking for a site, he discovered that the obvious one, the former Carpenter Steel factory yard on the harbor, was already taken, by Mr. Zeff. The site is now being used for parking for the track, although he had bought it for a casino to be built by Mirage Resorts.
When Steve Wynn of Mirage proposed a casino earlier, he learned that Mr. Zeff would be the most powerful opponent in Bridgeport to any plan that might harm his track, so he made him a partner.
Now Mr. Zeff is hoping to win permission to put slot machines in his clubhouse, over the objections of the Pequots.
In Bridgeport, the dog track is being praised by many residents after years in which the fronton was often criticized for not bringing prosperity to the East Side, one of the city's poorest neighborhoods.
From the clubhouse, the vista beyond the track is still one of deteriorated tenements, vacant warehouses and empty lots. But along the track's property, city streets have been widened and repaved and trees have been planted.
For the blocks beyond, the track helped start a neighborhood development corporation that received a $5 million Federal loan for street improvements, housing rehabilitation and store renovations. The loan will be repaid from the 1 percent of the track's daily betting receipts that it gives the city, in addition to an estimated $1.5 million a year in taxes.
"If they are successful, we will be successful, or at least the neighborhood won't die," said Luis Hernandez, the owner of a furniture store on nearby East Main Street, who is part of the development corporation.
Although the East Side's main business area is farther north, the loan will be spent to fix up only the southern end of East Main Street, where turnpike ramps lead to the track. But the entire community should benefit, Mr. Hernandez said.
"If you come in and see a lot of debris and a lot of ugly things around, you won't want to come back, even to the dog track," he said. "Let's not forget, the track is employing 600 people, and they will buy in our neighborhood. So we're not protecting the track, we're protecting our own jobs."
The track is also being welcomed by its new employees, who have year-round, full-time union jobs; the fronton had a full-time staff of only 20 and 260 part-timers. At a recent job fair, 2,500 people applied for the 350 jobs that were not taken by former fronton workers.
"I think I'm going to love it," Evelyn Felix, a former fronton bartender, said this week as her son, newly hired as a waiter, showed her how to operate a computerized cash register in the clubhouse. "This is the only thing I have to get down right now."

HEADLINE: Clinton Analyzes His Term, And Finds Himself Wanting

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
In his first two years in the White House, Bill Clinton behaved "like a prime minister, not a President," was not "pleased with" the welfare overhaul plan he proposed and "lost the language" of the moderate new Democratic thinking that helped to elect him in 1992.
Who made that trenchant analysis? 
 Bill Clinton himself, in the latest of a series of public explanations and apologies that run counter to the White House's official message of resolute determination. Once again, he left his aides scrambling to absorb and account for his words.
Mr. Clinton's most recent self-criticism came last week in a nearly hourlong telephone call to Ben Wattenberg, a neoconservative columnist and author of a new book, "Values Matter Most." The book argues that social conditions in the nation have deteriorated so much over the last 25 years that "values issues like crime, welfare and school disorder are now even more important than economic concerns," and the President called to praise it.
Mr. Wattenberg recalled in a telephone interview today: "I was sitting in a hotel room in San Diego last Thursday, and he called and said, you know, he's been reading it and skimming it, and he praised it at great length. It's a book that in certain parts is quite critical of him, but he said it was the most honest criticism of his Administration."
In his syndicated column to be published Thursday, Mr. Wattenberg quotes Mr. Clinton as saying that he was initially too interested in the "legislative scorecard, rather than in philosophy," focusing like a prime minister on shepherding his party's legislation, instead of using the bully pulpit like a chief executive. The column says Mr. Clinton said he was "so anxious to fix the economy" that he "changed philosophically and missed the boat."
Noting that the Clinton Presidential campaign stressed centrist themes of personal responsibility, Mr. Wattenberg goes on to quote Mr. Clinton as saying he had "lost the language" on taking office, and had "let Democrats down" by not drumming that message home.
Tonight, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Clinton disputed some of the quotations attributed to him, and in particular did not believe he said that he had "changed philosophically." On other points, Mr. McCurry said, the President thought Mr. Wattenberg had "truncated" some "very nuanced discussions about policy" on issues like welfare and education in ways that altered Mr. Clinton's meaning.
Asked if the President was sore at Mr. Wattenberg, Mr. McCurry said, "You know, he said, 'Look, Ben's characterized about half of this conversation.' "
Mr. Wattenberg writes that when he told Mr. Clinton he had not liked the President's original proposal for overhauling welfare, believing it was too soft and weak, the President agreed, saying, "I wasn't pleased with it either." Mr. Wattenberg said Mr. Clinton said he should have introduced a welfare bill as soon as he saw that his health care plan was in trouble, but did not.
But Mr. McCurry said the President had actually been reflecting that the lack of money available for adequate child-care programs as part of any welfare plan had forced him to be less stringent about requiring welfare mothers to find jobs in a fixed time than he would have preferred.
By the time of the 1994 midterm elections, Mr. Wattenberg writes, Mr. Clinton said he realized he had created "a cardboard cut-out" of himself. But now, Mr. Wattenberg adds, Mr. Clinton intends to recapture his moderate philosophy. He said the President praised Congressional Democrats for moving toward the center on issues like welfare and crime. Mr. Wattenberg said Mr. Clinton hoped to compromise with the Republicans on an "honorable budget," though Mr. Clinton has repeatedly vowed to veto any budget that does not protect his priorities.
Mr. Wattenberg said he did not tape the conversation, but rather took longhand notes and transcribed them on a lap top computer after a discussion that lasted between 50 minutes and an hour. He said he informed Mr. McCurry of his plans to write about the conversation, and Mr. McCurry confirmed that the President had expected that.
Mr. McCurry said he did not know where the President was when he made the call, but said Mr. Clinton apparently did so on his own without consulting any aides or advising them of his intentions. Mr. Clinton is fond of calling all sorts of friends and advisers at all hours of day and night just to talk, and swap ideas and advice.
But in telephoning Mr. Wattenberg, Mr. Clinton took some obvious risks, since the columnist has made no secret of his belief that Mr. Clinton won as a moderate but veered left on taking office, and he could have been expected to spread the word of any Presidential second-thoughts.
Mr. Wattenberg said, "For someone like myself who's literally been writing for 20 years that the Democrats are not going to make headway until they acknowledge they've made some mistakes, it was a joy to hear that."
White House aides were clearly chagrined that Mr. Clinton had once again meandered into a discursive public discussion about his failings that seemed all but certain to muddy the White House's official message of the week, which is resoluteness in the face of Congressional Republicans' plans to cut the Federal budget in ways Mr. Clinton opposes.
Two weeks ago, at a fund-raising dinner in Texas, Mr. Clinton told wealthy contributors that he raised taxes "too much" in his first budget in 1993, only to insist a day later that he had simply meant to say no one likes to raise taxes. Six weeks ago, the President said he was trying to lead the nation out of a "funk," only to insist he had never meant to say he believed citizens were still depressed, but that they had been before last fall's elections.

His comment should have read, "For someone like myself who's literally been writing for 20 years that the Democrats are not going to make headway until they acknowledge they've made some mistakes, it was a joy to hear that."

HEADLINE: A JAPANESE BANK IS INDICTED IN U.S. AND ALSO BARRED

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Federal and state bank regulators yesterday ordered Daiwa Bank Ltd., the big Japanese bank, to close its operations in the United States within three months. The order came as a Federal grand jury accused the bank of illegally covering up $1.1 billion in trading losses at its New York branch.
The expulsion and the Federal indictment appear to be an action without precedent against a large foreign bank, Federal officials said. If convicted, Daiwa could face fines of as much as $1.3 billion. 
 Daiwa did not disclose the huge losses to American regulators until late September, two months after Toshihide Iguchi, an executive at the bank's New York branch, confessed to executives at Daiwa that he had lost $1.1 billion over 11 years in unauthorized bond trading and that he had then illicitly sold securities belonging to the bank and its customers to cover up his losses. Even when the bank did report the losses, as is required by law, it attributed them to a rogue trader and did not mention that it had known about the losses since July.
But the indictment returned yesterday asserted at great length that the bank's top management had communicated extensively with Mr. Iguchi between July and September about how to handle and even conceal the losses from regulators and the financial community.
In part, the action yesterday reflected the sharply different reactions authorities in Japan and the United States had to the Daiwa scandal. The Japanese Government's initial instinct was to keep everything quiet and paper over the problem, dealing with it as a family matter. In the United States, prosecutors viewed the actions surrounding Daiwa as plain and simple fraud compounded by an elaborate cover-up. [Page D5.]
Tokyo moved today to prevent possible panic over the sanctions against Daiwa from spreading to the rest of the banking system. And Japan's Finance Ministry ordered Daiwa to cut back its international operations and asked Sumitomo Bank to help close Daiwa's businesses in the United States. [Page D5.]
The charges against Daiwa include conspiracy, mail and wire fraud, obstructing an examination of a financial institution, falsification of bank records and the failure to disclose Federal crimes. The former general manager at the Daiwa branch, Masahiro Tsuda, was also indicted on charges of conspiring to deceive regulators. Mr. Tsuda's lawyer, Stanley Arkin, said yesterday that his client, who had only become general manager in July, was innocent. Mr. Tsuda resigned from the bank last month.
Daiwa, based in Osaka, said in a statement yesterday in New York that it intended to defend itself against the Federal charges. Takashi Kaiho, the recently appointed president of Daiwa, said the bank was motivated by its desire "to investigate thoroughly the unauthorized activities by which it was victimized, to take all necessary action to protect our customers, and to act in a way that was not harmful to the international banking system."
Mr. Iguchi, the Daiwa trader, pleaded guilty last month to bank fraud and is cooperating with the United States investigation. At his hearing, Federal prosecutors said for the first time they believed that Daiwa executives had participated in a cover-up of the losses for two months.
The indictment against Daiwa sets out new information detailing a more extensive and intricate deception at the bank, involving misrepresentations made to bank regulators and examiners for several years. In early August, the indictment said, as top management became involved in the cover-up, the bank even considered concealing the whole trading loss at a company in the Cayman Islands.
That plan, though, was "ultimately rejected by Daiwa's senior management as not feasible," the indictment said. Daiwa had used that technique before, the indictment asserted, when in about 1987 the bank "successfully concealed a multimillion-dollar trading loss at Daiwa Bank Trust through a Cayman Islands entity." The Daiwa Bank Trust Company is a Daiwa subsidiary in the United States.
Mr. Iguchi first confessed his losses in an extensive letter sent to Daiwa's president in mid-July. But yesterday's indictment detailed as many as five letters that Mr. Iguchi wrote to his superiors as they pondered what to do about his horrendous losses. It also outlined Mr. Iguchi's associations with his bosses as they discussed the losses, including meetings held in late July at the Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan.
As she announced the indictments at the Federal courthouse in Foley Square, Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, said that "The message to the financial community from today's indictment should be clear and unambiguous: Law enforcement will not tolerate financial institutions who unlawfully attempt to mislead regulatory authorities and cover up criminal conduct by their employees."
The order to shut down the operations was issued by the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the New York State Banking Department and regulators in California, Illinois, Massachusetts, Florida and Georgia, states where Daiwa has operations. Even though operations here are closed, Daiwa can still trade with American firms from Japan.
The tough action against Daiwa comes as Japanese financial institutions are under considerable pressure because of billions of dollars of nonperforming loans, a slow economy and sagging confidence.
It is now several weeks since the news of Daiwa's trading losses became public and markets have already adjusted to them. The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the rating agency, for example, said the actions yesterday would not immediately affect Daiwa's credit rating because the agency had already downgraded Daiwa two notches from A- to BBB.
"The action taken by U.S. regulators goes a bit further and will have a more serious effect on the bank's activities than we expected," said Ernie Napier, an S.& P. analyst. "It's a major setback, but it's one they can cope with," he added, noting that overseas operations represent only 10 percent of Daiwa's profit.
But Mr. Napier expressed concern that the bank's business in Japan could be hurt by the defection of Japanese clients who want a more international bank, or at least one with full access to markets in the United States. Mr. Napier said that even if Daiwa was hit with a large fine, the penalties should not have a ripple effect on the troubled Japanese banking system.
While Daiwa has been shaken by the scandal and its two top executives in Japan have resigned, analysts said it should be able to pay whatever penalties it might suffer. At the end of 1994, Daiwa had equity capital of $6.9 billion and total assets of $304 billion, ranking it the 15th largest bank in Japan and the 19th largest bank in the world, according to American Banker, a trade publication. (Daiwa Bank Ltd., its New York branch and its United States subsidiary, the Daiwa Bank Trust Company are not related to the Daiwa Securities Company, the Japanese brokerage firm.)
The charge that the bank deliberately evaded regulators has had a damaging effect on confidence in Federal regulation, some experts said. Daiwa's conduct "is very disruptive because it has undermined the examination process," said Michael Bradfield, a former general counsel to the Federal Reserve and a partner at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.
Deliberately concealing information, as prosecutors contend Daiwa Bank did in the last several years, is inconsistent with the entire theory and practice of examinations, Mr. Bradfield said.
"The whole system of bank regulation works on the basis of full availability of records to examiners and a willingness to cooperate with supervisors when they discover problems," he said. Mr. Bradfield said that harsh action against Daiwa was justified.
But the stiff potential penalties could leave the Government open to criticism that it has employed a far harsher standard for a foreign bank than has been applied in cases involving American brokerage firms.
For example, prosecutors elected to bring no criminal charges against Salomon Brothers Inc. for having illegally obtained millions of dollars through fraudulent bids in the Treasury markets in 1991. No charges have yet been brought in a case involving a trader at Kidder, Peabody & Company, who was accused by the firm of engaging in a series of bogus trades strikingly similar to those at Daiwa.
And last year, Ms. White, the Federal prosecutor, chose not to indict Prudential Securities for taking more than $1 billion from 100,000 investors through the fraudulent sale of risky limited partnerships. Indeed, while the Government said in court filings that Prudential executives knowingly committed the fraud, no individual has ever been charged with a crime.
Some prosecutors yesterday drew parallels with previous Federal regulatory action against the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. B.C.C.I. was the rogue bank based in Luxembourg and with headquarters in London that was closed by regulators around the world in July 1991 after it had become extensively involved in money laundering, falsifying accounts and many other infractions.
But B.C.C.I., unlike Daiwa Bank, was never formally admitted into the United States, or allowed to operate branches in this country. It did, though, secretly and illegally buy banks and other financial institutions in the United States.
Just what regulators in the United States knew about Daiwa's New York branch, and when they knew it, is still a murky issue. According to several former Federal Reserve officials, there was considerable concern about Daiwa's sloppy controls and trading practices as long ago as 1993. But it seems Fed regulators took Daiwa's assurances that the bank would redress the shortcomings they had identified.
Congress is now preparing to hold hearings on Daiwa, the trading debacle at its New York office and regulatory oversight of the bank. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, said in an interview yesterday that the actions against Daiwa were "an appropriate response to illegal activities."
Senator D'Amato said that his committee's hearing would look into what procedures might minimize the chance of a recurrence of the Daiwa scandal. He said his purpose was "not to admonish the regulators, but to ascertain from them what they are doing" and "to ask them to explain what did happen."
 
Iguchi's Letters
 Prosecutors have accused Daiwa Bank and several top executives of conspiring for months to cover up $1.1 billion in losses incurred by a trader, Toshihide Iguchi, through unauthorized bond trading. In addition to the confession letter from Mr. Iguchi that set off the whole chain of events, prosecutors say Mr. Iguchi wrote at least four more that figure in the cover-up.
 
1. The Original Confession -- July 21
 
Addressed to Daiwa's then-president, Akira Fujita; Mr. Iguchi characterized it as his "honest confession" and said he had "caused approximately a $1.1 billion loss from trading in United Staes Treasury bonds at the New York Branch." He suggested that the bank should "keep the secret until the bank and possibly the Japanese authorities can take appropriate measures," and he added that "it is clear from a legal standpoint this will make the continuation of the U.S. operation difficult."
 
2. No One Will Catch On -- July 24
 
Along with another copy of the confession letter, Daiwa received a second letter from Mr. Iguchi in which he said, "I can clearly say on the basis of the experience I gained from the Fed inspection the year before last, that there is a zero possibility that this case would be found out in the United States if we bought back (the Unites States Treasury obligations). . . "
 
3. Ways to Hide the Losses -- July 25
 
Addressed to the deputy president of Daiwa Bank Limited; the indictment says that in this third letter Mr. Iguchi "outlined his suggestions for ways in which the defendant Daiwa could continue to conceal the $1.1 billion loss."
 
4. More Details on the Trading -- July 28-29
 
According to the indictment, three senior executives met with Mr. Iguchi in late July. Masahiro Tsuda, Daiwa's managing director in New York, said at the meeting that the losses would not be announced until late November, after Daiwa was due to announce financial results, and that keeping the losses secret in the meantime was imperative, the indictment says.
 
The next day, the indictment says, Mr. Iguchi gave the three executives a fourth letter explaining his trades, losses and unauthorized sales of bonds to cover his losses in greater detail; Mr. Tsuda then asked Mr. Iguchi "to destroy the computer disk on which he had prepared the confession letter."
 
5. A New Undated Confession -- Aug. 4
 
The indictment says another of the three executives directed Mr. Iguchi to "prepare another version of the confession letter, which was to be undated," and told Mr. Iguchi "to discuss only his unauthorized trading losses and the losses that resulted from that trading" and omit mention of "other matters" addressed in the first confession letter in July.

HEADLINE: California Smog Cloud Is Cleaning Up Its Act

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The noxious haze of smog that hangs over Los Angeles and the surrounding urban basin has long been the thickest, unhealthiest and most infamous in the country, as much a symbol of the city to many people as Hollywood.
But the latest pollution measurements show that however noxious the cloud might be, determined cleanup efforts are steadily reducing its size and toxicity. 
 Thirty-five years ago, the pollution level in the basin, as measured by the presence of ozone, exceeded the minimum Federal Government health standard of 0.12 parts of ozone per million parts of air on four of every five days.
But now, new measurements show, that safety standard is exceeded on fewer than two of every five days because of two decades of stringent emission controls on vehicles, factories and even private residences.
There is still far too much air pollution over the Los Angeles region, irritating eyes and lungs and causing more illness and premature death than anywhere else in the country. Some days the gray-brown haze hangs so heavy that it seems that no progress has been made.
But, in fact, at least two-thirds of the health-threatening pollutants have been stripped out, air-quality experts say. Few other major metropolitan areas can match that progress.
"This is a good news-bad news situation, but there's now more good news than bad news and that's remarkable," said James M. Lents, who heads the South Coast Air Quality Management District, the state government body that monitors and enforces the cleanup.
"Keep in mind," Mr. Lents added, "that this dramatic progress occurred while the number of people and cars in the region essentially tripled and new industry sprouted everywhere. So if we keep making headway against odds like that -- we need to eliminate two-thirds of the pollution that's still left and there's some resistance -- we just might have truly healthy air again by as soon as 2010."
Federal officials, the ultimate arbiters of the country's air quality, are equally encouraged.
Arnold Robbins, a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency's regional office in San Francisco, said: "California in general and the Los Angeles area in particular have been very aggressive national leaders in air cleanup. They have adopted measures that other places are just now beginning to consider."
Back in the bad old bad-air days in the Los Angeles basin, smog often covered the region from the mountains to the sea, obscuring the bright California sun, hiding the tops of skyscrapers, seeping under doors and leaving most everyone wheezing.
Motorcycle messengers sometimes donned gas masks.
On the very worst days, government officials would close schools and businesses and urge everybody to remain shut up indoors.
But these days the sun shines through -- more often than not.
The peaks of the distant San Gabriel and San Bernardino Mountains once again soar, still a little hazily, but nevertheless visible.
And in coastline towns like Pacific Palisades and Santa Monica, the pollution cloud has lightened and pulled back so much that itchy eyes and irritated lungs are a rarity.
Even in the heart of the cloud, 30 miles or so east of downtown Los Angeles, the really bad days are farther and farther apart, the visibility better and better.
So far this year, there have been only 13 days when air quality in the basin deteriorated to the Stage 1 level of 0.20 parts of ozone per million parts of air. That is the polluted point above the basic 0.12 safety threshold at which government health experts publicly warn that air quality has slipped from being simply "unhealthful" to being "very unhealthful."
Last year at this time, there had been 23 Stage 1 alerts. In 1990, there were 41; in 1985, there were 83, and a decade earlier there were close to 120.
Not since 1988 has there been a Stage 2 alert in the basin, the point when ozone reaches the 0.35 level and some industries are ordered to slow operations, driving is curtailed and schoolchildren are not permitted on playgrounds. And not since 1974 has there been a Stage 3 alert, when ozone reaches the 0.50 level and a general holiday is ordered.
"Any way you measure it, things are a lot better," said Linda Waade, the executive director of the Coalition For Clean Air, a California public interest group that lobbies for stronger cleanup efforts.
But Ms. Waade worries that the conservative political tide now sweeping the country could result in a loosening of the strict health standards that made California the national leader in mandating such cleanup devices as catalytic converters on the cars, vapor traps on fuel and solvent sources and soot screens on smokestacks.
She noted "growing opposition" to government-ordered development of electrically powered cars. She said that new emission standards for planes and trains were a year behind schedule and that plans for reducing smoke emissions from restaurants were two years late.
Business leaders counter that such delays result from a growing acceptance of the need for "pragmatic" trade-offs between the environment and the economy.
"Local and state air quality officials are now more receptive in taking economic concerns into account," said Ray Remy, the president of the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce.
Whatever the case, pollution experts at the South Coast Air Quality Management District calculate that every day a minimum of 8,000 tons of noxious hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, carbon monoxide and miscellaneous microscopic particulates are still sent skyward by the region's 10 million cars, trucks, trains and planes, its 40,000 or so industrial sites and the private homes and apartments of its 14.5 million residents.
A study by the district estimates that each year the resulting bad air, even at reduced levels, costs basin residents $10 billion in health problems, sends 1,600 people to a premature death and causes at least 15 million days of lost work, study and play.
The district's air problems are exacerbated by unusual weather and topographical factors.
The Los Angeles basin is so tightly hemmed on the land side by mountains and hills that prevailing offshore Pacific winds are unable to push out the pollution and, in fact, often tamp it down with a heavy, damp cloud layer.
Then the hot sun burns relentlessly on the trapped mixture, chemically cooking some of its pollutants into still another particularly unhealthful pollutant, ozone.
"We've got a lot of things working against us besides pollution," said Joseph C. Cassmassi, the district's senior meteorologist.
Actually, several California communities must contend with similar air-quality factors.
Of the 10 urban areas in the country considered by the Environmental Protection Agency to have the worst air pollution problems, nine are in California. Most are along a line stretching roughly from San Diego, up through Los Angeles and the Central Valley and on to Sacramento. But the Los Angeles area is easily the worst of the 10, with almost twice as much pollution as any other area -- still.
The only non-California city on the top-10 list is Houston, which ranks sixth. Beyond that list, ranking 11 through 15 in order of pollution are a string of five cities in the Northeast: Bridgeport, Conn., Hartford, New York, Trenton and Philadelphia.
In recent years, on average, the pollution in those five cities has exceeded the minimum 0.12 Federal health standard only four days a year.
Even with all its progress, Los Angeles still has at least 25 times that many bad days.
