HEADLINE: SHRINKING THE CITY: Sector by sector;
How New Yorkers Feel Budget Squeeze

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
At Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, one physician is now responsible for the care of all 60 patients in two of the hospital's general medical wards each night from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. Doctors consider that a nearly impossible task; until recently, five doctors, including several residents, covered the shift.
At Joseph Pulitzer Intermediate School in Jackson Heights, Queens, some classes were so overcrowded this week that in one class, nine students had to stand all through class, using windowsills or the tops of radiators as desks. 
 On the No. 7 subway line from Times Square to Main Street in Flushing, Queens, only 35 trains ran between 4 and 6 P.M. one recent afternoon. The number was 43 a month ago, and the official schedule says it should now be 37.
Over the last 10 months, the city and state governments have made extraordinary cuts in spending, and additional cuts from Washington seem virtually certain. The effects are just beginning to reverberate throughout New York City.
An examination by The New York Times, which surveyed 14 city and state services whose budgets were reduced, shows that shrinking the size and cost of government has produced a significant, and in some cases striking, diminution in services.
Sometimes, the changes have been modest or mundane. In many cases, though, the quality of municipal services has declined markedly. Class sizes have swelled at virtually all levels of public education, and fewer courses are being offered in both secondary schools and universities.
Libraries have cut back spending for new books and related materials by more than 30 percent. Litter baskets on street corners in many parts of Manhattan are overflowing by midafternoon because there are fewer midtown trash pickups.
And while the cleanliness of city playgrounds has improved now that welfare recipients have been put to work with rakes and brooms, more sophisticated work, like maintaining swings and slides, has sharply deteriorated. Nearly half the no-parking signs in three neighborhoods were found to be faded, unreadable or simply missing, and half the storm drains in three other communities were clogged with leaves and trash.
Some city services have been maintained or even improved. The police and fire departments have been spared major budget cuts; in fact, the Police Department's budget was actually increased, reflecting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's view that some services are so important to the city that they should be held above the others.
When Mr. Giuliani introduced his $31.1 billion budget in April -- with a $1.1 billion spending cut, the largest since World War II -- he vowed that city services would not suffer, and that most New Yorkers would feel no effect. The reductions, he said, were carefully selected to avoid an erosion of services.
The Mayor repeated that view last week. "There is no correlation between high budgets and delivering effective services," he told a group of student journalists. "Nor is there a correlation between budget cuts and reducing services."
Not all the service reductions result from decisions by Mr. Giuliani. While New York City's budget was reduced, so were state contributions to the city. In fact, some services in the city are provided mainly or entirely by the state or Federal governments.
For example, the City University system receives most of its government support from the state, and the new state budget cut $100 million from the system -- a 16 percent reduction. One result was a tuition increase of $750 a year, a rise of 31 percent.
The state, as well as the city, reduced its contribution to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the quasi-independent agency that oversees New York's subways and buses. That helped lead to service cuts and the 25-cent fare increase that goes into effect on Nov. 12.
But most services examined by reporters for The Times are financed by the city. And so the changes in the quantity or quality of services are largely the result of fiscal decisions made by Mr. Giuliani, the City Council and to a lesser extent, former Mayor David N. Dinkins, who started scaling back some city spending in the early 1990's.
The Mayor did not make his decisions in a vacuum. For several years, independent officials who monitor the budget have warned that the city's tax base can no longer support New York's vast array of government services. City services will have to be reduced, they said.
But some of the same officials have also been concerned that as the budget is cut, services might deteriorate so badly that individuals would be hurt and New York's standing as a capital of finance, commerce and culture would suffer.
In a city as vast as New York, no one can comprehensively assess the relationship between spending reductions and changes in the broad array of government services. The Times's examination was anecdotal; reporters visited schools, parks, municipal hospitals, social service agencies, libraries and subway stations, trying to measure how services were delivered.
For example, reporters spent 22 hours on subway platforms, counting trains on six lines on which service were cut back in September.
What emerged were snapshots of New York City in a year of unequaled spending cuts. And the anecdotal evidence shows that all but the most affluent New Yorkers are exposed to the effects of the budget cuts in ways large and small.
Public hospitals and social service agencies, which the city's poorest residents use, received some of the largest city and state spending reductions, and recipients of these services have noticed the effects.
But many services that affect a wider cross-section of New Yorkers have also begun to show the consequences of diminished financing. At Bernard M. Baruch College in Manhattan, there are 51 students, on average, in history classes this fall. Two years ago, the average was 33.
While playgrounds are cleaner, stolen or broken equipment often is not being replaced. At Morningside Playground in Harlem, four of six swings for small children are gone. At Gen. Douglas MacArthur Park on Staten Island, two of four swings for older children are missing. At the Speradeo Brothers Playground in East New York, all four swings are gone.
In midtown Manhattan, trash baskets are filled or even overflowing, because of modest cutbacks in Sanitation Department pickups. In many parts of midtown, local crews working for private Business Improvement Districts have begun emptying the trash themselves and collecting it in colorful plastic bags with their own logos; sometimes six, eight or a dozen such bags surround the city's litter baskets on street corners.
For some services, there were noticeable disparities between neighborhoods. A park in Riverdale, the Bronx -- with six tennis courts, groomed softball fields and brand new playground equipment -- stood in sharp contrast to the rundown playground in East New York, Brooklyn.
In Gravesend, Brooklyn, a middle-class area near Coney Island, only half as many parking signs were legible per block, on average, as on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. More than 40 percent of the alternate-side street signs in Gravesend were so faded that they were unreadable. And on many blocks in the South Bronx and East New York, most signs were simply missing.
Mr. Giuliani, who declined requests for an interview for this article, has long contended that he had no choice but to reduce the overall size of city government, given the city's huge budget gaps. Mr. Giuliani also argues that by shrinking the municipal work force and lowering taxes, he can stimulate the local economy.
The survey of 14 city services suggests that the city, as well as the state and the quasi-independent agencies like the public schools, the City University and the M.T.A., are often doing less with less.
Data from the city's own annual management assessment, the Mayor's Management Report, also indicates many other areas where city services have declined, particularly compared with the same services in the mid- and late-1980's, when tax revenues soared and New York ran up huge annual surpluses.
The report says the city took an average of 37 days last year to provide an elderly person with a home-care attendant after the person was determined to be eligible; five years ago, it took 20 days.
When a New Yorker was denied welfare, but then was determined to be eligible on appeal, the city began providing assistance within 30 days of the appeal decision 78 percent of the time last year. In 1991, 96 percent of those found eligible on appeal received assistance within 30 days.
The backlog of sewers in need of repair was 5,735, on average, during the fiscal year that ended in June. In 1990, the average backlog was 1,898.
In addition to short-term inconveniences, several officials said service reductions may pose long-term problems for the city.
"A city's competitiveness, its ability to be an attractive place for people to reside in and work in, hinges on two major considerations: cost and quality of life," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that monitors the city's finances. "From that I think it follows that if services are being diminished substantially, then it's a serious issue for the city's future."
 
 
 
City Help Lines Keep On Ringing
 Over several days, calls were made to 35 city agencies, many with fewer employees as the result of budget cuts. The phone numbers were taken from the government section of the Nynex White Pages. In 21 cases, the phone was answered within three rings. In five cases, the line was continually busy, or there was no answer.
At these agencies, the outcome was more unusual:
PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU The phone rang 96 times (10 minutes), then switched to an automated help line. An operator answered in one minute.
HEALTH DEPARTMENT The 24-hour crisis line rang 20 times, then went dead.
DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE Its general information line rang once, then it transferred to an automated message. But once a selection was made, the line disconnected.
RECORDS AND INFORMATION SERVICES DEPARTMENT The number for obtaining birth and death records rang 35 times, then switched to a busy signal.
HOUSING AUTHORITY Its line for applications for project apartments was continually busy on two afternoons.
CITYWIDE INFORMATION LINE After two rings, the line switched to an automated message that did not include an option to speak to a person.
CITY TAX 24-HOUR LINE After one ring, a caller was switched to a five-minute-long automated message with no option to speak to a person.
DEPARTMENT OF INVESTIGATION A line for callers to report corruption complaints rang five times before a tape recording listed the department's office address and hours. The message then requested that the caller leave a message.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks to Shore Up Muslim-Croat Federation

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 2

 BODY:
On the second day of Balkan peace talks here, the outlines of the Clinton Administration's strategy are already clear: strengthen the Muslim-Croat federation and seek to oust the separatist Bosnian Serb leadership as a means to cement the fragile unity of the single Bosnian state envisaged in any peace agreement.
A statement issued today by the State Department said the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, had agreed on steps to shore up the tenous federation brokered last year by the United States. 
 The federation, whose creation stopped the 1993 war between Muslims and Croats, recently came under acute pressure when a Muslim-Croat offensive in western Bosnia last September turned into a race for territory between the two armies that twice degenerated into fighting between them.
Under the accord, about 300 Muslim families are to return to two towns, Jajce and Stolac, that are controlled by the Croats. At the same time, 300 Croat families are to return to two central Bosnian towns, Travnik and Bugojno, controlled by the Muslim-led Government. Up to now, mutual suspicions have prevented such returns of refugee families.
The federation is viewed as critical by United States officials because, without it, Bosnia would disintegrate altogether. The Croats control about 22 percent of Bosnia and their strong inclination is to govern this territory directly from Zagreb rather than work with the Sarajevo Government.
The overall peace plan presented here today to the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia calls for the establishment of several centralized institutions, including a presidency and a parliament, and for what Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Wednesday called a Bosnian state "with a single international personality."
But at the same time it envisages splitting the country roughly in half between a Muslim-Croat federation and a republic of Serbs.
The Serbs, who have fought since 1992 to establish their own state in Bosnia and now control about 48 percent of the country, have told American officials that they want the central Bosnian institutions to amount to no more than "a paper roof."
It is this tension -- between the centralized unitary state sought by the Bosnian Government of President Izetbegovic and the very loose union that might open the way to eventual secession sought by the Serbs -- that lies at the heart of the peace talks. It is by no means clear that the diplomatic acrobatics of the chief American mediator, Richard C. Holbrooke, can resolve it.
Mr. Christopher made clear in a television interview broadcast today that the United States expects Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the political and military leaders of the Bosnian Serbs who have been indicted by an international tribual in The Hague as war criminals, to be ousted in the very near future.
This statement amounted to by far the boldest demand yet made by the Clinton Administration for the removal of two men who would certainly work determinedly to insure that Bosnia is irrevocably split in two.
"We can't really expect that forces of NATO would be there at the same time as these individuals are in positions of power," Mr. Christopher said.
Because a NATO force, including at least 20,000 American soldiers, is expected to go to Bosnia almost immediately after any peace agreement, this statement suggested that the Clinton Administration now wants the two men removed within weeks. This demand appeared to reflect the impact on the Administration of recent Serbian massacres of Muslims in Srebrenica and northwestern Bosnia.
Up to now, however, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has only offered to work for the removal of Dr. Karadzic through elections that would take place within the next year, Western officials said.
Thus considerable new pressure is being applied to Mr. Milosevic and it appears by no means clear that his response will be positive. The Serbian President heads a delegation that includes three senior Bosnian Serb officials.
The aim of the American policy seems clear: open the way for Bosnia to be knitted together again by removing the men most identified with its division. But the risks are considerable, for the two men have solid bands of highly armed supporters with little to lose.
Nicholas Burns, a State Department spokesman, said the three delegations were today handed four draft documents of an eventual peace. He said the papers included what he called "the general peace agreement" -- covering the overall terms of an accord -- and separate papers on the organization of elections, constitutional issues, and the separation of military and paramilitary forces.
The documents were mainly drafted by the State Department and the team working with Mr. Holbrooke. But they were reviewed by delegations from Russia and the European Union. Other documents, on issues like economic reconstruction, are still under review.
Apart from the highly contentious issue of territory, and particularly the status of Sarajevo, the question of elections is also a highly charged one, officials said.
Apart from their objections to any role for Mr. Karadzic and General Mladic, the Bosnian delegation wants the central parliament to be elected by direct, popular vote. The Serbs want its members to be appointed by the respective parliaments of the Muslim-Croat federation and the Serb republic in order to insure that ethnic balance of its members is roughly even.
In an indication that the meeting will last at least another week, the United States Ambassador to Croatia, Peter Galbraith, and a European mediator, Thorvald Stoltenberg, were sent today to eastern Slavonia, the one remaining Serb-held area of Croatia. They are to return to Dayton in about a week.
Mr. Tudjman and Mr. Milosevic agreed on Wednesday to work "toward full normalization of relations" between Croatia and Serbia, but no accord was reached on the fate of eastern Slavonia. Mr. Tudjman, who is to leave Dayton today and return next week, said recently that Croatia would take the area by force or negotiation by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Vote Set on Bills to Keep Government Operating

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Republican leaders in Congress said today that they would vote next week on temporary measures to keep the Government in business while lawmakers and President Clinton try to resolve their differences over the budget.
The leaders -- Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip in the Senate, and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader in the House -- said no decision had been made on what form the new measures would take or what length of time they would cover. 
 Only 2 of the 13 appropriations bills to provide money for the Government's departments and agencies in the current fiscal year have been enacted. A stopgap appropriations bill lapses on Nov. 13.
In addition, the Government is close to exceeding the $4.9 trillion statutory limit on how much it can borrow. Unless the ceiling is raised, the Treasury may not have enough money to pay $25 billion in interest due Nov. 15 on Government bonds.
President Clinton told Congressional leaders at a meeting at the White House on Wednesday that he would like the borrowing limit and the appropriations legislation to be extended past the first of next year. The leaders would like to have the laws expire in early December.
Republicans would like to use the extension of the laws as a lever to force the President to accept some of the measures he is likely to veto. One suggestion tonight was that the extensions be tied to a bill to abolish the Department of Commerce, but there was no indication that this is what the leaders intended to do.
Meanwhile, Republican staff assistants, and in some instances the lawmakers themselves, had meetings all across the Capitol to try to work out the differences between the House and Senate versions of the big budget bills approved last week.
Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, said an agreement was near on how much to cut financing for student loans over the next seven years. The House voted to cut the program by $10.2 billion and the Senate by $4.7 billion. A staff assistant said a likely compromise was in the range of $5 billion to $6 billion.
In New York tonight, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said he was confident that Congress and the Administration would adopt legislation to balance the budget. Mr. Greenspan spoke to the Concord Coalition, a public affairs group that works for deficit reduction.
Mr. Greenspan has hinted in the past that the Federal Reserve Board might be more receptive to lowering short-term interest rates if a plan to balance the budget became law. But the chairman did not make such a suggestion tonight.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Daiwa Ordered to Close Its American Operations
Banking regulators ordered Daiwa Bank of Japan to close its operations in the United States within three months as a Federal grand jury charged the bank with a criminal cover-up of $1.1 billion of trading losses at its New York branch. The former general manager of the branch was also indicted. Daiwa could face fines as high as $1.3 billion. [Page A1.]
 
Daiwa is curbing its foreign operations for various violations of foreign exchange and banking laws, under a Finance Ministry order. Daiwa said it asked Sumitomo Bank to help close its operations in the United States. [D5.]
 
The harsh American action demonstrates once again the degree to which two powerful countries that talk to each other constantly rarely seem to communicate. [D5.]
 
Stocks Scale New Peaks
Led by transportation, technology and retail issues, the stock market surged. The Dow industrials climbed 41.91 points, to 4,808.59, eclipsing the average's previous high of 4,802.45, reached two weeks earlier. [D6.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose, on hopes that the soft numbers for retail sales and jobless claims would let the Fed cut interest rates. [D17.]
 
Anemic Growth in Factory Orders
Strong demand for commercial aircraft pushed factory orders up 1.5 percent in September, but that was barely half the rate recorded in August, showing the manufacturing economy is slowing. [D13.]
 
Head of Ex-Im Bank Quitting
Kenneth D. Brody, a former Goldman, Sachs executive who transformed the once-lethargic Export-Import Bank, is quitting. Congressional budget cutters contend the Federal agency provides welfare to companies like Boeing and G.E. [D17.]
 
Chrysler to Think Things Over
Chrysler's board said it would take three months to consult with shareholders and consider its options before deciding on most of the proposals from Kirk Kerkorian, Chrysler's largest private shareholder. [D2.]
 
Republicans Plan Deficit Vote
Republicans said they would hold a vote next week on temporary measures to keep the Government in business while lawmakers and President Clinton try to resolve their differences over the budget. [A24.]
 
Apple Marketer Leaves
Apple Computer's head of worldwide marketing, Daniel Eilers, resigned, becoming the fourth senior executive to leave the company in the last year. [D6.]
 
Carnival in Talks With Kloster
Carnival is reportedly close to acquiring a majority interest in Kloster Cruise Ltd., by making an investment of $50 million. [D13.]
 
'Dream Girls' of Madison Avenue
As advertising heralded the rise of the American consumer society, women often became the focus, and subject, of ads. An exhibition coming to New York, "Dream Girls: Images of Women in Advertising," shows how women were presented as symbols of ideals as disparate as purity (Psyche, the White Rock girl) and pleasure (Jean Harlow for Lucky Strike cigarettes). Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D18.]
 
Hospital Ratings Imperiled Moody's Investors Service may lower the credit ratings of many big hospitals. It said some of them might not survive the expected Medicare cutbacks. [A20.]
 
Salvo Against Chip Agreement
Japan's electronics industry called for the end of a 10-year-old semiconductor trade agreement with the United States, in what could be the opening salvo in a new trade dispute.The Japanese Government is expected to back that position. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
End the War

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The Million Man March on Washington, a largely middle-class gathering, left tormenting questions about the black underclass. What can be done to break the cycle of despair in our inner cities? What, especially, can be done for their lost young men?
If we are prepared to look past shibboleths, one answer should come to mind. That is to end the so-called war on drugs. 
 Drugs are terrible. But it is not drugs that have done the real damage to our society. It is the misbegotten effort to use the criminal law against them.
We tried Prohibition to end alcohol abuse. It brought so much crime that we quickly gave up the Noble Experiment.
Prohibition of drugs began in 1915. The experiment has been going for 80 years now, and by every rational test it is a ghastly failure.
The huge amounts of money spent in recent years on the drug war have not reduced addiction. Per capita use of cocaine has in fact increased.
And the effort to stop drug use by harsher and harsher criminal penalties has had devastating side effects. It has made importation and distribution of the forbidden products immensely profitable. That in turn has lured large numbers of young men, even children, into the trade.
"We're giving these kids a criminal identity," Joseph D. McNamara, former police chief in San Jose, Calif., said, "when we should be trying to find every possible way to keep them in school and get them into employment."
Mr. McNamara is now a research fellow at the Hoover Institution in Stanford, Calif. Last May, Hoover put on a conference about drug policy. The participants included George Shultz, the former Secretary of State, and Milton Friedman, the economist -- both also at the Hoover Institution -- and dozens of police officials. The participants ended by favoring, overwhelmingly, medical and educational alternatives to the war on drugs.
"Any objective group that studies the war on drugs has to recognize that it's a disaster," Mr. McNamara told The Palo Alto (Calif.) Weekly. "It is not stopping the spread of drug abuse, it's causing a good deal more crime and violence than we'd otherwise have, and it's having severe negative effects on race relations in America."
Another terrible cost of the drug war is the incarceration of enormous numbers of people. This country now has more than one million prisoners, many of them sentenced to long terms for nonviolent drug crimes. It costs us upward of $20,000 a year for each one -- and it will cost hundreds of billions to build new prisons.
The racial impact of the drug war is particularly devastating. One third of this country's black men between 20 and 29 are now in prison or under supervision of the criminal justice system, most of them for drug crimes.
Then there is the murderous quality of life in urban ghettos. Guns accompany the drug trade, and small children are incidental victims of the street battles that result. By one estimate, we have 10,000 drug-related homicides a year.
If we began to decriminalize our drug laws, there might be an increase, perhaps temporary, in casual use. But against that possibility one has to weigh the great gains for society in taking the profit out of the trade.
That is one point made in a compelling piece on drugs in the October issue of The Washington Monthly. By Joshua Wolf Shenk, it argues that we must try to limit drug use -- but not use methods that do more harm than good.
Cigarettes have been found to addict young users more than any other drug, Mr. Shenk points out; and 400,000 Americans die prematurely each year because of tobacco use. But we fight that problem not by criminal prohibition but by rules and education, which have substantially reduced smoking.
Politically, it is very hard to talk sense about drugs. President Clinton has just signed legislation rejecting a recommendation of the Federal Sentencing Commission to end the grotesque disparity of sentences for crack and regular cocaine: up to 100 times more for the former.
But some day we may have political leaders brave enough to do what most of the police authorities and judges who are on the front line have concluded is essential: Stop the self-destruction of the war on drugs.

HEADLINE: At Last, a Watershed Agreement

 BODY:
Every once in a while something happens to demonstrate the powers of firm political leadership coupled with the good will of ordinary citizens. A case in point is the agreement announced yesterday between New York City and upstate communities to clean up the 2,000-square-mile watershed that supplies drinking water to seven million city dwellers and one million suburbanites.
There are weaknesses in the plan, but it represents a huge step forward. On a purely financial level, it will spare the city and its taxpayers the cost of building an $8 billion filtration plant. Politically, it represents a rare triumph of good sense over once insurmountable grievances. 
 To grasp the importance of this agreement it is necessary to understand some complicated history. New York City has long had the power to acquire property around the city's 19 reservoirs and to regulate development on adjacent lands. Because the city did not exercise that power for many years, local residents naturally got the idea that they could do whatever they liked. Development proceeded rapidly, first in Westchester County, later in Putnam County and now in the Catskills. Water quality declined, and in 1989 the Federal Government ordered the city to clean up the watershed or build a filtration plant it simply could not afford.
The city then decided to enforce its powers, announcing that it would acquire thousands of acres of land to provide buffer zones around the reservoirs and writing new regulations governing sewage treatment plants and septic tanks. Upstaters bridled at these restrictions and filed one lawsuit after another. Not an acre of land was acquired, not a single sewage treatment plant upgraded. The watershed continued to deteriorate, and Washington renewed its threats.
Enter Gov. George Pataki, who had promised during his campaign to save the watershed. Seven months ago, he convened all the interested players -- city officials, environmentalists, representatives of the Coalition of Watershed Towns and observers from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. There were more than 200 meetings, many of them bitter and unproductive. But in the end -- the last details were worked out at 4:20 yesterday morning -- the combatants agreed on a plan.
Under the plan, the city will spend some $1.2 billion to acquire more than 100,000 acres of land from willing sellers, to upgrade 100 or so sewage treatment plants, to repair many of the region's 128,000 septic tanks and to underwrite a program to reduce runoff from farms.
The project will be administered by a new Watershed Council made up of residents, city and E.P.A. officials, and environmentalists. They have an important custodial and enforcement job ahead. Environmental groups, for example, complain that the restrictions on new sewage treatment plants are too weak and thus an invitation to destructive development.
On balance, however, there were no real losers in this deal. If everything works out, upstaters will get an economic transfusion. New Yorkers will continue to receive inexpensive, high-quality drinking water. The water rates may rise $4 to $7 a year per household, but this is a pittance compared with the carrying cost of a multibillion-dollar filtration plant.
Mr. Pataki deserves a lot of credit, as does his chief counsel, Michael Finnegan, who ran the meetings with inexhaustible patience. But they were not the only heroes. Various environmental groups -- chiefly the Hudson Riverkeeper -- sounded an early alarm. Two successive bosses of the city's Department of Environmental Protection -- Al Appleton, who worked for Mayor David Dinkins, and Marilyn Gelber, the incumbent -- represented the city's interests. The Coalition of Watershed Towns deserves credit for sacrificing local commercial ambitions to regional harmony, which is what this agreement is about.

HEADLINE: Allies of Two Minds

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
From the start, United States officials and their Japanese counterparts never agreed about how to deal with a huge financial institution that misled regulators in both countries and sought to hide losses of $1.1 billion in illegal trades.
But the stunning American response today to the Daiwa Bank scandal again demonstrates the degree to which two powerful nations, which constantly talk to each other, rarely seem to communicate. 
 The Japanese Government's initial instincts in the bond-trading scandal were to keep everything quiet and to paper over the problem, dealing with it as a family matter. For six weeks, the Finance Ministry did not even tell the United States Treasury Department or the Federal Reserve that officials suspected a huge banking fraud had been committed on American soil.
Full disclosure, Japan's rattled financial officials feared, might further shake the foundation of the nation's once-proud banking system.
In the United States, the attitude has been the reverse. Federal prosecutors viewed the case as a fraud, plain and simple, compounded by an elaborate cover-up in which the Japanese Government may have been an accomplice in recent months.
Their instinct was to trumpet the extent of the problem, much as American officials eventually did in the savings and loan crisis, and to make an example of the offenders.
Publicly, officials like Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin never expressed anger at the actions of the Japanese Government. But the Clinton Administration's views were privately conveyed in a phone conversation with Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura. Mr. Rubin and many others here were upset.
So when regulators made brief inquiries around Washington about whether high-level diplomatic concerns should take precedence -- as they probably would have in the past -- the only message that came back was to deal with the whole affair by the book.
"It tells you everything about the wide gap in how the two countries deal with the transparency of the financial system, and in the nature of the relationship between the government and corporations," said Michael Mochizuki, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, who studies the relationships between the two governments. "In Japan, there would have been a ritual resignation, and the old boys would have taken care of it. And that is why there is so much shock in Japan these days that this has been dealt with so severely -- that the U.S. views this as such a breach of trust."
American officials made every effort today to argue that this was a legal, not a diplomatic dispute, and that no one in political channels was even involved in the decision making about how Daiwa should be punished.
But it only added to the unpleasant air already surrounding President Clinton's visit to Japan scheduled to begin on Nov. 17. Senior officials, led by Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, are in Japan this week trying to calm a political storm involving the Japanese-American security treaty, one fueled by accusations of the rape of a 12-year-old girl on Okinawa by three American servicemen. Then there were disclosures that the Central Intelligence Agency spied on Japanese trade negotiators.
The broad significance of the order that Daiwa Bank give up its American operations was noted today by Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, the House Banking Committee chairman. "As profound a legal and regulatory issue that this may be for one institution," he said, "it is far more serious for U.S.-Japanese economic relations."
Perhaps the only precedent for today's action took place late in the cold war. In 1987, a scandal erupted over the actions of a Toshiba Corporation subsidiary, which was accused of shipping submarine propellers to the Soviet Union, making its underwater nuclear fleet harder to detect.
For months, the United States prodded Japanese authorities to look into the situation more closely. The Japanese fumed, as they did in this case, and investigators in Tokyo contended that the evidence was scant. Finally, Washington retaliated, barring the Toshiba Machine Company from doing business in the United States for years and going so far as to include intelligence-agency reports in leaking details of the secret deal.
The Americans were intent on making an example of Toshiba. The Japanese, by contrast, were interested in skating past the incident as smoothly as possible. Washington's handling of the affair bred resentment in Tokyo for years: television never tired of showing a film clip of American lawmakers smashing a Toshiba stereo system to bits. For many Japanese, that image embodied the term "Japan bashing."
Nothing so graphic is likely to emerge from today's indictment, but the resentments may be no less acute.
Already, some Japanese officials argue that the United States has wildly overreacted to the Daiwa case. Japanese magazines have suggested that Washington is kicking out a big Japanese bank because of some kind of resentment over the power that Japanese financial institutions wielded in the late 1980's, when they went on buying sprees through the United States. There are conspiracy theories galore.
And some Americans charge, without any clearer proof than the Japanese theories, that the penalty applied to Merrill Lynch last week for a relatively minor infraction of Tokyo's own rules was a tit-for-tat response to the Daiwa case.
In Japan, bank executives are highly unlikely to go to prison for the kinds of actions contained in today's indictment. Like Toshiba's top leaders, two of Daiwa's senior executives have already resigned or retired.
But the American action suggests that Daiwa's top managers may not receive the rehabilitation accorded to Toshiba's, who gradually reappeared on various advisory boards. The bank has caused something of a national humiliation abroad, the sort of thing that is not dealt with lightly in Japanese society. The American court action is likely to force into public view documents and accounts of the bank's internal operations that would ordinarily stay under wraps.
"The Japanese banking world is such a cocoon," said a top official at a rival Japanese bank in New York, "that it is hard for everyone to understand that when you go overseas, the usual protections do not apply. This is the real meaning of 'getting internationalized.' "

HEADLINE: In America;
Strength in Numbers

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
On Tuesday Secretary of Labor Robert Reich said, "There is something wrong with rising profits, rising productivity and a soaring stock market, but employee compensation heading nowhere."
The Labor Department had just reported that an expanding economy had driven stock prices to record levels in the past year but the earnings of American workers had risen by only 2.7 percent, the smallest annual increase on record. 
 The report was not surprising. American workers have been on a downhill slide for years, losing wages, losing benefits, losing jobs, losing respect, and in all too many cases, losing hope.
Now comes Sara Horowitz, young and energetic and optimistic, with a project that is bold and timely and just might work.
Ms. Horowitz is the president of a new organization, based in New York, called Working Today. It is (or, more correctly, aspires to be) an employee lobby, an association of all types of workers modeled on the American Association of Retired Persons.
"It is open," said Ms. Horowitz, "to all those who work or want to work: professionals and service workers, managers and time-clock punchers, consultants, freelancers, and part-time and seasonal workers, as well as all those who are unemployed."
Downsized managers and part-time hamburger flippers (the distinction is not as great as it might seem; some individuals inhabit both roles) are among the millions of American workers adrift in the bewildering new world of employment. It is a world that increasingly favors the fortunate few at the very top.
For millions of others in all income groups the mere thought of the workplace can provoke anxiety and dread.
The smart set, obsessed by the impact of technology and the global economy, would have you believe there is not much that can be done to counter the humiliation of American workers. That mystical force called the market has spoken. The message is as follows: Bill Gates has an operating system that is more efficient than you, and Bangladesh has workers that are far cheaper than you.
Now what was that you said about a raise?
Ms. Horowitz and her colleagues, including Prof. Herbert J. Gans of Columbia University, who has been studying the problem of unemployment since the 1960's, offer a somewhat different message:
"That companies are able to shift from offering good jobs with benefits and security to offering poorly paid jobs with no benefits and no security is due, in part, to the absence of a strong voice from those who work."
Working Today hopes to remedy that by being an advocate on issues important to the 150 million workers or potential workers who have no unified national voice, and by providing practical services and advice to its members, who pay a $10 annual fee.
The organization, with headquarters at 25 West 43d Street, is in its earliest stages. But members are signing up, some foundation money is coming in, and Ms. Horowitz's plans are moving smartly ahead.
Some of the issues are obvious -- job creation, wage stagnation, the portability of health and pension benefits. Some are less obvious. People who work at home, for example, have to pay for office supplies, which can be hugely expensive. Working Today will try to find ways to pool resources and buy in bulk, thus providing discounts for its members.
Ms. Horowitz is a lawyer who recently finished a stint at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. She is a strong believer in civic participation and cooperation, and believes the same principles should be applied to the workplace.
"People are focusing so much as individuals, and they don't really have the organizations or institutions to bring them together," she said. "When these big problems like downsizing start happening, it's almost as if everyone sort of looks at each other and says, 'Now what?' "
An important goal of Working Today is to link individuals and groups from around the country that are already working on employee issues. "We're designing an Internet strategy," Ms. Horowitz said, adding, "We're trying very hard to reach people, to connect people and ideas."
She made it clear that advice and expertise and any other type of support would be welcome.
Working Today is a big project and worth rooting for.

HEADLINE: Rates to Rise 2% at Most Under Plan to Protect City Reservoirs

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Water rates will rise 1 to 2 percent, or less than $7 a year for the average residential customer, under a $1.2 billion plan bringing upstate and urban interests together to protect New York City's drinking water.
The plan, released yesterday, is intended to avert the need to build a multibillion-dollar filtration plant and promote nonpolluting economic development around the city's 19 upstate reservoirs. 
 Under the agreement, the city will try to triple its land holdings within the drainage basins that feed its reservoirs, spend $350 million on environmental protection projects for communities in those basins, and institute the first revisions in water protection rules since 1953.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said much of the cost of the program had been anticipated in the Department of Environmental Protection budget. Since the late 1980's the city has been facing a Federal ultimatum: Protect your water, or filter it. The added expense, the Mayor said, will be about $400 million over the next 10 years.
He added that the new rate increase, which takes effect in 1997, is a tiny fraction of the $8 billion that would have to be raised if increasing pollution forces New York City to build a filtration plant.
Satisfied with the new plan, Federal officials said they would delay until December 1999 any decision to order New York City to filter all of its water.
In a rare display of regional harmony, officials from the city, the state and the communities around the reservoirs stood shoulder to shoulder with environmentalists yesterday to announce the pact at a news conference at the World Trade Center.
Congratulating several dozen negotiators who had forged the agreement in 250 meetings over seven months, Gov. George E. Pataki said they had somehow found consensus "after years of fighting and lawsuits that literally threatened to tear this state apart and split it between upstate and downstate, between the city and the suburbs."
He added, "This was an issue in which people not only couldn't reach agreement, they couldn't even talk to each other."
The agreement entailed substantial compromises on all sides from positions staked out at the beginning of 1995.
A key component is a commitment by the city to spend $350 million to help local communities cut pollution in the watersheds and spur economic growth in many of the economically depressed communities in the Delaware River Valley and the Catskills, regions west of the Hudson River that together supply 90 percent of New York City's drinking water.
In return, the upstate communities agreed to drop several lawsuits and abide by new rules written by New York City governing everything from the installation of septic tanks to the creation of parking lots. The detailed package of rules is to be released in a month, city water officials said.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a lawyer for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, a private environmental group, said, "This partnership program is a recognition that we cannot have strong environmental protection if we don't also make sure that these communities have strong economies. That was an extraordinary philosophical step for the city to take."
Reflecting the dramatic change in the tone of the watershed debate, at the ceremony yesterday Mr. Kennedy, who for years had been openly reviled by many watershed residents, stood smiling alongside Anthony Bucca, the Supervisor for the Village of Hunter and a politician who once railed against New York City for trying to regulate how watershed towns buried their dead.
Any municipality can choose not to participate in the program, city water officials said, but would then not share in the economic development funds.
Along with the new rules and the funds for upstate development, the city added $60 million to the $201 million already set aside for expanding a buffer of city-owned land around its reservoirs.
In a major concession, the city agreed to forgo forcing landowners in those areas to sell through condemnation.
Watershed communities did not win veto power over proposed land deals, but will be allowed to review them and ask the state to assess whether a purchase is justified.
Eric Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group, criticized the land-purchase plan because it does not include a firm timetable and targets for acreage.
He also said the agreement will allow the flow of treated wastewater into the reservoirs to continue to increase, when more than half of the reservoirs are already overloaded with phosphorus and other unwanted nutrients.
Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's counsel and the person credited with orchestrating the negotiations, said the Federal Government will monitor the water-protection effort until the summer of 2001 and will be able to demand changes if water quality declines.

 Key points of the $1.2 billion plan, released yesterday, to protect the city's 19 upstate resevoirs and thus the quality of its drinking water.

 City will try to triple its land holdings in watershed areas, committing $261 million for purchases in the Catskill, Delaware and Croton drainage basins.
 
CITY-FINANCED PROGRAMS

 $350 million for environmentally sound economic development and pollution reduction.
 Creation of a Watershed Partnership Council to act as a regional advisory board.
 
NEW REGULATIONS
 Stricter rules to govern many activities in the watershed areas, replacing rules used since 1953.

HEADLINE: A Volley Over Chrysler Quality

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 2

 BODY:
A perverse computer can vaporize hours of work; a bad pair of contacts can strain the eyes. But a flawed car can do untold damage to the body or psyche.
And what intricate, vulnerable products they are: aggregates of some 30,000 bits and pieces, racked by thousands of explosions a minute, abused by weather and roads, controlled by one frequently neglectful mind. 
 Yet the disturbing truth is that customers and investors cannot pin down the quality of any model or company. Although the industry says it has made great strides in measuring itself, its public benchmarks of "quality" -- surely the most overworked, elastic term in the business -- are incomplete.
This fogginess is enveloping the dispute between the Chrysler Corporation and Kirk Kerkorian, its largest private shareholder. Mr. Kerkorian and his proxies have seized on Chrysler's reputation for shoddy vehicles as a wedge to split institutional investors from management, and perhaps to separate some managers from their jobs.
It is a handy tool, since Chrysler vehicles have been tarred for decades with an image for fits that don't, finishes that aren't, and little engines that can't. But company executives say this corrosive reputation is outdated.
Each side supports itself with popular yardsticks of quality. Spokesmen associated with Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian's company, use them to bash Chrysler's cars, Chrysler to praise its light trucks and boast about how much better its cars score as they age. Chrysler also argues that the numbers do not reflect buyers' enthusiasm, which it says outweighs the aggravation caused by, say, too much wind noise or hard-to-adjust headrests.
"There is no other area in the field of human communications that is as rife with disinformation as the story on Chrysler quality," Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, declared in an interview.
The trouble is, neither side can prove its case, a standoff that will probably work to management's advantage. As Chrysler marshals its counterarguments, the dispute seems likely to blur, leaving Mr. Kerkorian without the cut-and-dried case that investors may insist on before ejecting managers and directors of a profitable company.
Consider the most widely used measure, the Initial Quality Survey conducted by J. D. Power & Associates. Jerome B. York, Mr. Kerkorian's chief strategist, turns the survey against Chrysler, saying it shows that "Chrysler has the second-lowest car quality among all manufacturers." Chrysler's cars did score a hefty 33 percent below the industry average for 1995 models.
Chrysler prefers to emphasize other findings: that its light trucks scored slightly better than average and better than those of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation. Chrysler sells more mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups than cars, and generally makes more profit on each one.
One reason for the low car scores is that Chrysler, like other manufacturers, has trouble switching to new models, and it has overhauled its car line in the last three years.
But the debate ignores a basic issue: the Power survey, though widely used in news reports and advertisements, is not intended to measure how vehicles hold up, surely a crucial issue for customers. It scores vehicles after 90 days, long before mufflers fall off or ashtrays flop open.
The study is widely credited with forcing auto companies to improve as-built quality sharply. But long-term quality at Chrysler could be better, or much worse, than the numbers reveal.
Mr. York, who has commented publicly on Chrysler's quality since he was hired by Mr. Kerkorian two months ago, declined to be interviewed on the record for this article.
Power also publishes a five-year survey, but it is rarely cited. In it, Chrysler scores below average. Mr. Kerkorian's group has not referred to that study, perhaps because one group member, Lee A. Iacocca, was running the company five years ago.
Within the Power numbers, variation is small. The best car on this year's initial quality survey, the Honda Prelude, scored 48, meaning that of 100 Preludes sold, owners complained about an average of 48 defects; one of Chrysler's mediocre performers, the Dodge Intrepid, scored 130, far worse than the industry average of 103. Stated one way, this suggests that the Intrepid's quality is, appallingly, nearly three times as bad as the Prelude's.
But if each Prelude averaged 0.48 defect, and each Intrepid averaged 1.30 defects, the gap averages out to about four-fifths of a defect. That is the same as the gap between Chrysler cars as a whole and those of Infiniti, Nissan's luxury division, which is the industry leader in the study. Four-fifths of a defect is doubtless enough to break some owners' hearts, but it may not be enough to sustain a shareholder revolt.
Chrysler's worst-performing car, the Eagle Talon, scored 217, lagging behind the Prelude by a far more substantial 1.69. Some Talons have a Chrysler engine and transmission, but the car is assembled by Mitsubishi in Illinois.
Stephen C. Goodall, senior partner at Power, acknowledged that the gap between domestic and Japanese companies had "substantially closed." But, he cautioned, "The funny thing is that customer expectations have also increased."
Chrysler insists that the Power numbers and studies by Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, do not capture owners' enthusiasm because they measure "things gone wrong," rather than "things gone right."
That's like analyzing a company "based purely on costs and not looking at the revenues," said Mr. Lutz, the Chrysler president. "What we have frankly focused on and strongly believe in is to minimize the things gone wrong -- i.e., the costs -- while maximizing the things gone right, to wit, the revenue."
That is a delicate balance; a dramatic curve that excites buyers may make a car's doors fit less snugly. Mr. Lutz argued that Chrysler makes the right trade-offs between solid, dull cars and sexy, temperamental ones. In between "is the sweet spot," he said, "and we've got it."
Chrysler's critics dismiss its talk about things gone right as an attempt to duck the quality issue.
But Chrysler says that because things are going right, owner loyalty -- how many owners buy another Chrysler vehicle -- has climbed to 57 percent from 46 percent five years ago. If its cars fall apart, Chrysler asks, why do people come back?
In tacit acknowledgment of such complaints, Power began a new survey in October that seeks to measure how pleased buyers are after four to five months of ownership. Power has released the names of only the top vehicles in several categories.
But Mr. Goodall said that over all Chrysler outscored Toyota, including its Lexus luxury division. Chrysler's cars did slightly better than Ford's, and worse than G.M.'s, he said. G.M.'s score is particularly impressive, given its recent reputation for building unreliable, unlovable clunkers.
As Chrysler defends itself to investors, its message appears to be sinking in. "All this stuff about quality is the most ridiculously overdone thing I have ever seen," said Seth Glickenhaus, the independent-minded chief of Glickenhaus & Company, a money management firm and large Chrysler shareholder.
Mr. Glickenhaus said Mr. Kerkorian was manipulating the press by harping on quality. "He nitpicks at this stuff and you people pick it up," he said.
But the other quality indicator that Mr. York has zeroed in on could anger shareholders. He said that Chrysler's warranty costs had jumped 50 percent since 1993, to $2 billion or more.
Without citing numbers, Chrysler acknowledges that costs have climbed, pointing to changes in its warranty coverage and to more sophisticated components that cost more to fix. The numbers show, it said, that warranty incidents have dropped. But for shareholders, the fact that Chrysler has fewer, more expensive claims is cold comfort.
Again, though, an apparently clear measure turns fuzzy. Mr. York appears to base his assertions about warranty costs on internal Chrysler documents. But since such costs are among the industry's most closely guarded secrets, comparisons are impossible. Industry analysts say Ford pays less per vehicle for warranty claims, but no public data support that.
Chrysler is walking a narrow line: insisting that its cars and trucks are competitive in quality with the best in the business, while trying to assure investors that quality is improving rapidly. Mr. Lutz goes out of his way to praise Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, who sits squarely in Mr. Kerkorian's cross hairs.
Mr. Lutz said Chrysler started "making quantum leaps in quality" with Mr. Eaton's arrival three years ago. Mr. Eaton has sharply increased spending on training, considered a key to quality, from $145 million in 1993 to just under $300 million this year. And he created a "Special Quality Fund" -- $100 million in each of the last two years -- to finance unusual quality-related improvements.
Such moves appear to be paying off. While Chrysler's cars do relatively poorly when introduced, after a year they score far better. In the 1995 initial-quality study, Chrysler had five of the nine-most-improved models.
Longer term, Chrysler is trying to discipline production. Modeled on the approach at Toyota, the "Chrysler Operating System" is supposed to break down each work station into a precise series of steps, encouraging workers to root out waste and wring out flaws.
Dennis Pawley, Chrysler's manufacturing chief, says the system will help Chrysler achieve its goal of being the world's "premier" auto company by the end of the decade. Down the road, Mr. Pawley says he hopes Chrysler workers will say that "what they did back in the late 1990's is the reason we're the company we are in the year 2030." They could well say exactly that -- whether or not Mr. Kerkorian wins his fight.

HEADLINE: Stocks Jump, With the Dow Up 41.91 to Another High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing to a new high, as weak economic data pushed up bond prices and reignited investors' hopes for lower interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 41.91 points, to 4,808.59, eclipsing its previous high of 4,802.45, reached on Oct. 19. 
 Leading the market higher were stocks closely tied to the performance of the economy, including transportation, technology and retail issues.
"The current thinking is that if interest rates drop, it's going to benefit the economy, and benefit the cyclical stocks first," said Thom Brown, market strategist at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood in Philadelphia.
The Dow Jones transportation average shot up 60.56 points, or 3.15 percent, to close at 1,985.44. Among the biggest transportation gainers were Federal Express, up 4 1/8, to 86; and the CSX Corporation, up 3 5/8, to 85 3/4.
Technology stocks, which often move with the economy, were sharply higher as well, with the Nasdaq composite index climbing 16.82 points, to 1,057.32. The technology advance was led by Internet-related stocks like Netscape Communications, which surged 9 1/4, or 10 percent, to a record 98 1/4.
Stocks got a lift from bonds, which began climbing early in the session after the Labor Department said first-time claims for jobless benefits rose by 6,000 last week to a six-week high. Analysts had expected a slight drop and said the rise pointed to sluggish job growth.
The Commerce Department said orders to factories for durable goods rose 1.5 percent in September, in line with analysts' expectations. Manufacturing inventories rose.
Meanwhile, major retailers reported October chain-store sales were mostly weak, with a few notable exceptions. And separate reports from auto makers late Wednesday said car sales fell about 6 percent in October.
Taken together, analysts said the data could indicate that the economy was growing slowly enough to justify another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.
Even some retail stocks, a cyclically vulnerable sector, weathered mixed reports on October sales to come out ahead. Dayton Hudson jumped 5 1/4, to 73 7/8; Gap surged 3 7/8, to 42 3/8; Kmart rose 1 1/8, to 9 1/2, and and Wal-Mart rose 1 1/4, to 23 1/2.
"When sales slow and inventories are high, that combination puts the lid on the manufacturing sector," said Hugh Johnson, the First Albany Corporation's market strategist. "That means we can continue to grow, but growth will be very moderate. I'm having trouble having something wrong with this picture."
The market's surge was broad based, with advancing issues leading decliners by more than 16 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 397.1 million shares, up from 378.1 million shares on Wednesday.
Among other indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.50 points, to 589.72; the Big Board's composite index rose 2.67 points, to 313.69, and the American Stock Exchange's, market value index rose 5.40, to 528.04.
Big gainers on the New York Stock Exchange included I.B.M., up 2 3/4, to 99 5/8; Motorola, up 2 1/4, to 67 1/4, and Advanced Micro Devices, up 1/2, to 23 1/4. In Nasdaq trading, Intel led in volume and rose 2, to 72 7/8, a day after it introduced its new Pentium Pro chip.
Leading the surge in Internet-related stocks was Spyglass, a software maker, which soared 13 3/4, to 70 1/2, after it posted stronger-than-expected results late Wednesday. Other Internet gainers included UNET, up 5 3/4, to 67, and Netcom On-Line, up 5 1/8, to 68 5/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose for the third time in as many days yesterday, as traders gained solace from soft chain store sales reports and talk of softer numbers to describe how many jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month.
Investors bought on rising expectations of a Fed easing sometime soon, with December likely. 
 The initial rise in prices came from on an unexpected jump in the weekly initial jobless claims report for the week ended Saturday. Claims increased 6,000 over the previous week to 365,000. Economists had forecast a slightly lower 356,000 reading.
By the close of the New York market the current issue 30-year Treasury bond was up 24/32 , to a price of 108 17/32 to yield 6.24 percent, down from 6.29 percent on Wednesday.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said the market remained in a bullish mood and it was hard to find anything that would keep it down at the moment. "It has been impressive the way it has ignored even strong data, and rallied considerably on any signs of weakness," she said.
"I think the market is putting all its chips on a Fed easing and ignoring the particulars coming from a budget agreement, since the impact wouldn't be felt for a couple of years at least," Ms. Rupert said.
Retailing companies that report same-store sales on the first Thursday of every month reported weak numbers yesterday, analysts said, and that may have helped raise expectations of a weak retail sales report for October due on Nov. 14. Market participants say it gives the Fed a stronger case for an easing down the line.
The Commerce Department said September factory orders were up 1.5 percent, which was lower than expected and down from the August gain of 2.7 percent. The Conference Board's help-wanted index fell 4 points, to 126 in September. While the level is still respectable, analysts say, the direction was enough to fuel perception of a sluggish job market, especially considering the rise in the weekly initial jobless claims yesterday and forecasts for a payroll gain of less than 100,000 in today's employment number.
The Conference Board added that job growth had softened after the spring/summer gains.
Jay Goldinger of Capital Insight, Beverly Hills, Calif., said: "On a day when everybody is bullish, I may be the only voice of cautiousness here. The unemployment picture obviously gets painted tomorrow. No matter what the news is tomorrow, I think we're going to have sellers in the market."
The mentality of the bond market right now, he said, is very similar to that of the stock market, which is to buy on every dip, and within a week you have a profit.
"The market is probably a little frothy and over done," Mr. Goldinger said, "and no matter what the news is tomorrow, the market is set up for some selling."
Larry Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data, Boston, forecast some profit taking would occur. "We have reached short-term targets on a yield basis at 6.25 percent, and that should add some selling pressure by position traders" who expect to take profits at these levels, he said.
He said the longer-term picture remained very bullish for a move to the 6 percent level, but cautioned that it would not be an easy ride, as the Government faces several key economic issues, including the debt ceiling and budget problems.
Since next week's note auction dates are not concrete because no debt ceiling has been passed, there has not been any when-issued trading, but in the cash market the current three-year note is yielding 5.52 percent and the 10-year note, 5.88 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of new 48-day and 83-day cash management bills, which the Government occasionally sells to meet cash flow shortages when it needs to meet interest payments.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Kept Rising In September, but Rate Slowed

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Commerce Department said today that strong demand for commercial aircraft pushed factory orders higher in September, though the orders grew at only half the rate recorded in August.
The report added to signs that the manufacturing economy is slowing under the weight of bulging supplies of goods, with caution evident ahead of the holiday shopping season. 
 September orders increased 1.5 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $306.5 billion, down from a revised 2.7 percent gain in August.
The figure was heavily influenced by aircraft orders, which are received infrequently and cost millions of dollars. Excluding transportation, which includes aircraft and parts, orders rose only two-tenths of 1 percent after an August rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
In another worrisome sign, inventories mounted in September for a 12th consecutive month.
"The manufacturing sector is still struggling to come out of this inventory correction," Astrid Adolfson, an economist with MCM Moneywatch in New York, said. "As long as they're struggling, they're likely to choose to extend their workweeks when they need to and to be cautious about hiring."
Underlining that trend, the Labor Department reported today that the number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits climbed by 6,000 last week.
New claims for unemployment pay in the week ended Saturday rose to a seasonally adjusted 365,000 -- the highest in six weeks and more than the 356,000 that had been forecast.
In another sign that job prospects were scarcer, the Conference Board said its index of help-wanted ads dipped in September from August. "After rising through the spring and early summer, want-ad volume has softened," Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist, said.
The Commerce Department report showed that durable goods orders, which account for more than half of total factory business, rose 3 percent in September to $168.9 billion. Orders for nondurable items like food, clothing and paper products weakened one-tenth of 1 percent, to $137.6 billion in September.
Transportation equipment orders posted the largest rise, up 10.6 percent after a 17.6 percent jump in August. Shipments of motor vehicles and parts rose just 3.1 percent in September after a 16.5 percent increase in August.
Hugh Johnson, an economist with First Albany, said that the factory-orders report strongly implied the overall economy was slowing and would continue to do so.
"There was a third-quarter buildup in inventories that simply is unsustainable, and it's going to require both production and employment cutbacks," Mr. Johnson said.
Manufacturing inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $415.6 billion, in September after an August increase or two-tenths of 1 percent.
Shipments of manufactured goods, which reflect more immediate demand than orders, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September after a much stronger August increase of 3.3 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Indictment of Daiwa Produces Spurt in Already Rising Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged past 104 Japanese yen yesterday after Daiwa Bank of Japan was indicted on charges of conspiring to deceive American regulators.
The dollar, which had been steadily rising all day, jumped in afternoon trading in New York after the first reports that Federal and state banking regulators had ordered Daiwa to cease all operations in the United States. 
 Currency traders saw the situation as a sign of deep-seated problems among Japan's banks. New trouble in the Japanese banking industry, they said, could further strengthen the dollar against the yen by prompting sales of the Japanese currency. "We're going to know more about the Japanese banking system in this one incident than at any other time," said Marybeth Slack of MCM Currency Watch.
Weakness in the Japanese banking system could lead to increased sales of the yen against the dollar, as Japanese investors seek safety in more stable, and better yielding, investments overseas.
Yesterday, the dollar rose as high as 104.13 yen -- its highest level since Sept. 20, when it touched 104.65 yen -- before settling at 104.02 yen, up from 103.32 late Wednesday. The dollar also increased to 1.4232 German marks from 1.4177 marks and to 1.1457 Swiss francs from 1.1355 francs. The British pound edged up to $1.5788 from $1.5783.
The dollar has been strong in recent days on growing optimism that Japanese buyers were moving funds overseas. "Japanese investors want to buy foreign-currency bonds," said Toshio Sako, chief dealer at Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank. "The reason is they fear the Japanese economy is still not good."
The dollar also benefited from strength in other European currencies against the mark. Dealers said investors seemed confident that political trouble in France and Italy had eased and felt more comfortable putting money into their high-yielding assets.
"Some of the pressures in Europe have subsided and have taken some of the upward pressure off the German mark," said Bob Lynch, currency analyst at MMS International. "That's giving dollar-mark a little bit of breathing room."
The Mexican peso did not trade yesterday as financial markets were closed for the Day of the Dead, a holiday dating from pre-colonial times, when Mexicans pay tribute to their departed ancestors. The holiday provided a breather for the recently slumping peso, which has also weighed down the dollar.

HEADLINE: Rosalind Cash, 56, at Home on Stage and Screen

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Rosalind Cash, an original member of the Negro Ensemble Company and one of its most vibrant and versatile actresses, died on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 56.
The cause was cancer, said her agent, John Sekura. 
 Although she was best known for her acting in naturalistic dramas like Lonne Elder 3d's "Ceremonies in Dark Old Men," Ms. Cash was equally at home in musicals and in classics, portraying Goneril to James Earl Jones's King Lear for the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1973.
Before joining the Negro Ensemble Company in 1968, Ms. Cash had a widely diverse career, singing in nightclubs and performing Off Broadway (in "Junebug Graduates Tonight!" at the Chelsea Theater Center) and on Broadway (in "The Wayward Stork"). Cast in "The Great White Hope" at the Arena Stage in Washington, she decided to forgo that play, and paid the Arena the equivalent of two weeks' salary so she could return to New York to join the new black theater company.
In the first season of the Negro Ensemble Company, she was featured in "The Song of the Lusitanian Bogey" by Peter Weiss, Wole Soyinka's "Kongi's Harvest" and Richard Wright's "Sweet Daddy Goodness." In "Ceremonies in Dark Old Men" the next year, Douglas Turner Ward played a barber facing economic hardship. Ms. Cash was his strong-minded daughter, the family's principal wage-earner. The role remained a hallmark of her career, and in 1975 she repeated it in the ABC television version.
After her initial success, she moved back and forth between theater and films. In 1980 she returned to the Negro Ensemble Company to appear in "The 16th Round" by Samm-Art Williams.
In Hollywood, she repeatedly battled stereotype. Calling herself "a one-lady movement," she was not afraid to speak her mind, realizing that as an actress, "if you yell loud enough, someone will listen." Her movies included "Klute," "The Omega Man," "Hickey and Boggs," "The New Centurions," "Uptown Saturday Night" and "Wrong Is Right" (in which she played the first black woman to become Vice President of the United States). In 1995, she was in "Tales From the 'Hood."
On television she appeared in Melvin van Peebles's "Sophisticated Gents," Maya Angelou's "Sister, Sister," "A Killing Affair" and the American Playhouse adaptation of James Baldwin's "Go Tell It on the Mountain." She was Mary Mae Ward on the soap opera "General Hospital."
Ms. Cash was born in Atlantic City and attended City College of New York.
She is survived by a sister, Helen Cash Jackson, and two brothers, Jack and Robert.
