HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Discreetly or Scrappily, They Defied the Soviet Line

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
Chapter by chapter, the story of Soviet art in this century has been told in recent exhibitions, and it turns out to be Tolstoyan. Its first part, meaning the revolutionary years when Lenin and company denounced everything associated with Russia's czarist past, unfolded in events like "The Great Utopia" at the Guggenheim Museum. The P.S. 1 Museum in Queens presented paintings from the next era, the years when Stalin denounced the art of the revolution. Those paintings came from the basements of Russian museums to which they had been exiled when Khrushchev denounced Stalin in 1956.
Thirty years or so later, the Soviet people took matters into their own hands and denounced the whole lot of them. About the art of that volatile period in between, meaning the decades from Khrushchev's 1956 speech to the unraveling of the Soviet empire that began in the late 1980's, there have been occasional shows, but no major survey. Until now. 
 With the donation by Norton and Nancy Dodge of 12,000 works of so-called nonconformist art to the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University, in New Brunswick, N.J., it is possible for the first time to look in depth at what the artists who refused to toe the line in the Soviet Union were doing during those momentous years. The first installment of several hundred works from the collection has just gone on view.
Mr. Dodge is an American professor of Soviet economics who, beginning in the 1960's, managed to smuggle vast numbers of sometimes very big paintings and sculptures out of the Soviet Union. Precisely how he did so, not to say how he managed to pay for them, remains something of a mystery, which, as John McPhee writes in "The Ransom of Russian Art," a new book about Mr. Dodge and his collection, seems to be the way Mr. Dodge wants it. In any event, what matters is his heroic effort, and the unparalleled breadth of what he acquired.
Breadth is not quality, and as Mr. Dodge admits, the quality of his collection varies. You have only to see the careful selection of works by Ilya Kabakov, Leonid Lamm, Ernst Neizvestny and Oskar Rabin, to name a few artists who are in the "Russian Jewish Artists" show now at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, to realize that important figures are not always represented at their very best at the Zimmerli. But this is what you would expect even of a private collection as formidable as the one the Dodges put together, and it is worth mentioning only because their collection is so big it might be mistaken for the last word on nonconformist art. It is not, though it clearly makes the Zimmerli, and so the New York area, all at once a major center for the study of late Soviet art.
If the study of late Soviet art sounds like an arcane pursuit, it shouldn't. Counting Soviet Socialist Realism, Hitler's fascist art and the art of Communist China, totalitarian art may have as much of a claim on the cultural identity of this century as high modernism does. Which means the reaction against it, by nonconformists in totalitarian states, has historical significance, too. We in the West tend to dismiss much nonconformist art as merely derivative, too much like Cezanne or Pollock. But the nonconformists thought in terms of artists like Isaak Brodsky and other official painters and sculptors conscripted by Soviet leaders to extol the virtues of Communism. Context is everything, and while our context is modernism, for the nonconformists it was not. Or more precisely, modernism signified something different to them than it does to us: among other things, it signified political resistance of a kind Pollock, at least, never intended.
It will take a while, then, for us to learn how best to interpret nonconformist Soviet art. The installation at the Zimmerli is divided into familiar categories like Surrealism, religious art, geometric abstraction and primitivism, none of them acceptable to a regime that sanctioned Socialist Realism and nothing else. But the categories aren't altogether precise. You may wonder, as I did, what the difference is between Assemblage, say, and the Art and Object section next to it, or what to make of artists who appear in several different sections. Which is not meant to slight the Zimmerli's largely straightforward effort at organization so much as to underscore the notion that nonconformist art ultimately may make most sense when it does not conform to our own expectations.
Many of the artists themselves have made clear they prefer "nonconformist" to "dissident" or "underground," because those words imply a level of political engagement that wasn't always the case. Some artists, like Mr. Lamm, were indeed sent to prison. Others were forced into exile. Yevgeny Rukhin, one of the leading nonconformist painters, died in a mysterious fire. But many artists went about their business as discreetly as possible on the fringes of Soviet society, sometimes getting money and materials by working as illustrators for children's books, or being supported by their wives. (Nonconformist female artists seem to have been rare, and often worked as official artists to support themselves and their husbands.) Some artists clearly made a little money selling art on the sly to Mr. Dodge. But most just showed their modest works surreptitiously to friends in cramped apartments, as they had no access to public exhibition spaces, much less to the art market.
For a while, during a thaw after Khrushchev's 1956 speech, exhibitions of work by Picasso and other European and American modernists were permitted in the Soviet Union. The thaw prompted a generation of independent-minded Soviet citizens to explore styles and subjects that had been banned under Stalin. This period of official tolerance lasted only until Khrushchev visited a show of contemporary Soviet art in Moscow in 1962 and concluded that a little freedom had been too much freedom. Another crackdown ensued, but by then there was no way to make people unlearn what they had learned. The nonconformists were around to stay.
Occasionally during the next years they would organize hit-and-run shows, which the authorities would shut down as quickly as possible (one show lasted 15 minutes). And when several nonconformist painters displayed their works on a vacant lot in a Moscow suburb in 1974, the authorities sent in bulldozers and water cannons. Yet even these repressive measures couldn't undo the nonconformists, not least because Western journalists' accounts of events like the "bulldozer exhibition," as it came to be called, gave the artists precisely the exposure that the authorities had tried to quash.
One of the paradoxes of life in the Soviet Union was that fact and fiction were reversed. The authorities claimed Socialist Realism depicted real life there, but of course it was fantasy. On the other hand, when nonconformists made works that dealt explicitly with the hardships that Soviet citizens had to endure, they were condemned as decadent fantasists. No wonder, in this Alice Through the Looking Glass existence, that irony became a favorite mode of artistic expression. Which partly explains the triumph of so-called Sots artists like Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, with their tongue-in-cheek remakes of official art, and of Conceptualists like Viktor Pivovarov, Vadim Zakharov and Mr. Kabakov.
Mr. Kabakov's art has achieved a certain fashion in the West during the last decade, aided by the resurgence of Conceptual art here. Which is interesting, since what is largely distinctive about his nonconformist work, like much other Soviet Conceptualism, is how much it deals with the specific facts of Soviet life: how local the art is. For example, Mr. Kabakov's "Where Are They?" in the Dodge collection is a series of pages on which are neatly printed, in Russian, of course, lists of familiar objects along with the names of old and sometimes lost friends and colleagues, followed by the phrase "they are not . . . " You can regard the work as Dadaist, maybe, or Minimalist, if you think in terms of Western models. But with its anonymous visual style and the almost incantatory sameness of its prose, it is really a moving commentary on everyday Soviet existence -- though only if you know Mr. Kabakov's context to start with.
Many of the nonconformist works of the 70's and 80's, not just Mr. Kabakov's, involved language, which makes sense considering Russia's great literary heritage. Other Conceptualist works entailed performances that seem indebted to the tradition of Meyerhold and early Soviet theater. There's a Russian source for abstract paintings like those by Eduard Shteinberg, too ( whose pictures are at both the Zimmerli and the Jewish Museum), namely the art of Malevich and the Constructivists.
I belabor the parochialism of these works because the question arises: In the absence of a Soviet foe, and with the diaspora of nonconformists since the Soviet Union's collapse, what is to distinguish the artists today? Soviet existence, in its grim insularity, also turned out to be a creative hothouse. But now what? The essayist Joseph Bakshtein, in the catalogue to the Zimmerli show, writes that the drama of the nonconformist's life has become "the realization that if one were to speak of paradise in Russia, it would exist not 'now' but 'then.' "
Which seems oddly right: after all, it's one thing to make art that derives its edge from opposition to the status quo. But it's something else altogether to make art in the absence of that opposition. And many nonconformist artists evidently have yet to figure out what it means, in a sense, to be conformist. So while the story of Soviet art may now be over, there are clearly chapters still to be written about once-Soviet artists.
"From Gulag to Glasnost: Nonconformist Art From the Soviet Union" is a permanent display of works from the Dodge Collection at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. The museum is at the intersection of George and Hamilton Streets in New Brunswick. "Russian Jewish Artists in a Century of Change, 1890-1990" remains at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, in Manhattan, through Jan. 28.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Tries to Calm Any 'Financial Anxiety'

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The Japanese Government moved immediately today to prevent possible panic over sanctions against Daiwa Bank Ltd. from spreading to the rest of Japan's banking system.
"I hope there will be no damage to the confidence in the Japanese financial system," Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura told Japanese television this morning. "We will make every effort to restrain the spread of financial anxiety." 
 The Bank of Japan also said it was ready to provide Daiwa with money if liquidity problems arose. Japanese financial authorities also seemed to be playing a behind-the-scenes role in encouraging discussions about a possible merger between Daiwa Bank and Sumitomo Bank, one of the country's largest institutions.
The growing concerns about Daiwa come a day after Daiwa was indicted in the United States for its involvement in a trading scandal and ordered to close its operations there. Today, Japan's Finance Ministry ordered Daiwa to scale back its other international operations sharply.
Toshio Morikawa, Sumitomo's president, said this morning that his bank had not held detailed discussions with Daiwa about a merger. But he added that "in the process of the support, if both banks agree, we may discuss it," Mr. Morikawa said.
Sumitomo agreed today to take over at least some of Daiwa's operations in New York and Los Angeles. Daiwa said Nomura Securities, the world's largest brokerage house, had also agreed to help it dispose of its American operations.
The American actions against Daiwa come against a backdrop of growing financial problems for Japanese banks, which have been increasingly shaken by billions of dollar in bad real estate loans and a sluggish domestic economy. The Japanese financial community seemed stunned and sobered by Daiwa's latest setbacks.
The Federal Reserve's order to close Daiwa's American operations and the bank's indictment could result in more problems for other Japanese banks. Foreign banks have already been tightening up on loans to Japanese banks, and the actions by American authorities are likely to intensify these problems and could lead to liquidity problems.
Some analysts said that the stiff measures by American regulators could act as a wake-up call to Japanese financial authorities to take swifter action to rescue Japan's banks.
"It is a shock for the financial system and the authorities, and also a bit of an offense," said Richard A. Werner, chief economist at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo. "But if they feel a bigger sense of crisis, they may clean up this mess in the financial system."
Daiwa was ordered by the Finance Ministry to cut back its international operations because of violations of Japan's foreign exchange, trust banking and banking laws. Daiwa will have to shrink its foreign exchange activities by October next year, but the Kyodo News Service said that the ministry would suspend Daiwa's foreign exchange trading activities at both its New York branch and at its headquarters in Osaka.
The ministry also ordered Daiwa not to open any new foreign branches.
Daiwa's new chairman, Takashi Kaiho, said he was arranging to have Daiwa's American branches transferred to Sumitomo, although he and other Daiwa executives did not release details about the arrangements. Japanese press reports, however, said that Daiwa executives believed that a merger with Sumitomo "is possible."
The Finance Ministry also told Daiwa to to reduce the balance of its international lending and cut its securities holdings in international operations. Daiwa has international loans outstanding of $25 billion and securities held overseas of $5 billion, but apparently only $4.5 billion of those assets are actually held in the United States, the Finance Ministry said today.
Daiwa said that its chairman, Sumio Abekawa, will step down immediately, rather than sometime in March as it had said earlier. Mr. Abekawa, however, will remain as an adviser to the bank.
In the last few weeks, much speculation has focused on how the $1.1 billion loss by Toshihide Iguchi, a bond trader in Daiwa's New York office, would affect the overall reputation of Daiwa in Japan. Some financial specialists have said that Daiwa's name has been so sullied that it would be better off merging with another Japanese institution.
Daiwa also announced a reorganization of its worldwide operations, which would include closing all branches in the United States and consolidate or shrink its branch in London and elsewhere in Europe. While it said it plans to expand in Asia, it will also close down branches in Seoul and Malaysia.

HEADLINE: Gaffney Holds Lead in Suffolk Race

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 2

 BODY:
In his four years as Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney has often faded into the background, overshadowed by an aggressive County Legislature and a combative, colorful District Attorney.
But when brush fires swept across the heart of eastern Long Island two months ago, Mr. Gaffney took center stage, marshaling firefighters and appearing hourly on live news reports from the front lines. 
 It was the perfect opportunity to counteract charges by his opponent, Tony Bullock, that he is a a do-nothing official, too laid back to be an effective manager.
When it was over, Mr. Gaffney, with flags waving and bands playing, led tens of thousands of thankful Suffolk residents -- and voters -- in a daylong celebration honoring the firefighters.
Whatever the impact of the fires on his image, Mr. Gaffney enters the final days of his re-election campaign with a solid 2-to-1 lead over Mr. Bullock in a Newsday poll.
It is a race that defies stereotypes. Mr. Gaffney, the Republican, was raised in a family of Democrats from Brooklyn; his father was a telephone worker. Mr. Bullock, the Democrat, is from a Republican family. He grew up on Manhattan's Upper East Side, attended St. Paul's School in New Hampshire and graduated from Yale University.
Mr. Gaffney, 51, a lawyer and a former F.B.I. agent, said he had done a good job turning the county government around, charging that his Democratic predecessor, Patrick G. Halpin, had left the county "in absolute chaos."
"Our economy was in shambles," he said, "the bond rating had been reduced to below investment grade, the Police Department had not been tended to in years, the Department of Social Services was literally hemorrhaging taxpayers' dollars, and taxes had been increased by 160 percent in some areas. But four years later, we have made dramatic progress in all these areas.
"The bond rating is up, we've had four consecutive balanced budgets, the Police Department has a record number of officers on the streets, Social Services has become a model for agencies throughout the country."
"If re-elected," he said, "I would do much the same and continue to cut costs where possible in hopes of reducing taxes."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Bullock paints a far less rosy picture, accusing Mr. Gaffney of increasing county spending by $365 million since he took office "through waste, patronage and gross mismanagement."
Mr. Bullock, 38, who has served four two-year terms as Supervisor of East Hampton, said Mr. Gaffney had failed to keep his promises to lower the county's 8.5 percent sales tax, the highest in the country, and to cut the Long Island Lighting Company's electric rates, also the highest in the country.
"Bob Gaffney does a lousy John Wayne imitation about Lilco, but the truth there is that Lilco rates have gone up every year he's been in office," Mr. Bullock said.
While both candidates know that attacking Lilco is a sure way to reach voters, they also know that whoever is elected on Nov. 7 will be facing an $80 million bill from Lilco for overpayment of property taxes on the decommissioned Shoreham nuclear power plant.
Mr. Bullock says that had Mr. Gaffney fought to pay the Lilco refund sooner, he would have saved on interest that could increase the bill to $400 million. Mr. Gaffney, in turn, blames the County Legislature, controlled by his fellow Republicans, for refusing to issue bonds for the $80 million. Mr. Gaffney also said he hoped that a public-private takeover of Lilco, now being studied by the state, would spare Suffolk from paying Lilco the refund.
Mr. Bullock said his first step toward cutting county spending would be "an honest budget that does not hide expenditures, misstate expected revenues and mislead taxpayers."
One of Mr. Gaffney's biggest mistakes, he said, "was his failure to reinvigorate economic development."
"For example, I'd like to encourage film production," he said. "Hollywood is moving east and we're ideally suitable for studios to make their home here. I'd also like the county to lead in the construction of a convention center and a baseball stadium here. We've got the sites and the location and the fans. We just need the leadership to move ahead on this."
Mr. Bullock said he was confident that he could overcome Mr. Gaffney's lead, even though Republicans outnumber Democrats in Suffolk by 2 to 1.
"As a Democrat, I'm well aware of the odds," he said. "And I have won seven elections against those odds."
Although his backers include entertainment industry heavyweights like Steven Spielberg, Alec Baldwin and Billy Joel, Mr. Bullock has raised only about $500,000, far shy of the $2.5 million campaign war chest provided by the well-organized Suffolk County Republican Committee.
To date, Mr. Gaffney has outspent Mr. Bullock by almost 4 to 1, spending $100,000 a week just for television advertising. Mr. Bullock said he was saving the bulk of his funds for a blitz this week.
An issue that greatly separates the two candidates is Mr. Gaffney's proposed a $1.6 billion budget for 1996, which promises a tax cut of up to 3 percent for some residents. Mr. Bullock contends that the budget figures are wrong and that taxes will rise 7 percent next year because of a $17 million deficit.
Mr. Gaffney defended his budget figures and questioned Mr. Bullock's fiscal record. "What Tony hasn't told you is that he's increased taxes in the Town of East Hampton in five consecutive years."
Republican Party officials say Mr. Bullock is not serious about running for county executive, but is laying the groundwork for a race for Congress against Michael Forbes, a Republican and a strong supporter of House Speaker Newt Gingrich.
But Mr. Bullock said: "I'm not running for Congress. I'm running for County Executive, and I'm going to beat Bob Gaffney."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A Front-Runner's Commercial

 BODY:

BODY: Broadcasts of Senator Bob Dole's first campaign commercial in Iowa, site of the first Presidential primary, begin on Friday. It will later run in other states, including New Hampshire. The 30-second commercial, titled "Historic Conservative Reforms," contrasts Mr. Dole's conservative record with what the advertisement portrays as President Clinton's liberalism.
 
PRODUCER: Stuart Stevens, The Stuart Stevens Group.
 
ON THE SCREEN: The commercial starts with a still picture of Mr. Clinton taking the oath of office in 1993 with his wife, Hillary, looking on. On top of the photograph are the words, "Liberal Agenda." Under it appears a text saying "largest tax increase," "huge spending increases" and "government-run health care." The scene shifts to Mr. Dole, smiling and waving, amid a group of well-scrubbed young people waving American flags, smiling or working in a manufacturing plant. Under these scenes is a text ticking off what the commercial calls "conservative reforms" for which Mr. Dole takes credit: "middle-class tax cuts," "balanced-budget plan" and "real welfare reform."
 
TELEVISION SCRIPT: Announcer: "From Day 1, Bill Clinton shocks America with his liberal agenda -- the largest tax increase in history, huge spending increases, government-run health care. Bob Dole leads the fight against the Clinton agenda. Dole rallies the nation and Congress passes historic conservative reforms: true middle-class tax cuts, the first balanced-budget plan in a generation and real welfare reform, putting people back to work."
The spot ends with a close-up of Mr. Dole addressing a campaign rally in an emphatic voice. "I am not afraid to lead, and I know the way," he says.
 
ACCURACY: It is not true that the $240 billion tax increase approved by Congress in 1993 at Mr. Clinton's behest is the largest in American history. When adjusted for inflation -- the only way to make comparisons of dollar amounts from different years -- a tax increase engineered by Mr. Dole in 1982, when he was the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was larger. Mr. Dole's claim to have rallied the nation to get Congress to pass several conservative proposals is also dubious. It was Speaker Newt Gingrich, not Mr. Dole, who largely developed the conservative agenda known as the Contract With America.
 
SCORECARD: This is clearly a front-runner's commercial, made for a candidate so far ahead of his rivals for the Republican nomination they may need a bloodhound to pick up his scent. Mr. Dole makes no mention of the other Republican contenders, instead attacking Mr. Clinton -- whom he refers to as "Bill Clinton," rather than by his title of President -- as if the general election campaign has already begun. In keeping with this strategy, Mr. Dole's tag line seeks to contrast what he claims is his steady, focused leadership with Mr. Clinton's purported flip-flopping style.

HEADLINE: Panel Seeks U.S. Pledge on Bosnia War Criminals

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The international tribunal on war crimes in Bosnia has formally asked the United States to make the surrender of indicted suspects a condition for any peace accord, a tribunal official said today. It also plans to indict 30 more people by the end of the year.
The commission is investigating whether Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, or any other Serbian officials are implicated in war crimes, the official said. 
 While the panel's actions and its request about the surrender of suspected war criminals have no direct effects on the peace talks that began on Tuesday in Dayton, Ohio, they could complicate the negotiators' already difficult task.
Two of the central figures in the Balkan crisis, Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander, and Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, already face war crimes indictments. It seemed unlikely that the Bosnian Serbs would accept any accord under which the two would have to be turned over to prosecutors.
As President of Serbia, the dominant partner in what remains of federal Yugoslavia, Mr. Milosevic is regarded by American officials as an instrumental figure in the peace talks among Balkan leaders at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. "We cannot deny that he is a suspect," the tribunal official said, referring to Mr. Milosevic. "He is a suspect. So are many others."
Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Secretary of State in the waning days of the Bush Administration, asserted nearly three years ago that Mr. Milosevic and several other high-ranking Serbian and Croatian officials were possibly war criminals. He cited their "political or command responsibility" in connection with the Bosnian Serbs' early "ethnic cleansing" campaigns against Bosnian Muslims.
No charges have been brought against Mr. Milosevic, but the United Nations tribunal has indicted 43 Bosnian Serb and Croatian officials for war crimes. The July 24 indictment of General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic focused on their leadership role in the "ethnic cleansing" and reported massacres and organized rapes that marked the first months of the Bosnian war.
Senior Clinton Administration officials have publicly and emphatically insisted in recent days that there will be no amnesty for those charged with war crimes in Bosnia.
Indicted war criminals, the White House officials say, will not be allowed to run for office in any post-war election the United States supervises. Any country that harbors war criminals, they say, will not be allowed to participate in international organizations like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, or the United Nations. At best, General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic can hope to be exiles in their homeland.
But American officials say privately that the Dayton talks may not go as far in guaranteeing the arrest of indicted war crimes suspects as the tribunal has asked. Administration officials say they have drafted proposals for all sides to cooperate with the war crimes inquiries. But the refusal of one to do so, one official said, would not be a "show stopper."
"We 're going to do as much as is realistic," one official said. "We're not going to take on a mission that may be unachievable and make it hostage to the larger peace settlement."
The tribunal's hopes that the United States would make war crimes prosecutions a cornerstone of any peace deal were conveyed in a letter from Richard J. Goldstone, the chief prosecutor for the United Nations commission, to Madeleine K. Albright, the American delegate to the United Nations, American officials said.
The letter also raised questions about whether the United States had turned over all of the evidence it had gathered about reported recent Bosnian Serb atrocities after the fall of the United Nations-designated "safe area" of Srebrenica. American officials say they have handed over all its evidence.
Administration officials said that a host of questions about the handling of war crimes remain unresolved.
Mr. Milosevic has told American officials, for example, that he will arrange for Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic to leave the political stage in Bosnia. But that does not address the question of where the two Bosnian Serb leaders would live. American officials said that if Serbia itself harbored war criminals, Belgrade would not be eligible for the international aid it needs to rebuild its economy.
But what if the two Bosnian Serb leaders remain as residents of the newly-created Bosnian Serb autonomous region within Bosnia? American officials say the sanctions would apply to the Bosnian Serb province as long as it gave refuge to war criminals.
The American officials added, however, that it was not yet clear how such economic pressure could be applied to one part of what is supposed to be a unified Bosnia.
The war crimes tribunal was created by the United Nations, and all members are obliged to arrest anyone charged under its authority. That means Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic have a very limited number of nations to which they could flee.
It is not clear how much progress the tribunal has made in its investigation of Mr. Milosevic. The United States has shared highly classified intelligence data with the tribunal, some of it with the proviso that it only be used to develop other leads.
The tribunal official said that a case against an incumbent president would have to be able to withstand "international scrutiny" and could only be based on the testimony of eyewitnesses who would be available for cross-examination and testimony in open court.
This is particularly difficult in the case of political leaders like Mr. Milosevic who might be charged with "political or command responsibility" for war crimes.
There has been speculation since the Bosnian war began in April 1992 about the role of Mr. Milosevic and the Belgrade-based military officers who provided crucial assistance to the fledgling Bosnian Serb army.
A former American official said the evidence provided to the United Nations in 1992 by Mr. Eagleburger suggested that the Bosnian Serbs' "ethnic cleansing" campaign of Muslim areas of Bosnia had been coordinated by military leaders in Belgrade. The documents, this official said, included intercepts of conversations on military radio networks.
Earlier this year, American and European officials disclosed that the Yugoslav Army, over which Mr. Milosevic has political authority, was continuing to funnel materiel and other essential supplies to their Serbian comrades in Bosnia.
There has been speculation in Washington that the tribunal was delaying its indictment of Mr. Milosevic at the request of American officials eager to work out a peace settlement. The tribunal official adamantly denied that charge.
"There's been no political interference at any level," the tribunal official said. "We're targeting all the people we regard as potentially responsible for the crimes."
One issue that has been settled, American officials said, was whether the international force sent to monitor the peace accord will make an active effort to find and arrest war crime suspects inside Bosnia. They will not.
Senior officials said a war crimes suspect like General Mladic would be arrested only if the peacekeeping troops came across them in their normal duties, such as manning checkpoints or patrolling roads.
"If they were to encounter war criminals, they would have the authority to arrest them, but they're not going to comb the countryside and track down war criminals," one official said.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 4, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about the international tribunal on war crimes in Bosnia referred incorrectly to correspondence between the tribunal and the United States Government. A confidential letter asking that any peace accord compel cooperation with the tribunal's inquiries was sent to Madeleine K. Albright, the American delegate to the United Nations, by the tribunal's president, Antonio Cassese, not by its chief prosecutor.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
More Talk of Possible Sumitomo-Daiwa Deal

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Sumitomo Bank Ltd. is negotiating to take over the beleaguered Daiwa Bank, creating the world's largest bank, two leading Japanese newspapers reported today, bolstering widespread speculation on such a deal in the Japanese financial community.
Masaji Tamura, a spokesman for Daiwa Bank, said of the reports: "There has been nothing decided yet about a merger with Sumitomo Bank. I think that all the Japanese press reports have been written with too much certainty about this." Nevertheless, it is not unusual for word of pending negotiations to be leaked to Japanese newspapers, allowing companies to gauge the reaction before committing themselves. 
 On the other hand, Sumitomo's president, Toshio Morikawa, suggested to reporters that a merger was possible, although he declined to disclose details, saying only that Sumitomo would assist Daiwa with its American operations in whatever way possible.
There have been rumors that a Sumitoma-Daiwa merger is a possibility, but today's reports went further and quoted inside sources as saying that some form of agreement had already been reached.
"Sumitomo Bank and Daiwa Bank have basically agreed to merge next fall and they are going to enter into discussions of concrete issues," The Nihon Keizei Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily, reported under a big headline in this morning's editions.
If Sumitomo and Daiwa merge, the combined bank would have assets of more than $600 billion, eclipsing what was expected to be the world's biggest bank: the merger of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. and Mitsubishi Bank Ltd., which is scheduled for April 1996. That institution would have assets of roughly $550 billion.
Reports about the merger come two days after Daiwa was indicted in the United States for its involvement in a $1.1 billion trading scandal. Daiwa was also ordered by the American authorities to close all of its operations in the United States, while the Japanese Ministry of Finance also ordered Daiwa to scale back its international operations.
Two Japanese newspapers cited industry sources, but several executives at the two banks would not discuss the issue this morning when they were reached at home.
Most Japanese newspapers carried reports on the prospects for a merger, and in recent weeks, the market has focused on speculation that Daiwa Bank's reputation has been so tarnished that it may need a white knight to save it.
Daiwa's new president, Takashi Kaiho, said on Friday that Sumitomo had agreed to help Daiwa dispose of its American operations. Daiwa executives declined to release details about the transfer and about whether all the American branches would be sold, or whether some would be closed and a few transferred to Sumitomo.
Speculation in recent weeks had focused on other possible takeover candidates for Daiwa. When asked why Sumitomo was playing a role in helping assume Daiwa's American operations, Daiwa executives said that the relations between the two banks were close and that they were both based in Osaka, Japan.
The Yomiuri Shimbun, another major Japanese daily, quoted an unidentified executive at Sumitomo Bank as saying that the merger would have to be delayed for about a year.
"Both banks share in wanting to go in the same direction," The Yomiuri Shimbun reported. "On the timing of the merger, next April may be impossible. The earliest would be next October."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS MAY PAY MORE FOR HEALTH AS CONGRESS CUTS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Businesses tallying the effects of projected cuts in Government health care spending are beginning to worry that they will have to help make up the difference.
At the heart of their concerns is cost-shifting -- the notion that as projected Medicare and Medicaid spending shrinks, hospitals and doctors will demand that employers and their insured workers pay a greater share of health care costs. 
 Economists and Washington business lobbyists warn that millions of working people and their employers could end up paying more for health care and that many people who work for small businesses could lose their insurance altogether.
"If you cut your price to one customer, you increase it to another," said Raymond Brusca, a vice president of the Black & Decker Corporation, the maker of power tools. "Whatever gets squeezed out on the Federal side through budgetary constraints will be shifted to the nonpublic sector. All we're doing is shifting dollars around."
Michael Rourke, a senior vice president with the A.& P. grocery chain, said, "If these cuts go through, there will be an increase in insurance premiums, because hospitals and other health care workers will have to cover the costs now provided by Medicare."
By one estimate, the increase in employers' costs from the projected $270 billion reduction in Medicare and Medicaid spending over seven years would be $90 billion. That figure would increase if dwindling Government payments result in the closing of some public hospitals, pushing more of the uninsured and underinsured into private-sector hospitals that in turn would tack the added costs onto private payers' bills.
Republican sponsors of the spending restraints dispute the predictions of cost-shifting. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he was confident that the program he has shepherded would not result in costs being transferred to the private sector. He added that limits on malpractice claims against doctors and hospitals, along with new hospital- and doctor-sponsored health plans encouraged by the Republican legislation, would produce "efficiencies" that would make cost-shifting less likely.
In general, business organizations have been among the prime supporters of the Republican program to shrink the Federal Government and cut taxes. Groups like the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and the Business Roundtable have not wavered in their endorsements. Lobbyists for business groups say most of their clients are more concerned about reducing the deficit and putting a lid on the Medicare payroll tax than the possibility of higher health care costs.
Their clients, though, are just beginning to hear about the increased costs that the Medicare and Medicaid changes may shift onto employers and employees -- in particular, the 55 million people covered by traditional fee-for-service health plans.
"The containment of Medicare costs, the way they're going after it, is a double-edged sword," said Ken Heller, president of the Nutech Environmental Corporation, a Denver company with nine employees. "Reducing payments to doctors and hospitals will encourage cost-shifting to small business."
That has been the pattern in the wake of previous efforts to curtail Medicare spending. In 1993, for example, hospitals said they absorbed losses of 11 percent on treating Medicare beneficiaries and 7 percent on Medicaid patients, but made up the losses by charging private payers a 29 percent markup.
"We are likely to see health care premium increases back in the double digits as a result of this legislation," said John Galles, president of National Small Business United, an advocacy group in Washington.
The yearly increase in employer health costs per employee reached 18.6 percent in 1988 and stayed above 10 percent for the next five years. But that trend reversed and costs actually fell in 1994, as medical inflation abated and employers moved more workers into lower-cost health plans, according to Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm.
Many corporate health care experts note that the Republican plan, after much internal debate, does not include strong financial incentives to encourage elderly people to switch to H.M.O.'s and other managed-care health plans.
 "Unless Congress gives Medicare patients an incentive to move from fee-for-service to more cost-efficient managed care, the patients won't make the move and that will undercut efforts at reform," said Jack Stair, a senior consultant with E. I. du Pont de Nemours, who studied the issue for the Financial Executives Institute, a business advocacy group.
Cole Tremain, a vice president of the LTV Corporation, the big steelmaker, said the Medicare cutbacks were "not being matched by reduced benefits or increased costs to retirees in higher deductibles or co-payments" that might make people think twice before visiting a doctor.
Employees who are still working will come under renewed pressure from their companies to move into health maintenance organizations and other managed-care health plans. And many experts say that traditional fee-for-service health plans will lose even more members.
For some procedures, LTV already pays about 50 percent more, on average, than Medicare. For example, LTV pays $33,519 for a coronary bypass with catheterization, while Medicare pays $21,455, Mr. Tremain said. By one estimate, with the projected impact of cost-shifting, the same procedure could cost the company $34,693 seven years from now.
"Our real concern is that Congress not make an already serious problem into one that would be a grave issue for American industry," Mr. Tremain said.
A study by Lewin-VHI, a health care research firm based in Alexandria, Va., concluded that about 45 percent of the projected reductions in Medicare payments to hospitals and doctors, or at least $66 billion, would be shifted. Those shifts would add 2.3 percent to the costs for employers, employees and self-insured individuals, the firm concluded. The Lewin study was done for the National Leadership Coalition on Health Care, a group of employers, unions and consumer and medical groups. Other estimates of the potential shift range from 25 percent to 50 percent.
An estimated $24 billion would be cut from projected Medicaid spending and passed on to private payers, the Lewin study said. This would add about 3.2 percent to their costs. "We low-balled the Medicaid estimate, because of the uncertainty" about how states would administer the program, said John Sheils, a vice president of Lewin-VHI.
The study said that employers, in turn, would require their employees to absorb much of the increased costs "in the form of reduced wages," truncated or denied pay increases, and less generous health coverage. About 523,000 people would lose their insurance coverage entirely in 2002, the final year of the proposed Government spending restraints, the study said. Medicaid cuts might leave five million more without insurance.
Even without the cost-shifting phenomenon, Stephen H. Long, an analyst with the Rand Corporation, said the number of uninsured Americans would surge to 55 million from 41 million as the population grows, if employers continue present trends in health coverage.
"If Medicaid is cut, the number would go even higher," he said.
Most experts said companies with employees enrolled in health maintenance organizations and other managed health plans would be relatively insulated from the Government spending shifts, because they would have the upper hand in negotiating rates with hospitals and medical groups.
But even companies well protected by managed-care arrangements are likely to face increases if the number of uninsured people grows. "The uninsured are going to need care, and those costs are going to be picked up by the businesses and citizens that pay health care bills," Walter B. Maher, a Washington-based health care expert with the Chrysler Corporation, said.
Small employers are scrambling to join health care purchasing groups that would give them more bargaining power, but such groups are scarce in many parts of the country. Indeed they are prohibited in some states.
"The employer with three or four employees is still having a hard time out there, shopping for health care," said Mark Isakowitz, a lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business.
But he said his group had been more concerned about the prospect of increases in payroll taxes to pay for Medicare than about health care cost issues. Very small businesses often pay more in payroll taxes than in income taxes. "Providing health insurance is voluntary," he said. "Payroll taxes are not."

HEADLINE: An Underdog Democrat Is Gaining in Mississippi

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 2

 BODY:
If it is still possible for a progressive Democrat to win statewide office in the Deep South, the pollsters and consultants say, it is by forging a coalition between black voters and white women.
That theory will meet a significant test in next Tuesday's election for governor of Mississippi. Although Mississippi is one of the most conservative states in the nation and has enjoyed robust economic health in recent years, Dick Molpus, a Democrat, has managed to stay within striking distance of Gov. Kirk Fordice, a Republican, by seeking a large black turnout and appealing aggressively to women. 
 In that effort, Mr. Molpus, who has been Mississippi's Secretary of State for 12 years, has received some unexpected help from Mr. Fordice.
Two weeks ago, during a lunch meeting with reporters, Mr. Fordice mockingly imitated the soft drawl of Mr. Molpus's wife, Sally, who appears in a television advertisement criticizing the Governor's record on education. It provided just the opening that Mr. Molpus's stagnant campaign needed.
Mr. Molpus, 46, quickly condemned Mr. Fordice for insulting his wife, and added, "Frankly, I'd like to take him out behind the woodshed." A few days later, after a televised debate, Mr. Fordice approached Mr. Molpus and told him, according to Mr. Molpus, "This 61-year-old man will take you to the woodshed," adding, in Mississippi vernacular, that he would harm him.
The exchange, which the Fordice campaign refuses to confirm or deny, has helped Mr. Molpus focus attention on Mr. Fordice's bombastic brand of Mississippi machismo, and Mr. Fordice's approval ratings with women have deteriorated correspondingly.
A poll of registered voters conducted by Mason-Dixon Political/ Media Research from Oct. 30 to Nov. 1 found that Mr. Fordice's 20-point lead in August had shrunk to 5 percentage points -- 45 percent for Mr. Fordice to 40 percent for Mr. Molpus. Among women, Mr. Molpus has turned a 49 percent to 37 percent deficit into a 46 percent to 39 percent advantage, according to the poll, which has a margin of sampling error of three percentage points.
Since Mr. Fordice's indiscretion, Mr. Molpus has positioned himself as a Mississippi gentleman defending the honor of his aggrieved wife. At a forum at Mississippi State University here today, he told Mr. Fordice, "Any person who would treat someone else with that type of arrogance and contempt does not deserve to be Governor."
Mr. Fordice, a construction magnate from Vicksburg who was elected four years ago as Mississippi's first Republican governor since 1874, has a well-chronicled history of government-by-bluster. He has offended blacks by threatening to call out the National Guard if the courts forced him to raise taxes in order to increase spending on historically black colleges. He has offended Jews by referring to the United States as "a Christian nation."
The Molpus campaign has forsaken subtlety in portraying Mr. Fordice as a man out of control. "I think they've got him on some kind of calmer," said Patsy Brumfield, the campaign's press secretary, "but it's always possible he might not take his pill and he could go off like a volcano."
The Fordice campaign, meanwhile, has tried to soften the Governor's edges by pairing him in television commercials with one of his young grandchildren. "I'll be tough while I'm Governor so our grandchildren, like Nathan, and all our children, won't have it so tough in Mississippi when they grow up," he says.
If victorious, Mr. Fordice would become the first Mississippi governor elected to a second term since the state began allowing governors to succeed themselves, in 1986. Republicans also have long-shot hopes of gaining a majority in the State Senate, where Democrats now hold a 34-to-18 edge.
In addition to the state's increasingly Republican leanings, the Republican Party has the benefit of what Mr. Fordice calls "the Mississippi miracle." Since he took office, the state has added 115,000 jobs, an increase of more than 12 percent.
Two-thirds of Mississippi's job growth has been in retailing and the service sector, where wages fall below average. Almost a quarter of the new jobs have been generated by the state's boom in casino gambling, an industry that Mr. Fordice once opposed (although not enough to return the industry's campaign contributions).
Both candidates support cutting taxes, with Mr. Fordice pushing for a three-year, 10 percent cut in income taxes and Mr. Molpus proposing a 50 percent cut in the state's 7 percent tax on groceries. That plan, Mr. Molpus said, should have special appeal to women, as should his emphasis on improving Mississippi's perennially substandard schools.
Yet, even Molpus supporters acknowledge that the economy and the state's relatively low unemployment rate of 6 percent give Mr. Fordice a strong platform. "To defeat an incumbent who's sitting on top of that is awfully difficult," said Joseph B. Parker, a political scientist at the University of Southern Mississippi.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dick Molpus, right, a progressive Democrat in conservative Mississippi, has been closing in on Gov. Kirk Fordice, left, in their race for governor. Mr. Molpus, seizing the initiative after an indiscretion by the Republican Governor, has forged a coalition of blacks and white women. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mixed Reports for New York and New Jersey

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York State fell to 6.3 percent in October from 6.8 percent in September, but the number of people with jobs also declined, the Labor Department reported yesterday. In New Jersey, the jobless rate increased to 5.8 percent from 5.7 percent, but employment increased.
In New York, the number of residents employed in October fell by 38,000, to 7.99 million. The size of the labor force shrank by 91,000 people, to 8.52 million. 
 The decline in employment followed three consecutive months in which New York recorded its highest total job counts since it sank into recession in 1990.
So far this year, New York has added 81,500 jobs in the private sector, at a rate that is 11 percent higher than the national average. Manufacturing employment, while declining over all in the United States, has risen by 5,700 jobs in New York.
 New York City, which accounts for about half the state's work force, added 15,100 jobs between January and September, according to the city comptroller's office. But the number of jobs in the city's public sector declined by 12,000 during the period.
Data for Connecticut will come out later. It is not one of the 11 states for which the Federal Government provides jobs data when the national employment figures are released each month.
New York officials welcomed yesterday's report. "Business has renewed confidence in New York State," said Charles A. Gargano, Commissioner of the State Department of Economic Development.
If so, that confidence has required a lot of coaxing. State and city officials last month offered one of the most generous packages of subsidies ever provided in New York City to persuade the board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to cancel plans to move to Jersey City. The move would have cost New York as many as 5,000 jobs.
 When Oxford Health Plans Inc., a managed-care company, announced last month that it had hired 500 people at its operation in White Plains, it praised the help provided by Gov. George E. Pataki's administration.
Despite the increase in New Jersey's unemployment rate last month, the number of residents employed rose 40,000 from September, to 3.84 million.
Still, job growth has slowed in New Jersey this year to a monthly average of 3,700 through September, compared with 6,100 last year. Chris Biddle, a spokesman for the New Jersey Industry and Business Association, said manufacturing employment had fallen by 12,900 jobs since last year, to 494,000 jobs, the lowest level since the 1930's.
The state's retail businesses have also suffered. The Jamesway Corporation and Petrie Retail Inc., two retailers based in Secaucus, have entered bankruptcy proceedings.
Jamesway, a discount chain, dismissed 200 people at its headquarters last month and said it would close all its 90 stores. It employs 5,900 in several states. Petrie, a women's retailer operating 1,700 stores under various names, expects to close at least 276 stores.

HEADLINE: Russians in a Panic Over New Currency: The U.S. $100 Bill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 3

 BODY:
It is unlikely that most Americans will pay much attention when the United States Treasury introduces a redesigned $100 bill in January. The old bill will still be accepted everywhere of course, and it's not exactly as if hundred-dollar notes are the coin of the realm.
But things couldn't be more different here, because Russians are completely obsessed with C-notes. They covet, hoard and trade them more than in any country other than America itself. 
 Despite the fact that it is illegal to use dollars for retail trade, people who can scrape them together routinely use hundred-dollar bills to buy cars, trucks or houses. Whenever they can get away with it, wage earners demand their salaries in hundreds, too.
No currency in any part of the former Soviet Union -- not the German mark, the British pound or the yen, and certainly not the ruble -- carries anything like the buying power and prestige of the hundred-dollar bill. According to the best guesses of the Russian Central Bank, there is at least $15 billion in United States currency circulating through Russia -- more than in any other foreign country -- and much of it is in hundred-dollar bills.
So it didn't take long for people to realize that the new hundred would make quite a splash here. But nobody was prepared for what has already happened and what might come to pass when the bills actually show up on the streets: Word of the new bill has filled people with such dread that many are already trying to dump their current hundreds and exchange them for marks.
Exchange counters, which routinely reject hundreds that are dirty, old or marred in even the smallest way, are already beginning to charge an extra commission on all old bills.
"We have a real problem," said Vitaly E. Sidorov, executive director of the Association of Russian Banks, which represents most of the country's biggest financial institutions.
"I think it's going to get bigger and bigger. People may simply refuse to accept old bills when there are new bills. Currency exchanges will tell people to go away and if we can't convince people that their money is still good the black market will return and prosper."
The United States Government, which is introducing the bills because they will be harder for counterfeiters to copy, has made several attempts to reassure Russians that their cash will always be welcome whether it is clean or dirty, new or old.
Explanations of the fact that all American currency is created equal have been delivered repeatedly and unequivocally. But in countries like Russia currency can be a deeply emotional issue and promises about cash mean nothing to people who have watched in horror as the ruble become almost worthless in a few short years.
"All American Federal Reserve Banks will accept all old-design U.S. banknotes at 100 percent of face value forever," Theodore E. Allison, a senior Treasury official, told Russian bankers on a recent visit here to discuss the new bills.
Moreover, he said, the United States Government will make certain that everyone who wants new hundreds can get them so there will be no need to panic.
Soothing words, perhaps, but currency reform in Russia usually means exchanging old money for new money. And when that happens, most recently in 1991, the result is always the same: desperate citizens stampede banks hoping to get new money before it runs out. Panic and currency reform run as one in Russia.
That is why there has been such a public relations offensive about the new bill. Front-page articles in major newspapers have repeatedly made the point that the old bills are as good as the new bills, and so have television news shows. Bankers clearly understand it, but a public that has grown deeply suspicious of any government that changes its money and says everything will be all right could hardly be more upset.
Most people standing in line at a shabby currency exchange office in central Moscow this week looked upon the introduction of a new hundred as a personal insult. Russians have so little faith in their own money, which has been ravaged by inflation and devalued continually since the fall of the Soviet Union, that even the notion of change scares them.
"We have no order here at all," said Nadezhda V. Pashanova, 38, who was waiting patiently in line to change a hundred-dollar bill. "In Russia it is always hard to predict what will happen, but we always expect the worst. I have already started having problems changing the old notes so I have had to get 5 percent less than usual for them."
Like most people interviewed, she said she would exchange her hundreds for new ones the moment she had the chance.
Most exchange offices in Russia refuse to accept any bills issued before 1988, despite a directive sent in 1993 from Russia's Central Bank to all commercial banks informing them they are obliged to take all American currency they receive, even bills that are 75 years old. Every person who uses hundred-dollar bills in Russia -- and that's every person who can -- has been turned away at least once by a skeptical hotel clerk, a rigid banker or even an obstinate baby sitter.
"I went to three banks and an exchange office," a teary-eyed Svetlana Zolorariova said last week after selling an expensive lacquer box and receiving her payment the usual way -- in hundreds. She then produced the offending note: a 1993 hundred-dollar bill so crisp it seemed as if it might crack.
"Look there," Miss Zolorariova said, pointing to two tiny ink marks on the back of the bill. "Nobody is going to take that."
There is at least some reason to take that second look at hundred-dollar bills here: estimates of counterfeiting in Russia range from significant to incredible. American officials say the amount of counterfeit currency in circulation is minimal, but as one senior Treasury official who asked not to be identified said, "To the degree counterfeiting is a problem it is a problem in Russia."
And with two-thirds of all hundred-dollar bills in circulation outside the United States, most counterfeiters don't waste their time on twenties or tens. The new hundred will help reduce the threat, and in an age when color laser copiers and digital technology can make the fake look strikingly real, nobody is arguing that the threat is getting smaller.
"You can say anything you want about what we should take and what we shouldn't," said a clerk at a currency exchange near Red Square. "But why is America of all countries issuing new currency if the old currency isn't a problem? So if your job is to earn a living exchanging money, you are telling me you would treat the safe new bills exactly like the bills they already know how to copy? What kind of sense does that make?"

HEADLINE: Along Bosnia Dividing Line, Federation Is Only on Paper

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzego vina, Nov. 3

 BODY:
To speak with her daughter and granddaughters in Los Angeles, Adila Glavovic must use the telephone of a friend who lives 10 minutes away, across a river in her hometown of Mostar.
On the other side is also the apartment she once lived in, groceries that are more affordable and the medical care her husband needs. But the west side of Mostar is largely forbidden to Mrs. Glavovic and people who, like her, are refugees in their own city. 
 The Croats, who govern the west side of the city, make it almost impossible for the Muslims, who live in the east, where the Bosnian Government has control, to cross the Neverta River. This divide exists in spite of the fact that Mostar, a 500-year-old city in a narrow mountainous valley, was supposed to be the showcase of the Bosnian-Croatian federation forged by Washington last year.
But if anything these are two peoples moving apart, not together. Each side has different license plates, currency and passports, and diametrically different views of what Bosnia should be.
Several days of travel through Croatian-held areas of central and western Bosnia show the federation to be little more than a piece of paper. That piece of paper, drafted to bring an end to fighting between Muslims and Croats, is also central to the American plan for peace in Bosnia, and its importance was underscored this week when negotiators in Ohio announced yet another agreement to strengthen the federation.
"It doesn't exist," a senior Western diplomat in Zagreb said. "We invented the federation and forced the sides into it."
Far from seeing the alliance between the Croats and the Bosnian Government as an enduring one, some diplomats and United Nations officials in the region fear that the alliance of Muslims and Croats might end in conflict between them after a peace agreement is signed.
Washington's peace proposal divides Bosnia between the Muslim-Croat federation (51 percent) and the Serbs (49 percent). In reality Bosnia's Croats control 20 percent of the territory of Bosnia, and the Muslim-dominated Government in Sarajevo, 30 percent. There are now an estimated 350,000 ethnic Croats in western Bosnia (about half the number before the war) most of them in the Herzegovina region.
"If there were a referendum, the people would vote not 90 percent, but 99 percent, not to be part of the federation," said Krunoslav Kordic, a Croat who is mayor of Capljina, 25 miles southwest of Mostar.
The Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, said in a recent interview that the Croatian people in the region want to be part of Bosnia, but that paramilitary units with aid from Zagreb are stoking the flames of separatism. But Western officials in the Mostar area say that Mayor Kordic's view of public opinion appears to be closer to the truth.
In front of Mr. Kordic's office, among the evergreens and leafy trees, flies the red, white and blue flag of the Croatian Republic of Herzog-Bosna. Asked where the Bosnian flag was, he said simply, "We don't recognize it." Bosnia's flag, with gold fleurs-de-lis on a blue background, is seldom seen in Herzegovina, nor are federation policemen.
The self-declared republic, which has its capital in Mostar, has not been internationally recognized. But it is a reality. It delivers the mail, collects taxes, generates electricity, educates children, and with its own 50,000-man army defends the territory of Herzegovina (with help from neighboring Croatia). Police officers wear the same blue uniform as the Croatian police, with an almost imperceptible alteration in the red and white checkerboard shield on their shoulder patches.
Don't try to buy beer or bananas, gasoline or shaving cream in Herzegovina with the Bosnian dinar. The legal currency in Herzegovina is the Croatian kuna, or the German mark.
The Bosnian Croats carry Croatian passports, not Bosnian ones. They vote in Croatia's elections, and in last week's parliamentary elections, they did so overwhelmingly for the Croatian Democratic Party of President Franjo Tudjman.
Under pressure from Washington and the European Union, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has publicly vowed support for the federation. But Western officials say they do not believe that his public stance matches his real feelings.
"In Zagreb, they don't want it to exist," a Western diplomat there said about Croatia's attitude toward the federation. Mr. Tudjman is under strong American pressure to go along with the federation.
One of the provisions of the 1994 federation agreement was that all people forced out of their villages during the Muslim-Croat war would be allowed to return home.
That has not happened. "The federation has brought about no integration of ethnic groups," said Kris Janowski, a spokesman here for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
This week's agreement in Ohio aims, in fact, to allow 300 Muslim families and 300 Croatian families to return to homes in areas occupied by the other group. Even if it works, these numbers are tiny in a country with nearly 700,000 internal refugees.
Mohammed Elezovic was born in the historic Muslim town of Stolac, where his family's roots go back 400 years. He was expelled by Croats in July 1993. Mr. Elezovic, 55, a professor of Slavic languages, has still not been able to go back, not even to pick up his poetry or albums with pictures of his children.
When Croatian troops recently recaptured the strategic town of Jajce from the Serbs, they moved Croatian civilians back in but did not allow displaced Muslim residents to return to their homes.
The grievances are not one-sided, however.
In Zenica, an industrial city controlled by the Bosnian Government, more than 12,000 of the city's 20,000 Croats have been forced out since the federation agreement was signed, European officials said this week.
"The federation is rubbish," said a 21-year old Croatian man, who said that he is unable to return to his village near Konjic.
There are only two ways to make the federation work, said a United Nations official. One is military force, the kind Washington does not want to use. The other is investing "billions" of dollars in Bosnia, so that there is an economy strong enough to provide jobs for everyone.
But the lesson of Mostar is that spending money is not enough.
In the last 15 months, the European Union has spent more than $200 million to rebuild and reunify this city. The reconstruction has been a success -- children are in schools, the hospital has clean sheets and medicines for patients, traffic lights work, water flows. The work has been carried out on both sides of the city.
What disturbs European Union officials in Mostar is that, because political unification has not been accomplished, the facilities are essentially segregated.
For example, teenagers from the east cannot attend high school in the west as they did before the war, and special permission is needed for Mrs. Glavovic's husband, who had a heart attack five years ago, to go to the hospital, which is in the west.
The failure of political reunification is why Mrs. Glavovic cannot call her daughter without applying for a permit and waiting 10 days for permission to make the 10-minute walk, and why she and her husband cannot return to their three-bedroom west Mostar apartment with balcony views of the valley, even though they can see their former home from where they now live as refugees with their relatives.
It is why reconstruction of the 400-year-old mosque in east Mostar is hampered. The quarry with the right quality of stones is on the other side of a river, explained Hussein Lulic, 71, a stonemason working at the mosque.
Croatian officials do not deny that they are restricting movement. If they did, they would be "demographically occupied" by the Muslims, said Mile Puljic, the deputy mayor of west Mostar, with the Muslims from the east coming west.
With money from Croatian and German business executives, west Mostar is thriving and lively -- like West Berlin was -- with sidewalk cafes where Croatian soldiers in camouflage engage in conversation with chic young women.
East Mostar, which was poorer before the war, and was more heavily damaged by Croatian shelling during the fighting, has suffered from a lack of significant private foreign investment since the end of the war. Muslims are still struggling to dig out from the rubble, and an old man was seen this week poking through garbage in search of something of value to him.
"The people live in a ghetto," Hans Koschnick, a German who is the European Union's administrator for Mostar, said about the Muslims in east Mostar. "I know something of ghettos. I don't like it."
As for the federation, what the Bosnian Government wants is a country built on the principle of one person one vote, the basis of the American proposal. It would like at least Herzegovina to be included, and the Serbian territories as well.
The Bosnian Croats, if they cannot get unification with Croatia, want to be an essentially independent state in a confederation with Bosnia. But the Bosnian Government rejected this two years ago, and it is not part of the American peace plan.
Mr. Puljic, the deputy mayor of west Mostar, calls the American idea "totally unacceptable."
"To Mr. Holbrooke, I wish him all the best," he said, referring to Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator. "But it is not as simple as he supposes."
 
SNAPSHOT

Although the European Community has spent $200 million in Mostar in an effort to rebuild and reunify the city, it remains politically and physically divided into eastern and western portions on either side of the Neretva River; the movement of people between the two is severely restricted.

HEADLINE: Rage Grows in Okinawa Over U.S. Military Bases

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: GINOWAN, Okinawa, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Children are flipping through their books and a teacher is passing out note pads when suddenly the floor trembles and the classroom is engulfed in a roar.
It is not an earthquake, or Armageddon, but an interruption that occurs at least hourly: A military helicopter soars into the sky from the American air base next door. 
 "Almost every time a plane flies over, I lose my concentration, I raise my voice, or the kids raise their voices," said Miyoko Uema, the 42-year-old librarian at No. 2 Futenma Elementary School here in Okinawa, in the south of Japan. "When the sound comes, the day automatically stops."
To listen to Okinawans, the American military presence here is not a source of comfort or protection, but an annoyance and a threat.
The result is a growing outcry to evict the American troops and American bases from Japan, or at least curb their presence. The uproar, backed by a recent protest of more than 50,000 demonstrators, is threatening to spoil the summit meeting this month between President Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama.
The meeting, which is to begin Nov. 17, was supposed to solidify the military alliance between Japan and the United States, based on the presence of nearly 60,000 American troops in Japan. But now Mr. Clinton is set to arrive in Japan just as record numbers of people are wondering whether American bases are necessary at all.
Part of the anger in Okinawa is directed at the Tokyo Government, which has never really paid much attention to what Okinawan people think. But the rage of the Okinawans -- particularly after the rape in September of a 12-year-old girl, in which three American servicemen have been charged -- echoes in some ways the discontent and rising nationalism of the Philippines in the late 1980's. As in the Philippines, many leaders want to keep the American bases but are reluctant to speak out against the rising tide of public opinion.
Yet even if no one knows where the tide of anger will lead, few doubt that the tide has been growing. For people like Rino Kayo, a 12-year-old girl clutching her notebook outside a classroom at the No. 2 Elementary School, the reasons are palpable.
"It's very scary," she said of the helicopters and jets. "I heard that a plane once crashed." In the last 23 years, Okinawans have seen 36 air crashes. Four years ago, a helicopter made an emergency landing and erupted in fire near the school.
"I would like the bases to just disappear," said Tamotsu Tokeshi, a homeowner whose seven-bedroom, two-story house is 765 yards from the double airstrip of Japan's largest air base, Kadena.
Mr. Tokeshi, who keeps a sound meter on his roof, says the American jets start revving their engines at 4 A.M. and run late into the night. For most of this year, daily noise levels have reached 100 decibels, compared with the acceptable standard in Japan of 70 decibels. So Mr. Tokeshi has filed a suit, along with more than 900 other local residents, to demand that the flight schedules be changed.
To damp the noise, local residents often reinforce their windows, thicken their walls or add a layer of tile to their rooftops, but there is little they can do about crime. Since 1972, 4,700 crimes have been committed by American military men, including a dozen murders, according to the Okinawan police.
Crime by American military men has actually been on the decline, but the rape of the sixth grader in September seems to have deeply touched Okinawans.
"Since the rape, people's feelings against the bases have become stronger," said Yoshiko Chibana, a 36-year-old mother of two children. "I feel it very keenly because I have children now, so it's not just someone else's problem."
Shuden Teruya, a retired Government worker in the Okinawan city of Naha, feels so strongly about ousting the bases that he is willing to forgo the majority of his income to see it happen. Mr. Teruya is a landlord who leases nearly two acres of residential land to Kadena Air Base, and along with nearly 3,000 local landlords, or about one percent of all the local military landowners, Mr. Teruya is refusing to renew his lease, which expires in 1997.
"I hate war, and I want the bases to be removed entirely," said Mr. Teruya, whose brothers, in contrast, are renewing their land leases. "We Okinawans are rather gentle people. There have been past murders that lead to small protests. But this rape, this time -- well, we feel we cannot put up with any more."
Mr. Teruya refused to renew his lease eight years ago, but the Governor of Okinawa appropriated the land-use rights and gave them to the Americans. But the new Governor, Masahide Ota, says he will not sign over the land-use rights anymore.
The result is that beginning in March, chunks of American bases could revert to the original landowners. In fact, Prime Minister Murayama will probably overrule the Okinawans and himself initiate a long legal proceeding to sign over the land-use rights to the Americans.
To be sure, the overwhelming majority of landowners want to continue renting their land to the American military because they want the rent.
Their uneasiness rises when they look at a 530-acre plot of barren land that the Americans returned in the 1980's. The Government has plans for a big development, but they are mostly still plans.
"For me, all my land assets are being used by the Americans," said Kaoru Shinjo, the president of the Federation of Landowners Association, which represents owners of land leased to the American bases. "So if they just returned them and left without there being any plans for development, the land could turn into wilderness."
Mr. Shinjo and others who like the American presence have not been getting much attention, but they are still numerous. While most people in Okinawa, where 75 percent of American bases and nearly half of the American troops are concentrated, want the Americans out in the long run, overall in Japan there is still a slim plurality in favor of maintaining the United States-Japan Security Treaty.
But the same poll showed 40 percent of Japanese want to scrap the treaty, up from 29 percent before the rape. Because the treaty has been the bulwark of foreign policy for most of the postwar period, the figure has stunned Japanese politicians.
American officials have also been alarmed, and have profusely apologized for the rape. But Defense Secretary William J. Perry said during a visit to Japan this week that the United States cannot close a major base or reduce its troop presence.
Ambassador Walter F. Mondale, said: "It provides stability in the region. The cold war ended in Europe, but it has not quite ended here."
Over the years, the contribution of the bases to the overall economy has fallen from 15 percent in 1972 to about 5 percent. But another withdrawal of sorts also seems to be taking place on the American bases, especially among the nearly 19,000 marines stationed in Okinawa.
Marines, many of whom are young and single, are banned after midnight from Okinawa City, and many unit commanders are admonishing their marines to stay out of trouble over the weekends.
These restrictions seem to have kept marines out of the local shops in general. One reason may be simply that tensions are in the air and that marines no longer feel as welcome as they did.
"I walk down the street and they step aside and walk away from me," said Pfc. Michael Caballero, one of the few servicemen out one evening on the streets of Okinawa City. "We're not all rapists."
Some Japanese and Americans argue, though, that the military breeds a macho atmosphere that allows incidents like the rape to happen.
To be sure, marines interviewed here said they were shocked by the rape, and some have contributed to a collection for the rape victim. Yet part of the problem is that in Japan, the marines have a reputation as a fearless force, trained to kill, and thus somewhat violent.
That reputation is growing as word spreads of the reason that one of the defendants, Marcus D. Gill, a Navy seaman, has reportedly cited for the rape.
"It was just to have fun," said Matsunobu Matsunaga, a Japanese lawyer for one of the defendants in the case. "He said he didn't have money to buy prostitutes."
