HEADLINE: Race for Kentucky Governor Slows to a Trot

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Nov. 1

 BODY:
Staring down at her scrambled eggs and ham this morning at Roundie's Restaurant here, Joan Buckley said she would probably vote Republican in the Kentucky governor's election on Tuesday.
As a retired middle-school teacher, Mrs. Buckley said, she does not much care for the changes in the state's public education policies that were passed in 1990 -- and as she understood it, neither does the Republican candidate, Larry Forgy. 
 Poking a fork at his own ham and eggs, her husband, Delmar, shook his head. "I haven't made up my mind yet," he said. "I just might kill her vote by voting Democrat. It's happened before. But I just don't know right now."
With their sentiments apparent if passionless, the Buckleys are typical of the divided and disengaged electorate this year in Kentucky, which the Census Bureau ranks as the nation's sixth-poorest state.
Neither Mr. Forgy nor his Democratic opponent, Lieut. Gov. Paul Patton, has generated much excitement among voters despite sharp differences in the candidates' positions and the increased nastiness of their campaigns. Most experts predict an unusually light turnout, even though the polls show that the race is virtually even.
The current Governor, Brereton Jones, a Democrat, is barred by law from seeking a second term.
"It has been a lackluster campaign," said Penny Miller, a political science professor at the University of Kentucky in Lexington. "There has been no silver-bullet issue to get the attention of the public."
Even Mr. Patton conceded today, after an appearance at a center for the elderly here, that the race lacked a burning issue, and added, "I don't know if that helps me or hurts me."
Much of the lack of interest is a result of Kentucky's new campaign finance laws, which limit each candidate to $1.8 million in spending and reduce individual contributions to $500 from $4,000. The spending limits have cut down on television advertising, leaving many voters unfamiliar with the candidates until recently. Mr. Forgy's television advertisements began running only last month.
Mr. Forgy, a wealthy lawyer who has run for governor before, has campaigned as a conservative Republican, opposing abortion and favoring lower taxes, less government regulation and a return to the methods of education that prevailed before the passage of the Kentucky Education Reform Act in 1990. That law placed greater emphasis on writing and group work in public schools. Mr. Forgy is running strong with farmers, religious conservatives and opponents of abortion rights.
Mr. Patton, a former coal mine operator, favors modest tax cuts, greater economic development and only modest changes in the education system. He has union support and has won editorial endorsements from the state's two largest newspapers, The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Lexington Herald-Leader.
In the closing days of the race, the candidates have used national issues to criticize each other. With tobacco as the state's leading cash crop, Mr. Forgy has tied Mr. Patton to the Clinton Administration's talk about regulating nicotine as a drug. Mr. Patton has warned elderly voters that Mr. Forgy's would-be colleagues in Washington, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, favor reduced Medicare benefits to help balance the Federal budget.
But the only real sparks in the campaign have come from personal attacks.
Mr. Forgy has said his opponent is part of "the most entrenched, corrupt political machine in the United States," and has called the Lieutenant Governor "a tax-and-spend-liberal." With great relish, Mr. Forgy has reminded voters of the Democratic politicians who are now serving prison terms for their role in recent state and Federal scandals, although he fails to mention the state's Republicans who have been imprisoned for similar offenses.
Mr. Patton has accused his opponent of telling voters "what they want to hear, then worry about it later." He has also suggested that by not making public all his income tax results, Mr. Forgy is "hiding some kind of business deal."
Both candidates agree that the main battleground of the campaign may be here in western Kentucky, where Democrats are no longer the automatic favorites they once were.
The Buckleys said the shift toward conservative candidates followed demographic changes in the area. Older residents, like Mr. Buckley, who followed his parents' lead and voted for "whoever the Democratic person was," are moving away or dying, he said.
"And the younger ones vote for people, not parties," Mrs. Buckley said. "The new generation is more receptive to change."
Even Mr. Patton has recognized the need to stay abreast of the political trends. Tonight, at the end of his final debate with Mr. Forgy, the Lieutenant Governor peered into the camera and earnestly asked voters to support "our conservative agenda for the citizens of Kentucky."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
It is pretty clear where most American Jews stand in the cultural wars now dividing the nation. It is not so clear where Judaism stands.
Most Jews in the United States continue to vote Democratic, back abortion rights, uphold strict separation of church and state, favor Federal initiatives to combat discrimination and inequality, respond with alarm to the emergence of a conservative Christian political movement and generally feel that the more secular the society, at least in its public demeanor and certainly in its government policies, the safer it is for the Jewish minority. 
 But some Jews -- a large segment of the Orthodox, plus a battalion of increasingly conservative intellectuals -- have challenged these positions as "liberal pieties" that, whatever the situation in the past, now contradict Jewish interests. Both Jewish camps in the culture wars contend that they have Jewish tradition on their side.
That is why the Jewish Theological Seminary, the intellectual nerve center of Conservative Judaism, situated on Manhattan's West Side, organized a series of lectures and dialogues on "Revisioning America: Culture Wars and the Jewish Tradition."
Running from mid-October to mid-November, the series features an impressive cast of Jewish intellectuals: Leon Wieseltier, Midge Decter, Michael Walzer, William Kristol, Leonard Fein, Jack Wert heimer, Richard Bernstein and Irving Levine.
Two weeks ago, the seminary's Chancellor, Rabbi Ismar Schorsch, debated the Rev. Richard John Neuhaus, neoconservative Roman Catholic theologian and the one non-Jew in the series, on "The Role of Religion in the Public Square."
Father Neuhaus argued that an adamantly secular "public square" in the United States, where more than 9 of 10 citizens base their morality on religion, was doomed to be anti-democratic. That, he said, would set Jewish interests against the overwhelming majority and be a formula for disaster.
A public life stripped of religion "is the most dangerous of places" for minorities, he warned, for it undercuts "inhibition against unspeakable evil."
In his rejoinder, Rabbi Schorsch disagreed that religion had been banished from American public life. The issue, he said, was the removal of religion not from society but from the state: a religiously neutral state did not mean a religiously neutral society.
In any case, the proposition that more religion in either state or society was better for the Jews "had not been verified by the Jewish historical experience" in Europe, he said, and Jews were loath to conduct a fresh experiment in the United States.
Father Neuhaus and Rabbi Schorsch carried on their exchange in a low key that held out the promise of common ground. Less so with the exchange on Jewish liberalism and conservatism last Thursday between Mr. Walzer, professor of social science at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton and the co-editor of Dissent magazine, and Ms. Decter, essayist and former head of the Committee for the Free World.
Liberalism, Professor Walzer said, has two meanings today: a liberalism of civil liberties, individualism, toleration and pluralism and a liberalism of the New Deal, welfare state, distributive justice and trade unionism. The Jewish connection to the second, he said, is clear; it was the first he wished to address.
This liberalism was relatively new to Judaism and Jews, he said: A century and a half ago, with emancipation from the ghetto, many Jews took up opposition to all enforced orthodoxies. "Like new converts," he said, "we were more liberal than the liberals."
"One cluster of liberal values appealed especially to Jews who wanted to be emancipated and who wanted to be Jewish at the same time," Professor Walzer said, "toleration, freedom of association and their derivative, cultural pluralism."
The latter implied political and economic integration in the larger society, he said, but also a cultural distinctiveness maintained by means of a full panoply of Jewish institutions, from nursery schools and community centers to philanthropic organizations and theological seminaries.
In current jargon, Professor Walzer said, this cultural pluralism could be called "meat-and-potatoes multiculturalism," -- not "a rhetorical, gestural, ideologically strident multiculturalism" but one focusing on "the actual institutions that make a common life possible," institutions that, in a liberal, pluralist society, frequently receive state help.
Not only is this meat-and-potatoes multiculturalism threatened, Professor Walzer said, from those who "aim at turning multiculturalism into a literal separatism" and, in the Jewish case, from those calling for "a Christian or at least Christianized republic." It is also threatened, he said, by those calling "for a market society in the strongest sense," which would remove the financial props now provided by government.
The liberal pluralism and multiculturalism that Professor Walzer defended, Ms. Decter described in starkly different terms. It was a liberalism that by the 1970's had grown hostile to merit and meritocracy and favored racial and sexual quotas. It was a liberalism, she said, that let itself be identified with "a deep-going decadence," rejecting all standards of achievement and moral conduct.
If Jewish conservatives like herself are willing to make common cause with Christian conservatives against this liberalism, she said, it is because the secularism that both oppose is "taking the country down into nihilism." She said, "Jews will not long continue to thrive under its umbrella."
Did Ms. Decter think that the "market society in the strongest sense," to use Professor Walzer's phrase, might have a good deal to do with "deep-going decadence?" Did Professor Walzer see anything embedded in the individualist and multicultural liberalism that he described that might have something to do with Ms. Decter's horizon of horrors?
Unfortunately, in the questions-and-answer period that followed their remarks, the opportunities to bring the two perspectives into useful confrontation always slipped away. Maybe that, more than anything else, is the curse of the culture wars.

HEADLINE: Man Accused of Fake Calls; One Led to an Officer's Death

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Since the beginning of September, officers from the 10th Precinct in Chelsea had responded more than a dozen times to false reports of pistol-toting men, drug deals and gunshots in the blocks around the Chelsea Houses on West 26th Street.
Yesterday, officers were sent to the Chelsea Houses again. But this time they made an arrest, charging a 38-year-old unemployed laborer with making 13 false 911 calls to increase the police presence in his quiet neighborhood. One bogus call in late September led to the death of a police officer in a car crash. 
 Investigators said they thought that the man, Manuel Perez, who lives in a ground-floor apartment in the project near Ninth Avenue, may have been making the calls since late 1993. "It's our belief that he wanted police protection in the area, and he would use these calls to get a response," said John F. Timoney, the First Deputy Police Commissioner. He added that the arrest was "the first time in the history of the department, to my recollection, that we've been able to conclude a case effectively by tracing phony calls to 911."
It was Mr. Perez's report of gunshots to a 911 operator at 9:32 A.M. on Sept. 23 that sent Officer David Willis, 29, and his partner, Officer Robert Avezzan, 31, racing down 11th Avenue 10 minutes later. According to a transcript of the call released yesterday, Mr. Perez told the 911 operator: "I just heard about, about 10 to 12 shots, and I looked out my window and they, they hid something."
As the officers responded with their lights flashing and sirens blaring, they were hit broadside by a postal van headed east on West 30th Street, and Officer Willis was thrown through the side window of the patrol car, breaking his neck.
He died two days later at St. Vincent's Hospital. Officer Avezzan, who was driving, was not seriously injured because the air bag in the car, a Chevrolet sedan, was activated by the crash.
Mr. Timoney said investigators began looking into a pattern of false calls in the neighborhood after the officer's death, placing an electronic tag on calls that came from the area and that involved reports of gunshots or drug dealing. On Oct. 28, Samuel Sams, a 911 operator, saw the alert flash on his screen when a man called to report a drug deal near the Chelsea Houses, and Mr. Sams called Nynex to have the call traced, Mr. Timoney said.
Detective Tom O'Malley of the 10th Precinct said Mr. Perez did not know that his call had resulted in the officer's death. "He is very, very broken up about it," Detective O'Malley said. For the Sept. 23 call, he was charged with falsely reporting an incident in the first degree, a felony that carries a sentence of up to a year in prison. He was charged with misdemeanors for the other calls.
Residents in Mr. Perez's building said officers went frequently to the building for the last several months and often frisked or questioned groups of teen-agers who congregated near a main entrance to the Chelsea Houses, only feet away from a window of Mr. Perez's apartment.
Mr. Timoney said false 911 calls, especially exaggerated reports made to draw officers more quickly to the scene, are a problem across the city.
"People in family disputes or even minor nuisance calls will jack it up, and it's very, very dangerous," he said. "The reason why there are priority calls is that officers obviously respond at different rates of speed and in a life-threatening situation, which this was, the officers are going as fast as they possibly can to get there."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

STATE PROPOSES TOUGHER REGENTS EXAMS
The State Education Commissioner, with strong support from the Board of Regents, proposed that all students in New York be required to pass the state's rigorous Regents exams to earn a high school diploma. [Page A1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
FOR SCHOOLS, HIGHER STANDARDS

HEADLINE: Dow Hits a High for 2d Day Despite a Drop in Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced to a record high yesterday for the second consecutive day, defying a dip in bond prices that followed a mixed employment report.
The Dow average spent most of the session in barely positive territory. But a burst of buying near the close propelled it 16.98 points higher, to 4,825.57, topping the closing high of 4,808.59 set Thursday. It was the blue-chip average's 52d record this year and sent it up 83.82 for the week, more than recovering its 52-point loss last week. 
 Advancing issues led declines, 1,290 to 940, on moderate volume of 345.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Broad market indexes rose but were shy of their records. The Standard & Poor's 500 list added 0.85, to 590.57, closing just below its record close of 590.60 on Oct. 19. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.58, to 314.27. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 8.34, to 1,065.66, just under its Sept. 13 high of 1,067.40, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index climbed 1.07, to 529.11.
Stocks rose even as the 30-year Treasury bond dipped a quarter-point, following a Labor Department report that the nation's unemployment rate dipped to 5.5 percent in October, the lowest level in seven months. But October payrolls increased by 116,000, below expectations, and the Government sharply lowered its September estimate. Average hourly earnings rose 6 cents in October to $11.59.
Analysts said the mixed employment figures did nothing to change their view that economic activity was slowing after a summer spurt.
"A weakish report was more or less expected," said James Solloway, research director at Argus Research. "It wasn't the kind of report that really elicits much inspiration.
"Manufacturing is still on the weak side, still being hurt by the earlier inventory buildup we saw in the first half of the year. And with retail sales being quite sluggish here, there is not any burning reason why the markets should do much of anything."
John Shaughnessy, the Advest Corporation's director of research, said he was surprised at the market's continued strength. "My own sense is that we're probably in for a choppy two weeks or so until we get the budget deficit problem worked out in Washington," he said.
Congressional Republicans and President Clinton remain at odds over the budget issue.
Mr. Shaughnessy said that after the budget matter was resolved, however, he believed the Federal Reserve could justify cutting short-term rates again, paving the way for a year-end rally for both stocks and bonds.
"The underlying fundamentals are solid," he said, including growing earnings and comfortable interest rates.
Several technology shares gained. On the Big Board, I.B.M. rose 1 7/8, to 101 1/2, and Micron Technologies rose 3/4, to 68 1/4. Silicon Graphics added 4, to 36 1/4, after First Chicago said the stock could go to 50. Sun Microsystems jumped 531/64 , to 8423/64 after the company set a 2-for-1 stock split.
Applied Materials was the volume leader in Nasdaq trading and gained 2 3/4, to 55 3/8, after Prudential Securities began coverage with a "buy" rating.
Transportation issues, the other impetus for the market on Thursday, were mixed. Delta Air Lines rose 1 1/4, to 69 1/2. But Federal Express slipped 1 1/8, to 84 7/8. The Dow Jones transportation average rose 5.51 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,990.95.
The EMC Corporation led in volume on the Big Board and rose 2, to 18 1/2. The company said that AT&T and Hewlett-Packard would sell EMC's Symmetrix 3000 open storage system. EMC also said it expected more than $250 million in 1996 revenues from the agreement.
Edison Brothers Stores Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, becoming the second major mall-based specialty retailer after Petrie Retail Inc. to seek protection in the last month. The stock was halted from trading, but the news send many other retail shares down; they had gained on Thursday after posting October sales. Dayton Hudson slipped 7/8, to 73, after jumping 7.6 percent.
In Tokyo the market was closed for Culture Day, a national holiday. In Frankfurt, the DAX Index of 30 shares fell 2.26 points, or 0.1 percent, to 2181.72,

HEADLINE: Voters Will Decide Whether to Curb State-Imposed Programs

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

 BODY:
Testing New Jersey schoolchildren for curvature of the spine sounded like a good idea when it was proposed in the 1960's.
Today, however, the program is considered by some the epitome of what is wrong with local governments being ordered by the state to adopt programs without receiving the money to operate them. 
 New Jersey voters will be asked on Tuesday to approve a constitutional amendment to prohibit the state from imposing programs on schools, counties or municipalities without providing money, unless the programs are approved by three-fourths of the Legislature.
Three other public questions appear on the ballot. Voters will be asked, among other things, to authorize a $340 million bond issue to allow the state to acquire additional land for conservation and recreational use.
As for the mandated programs, critics say that they waste millions of dollars in administrative costs every year, that they survive long after they have outlived their usefulness and that they eat up money better spent on services that communities really want.
The requirement that schools test for curvature of the spine offers a case in point, these critics say. It was useful to identify affected children in the initial survey, they point out, but the law as written requires annual testing of all public schoolchildren 10 or older, even if they are routinely examined by family physicians or have never exhibited any signs of the ailment.
Opponents of the amendment say voters should not throw the baby out with the bath water. Every effort should be made to weed out unnecessary or outdated programs, they maintain, but the mandates remain a useful tool to establish uniform economic and social policies that local governing bodies might otherwise neglect.
"We feel the Legislature already has the power not to pass irresponsible mandates," said Barbara Bohi, vice president for advocacy of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, a group that opposes the amendment.
Another opponent is the New Jersey Environmental Federation. "When efforts are made to shape policy based on budgets rather than the public good," said Amy Goldsmith, the federation's executive director, "then the needs of the public will not be met."
But the measure has the backing of powerful forces, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Republican leadership of the Legislature, as well as the League of Municipalities, the Association of Counties and the School Boards Association.
"Passage of the amendment will change the way business is done in Trenton," said William G. Dressel Jr., the league's executive director. "From now on legislators will need to analyze the costs of a bill in a public forum and who is going to pay for it."
The amendment would apply only to future or expanded state programs, not existing ones. Nor would it affect Federal requirements like welfare and environmental spending. It would provide for the creation of an independent, bipartisan council to determine whether new state laws or regulations imposed mandates on local governments without providing money.
The land-conservation-bond issue is being put before voters for the eighth time. A total of $1.1 billion has been approved to acquire 250,000 acres of woodlands, parks and farms. This year's bond issue asks for $30 million to be used to buy coastal property endangered by a rising sea and property subject to flooding along the Passaic River.
Also on the ballot are these items: a measure creating a state redistricting commission to redraw Congressional districts after every Federal census, and a resolution dedicating an increased portion of state gasoline taxes to the transportation fund, which is used for state roads.

HEADLINE: Job Growth Was Sluggish Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Despite fresh signs of stability in factories, the economy generated new jobs at a lackluster pace in October as the unemployment rate edged down to 5.5 percent from 5.6 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
The figures, the most comprehensive gauge of economic performance for the month, tended to confirm other recent indications -- including weak store sales -- that the economy had decelerated in recent weeks after a surge in the summer months. In terms of job growth, the rise of 116,000 in nonfarm payrolls last month was below economists' expectations. 
 The Clinton Administration, while contending that the economic expansion remains "on track" after four and a half years, still expressed some uneasiness about the economic outlook.
"This is not an environment where consumers are apt to run to the shopping malls," Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich said in an interview. He pointed to sluggish wage growth and a "mountain" of inventories as two factors that were likely to continue to restrain job growth.
Still, the employment report did not provide the financial markets with clear new indications of a sharper slowdown that might push the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term interest rates soon, and bond prices slipped. [Page 40.]
In one bright spot in today's report, the unemployment rate in the Northeast, which has long been higher than the national average, eased five-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.6 percent. In New York State, for example, the jobless rate fell to 6.3 percent from 6.8 percent. But in New Jersey, the rate edged up one-tenth of a point, to 5.8 percent. [Page 38.]
The other three regions of the country showed virtually no change.
Other upbeat elements included an increase in the index of production hours; 18,000 more jobs in finance, insurance and real estate, and 2,000 more factory jobs after accounting for strikes.
But the dominant assessment of today's mixed report was that it portrayed business conditions that have become markedly less robust.
"The economy is generating jobs at a very paltry pace," said Lacy H. Hunt, an economist at HSBC Holdings Inc. in New York. Along with the modest gain of 116,000 in payroll jobs last month, he noted that the Labor Department made a big downward revision that cut September's job growth to 50,000 from the 121,000 that it initially reported.
In fact, various analysts noted, the October payroll gain was slightly less than what the Labor Department calls the bias adjustment, that is, the number of jobs -- 118,000 for the fourth quarter -- that it assumes were created by new companies not yet captured in its statistical net.
And while the private-sector workweek expanded by 12 minutes, the factory workweek and factory overtime both contracted by that amount, portending further weakness. Factory hours are a component of the index of leading economic indicators, a widely followed forecasting gauge.
Irwin L. Kellner, senior economic adviser to Chemical Bank, said that the labor market was "weaker than it looks" and that the holiday shopping season would suffer because job growth had been concentrated in lower-paid industries. "Buying power," he said, "isn't growing."
Another negative sign, economists said, was a 15 percent decline, to 753,000, in the number of people who quit their jobs last month, an indication of workers' judgment that it would be difficult to find a new one.
Also, job growth in services was just 57,000 in October, the second consecutive month in which the increase was below the monthly average over the last year, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said in an appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
Robert L. Marks of SOM Economics Inc. in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was one of several analysts who found little significance in the 6-cent rise in average hourly earnings, the fourth significant advance in the last five months. This volatile series tends to jump in the first month of each quarter and, moreover, the 12-month rise is only 3 percent, he noted.
But others fretted about incipient wage inflation after figuring that hourly earnings had risen in the latest five months more than twice as fast as in the first five months of the year.
The Labor Department's survey of households showed an employment gain of 259,000 last month, which absorbed another very modest -- 57,000 -- rise in the labor force and cut the ranks of the unemployed by 202,000. As a result the unemployment rate, which must change slightly more than two-tenths of a point to be regarded as statistically significant, was calculated at 5.5 percent, the lowest since March, compared with 5.6 percent in August and September.
Among the largest states, the main changes were a decline of 1.3 points, to 5.1 percent, for Pennsylvania; a rise of 1.1 points, to 6.7 percent, for Florida; a decline of eight-tenths of a point, to 3.9 percent, for North Carolina, and a rise of six-tenths of a point for California, to 7.8 percent, that exactly offset September's decline.
The department has said it will stop its early reporting of the data for 11 large states in the new year if budget cuts force a reduction in sample sizes and thus make the results less reliable.
In another development, Commissioner Abraham announced that payrolls for March 1995 are now estimated to be 590,000 higher than previously thought, a benchmark revision, based on actual unemployment insurance reports, that would be somewhat higher than average.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down on Profit Taking After a Week of Posting Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar retreated yesterday, hurt by weaker-than-expected economic news in the United States, a drop in the Mexican peso and traders who sold the dollar to lock in profits from its run-up during the week.
"The market clearly was going to consolidate," said Bob Near, vice president of the Bank of New York. "Then the baton was passed over to the Mexican peso problems, and people sold the dollar on that." 
 In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 103.90 Japanese yen from 104.02 yen on Thursday. The dollar also fell to 1.4160 German marks from 1.4232 marks and to 1.1392 Swiss francs from 1.1457 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5787 from $1.5788.
The dollar first weakened after the Labor Department reported that the number of new jobs was far lower than expectations of at least 125,000. Payrolls grew by 116,000 in October, and the September figure was revised from 121,000 to 50,000. That suggested to many forecasters that the economy was slowing, a trend that would tend to diminish demand for dollars.
Just as the European markets were closing, the dollar retreated further on rumors of a possible military coup in Mexico. Many traders reacted to the rumors by dumping dollars in favor of marks and other European currencies.
The peso also weakened on the rumors, moving to 7.67 pesos to the dollar, from 7.35 on Wednesday. (Mexican financial markets were closed on Thursday for a national holiday). The peso later recovered, with the dollar settling at 7.365 pesos.
Even though the peso regained much of the lost ground yesterday after the coup rumors were found to be groundless, the damage to the dollar against the European currencies was already done.
Coupled with the strong gains the dollar had made through most of the week -- hitting six-week highs against the Japanese yen -- traders concluded that it was prudent to sell dollars going into the weekend, and the dollar fell further.
"The market just settled down," said Al Pugliesi, a foreign exchange trader for Bank Julius Baer in New York. "Nobody was willing to take dollars on a Friday."
The dollar might have fallen further, some traders said, if not for renewed concern about President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, who has been hospitalized for a week with heart trouble and was shown on Russian television yesterday. The uncertainties over Mr. Yeltsin have generated an underlying demand for dollars, a safe-haven currency.

HEADLINE: New York State Depends on Its Dairy Farmers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
After reading Richard Schrader's Oct. 28 letter about dairy policy and milk marketing, I suggest he visit a farm and see what's really going on. 
 The price New York dairy farmers get for their milk is no higher than it was a decade ago. Dairy farmers have already tightened their belts beyond the choking point.
Mr. Schrader claims dairy farmers get an average $42,000 annually from the Federal Government. I'm sure he would be surprised to learn that the Federal dairy program costs about $158 million a year -- which is more than covered by assessments paid by dairy farmers.
He would also be surprised to learn that dairy farmers work in excess of 80 hours a week and that the average net income of New York milk producers is less than $14,000 a year. Furthermore, the Federal milk programs have provided abundant supplies of low-cost dairy products for food giveaway programs.
The Federal market orders provide a stable market for dairy farmers and stable prices and supplies for consumers. The state's October price survey shows Upstate New York consumers paid $2.18 a gallon -- 1 cent less than the price Mr. Schrader said Wisconsin consumers are paying -- while New York City consumers spent $2.48. Instead of looking to blame Federal milk marketing orders, he should look within the city for the problem.
The loss of the Federal milk marketing orders would devastate New York dairy farms, reduce open space areas, including land in the New York City watershed, and severely reduce the $1.5 billion New York dairy farmers pump into the state economy. The economic shock waves from the loss of the Federal orders would be felt from the rural economies of the state all the way to New York City.
 
MARK F. EMERY
Director of Communications
New York Farm Bureau
Glenmont, N.Y., Oct. 31, 1995

HEADLINE: J. Bradbury Thompson Dies; Designer and Art Director, 84

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
J. Bradbury Thompson, whose talent for graphic design and art direction left its mark on America's books, magazines and postage stamps and influenced generations of students who studied with him at Yale University, died on Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Thompson was 84, and lived in Riverside, Conn.
Mr. Thompson's work extended to such limited-edition books as a masterly lectern Bible, Stephen Crane's "Red Badge of Courage" and Herman Melville's "Typee"; to art and fashion magazines like Art News and Mademoiselle, and to the design of more than 120 United States postage stamps devoted to subjects like architecture, belles-lettres and history. 
 Because Mr. Thompson was the design coordinator of the Citizens Stamp Advisory Committee from 1969 to 1978, his taste and influence extended beyond those stamps he created himself. These included 16 Christmas Stamps from Old Master paintings in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the "Love" series stamp with the word "Love" stacked five high and each "v" replaced by a heart, and United States Bicentennial stamps honoring George Washington, John Paul Jones and the Marquis de Lafayette.
Mr. Thompson's bold experiments with typography, photographic reproduction and color combined the best of traditional design and modernism. His strong sense of design, coupled with his belief in the power of the printed word, characterized his teaching to four decades of students at Yale, where he was a visiting professor of graphic arts from 1956 until ill health forced him to curtail his work there this year.
Many of Mr. Thompson's students went on to become art directors for well-known magazines, newspapers and corporations.
His artistic autobiography, "The Art of Graphic Design," was published by Yale University Press in 1988. It won the Art Libraries Society of North America's George Wittenborn Memorial Award as best art book of the year and was praised in The New York Times Book Review as a book in which "art and design are gloriously and daringly mixed."
Mr. Thompson, who was born in 1911 in Topeka, Kan., embarked on his career by designing yearbooks at Topeka High School and continued at Washburn College in Topeka. While working toward a bachelor's degree in economics in 1934, he was the editor and designer of the yearbook.
When he sent off copies of his work to Conde Nast's art director, he was encouraged to come East. Mr. Thompson arrived in New York City in 1938, and before long he was designing an official catalogue for the 1939-40 World's Fair.
With the outbreak of World War II, he went to work as art director for the Office of War Information's publications division, designing the magazines Victory, U.S.A. and America.
In 1938, Mr. Thompson began a 24-year association with the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company. The pages of its arts journal, Westvaco Inspirations, became a showcase of his experiments in typography, photographic reproduction and color.
In 1958, Mr. Thompson began designing the American Classic Book Series for Westvaco, using period typography and engravings in innovative designs for books like "The Red Badge of Courage" and "Typee."
From 1945 to 1959, he was the art director of Mademoiselle, where he hired many progressive artists to illustrate the magazine's strong fiction section, from Andy Warhol, who was then unknown, to Joan Miro, Willem de Kooning and Jasper Johns.
In all, Mr. Thompson designed or redesigned more than 35 magazines, including Business Week and the Harvard Business Review; in 1969, the Smithsonian Institution hired him to create the design for Smithsonian magazine, a classic format that has been maintained for more than a quarter of a century.
Mr. Thompson's work in mass-market books included Time-Life's "Library of Art" and "Foods of the World," both series that received design awards from the American Institute of Graphic Arts.
In 1969, Marshall Field 4th commissioned Mr. Thompson to create a great lectern Bible in the tradition of the Gutenberg folio edition. This resulted in what was widely regarded as Mr. Thompson's masterpiece: The Washburn College Bible, published by Oxford University Press in 1979 in a limited edition of 400 copies. Although Gutenberg's Bible was printed in columns of type of identical width, Mr. Thompson set the type of the Washburn College Bible in a flush-left, ragged-right format that allowed the lines of text to be printed in the phrases in which they were spoken.
Mr. Thompson was a recipient of the American Institute of Graphic Arts gold medal for lifetime achievement and the National Society of Art Directors Gold T-Square for career distinction, and was a member of the Art Directors Club Hall of Fame.
He is survived by his wife, Della Deen Dodge; two sons, Mark Thompson of Philadelphia and D. Dodge Thompson of Washington; two daughters, Leslie Keller of Cleveland and Elizabeth Riley of Manhattan, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: PROFILE;
Applying the Silber Standard to Boston U.

BYLINE: By David Barboza; David Barboza is writing a book on John R. Silber.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
It is just after 10 A.M., and John R. Silber, the tough-talking president of Boston University, is giving the incoming freshmen an earful.
"This is not Pinocchio's Pleasure Isle," he tells the class of 1999. "At Boston University, we take a very hard line on both alcohol and drugs. No drugs are allowed on this campus and you are not allowed to take alcohol into the dormitories. If you violate these rules, you will be subject to sanctions." 
 Mr. Silber adds that the university will not provide condoms in the dormitories. "If you are not smart enough to know how to use a condom and where to find one by the time you get to this university," he says, "you are too dumb to be here! We are not going to offer you lectures on 'safe sex,' because we don't know how much safer 'safe sex' is than just plain old sex. These are issues that, as far as we are concerned, are up to you as morally responsible adults."
Introductions like these are what Mr. Silber calls "reality therapy." They come from a man accustomed to harsh circumstances. His right arm, which ends at the elbow because of a birth defect, is always prominently displayed. And he expects others to be just as unflinching. He has been known to grill tenure candidates on their political views and churn out detailed critiques of their scholarship. In fact, his style harks back to the era of the commanding college president, like Harvard's Charles William Eliot in the late 19th century and the University of Chicago's Robert Maynard Hutchins in the 1930's and 40's. What sets Mr. Silberapart is what the Harvard sociologist David Riesman calls his "heroic indiscretions." Perhaps no other college president today is so admired for his boldness nor so savagely reviled for his arrogance.
"I don't wait for a plebiscite to find out who I am, what I am supposed to do, or whether I can hold my head up," said Mr. Silber, a wiry man of 69. "I know where my moral North Star is."
He has, however, sought public endorsement in a role not often pursued by a college president: In 1990, he ran for Governor of Massachusetts as a conservative Democrat, losing by only a narrow margin to William F. Weld. And he seems not to have lost his taste for public office. Last year he lobbied hard to become Boston's Superintendent of Schools, although the Mayor, Thomas M. Menino, eventually considered him too risky a choice. A man as outspoken as Mr. Silber, he indicated in published reports, would perhaps not have the diplomatic skills for the post.
While Mr. Silber's supporters consider him a man of great moral courage, his detractors say he is a tyrant who has enriched himself through his board of trustees. They point out that he is the nation's highest-paid college president, with total 1993-94 earnings of $564,000, according to the Chronicle of Higher Education's latest survey. In comparison, the president of M.I.T. earned $337,000, and the president of Harvard received $278,000.
"He came up from Texas a poor boy with a cardboard suitcase and now he's a millionaire," said Richard Rapacz, a retired professor of education at Boston University. "People don't know you can steal a university, but he did."
Financial operations at the university have raised questions. Three years ago, Mr. Silber and the university's trustees were the subjects of a lengthy investigation by Scott Harshbarger, the Massachusetts Attorney General, concerning charges of financial improprieties. Among the concerns were contracts between the university and the companies represented by various members of the board of trustees, and whether Mr. Silber had personally profited from university business. The investigation found that Mr. Silber had received a $386,700 bonus from the trustees in 1989 as a reward for his work on the sale of Seradyn Inc., a university-owned biotechnology company, to Mitsubishi. Mr. Silber explained that he had returned the bonus in 1991 and, in the end, Mr. Harshbarger said no laws were broken. But he did press the trustees to enact new conflict-of-interest policies because of the appearance of unsound business practices.
Mr. Silber said simply: "The facts speak for themselves. Harshbarger came up with nothing but a smear."
For all the controversy Mr. Silber engenders, there is one point on which his supporters and his critics would probably agree: John Robert Silber does not shy from a challenge. Born in San Antonio, he is the younger of the two sons of Paul Silber, a German-born architect whose business collapsed during the Depression, and Jewel Silber, a schoolteacher. His parents, Mr. Silber says, were stern but loving. His mother tailored his clothes to expose his deformed arm, and his father held him to the same standards as his brother. As a result, he says, he hardened himself to the schoolyard bullies who called him "One-armed Pete." Today, he often uses the toelike projection on the end of his right arm to grasp his briefcase.
Raised a Presbyterian, and deeply religious as a young man, Mr. Silber enrolled at Trinity University in San Antonio, where he met his future wife, the former Kathryn Underwood. After graduating with honors, he tried divinity school and then law school before deciding to pursue a doctorate in philosophy at Yale, where he became acquainted with the writings of Immanuel Kant. Reading Kant, he said, persuaded him to build his ethical life on reason rather than the religious guilt that arose from his Calvinist background.
"It changed my virtue from an impure act of contrition to a pure act of contrition," he said. "I regretted failing to live up to things, not out of fear of hell or hope of heaven, but just out of the rightness or wrongness of it."
After getting his Ph.D. in 1955, Mr. Silber returned to his home state, where he rose from professor of philosophy at the University of Texas in Austin to department chairman and, finally, in 1967, dean. But after a power struggle with Frank C. Erwin, the chairman of the board of regents, over Mr. Erwin's plans to split the College of Arts and Sciences into three separate schools, Mr. Silber was asked to resign as dean in 1970. He was wooed almost immediately to his current home, and there he has stayed. At a time when college presidents serve, on average, seven years, Mr. Silber has led Boston University for a quarter-century. Only Charles E. Young of the University of California at Los Angeles has served longer.
Mr. Silber has revealed, though, that his presidency is winding down. Last April, a committee he set up selected his provost, Jon N. Westling, as his eventual successor, even though Mr. Silber has not yet set a date for retirement. Not surprisingly, this choice, too, has become controversial. Some faculty members say that the president engineered the selection of Mr. Westling, who is his longtime aide. They also note that although Mr. Westling is a former Rhodes scholar, he never completed work on his doctorate. Meanwhile, retirement from the presidency does not necessarily mean Mr. Silber's departure. When he steps down, the board of trustees is expected to name him university chancellor, a position to be created especially for him.
In a series of interviews in his wood-paneled office overlooking the Charles River, Mr. Silber was at once charming and volatile. Although he bristled at even the slightest criticism, he moved easily into quoting Shakespeare or Dylan Thomas, or reciting a poem by Yeats, imitating the poet's wispy cadences. He often illustrated his points with sketches -- showing off some artistic talents from his youth -- and occasionally, he lighted a cigar and paced impatiently. He is a man of many moods, and periodically his temper flared with a thundering denunciation of his critics.
Mr. Silber insists, for example, that there is a "natural aristocracy" of intelligence and reason, and argues that American universities are not supposed to be democratic institutions.
"The hospital is not a democracy," he said. "You mean, when we come into the operating theater, the surgeon is supposed to ask the nurses: 'What do you think I ought to do next? How many are in favor of my making the incision here?' No, the decision is made on the basis of the exalted competence of the surgeon. You don't go out in the hall and say, 'Let's get a couple of janitors and see what they think about it.' "
Mr. Silber's critics say he looms large over the life of the university, but he dismisses such talk as jealousy, pettiness and the rantings of what he calls "second raters," who simply refuse to acknowledge "the greatest transformation in the history of higher education." By insisting on excellence, he says, he has been able to lure to his faculty some of the best and brightest. They include three Nobel Prize winners -- Saul Bellow, Derek Walcott and Elie Wiesel -- as well as Christopher Ricks of the English department (formerly the King Edward VII Professor at Cambridge University) and the composer Lukas Foss. He is proud of what he calls a "murderer's row" of great poets: Mr. Walcott, Robert Pinsky, Rosanna Warren and Geoffrey Hill, the Englishman whom Harold Bloom of Yale calls "the best living poet."
To attract such scholars, Mr. Silber has sometimes offered lavish salaries. For instance, in 1984, on the recommendation of Sheldon Glashow, a Nobel laureate at Harvard, he spent $5 million to lure a team of physicists from the University of Michigan.
"The tectonic plates in Boston are shifting," Mr. Silber said, looking out across the Charles River toward Harvard and M.I.T. "There are now three great universities on the Charles."
Mr. Silber doubted, however, that the Ivy League would acknowledge the achievements of Boston University, which was founded as a Methodist seminary in 1839. "There are not only glass ceilings for some women," he said, "but there are also glass ceilings for some institutions, and you simply have to butt your head up against that ceiling and break it."
Independent ratings bolster Mr. Silber's claims. In the National Research Council's 1995 study of graduate education, Boston University ranked in the top 40 schools in nine liberal arts categories. Moreover, its economics faculty ranks eighth in productivity, according to a 1995 University of Texas survey that rated department faculties by the times their members had published in prestigious journals.
"I don't think there's anything quite as dramatic as what they have in economics," said Dale Jorgenson, the chairman of Harvard's economics department. "It's a great success story, and John Silber has to get a lot of credit."
Part of Boston University's success can be seen in numbers. While Harvard, Yale and Columbia have had deficits in recent years, Mr. Silber has balanced his university's budget 24 years in a row. The university's current endowment is $416 million, up from $18 million in 1971, and the university now attracts significant Federal support. According to the National Science Foundation, Boston University received $102 million in Federal funds for research and development in 1993, the last year for which figures are available. That statistic puts it in 27th place among the nation's top research institutions, up from 77th place in 1971 and above Princeton, the University of Chicago and Emory.
Boston University has also become more competitive, even in the face of rising college costs. (Tuition, excluding room and board, now stands at $19,420, making the university as expensive as many Ivy League schools.) Last year, for instance, the university received 23,600 applications for its 4,400-member freshmen class, up from 10,000 applications in 1975. Moreover, the average combined S.A.T. score of this year's incoming freshmen is 1,158, 248 points above the national average.
And the university continues to grow. Under Mr. Silber's leader-
ship, it has nearly tripled its property holdings and financed over $700 million in new construction. Mr. Silber has also created a number of profit-making enterprises on campus, including several university-run convenience stores, a glitzy food court and a 60,000-square-foot bookstore. The bookstore, now operated by Barnes & Noble, should net the university a $10 million profit over five years, he said.
Arthur G. B. Metcalf, chairman emeritus of Boston University's board of trustees, called Mr. Silber a "visionary" who has saved the university from bankruptcy. "He had to do a lot of things that were unpopular," Mr. Metcalf said. "John Silber is not a nice Nellie or a doormat. He doesn't suffer fools gladly. If someone asks a question, they'll get a frank answer and it may not be a diplomatic answer."
Mr. Silber is the first to acknowledge that his reforms were harsh. But when he arrived in January 1971, he said, the university was like a patient near death, and he warned the trustees: "The surgery will be radical, and the patient may not survive. But he is certainly not going to survive without radical intervention." Within a year, he discovered that the university finances were heading toward an $8.8 million deficit and inaugurated a period of retrenchment that lasted for the better part of five years.
One of Mr. Silber's budget cuts concerned faculty members he considered "dead wood." He called his strategy "creative exportation," and said he told his deans: "See how many times you can transfer a faculty member from this university to another university, such that you can improve both institutions. We have plenty of second-rate professors in this university who would be ornaments at lesser colleges and universities, but who are a drag on this one."
Although Mr. Silber's presidency has been less volatile in recent years, faculty tenure continues to be a thorny issue. Recently, Mr. Silber overrode the university's tenure committee, which had voted 14 to 1 in favor of Michael Lynch, a sociology professor.
"It's an autocracy there," said Mr. Lynch, who now teaches at Brunel University in London. "There are a lot of disgruntled people at B.U. because their decisions are batted down by the higher-ups who think they're smarter than everybody else. The bottom line is that I had to write to please Silber and his staff. And I don't think that's academic freedom."
Mr. Silber countered that he had read Mr. Lynch's book "Scientific Practice and Ordinary Action," which recently won the Robert K. Merton Award from the American Sociological Association, and concluded that it was not very good. "He was writing in an area that I am very competent in, and that man's writing was just plain jargon," he said. "I'll stand by that decision." Arguing that the "two ablest members" of the sociology department were against tenure for Mr. Lynch, Mr. Silber summed up his opinion: "When you have a bunch of third raters saying 'yes' and two first raters saying 'no,' you go with the first raters."
Other areas have been contentious as well. Michael Manove, a professor of economics at Boston University, agrees with the president's admirers that he has increased the school's visibility, but Mr. Manove says that Mr. Silber has also damaged its credibility by promoting risky investment strategies and forming close business ties with members of the board of trustees.
"He is our Lenin and our Stalin," Mr. Manove says. "Perhaps the revolution was necessary, but what has followed is its undoing."
James Iffland, the former head of the faculty council, said: "It's almost as if you're living in some kind of banana republic. The bottom line on Silber is he doesn't know how to lead, he knows how to control."
Mr. Silber doesn't take such accusations lightly. In a faculty meeting a few years ago, he accused the faculty council of using "spin doctor techniques" in its reports and sharply criticized Mr. Iffland for circulating charges from anonymous sources. "I don't know what is more distressing," he told the group, "that Professor Iffland does not understand the moral and intellectual squalor of faceless accusations, or that he understands it and carries it on nevertheless." After the meeting broke up, Mr. Iffland said Mr. Silber approached him and began shouting at him, calling him a "liar and a coward." Then, Mr. Iffland said, the president stared him down and declared, "It's a shame the institution of dueling was abolished."
 But if Mr. Silber has sometimes alienated his faculty, he has consistently won over the people who count: the members of the board of trustees. Many of them are prominent in business - they include John F. Smith Jr., the president and chief executive of General Motors; Allen I. Questrom, the chairman of Federated Department Stores, and Karen Elliott House, president of a Dow Jones & Company operating group - and have praised Mr. Silber's entrepreneurial skills.
 "At Boston University, we have generated over the 24 years around $274 million in surpluses," Mr. Silber said. "Why should the board of trustees disagree with that? That's pretty good." In fact, it has been so good that last May the board awarded Mr. Silber an honorary degree, noting that in transforming the institution he had become "the rarest of public men."
 His supporters say his private life is just as distinguished. "There are many private, unrecorded charities of John that he wouldn't want anyone to know about," said Ketih Botsford, a friend and a Boston University professor. "Away from the university, away from contention, there is another John, a largely amiable, affable, funny man. And yet he is irritated with a world not going exactly as it ought to. He lives under high pressure and makes great demands on himself."
 Those demands include heading a large family. Mr. Silber and his wife, who has devoted her life to taking care of the couple's children, have raised six daughters, one son and two children who joined the household after their own parents, neighbors of the Silbers', died.
 "I can't think of anyone I'd rather be on my side if I got in trouble," said Kathryn Silber of her husband. "He's so generous. When anyone's in trouble he wants to help." The couple's son, David, an actor, died of AIDS in
their home last December at the age of 41, and the family's friends say that Mr. Silber supported him unstintingly and delivered a moving eulogy at his funeral.
"I think he's a really kind-hearted person," Mrs. Silber said. "I really do." But, she added, "When you come in and make tough decisions, you do make some people unhappy. He's not really tactful sometimes in the way he talks, and that's fine with me; I think that makes for some very interesting dialogue."
Mr. Silber insists that his ultimate concern has always been the students. By making their experience tougher, he said, "you make it easier." He added: "I want to encourage their virtue, and I can't do it by pandering to them. I can't by accommodating their willfulness and accommodating their ignorance. Now that may come across as hardness or as hostility. As a matter of fact, it's grounded upon genuine compassion."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 17; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 867 words

HEADLINE: Classroom Journal: Am I Really Ready for This?;
A college freshman finds in independent living a 'revelation.'

BYLINE: BY CHANA SCHOENBERGER 

 BODY:
I THOUGHT THE HARDEST PART ABOUT MOVing away from home for college would be sharing a bathroom with the three strangers who would be my roommates.
Instead, what I've found in the first few months of my freshman year at Harvard University is that the difficulty lies in becoming totally independent, from buying my own toothpaste to weighing the comparative merits of used textbooks versus new ones. My entire support system -- family, friends who have known me for years, high school teachers to whom I looked for advice, my Jewish youth group -- is back in Bethesda, Md., close enough for occasional phone calls, of course, but no longer in my everyday life. 
 In September, during "shopping week," when entering students here visit different classes to help them decide what to take, I began to realize the difference between high school and college. In my small private school, I knew most of the teachers and all of the administrators, and I had at least one friend who had taken every class I planned to take. When it came to choosing classes, there were no surprises and hardly any choices; I took the same six subjects every year.
At Harvard, I intend to major in social studies, but when I arrived for shopping week, no one could tell me what aspiring social studies majors should take to prepare themselves. (My parents could quote my high school's course book from memory.) Harvard's 788-page Official Register, with its thousands of courses and complex numbering system, offered no guidance. For the first time, I was entirely on my own.
So I visited classes, trying out five history and government classes for a single slot on my schedule. I finally decided on four courses: the basic economics sequence, a physics class that would satisfy a core curriculum requirement, expository writing (also required) and a Government class taught by three big-name professors. Whatever I learn in these classes will be added to the lesson I picked up choosing them: Advice, when you can find it, is only valuable up to a certain point, after which you have to decide for yourself.
This goes for life outside the classroom, too, of course. At first, the complete lack of an adult presence was a revelation to me. My parents, who insisted on a midnight curfew up until the day I left for school, had been constantly involved in everything I ever did. They even helped me pick out my prom dress. At college, however, I can stay out until 3 A.M. ("school nights" aren't an issue), oversleep and miss my economics lecture. Nobody's watching. If I do poorly on that week's set of economics problems, I have no one to blame but myself.
I can eat nothing but Lucky Charms and skim milk, as my roommate Mary does. I can fling butter at the ceiling of the Freshman Union cafeteria in hopes of getting it to stick, as the football jocks do. When I come home from class and I have an hour to spare, it's up to me to make the mature decision and do some assigned reading.
I'm also learning that self-reliance has its limits. "You don't learn to be self-sufficient, not freshman year," said Ben, an upperclassman and a friend of one of my roommates. "You learn who to ask for what you need. You learn to be self-motivatedly dependent."
I have followed his advice. I actually visit my professors and teaching fellows during their office hours. When I do my physics problems, I work with friends from the class.
Having to make an entire new set of friends is terrifying. During Freshman Week, before classes started, I went from mixer to mindless mixer, shaking hundreds of hands and asking the Three Freshman Questions: "What's your name? Where are you from? Which dorm are you in?" Some days during my first few weeks, I walked clear across campus without seeing a single person I knew. Even the people who became my close friends (in September, "close friend" meant my roommates, the people in my dorm and anyone I saw more than once a day) were people I didn't really know very well.
I've had to think about dating in a new way, too. Two words sum up the difference between going out in high school and going out in college: proximity. You can see the guy you're dating four times a day -- eat with him, study together, go out afterwards. Wherever he lives, it's nearby. He knows your roommates; he's around them a lot. You know the guys your roommates are dating; you're around them a lot. It helps if you all get along.
Finally, there's the question of food. I keep kosher and am therefore a functional vegetarian when I'm eating out. But the Freshman Union's nightly vegetarian dinners range from the awful to the inedible. Occasionally, I may have a salad, which translates into a few bites of lettuce and a piece of dehydrated broccoli.
But usually I eat starch three times a day: cereal for breakfast, a cheese sandwich for lunch and pasta for dinner. I'm terrified that I'll gain the freshman 15.
But I'm definitely adjusting. By now, my roommates and I are real friends. My schedule is working. I finally remember where I put the bottles of Advil when I moved in. I've found the late-night coffee shops. Over Thanksgiving break, I expect, I'll have to adjust to being home again.
