SECTION: Section 6; Page 35; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3145 words

HEADLINE: MONDERU-SAN'S LAST CAMPAIGN

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; Nicholas D. Kristof is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
EARLIER THIS YEAR, Walter F. Mondale stayed at a famous traditional inn in the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto. As is customary, Mondale and his wife, Joan, were each given a yukata, or light kimono, to wear while they stayed in the inn. So Mondale disrobed and packed his bulky frame into the yukata, carefully tucking the right side over the left.
He walked into the banquet room with the former Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, and his wife, Kayoko -- and the Japanese began to laugh. 
 The Japanese traditionally wear the kimono with the left side tucked over the right. But when used to dress a dead body, the kimono is arranged the opposite way, so Mondale was walking into the banquet inadvertently dressed as a corpse.
Learning the proper way to wear a yukata has been part of the education of the Mondales since he became Ambassador to Japan two years ago. "The most important relationship in the world," as Mondale and his predecessors alike call the American-Japanese partnership, is in a state of flux and uncertainty following the end of the cold war. Japan is impatient with its "little brother" role. It wants to grow up and get a Security Council seat and have an independent foreign policy and do the other things big countries do, and it has been engaged in a series of bitter disputes with the United States about trade and economics.
This relationship will become a focus of attention later this month, when President Clinton is scheduled to visit Japan. Clinton is preparing to participate in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Osaka -- a bit like a G-7 summit meeting of the leading industrialized countries, except that participants are all from the Pacific Rim and mostly represent economies growing twice as quickly as those of the G-7 nations. Then Clinton plans to travel to Tokyo for wide-ranging discussions with Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama.
Mondale's dream had been to participate in such meetings, and he will this time -- albeit not as President but as Presidential envoy. He has played a key role in preparing for the talks and in smoothing over crises that threaten to undermine them. The most recent erupted when three American servicemen in Okinawa were accused of kidnapping a 12-year-old girl, binding her with adhesive tape and gang-raping her. The incident has inflamed smoldering resentment at the American military presence in Japan and has raised calls for the closing of the American military bases in Okinawa. Late last month, 50,000 or more people took to the streets to protest the rape and to demand an American withdrawal from at least some bases.
While most Japanese officials want the American military presence to continue, the rape trial, which is to begin this week, is helping to jeopardize a strand of the Japanese-American relationship that Mondale has worked passionately to preserve: the military partnership. Mondale apologized publicly for the rape -- he is one of the best apologizers in the diplomatic world, and his remarks helped to soothe tensions -- but the tensions that the rape provoked will take months to work out fully.
Mondale, at first glance, is poorly prepared to serve as the President's emissary to Japan at such a crucial time. As a Senator from Minnesota, and then as Vice President under Jimmy Carter, Mondale was interested primarily in domestic affairs rather than foreign policy. He never focused on trade or international economic affairs. And although Mondale arrived hoping to learn some basic Japanese, a language so fiendishly complex that it has been described as the greatest barrier to human communication ever devised, he gave that up after one lesson. The only reference to Japan in his biography (now translated into Japanese and selling in the bookstores) is an incident when he was a boy during World War II. He made an ugly comment about "Japs," and his father reprimanded him, saying of the Japanese, "They are individuals under God just like us."
Nevertheless, Mondale has fit in well in Tokyo almost from the moment he donned a morning suit and traveled in a horse-drawn carriage to call on Emperor Akihito to present his credentials. He has cultivated a network of Japanese contacts, pressed the Japanese to open their markets further and worked the scrambler phone ceaselessly to keep a channel open between Tokyo and policy makers in Washington. Some Americans in Tokyo say they would prefer a Japanese-speaker and expert on Japan in the Ambassador's office, but almost everyone acknowledges that Mondale is a good argument for Big Cheese ambassadors.
Monderu-san, as he is known in Japan, is the most powerful foreigner in the country these days. He was deeply involved in this year's effort to improve access to the Japanese market for American cars and auto parts, and he is constantly advising Washington on how to pursue other trade issues. But perhaps more important for the long run, he has emerged as a leading spokesman for close security ties between the United States and Japan and especially for an expansion of student-exchange programs so that more Americans can live in Japan and learn Japanese while they are young.
There are not that many ways a former Vice President can feel useful, and being the Ambassador to Japan is one way he can remain active and important -- and enjoy perks like a $100 million mansion that comes with a pool and a vast garden, not to mention a residential staff of 16.
"Life here is very enjoyable," Mondale says as he relaxes in his spacious office, decorated with posters and photographs from a life in politics. It is a bit odd for Americans who remember Mondale as the boy politician -- Minnesota's Attorney General at 32 and Senator at 37, Vice President at 49 -- to see him now, at 67, as a gray-haired elder statesman.
He was an icon of American liberalism, a bleeding heart in the days when it was still respectable to be one. Mondale was not telegenic, and that may have been one reason he was soundly defeated by Ronald Reagan in the 1984 Presidential election. But to his fans, his difficulties with television only confirmed his sincerity and honesty. In an age of television packaging, Mondale made a terrible product, partly because his best-known campaign promise was to raise taxes.
In person, Mondale comes across as everything he does not on the screen: warm, personable and relaxed. He seems comfortable with his own status now, perhaps because he no longer has his eye on the Oval Office.
"This is a nice time of my life," he says. "I have no political aspirations, and haven't for some time. I find this to be a cure -- there's no medicine for it -- because I know I won't ever run for anything again. So this is a way of being in public life, doing something different and in a strange way having a kind of independent operation here."
Mondale has given up not only on learning the Japanese language but also on certain Japanese customs. The Japanese bow a dozen times a day, the degree of incline carefully calibrated to the status of the other party, but Mondale does no more than nod. "A Minnesota bow," he calls it. Similarly, just about everybody in Japan hands out business cards at meetings, except the Emperor and Empress (not only would it be undignified, but they don't have a last name). But as an "omono" -- literally, a "venerable being" -- Mondale leaves his cards at home.
Since he knows much less about Japan than does his staff at the embassy, many of whom speak excellent Japanese and would not be caught alive with their kimonos tucked right over left, Mondale is at his best when using his considerable political skills to push the American agenda. He is charming but forceful in pressing Japan to open its markets, and he exudes prestige.
Mondale as a politician was an oddity in that he was always a conciliator, never a polarizer. "The thing that is most evident about Mondale is that he's nonabrasive," said Hubert H. Humphrey, his fellow Minnesotan and patron. This skill for peacemaking makes Mondale's adjustment to diplomacy easier than it would be for many politicians.
Still, there is no question that in some ways Japan has been a monumental disappointment for Mondale. He arrived at a very hopeful time, shortly after the collapse of a system that had kept the Liberal Democratic Party in power for 38 years straight. It looked as if Japan were undergoing a revolution. There was hope that red tape and bureaucracy would come crashing down, easing the way for a flood of American goods.
No wonder Mondale said, before he arrived in Tokyo, that he wanted "a more dignified relationship" based on something more than fistfights about trade. He said then that he had not been drawn back into public service to spend his time badgering Japan over semiconductors and wood products.
And then the Japanese revolution collapsed. Hosokawa resigned after being tarred by scandal. Within a year, the Liberal Democrats had effectively returned to power. Mondale found that his appeals to open markets were stonewalled, just as similar appeals had been for decades before. He seemed to those around him to drop into what his former boss, Jimmy Carter, might have called a deep malaise.
"There was just a businessman in my office from New York," he tells his assistant, Andrew Myers, as he stands in the corridor outside his office. "He's trying to sell medical equipment here. He's been buying equipment here for years, and now with the high yen, he's trying to sell as well. But he just can't get in." Mondale sighs and turns to a visitor. "I hear that story 10 times a day."
Mondale grew increasingly frustrated as time passed. One of his ancestors in Norway, before his great-grandfather left the eponymous Mundal village in 1856 for America, is said to have been a seventh-century chieftain who consolidated power by inviting rivals to a banquet in a building with one door and no windows. When the guests were all drunk, the host excused himself and locked the door -- and then burned the building to the ground. Asked if he was ever tempted to try the same tactic during arduous trade negotiations, Mondale smiles enthusiastically. "It came pretty close," he says.
It was during this irritating period of Japanese political paralysis that Mondale apparently decided that he would be more than an elder-statesman Ambassador. He waded in and twisted the arms of Japanese officials. The man who once curled up his lip at the idea of badgering the Japanese about microchips has lately been badgering the Japanese about cars, air freight and Kodak film.
In Mondale's office, as in his home, there is a telephone console that enables him to make scrambled calls to Administration officials without the risk of Japanese eavesdropping. Among the speed-dial buttons, the one labeled "Kantor" is near the top, well above "Christopher."
Of course, Mondale does talk regularly to Warren Christopher, the Secretary of State, as well as occasionally to President Clinton. But he seems to talk most to Mickey Kantor, the trade negotiator. And that, in turn, perhaps says something about the Administration and its emphasis on trade as a central element of foreign policy.
"The way in which we connect with each other in the post-cold-war world is increasingly based on trade and investment, international economics," Kantor says. "Ambassador Mondale understands this as well as anybody, and he has tried to change that embassy to be more responsive to and have personnel trained with regard to economic issues and trade issues."
Kantor and Mondale go way back, to 1969, and Kantor describes the Ambassador as a mentor as well as a friend. "I value his input almost more than that of anybody else," he says.
During the auto talks, Mondale was a major force in determining strategy, as well as applying pressure on the Japanese Government and the heads of the auto companies. Some Japanese believe, however, that Mondale misread the situation -- partly because he listens to trade hawks -- and advised Washington that the Japanese were more willing to compromise than they actually were. That, they believe, is why the negotiations reached a dangerous impasse before a final round of talks in Geneva at the end of June, when both sides finally retreated and declared victory.
Mondale was in the fray throughout. During a break in a World War II memorial service in Okinawa, he met with Japan's Trade Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, to work out the last-chance meeting in Geneva. Then he met secretly with Shoichiro Toyoda, the chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation, to discuss Toyota's plans for voluntary purchases from America and how this could be used to avert sanctions.
During the final hours, he stayed up all night to remain in telephone contact with Kantor and other negotiators in Geneva. The final agreement, a package of steps that will make it somewhat easier to sell cars and parts in Japan, was reached in the early morning, Tokyo time, and Mondale stayed up to watch television coverage of the pact. Shortly after 7 A.M., Japan's Foreign Minister, Yohei Kono, called to invite him over for a victory breakfast in the nearby Okura Hotel.
"It was terrific," Mondale said a few hours later, his eyes still puffy from lack of sleep. "We had a great time. And I think we have a good trade agreement." The bottom line, he said, is that the deal will mean far more sales of American auto parts and vehicles in Japan, and thus more jobs in America. And he argues that progress in reducing the American trade deficit with Japan will in turn foster a much healthier overall relationship between the two countries.
"If we've made important progress in autos, that removes one of the most contentious issues," Mondale said. "You know, I remember the semiconductor agreement -- a few years ago, that was one of the biggest issues, but now the heat has come out of it. Every time you solve one of these hard problems, one of these basic areas, you take some of the heat out of the trade relationship."
Conversely, the case can be made that one of the most important consequences of the auto negotiations was to bolster the side of Japanese nationalists who argue against caving in to American pressure. Hashimoto, the Trade Minister, is a master of kendo, or Japanese fencing, and keeps his equipment ostentatiously in his huge office, as if to challenge any impertinent American to a duel at a moment's notice. Throughout the negotiations, Hashimoto took a consistently tough line, and it helped him politically, so that this fall he became Deputy Prime Minister and head of the Liberal Democratic Party, the nation's biggest political party. He thus stands an excellent chance of becoming Prime Minister and incorporating his tough negotiating style into the broad range of relations with the United States. American diplomats who butted heads with Hashimoto over trade may now butt heads with him over security issues as well.
In speeches and meetings, Mondale constantly tells Japanese officials that it is in Japan's own interest to deregulate and open up its markets. But while officials often agree in principle, changing specific regulations is a grueling process. Sometimes the interest groups that will be most affected by the new rules are effectively in charge of drafting the changes, and the bureaucracy often leads the Parliament, or Diet, instead of the other way around.
"In the Diet, when you see bureaucrats also participating in the debates, answering questions, preparing amendments, preparing the budgets, you realize that this is a society in which the publicly elected side is very limited," Mondale says. Political change will come, he believes, but very slowly.
"This has been the toughest part of my job, without any question," he says. "Boy, trying to get a more open Japan economically has been very difficult. You can talk forever, but you don't get anywhere. I keep looking for some way of getting it done, but I haven't been able to find it."
Despite his frustrations with Japan's trade restrictions, Mondale wishes that the United States would learn from Japan in some other respects. Japan's savings rate, for example, is several times higher than that of the United States. And the safety of Japanese streets and the absence of guns are also worth pondering, he says.
"I believe the U.S. is too violent and has too many guns," Mondale says. "It's no longer just a domestic issue. I think it cuts across America's moral authority in the world. Maybe we have something to learn from Japan about how people are raised to prevent violence, to be more thoughtful toward one another."
As a former Vice President, Mondale is hugely respected in Japan. In the Japanese culture, "retired" executives sometimes still run companies they have quit, and "retired" politicians control prime ministers. The Japanese know that Mondale is no longer at the center of power, but he is undoubtedly appreciated more in Tokyo than in Washington.
Yet he has been less active on the rubber-fish lecture circuit and less prominent in the public eye than his predecessor, Michael Armacost. Mondale has invested much of his time in diplomatic functions and behind-the-scenes meetings and has been less energetic and less visible than Armacost was in calling on Japan to change its ways. Armacost's tactics were not popular -- he was nicknamed Mr. Gaiatsu, or Mr. Foreign Pressure -- but they did have an impact in helping set the public agenda. Mondale is better liked but less conspicuous.
Mondale does make some public appearances, of course, and he seems to thrive on meeting young people. During a recent question-and-answer session at Keio University in Tokyo, the question that engaged him the most was why more Americans are not studying in Japan.
"If we could get many, many more Americans over here as high-school students living in homes, it would make a tremendous difference," Mondale replied. But he cited various problems, including Japanese Government restrictions on branch campuses of American universities.
The gap in students is something that deeply troubles Mondale, and he often notes that 45,000 Japanese study at American universities while only 1,700 Americans study in Japan. The American Embassy is studying ways to boost the number of Americans studying in Japan, and negotiations are under way on some proposals to open the doors.
"I'd like to see 50,000 American students over here, starting at the high-school level," Mondale said at Keio. "I feel very strongly that that's the most important thing. Politicians and diplomats deal with what is there. All we can do is kind of move the chairs around the table a little bit. Your generation can move the whole thing, by opening up, by coming to know each other better, by learning each other's languages and cultures."

HEADLINE: The Lake District

 BODY:
To the Editor: For newcomers to this beautiful corner of England, it serves neither economy nor comfort to sleep cheaply and dine expensively. Ms. Spano could have joined the Youth Hostels Association, which, including her membership for one year, would have provided more comfortable if somewhat less Spartan conditions, and breakfast and dinner for $25 a day. Or she could have used one of the many bed-and-breakfast hotels throughout Keswick, Borrowdale and Buttermere for very little more than her average cost of $39 a day. 
 A little prior research, by purchasing a copy of A. Wainright's guide "The Central Fells" (Michael Joseph, London), available from larger New York City bookstores, would have counseled her on wearing two pairs of socks in her boots to avoid blisters and on buying Bartholomew's one-inch map (easier to follow than the Ordnance Survey Map). Mr. Wainright's walking guides are bibles to the fell walkers and offer incisive information along with easy-to-follow routes and drawings and would have saved Ms. Spano that four-hour slog along the busy shore road of Lake Derwent Water in favor of a relaxing and scenic trip on the lake steamer from Keswick to Ashness Bridge for Watendlath. En route the boat stops at High Brandlehow, once the home of Sir Hugh Walpole, which I mention only because as she enjoyed her tea, scones, jam and thick clotted Devon cream in the tea shop she apparently did not notice a plaque: "This is the home of Judith Paris, heroine of the novels of Hugh Walpole."
 
BERNARD J. CUNLIFFE
Sparta, N.J.
 
Susan Spano responds: The Buttermere Youth Hostel, Derwent Water launch, a B &B in Keswick for $25 a night, and Alfred Wainwright were all mentioned in the article. I got blisters not for lack of an extra pair of socks but because my boots needed breaking in, and I would never call the walk along the beautiful east side of Derwent Water a slog. Finally, though the barns where I stayed offered few amenities, which I wanted to make perfectly clear, walking between them was for me a wonderful experience.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1453 words

HEADLINE: Politically Correct? Perish the Thought!

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
HE is the co-author of several children's books, one of which, "My Brother Sam Is Dead," is usually getting banned somewhere on the contention it is too profane and excessively violent.
He thinks that public school education, particularly when it comes to teaching history, runs the gamut from deplorable to terrible. 
 And he doesn't think Nathan Hale should have been designated as Connecticut's official state hero.
Is this some spokesman for the anti-education lobby or a radical who wants to rewrite history to his own liking? No, not really. In fact, not even close.
He is Christopher Collier, professor of history at the University of Connecticut and official historian of the state of Connecticut. An author, scholar, swimmer, hockey player, water skier, figure skater, even trumpet player, Mr. Collier is a man of many parts, and certainly of many opinions.
At home in Orange, in a lovingly restored 18th-century home where he lives with his wife, Bonnie, a librarian at Yale, Christopher Collier fits the image of the man of academia, surrounded by books and graceful furniture.
Then he starts to talk and the Mr. Chips image starts to implode. This is no tweedy educator selecting his words slowly and carefully, as if he were addressing a class of freshmen. This is a man of opinions, freely stated. The words come tumbling out on any subject that happens to come up, none excluded. On some subjects he happens to be more passionate than others. Historical revisionism, for instance. He's for it.
"All historians are revisionists," he said. "They change as new evidence comes to light."
What he disagrees with, very much so, is with people who revise history simply to make it more acceptable, to soften it up, even to deny some things ever happened or some words were ever used: the N word for instance.
Mr. Collier often has used the loathed word in the historical novels for children that he writes with his brother, James Lincoln Collier. It is the word, of course, also sprinkled through Mark Twain's "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," a more famous work banned now and again because of it.
The two Colliers use the word in their books, Christopher Collier said, because it was a common word in the America of the 18th and 19th centuries and indeed much later.
The Colliers explained in an addendum to one of their books, "Who Is Carrie?" that they had to consider very carefully the use of the word because they know it is offensive to modern readers "but it would have been a distortion of history to avoid its use entirely."
In any case, the sometime-banning of "My Brother Sam Is Dead," the story of a Connecticut boy caught up in the Revolutionary era conflict of his Tory father and his rebel brother Sam, has not affected the prestige, or sales, of the book since it was published in 1974.
It received accolades from the start (one reviewer said it "assumes for once that children can think"), was named of a Newbery Honor Book and has sold more than 1.5 million copies to date.
What bothers Christopher Collier perhaps even more than people who distort history for acceptability is how badly he believes history is being taught today.
"I know some superb teachers, but generally teaching is mediocre to terrible in elementary schools," he said. "Some teachers are teaching American history with only one semester of it in college, which is all that is required. We've fought to make it two semesters and that should be the minimum for anyone teaching it."
He is no great admirer of public education as it is today in general, certainly not of what he considers to be less than a substantial effort put forth by many teachers. "We need a more professional attitude," he said. "Teachers should be working 50 to 80 hours a week and then rest in the summer, which they get off anyway. If we're paying them $50,000 to $60,000 a year, they should be willing to do this."
One thing that particularly disturbs him, he said, is the lack of writing assignments, a lack he traces to the reluctance of high school teachers to spend the time reading and correcting papers.
Several years ago, he said, one of his sons was a student at Amity Regional Senior High School in Woodbridge and at a school event for parents the principal mentioned that they were welcome to drop in at classes any time. So one day, Mr. Collier did just that, spurred on, he said, by questions such as why his son had had only one writing assignment in English for an entire school year and no writing assignment in history at all.
He was not happy by what he encountered. His appraisal of the faculty that taught his son: "He had one superb teacher, in physics. The rest were mediocre to terrible."
As much as Mr. Collier is critical of secondary school teachers -- "You can tell kids aren't ready for college by the way they write, there's very little worthwhile instruction in writing in high school" -- he is more critical of parents.
"The central problem is television," he said. "Parents are more interested in watching TV. If kids aren't reading, the blame should go to the parents. There are real failures in education because teachers are failing but parents are failing more."
It might be assumed that he would take take a softer stance about teaching history at the college level, his level. Drop that assumption. He is pacing around his living room, as he is wont to do, and says that he really doesn't want "to get into something with my colleagues, but teaching of history in college is some of the worst I have ever seen."
One professor, he said, announces at the start of a term that he will not entertain any questions from his students. Another reads, in a monotone, from a prepared script. Some just want students to memorize dates that will get them through a quiz -- but which they will have forgotten two days after the quiz.
Teaching, he said, should be better than that. "The first thing any teacher should do is not think about teaching but think about learning. I want students who are involved in a project. I want active involvement, not passive listeners."
He seldom sits in his classes. "I walk around, I wave my arms." In one class, he climbs onto his desk and then leaps off to make a point about the beliefs of early American settlers, explaining that as today's people believe explicitly in the laws of gravity so did the settlers believe explicitly in the power of good and evil and in witchcraft.
He seems to be possessed of an unlimited store of energy, which he burns off in many ways.
"I was never very good at athletics when I was younger," he smiles, "but I had a second adolescence when I was in my 50's." His wife is a very accomplished figure skater, so he took that up. Then he extended it to playing hockey and other sports. Last month was a good one for the band in which he plays trumpet: three gigs. All this activity keeps him as lean and fit as a middleweight boxer.
Somehow, he finds time to be the state historian. "I spend most of the time answering questions," Mr. Collier said. "People call up and I can answer some of the questions off the top of my head but others take two hours of research."
The job originated with the state's tercentenary celebration in the 1930's, and Mr. Collier has been the historian since 1985, recommended by the trustees of the University of Connecticut and appointed by Gov. William A. O'Neill.
The job paid nothing but a stipend of $4,800 a year was allocated for expenses. That was cut out five years ago because of the state's economic crunch, so now Mr. Collier spends his own money for such items as postage stamps. "I even buy the letterhead," he said.
He is not happy about it but accepts it philosophically and the office does give him a platform for what he considers a more realistic view of history. Nathan Hale, for example, the Revolutionary War figure hanged by the British who was named by the General Assembly as the state's official hero several years ago.
"It was inappropriate," Mr. Collier said. "Nathan Hale was a failed spy alleged to have made one statement, but we don't know that he said it." ("It," of course, was "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.")
He also isn't thrilled that Prudence Crandall, who opened a school in Canterbury for young black women in the first half of the last century, has more recently been designated as the state's official heroine. "She was a one-issue person and her case was doomed from the start."
In an age of political correctness, Connecticut's state historian can be most politically incorrect and that doesn't seem to bother him at all.
He doesn't believe in politically correct.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Collier, state historian, at home in Orange. "All historians are revisionists," he said. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Outside Southern Counties, Prices Are Often Lower

BYLINE: By VICTORIA WHITE

DATELINE: INVERNESS, Fla.

 BODY:
OUTSIDE southern Florida, many parts of the state offer housing that Northerners find attractive, often at a lower price than in Dade, Broward or Palm Beach Counties, and in a more relaxed environment as well.
But there is also dynamic growth, and the center of it at present is the Orlando area. Jacksonville is another growth center, and by some accounts it has become one of the better locations for young people seeking starter homes. 
 The housing stock around the state is varied -- from modest two-bedroom houses for as little as $30,000 in rural outposts to properties selling in the millions in Orlando, Tampa and Naples. One common thread for many of them, in this peninsular state, is their access to water.
Waterfront properties can be found well inland from the coasts, as the many lakes and rivers offer their own natural vistas. Waterfront always comes at a price, but the price varies greatly by location. In the tiny town of Inverness, the seat of the rural central Gulf Coast county of Citrus, two-bedroom, two-bath condominiums on Lake Henderson go for as little as $55,000. Fifteen miles away, in Crystal River, that much money would buy a one-bedroom, one-bath unit on the water.
In the Orlando area, waterfront land is especially pricey. Lakefront land is selling for $400,000 to $750,000 an acre, according to Seminole County Property Appraiser Bill Suber. At those prices, people are buying the land only for large luxury homes. While there are still smaller 1950's-era homes on the lakes, they are beginning to be razed to make way for the pricier fare.
Near Jacksonville, beachfront property is selling for $3,000 to $7,000 a front foot.
The market for resale -- as opposed to new -- housing is described by brokers as "normal" -- neither in a boom nor a bust. In the Orlando area, four- and five-bedroom houses in gated communities are priced roughly between $200,000 and $300,000. Three-bedroom patio homes are listed from $150,000 and up.
In the Tampa Bay area, a favorite among retirees, two-bedroom, two-bath condominiums in gated communities list from $140,000 on up. Luxury homes on the west coast -- with more than 3,500 square feet of living space in golf-course communities -- are priced upwards of $300,000.
Then there are the rural counties, which offer great value for housing dollars for those who prefer the small-town or country experience. George Rusaw, whose Citrus County-based Rusaw Homes constructs 50 houses a year, said that in comparison with south Florida, "here a person can get a lot more property for a lot less money."
Mr. Rusaw's customers typically want to build on half-acre lots. In one of Citrus County's more upscale communities, Citrus Hills, a typical price for a half-acre lot would be about $15,000, he said. In urbanized south Florida, "half an acre would seem like an estate," Mr. Rusaw said. The houses he builds range in price from $60,000 to $160,000, and about 70 percent are sold with pools.
The company used to aim at a slightly higher market, but has discovered in the post-recession years that its customers -- many from the Northeast -- are arriving in Florida with fewer dollars to spend. "We feel that there are just fewer people who are selling up north, either by choice or the economy," he said.
TWO Rusaw customers, Norbert and Louise Galle, are typical. They sold their two-family home in the Glendale section of Queens for $250,000 two years ago. Had they sold earlier, they said, they might have received as much as $375,000 for it.
In Citrus County, they had Rusaw Homes build a house for $150,000. For their money, they got a 2,800-square-foot house with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a fireplace, living room, kitchen, dining room, washroom, two-car garage and a screened-in garden in a community with a clubhouse and pool.
The Galles chose Citrus County for its beautiful countryside, rural flavor and low traffic and crime. "After all those years in New York, I wanted to be in a nice quiet place," said Mr. Galle, a 58-year-old retired butcher.
Though a few years old, the 1990 census can give some indicators of the range of home values in the state. The median home value in Florida then was $77,100. The median in some rural counties was significantly lower. In Holmes County, on the Alabama border, the median was just $36,200. Other Panhandle counties also had modest values.
By contrast, the median value in Palm Beach County was $98,400. In the Florida Keys county of Monroe, the median value was $151,200.
The Orlando growth is fueled in large measure by the success of Disney World. The leader in the big-ticket amusement-park business is now delving into housing development. Disney Development Company is creating a planned community called Celebration just minutes from Disney World. First occupancy of homes will begin next July.
Celebration is planned to include 8,000 residential units. Town houses and detached homes are priced at $127,000 to $600,000. No units have been built yet, but interest has been brisk. Thousands have visited the Celebration preview center since it opened last summer.
Celebration is to include a golf course, school, parks and a mix of retail.
Elsewhere in the Orlando area, new housing is cropping up around the University of Central Florida in the $75,000 to $100,000 range. On the other end of the scale, said Mr. Suber, the appraiser, large, expensive homes were being constructed to cater to the many executives employed by the growing corporate presence in Orlando.
"We have several different developments which give you a country-type atmosphere, with very large homes of 4,000 to 6,000 square feet," he said. "They range in value from half a million to $7 million or $8 million."
IN Jacksonville, "there's an area that's just exploding," said Duval County Property Appraiser Ernie Mastroianni. Butler Boulevard stretches from the Intracoastal Waterway near the beach to Interstate 95.
"They can't build houses fast enough," Mr. Mastroianni said. "You're talking about tens of thousands of acres that used to be nothing but trees."
"As South and Central Florida are becoming more and more saturated, people are looking here," he said. "You can buy a much nicer home for the money than in Orlando, Tampa or Miami. You can get a starter home of maybe 1,200 to 1,400 square feet for $60,000 to $70,000. You're not going to find that in most places."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Plugging Into the Right Niche for New Housing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
HOUSING starts in Connecticut were down through late summer and early fall by as much as 20.3 percent from last year. But a developer who knows his or her niche can do surprisingly brisk business.
Two projects in different parts of the state at disparate but regionally competitive prices are currently attracting ready buyers thirsting for new construction. 
 Fox Glen, a 22-acre wooded tract in North Stamford, has sold houses from three blueprints on 8 of its 13 one- to two-acre lots, with combined prices ranging from $540,000 to $625,000. Prices rose within the last few months from an initial $525,000 to $595,000, "on the broker's advice," said the developer, Anne Leepson, president of Grayson Construction of Westport, "because there was no price resistance."
In Middlebury, 18 buyers snapped up the entire first sector of lots after seeing two models at Steeplechase, a 53-acre, 75-home cluster development. The houses, priced at $189,000 to $219,000 since opening for sales on Oct. 9, will soon cost $10,000 more.
Both builders expect to have buyers moving in by spring.
Location is still a high priority, but customizing has become a major component of the successful subdivision. The time when buyers were willing to accept a few cookie-cutter models as the only alternative to an individually designed and built house are as passe as the hula hoop.
Ms. Leepson operates on the one-stop shopping principle. "We do everything -- people like that," she said. "I am the designer, I have a draftsman who draws up the floor plans and an architect who does the blueprints."
Under Connecticut law licensed architects are not required to design homes, but local building officials are empowered to require architects for very large or complex residences.
"I design from a woman's point of view," said Ms. Leepson, "from the inside out. You buy a basic one-story A, B or C model and the land at the basic price. Then we sign a separate contract for customization. We will add a second story, even do the interior decorating if the customer wishes."
Lest anyone underestimate her basics, they include marble and hardwood floors, two bedrooms and convertible den, 2-and-a-half tiled or marble baths with whirlpools and bidets, carpeted bedrooms, 9-foot ceilings, fireplaces, granite or Corian kitchen countertops, top-grade appliances, oversized closets, central air-conditioning, flagstone patios, cedar siding, landscaping, and 2-car garages.
OTHER basic features might be an inner courtyard surrounded by the kitchen, living room, master bedroom and a glass-walled passage connecting two of the rooms. Or buyers may choose a vaulted great room open to the kitchen. Small sitting rooms and dressing rooms off the bedrooms are also basic in the 2,275- to 3,155-square-foot homes.
Ms. Leepson has been a builder for 15 years, the last four as head of her own mostly female company. Her vice president of operations is Susan McKeon and the administrator is Lynn McArdle.
"Years ago I had a kitchen guy who thought I was the little woman who owned the house," she said. "He couldn't understand that I was the general contractor. But over the years I've developed a group of men who work well with me."
Fox Glen homes are being sold to a growing market of empty-nesters in their 40's through 70's who spend a lot of time traveling or at a second home, and who no longer need to accommodate children.
Common charges of around $300 a month will pay for maintenance of landscaping, a small community pool, snow plowing and an elaborate security system that will encircle the complex. A key punch will open the gate and each house will be connected to a 24-hour monitor for fire and freezing emergencies and ambulance dispatch.
The developers in Middlebury named their project after the traditional horse race whose finish was marked by a distant church steeple, and whose course traversed the kind of unspoiled rolling countryside that prevails in this 188-year-old village. Some 6,200 people live within its 18 square miles, at the center of which are a small green, three venerable churches, a Town Hall, some Colonial houses and lots of very old, very tall trees.
Steeplechase Development Corporation of Woodbury bought the raw land in 1985. It was granted a zone change for clustered development and its site plan was approved just before the recession. The project was shelved in the late 80's.
Last year the group entered into a joint venture with Pemberwick Associates of Greenwich, an established development firm owned by Sy Schwartz and his son, Eric.
"Steeplechase was attractive to us," said Eric Schwartz, "because of the quality of the architecture, the high regard in which the town and its schools are held, the availability of public water and sewers, and the fact that there has been no comparable new construction in the area for decades."
He convinced the Yankee Gas Company to extend its main two miles from the town of Oxford to supply the complex with gas for heat, cooking, clothes drying and water heating.
While only two models have been built, five are available, designed by Drexel Yeager, an architect with Atelier Associates in Waterbury. Sales are going so well from plans that "we may never build the other models," said Mr. Schwartz.
Home sizes range from 1,700 to 2,200 square feet, surrounded by about a fifth of an acre of landscaped land. Some lots will be bordered by old stone fences, some will overlook a large natural pond.
CATHEDRAL ceilings and oversized windows, enormous closets, fully equipped kitchens, tiled baths, one to three bedrooms, lofts overlooking the foyers, family rooms open to the kitchens, one and two car garages, security systems, and wood-burning fireplaces are some of the basics in various models.
Large finished storage areas behind knee-walls, decks, central vacuum systems and air-conditioning are optional. Dormers can be built out for additional space.
The smallest house -- a 2-family model with two and three-bedroom units of 1,180 and 1,280 square feet, respectively -- will provide 20 percent of the total units. They will be scattered throughout the development and be available to people with household incomes of $49,000 to $56,350. The units will sell for $134,900 and $149,900.
In municipalities where less than 10 percent of the housing is for low- to moderate-income residents, developers who provide 20 percent of their units for such buyers may receive a density bonus. To be eligible, buyers must earn 80 percent or less than the area's or the state's median income, whichever is lower.
A menu of common charges will be available because "in this price range we felt that some people could not afford a mandatory $150 or $200 a month," said Mr. Schwartz. Everyone will pay $69 a month for maintenance of common areas, but residents may choose whether to enroll in individual maintenance plans at extra cost. Those who neglect their properties will be billed by the homeowner's association for having the work done for them.
Prospective buyers should be aware that Steeplechase is under the flight path of the Oxford Airport, two-and-a-half miles away, where 150,000 arrivals and departures of small private planes and corporate jets take place annually. Peter Zguzenski, the airport manager, said that there was a master plan for expansion, adding that flights would not increase unless area businesses in a 25-mile radius grow. So far, he said, "we haven't had any serious problems with neighboring residents."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, the Osborne house at Steeplechase, a 53-acre, 75-home development in Middlebury. Left, the Bronson model. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3070 words

HEADLINE: In Florida, A Market That Plays by Different Rules

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

DATELINE: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
"I NEVER had any intention of moving to Florida!" said Gloria Olsher. But there she is, to her astonishment, in the Palm Isles active-adult community in Boynton Beach, amid a bevy of new friends.
A retiree in her 60's with three children "back North," she made the move a year ago, yielding to the advice of old friends who were in Florida already. She bought a large villa unit -- a single-level home in a building with four units -- for $140,000, plus a few thousand more for upgrades such as larger floor tiles and patio screening. 
 Now she is happy beyond her expectations. "I bought a way of life," said Mrs. Olsher, who burned her bridges by selling her co-op in Bayside, Queens. "The people I'm friendly with feel the same way."
Florida still exerts its spell upon older adults and retirees who yearn for a leisured life in a warm climate. Many have already been visiting or vacationing there for years. The state also draws its share of younger Northerners who also seek a pleasanter style of life, but have career aspirations as well.
But if Mrs. Olsher is like many others who have preceded her, her first housing choice will not be her last. Interviews with people who have relocated full time to south Florida from the North, recently or long ago, underscore the fact that whatever people find on arrival, they often want or require something else eventually -- something better, different or elsewhere.
The breadth of choice is impressive. Not only is the inventory of available resale housing in south Florida substantial -- as even a glance at the thick weekly real-estate sections of The Miami Herald, The Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale, or The Palm Beach Post in West Palm Beach suggests -- but also much more new construction is under way than a visitor from the Northeast may be prepared for.
Some of that new construction is serving families on the move because of damage caused by Hurricane Andrew in 1992, and some of it is the result of corporate relocation and job movement. And some, buyers candidly admit, is caused by ethnic change. The very pace of new construction has the effect of limiting the rate of appreciation in existing housing that doesn't offer a special characteristic like an ocean view.
Geographically, the new development in south Florida stretches from the Florida Keys northward through Miami Beach and sections of Broward and Palm Beach Counties. There are several current development hotspots, including some farther north in St. Lucie, Indian River and Brevard Counties.
The range of housing styles and prices is striking as well. Much of the development is in large-scale communities with gated entrances and common recreational facilities. New infill housing on unbuilt land in already developed neighborhoods, common in northern communities, would be an unusual sight in south Florida.
There are high-rises on or near the ocean, and single-family, patio, villa and condominium units, built to varying densities, often in subdivisions that take several years to complete and sell out. Most of it is meant as primary housing for middle-income Floridians.
There are also adult communities for older people, with a considerable range in house sizes and styles, amenities and prices. There may be a large clubhouse, or a modest one, or none at all. A golf course, or golf courses, may be on the site. At a country-club community there will be not only a golf course but also a membership club in which an equity participation is part of the purchase price.
Many of the adult communities emphasize the "lifestyle" they offer rather than the housing only, because they are heavy on elaborate well-staffed clubhouses with ongoing recreational activities and even theaters, and they sometimes have an age restriction: one member of the household must be over 55. But many developments describe themselves as "family oriented" because they are light on clubhouses and organized activities, and even those that have them and are clearly oriented toward retirees may shy from describing themselves as age restricted. Why turn away buyers?
Finally, there are continuing-care and assisted-living developments for people who want still higher levels of services. New arrivals are usually in their 70's, or older.
Compared with the mid-80's, the pace of new development is subdued. "There have been times when there was so much on the market you couldn't give it away," said James G. Mueller, a principal in Prudential Florida Realty, which has 65 Florida offices. "Now there's an ample inventory, but less than last year. The hardest thing to find is waterfront property at a modest price." By "modest" he means under $250,000, he said. Many others seem to want units on golf courses for under $125,000, also not an easy find.
For moderate prices many out-of-staters have been turning toward mid-Florida -- the Orlando area in particular -- or the Tampa-St.Petersburg-Clearwater area on the west coast, or the farther northern reaches of the east coast, Mr. Mueller said.
In the Miami Beach area there has been a mild resurgence in new high-rise construction. It includes such projects as the oceanfront Grand Bay Residences on Key Biscayne Island; the 44-story Portofino Tower in the Latin-flavored South Beach section of Miami Beach, and the 32-story Mirabella condominium off Collins Avenue, also in Miami Beach. New high-rises are taking shape in the Aventura section of North Miami, and farther north in Fort Lauderdale, in Broward County.
In the more westerly reaches of Broward County the region is witnessing its largest current burst of new primary housing. Pembroke Pines, which also has one of the newer Century Village retirement communities, is a new center of this growth. Farther north, the communities of Coral Springs and Parkland are also centers of new residential construction. Such builders as Lennar Homes, Engle Homes, GL Homes and Minto Builders, a company based in Ottawa, are putting up small-lot single-family houses in gated subdivisions, with pools and tennis courts. In this relatively low-land-cost area new housing can be found in the price range of $100,000 and $200,000.
FARTHER north, in Palm Beach County, the new offerings range beyond age-mixed family housing to include communities more specifically attractive to older adults and second-home owners. In Boca Raton, Delray Beach, Boynton Beach, Lake Worth, West Palm Beach, Palm Beach Gardens, and Jupiter farther north, builders are catering to middle-income, upper-middle-income and wealthy buyers. Prices may range from $150,000 to $400,000 and beyond.
Still farther north, another growth center is in St. Lucie County, with both primary and retirement housing emerging in Port St. Lucie and St. Lucie West. Prices are lower than in Palm Beach County. New housing can be found for under $100,000, brokers say, and rarely costs more than $200,000.
"The emphasis now in new construction is on detached houses at more affordable prices -- even in the luxury country-club communities," said Lewis Goodkin, a Miami-based consultant to national building companies. Buyers who used to find attached housing or "stacked" units in condominiums on two to four levels now are buying detached houses, frequently at prices $10,000 to $20,000 lower than such houses would have cost in the late 80's, Mr. Goodkin said.
Sales activity has grown steadily since the recession years of the early 90's, and in 1994 reached its highest level of the 90's in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties, he said. But this year, to widespread surprise, the sales trend has turned downward. Mr. Goodkin projects an 11 percent drop in new-home sales and about 7 percent in resales.
One reason may be that that higher prices have frozen out more buyers at the lower end of the market, he said. Another may be that the economy has picked up in the Northeast so that the exodus of jobs has slowed.
Figures prepared by Appraisal and Real Estate Economics Associates Inc., a Miami consulting firm, show that in the last few years about one sale in every four is of a new house rather than a resale house -- a high proportion in comparison with the Northeast, where older housing historically has attained favorable appreciation rates in many locations.
Last year, for example, 11,600 new houses were sold in Broward County and there were 36,200 resales. Through June of this year there were 4,500 new-home sales and 16,400 resales.
The resellers are often buying new houses. Among them are many buyers who came originally from the North.
Two such are Irwin Schwartz, 65, and his wife, Estelle, late of Fair Lawn, N.J. They moved 15 years ago, largely to escape Northeastern winters. They had been living in a house in Pembroke Lakes, in western Broward, but now have bought a $170,000 house in a new gated community called Pembroke Falls, a mile away, to be finished next year. Eventually there will be 2,000 single-family houses on 1,500 acres, including a lake, but so far there is mostly raw land and a sales office. Engle Homes, based in Boca Raton, is the developer. The couple exemplifies the move-up buyer of retirement age. Their new house will have four bedrooms, three baths and a two-car garage, a view over a manmade lake, and young families with children all around. One bedroom will be used by Mr. Schwartz as an office for his work as a part-time arbitrator in the juvenile-justice system. Another will be Mrs. Schwartz's art studio. The third will be a guest bedroom for their grandchildren. The fourth will be for themselves.
"This home will appreciate in value, whereas if I bought a smaller house it wouldn't appreciate as much," Mr. Schwartz said. "Who would you sell it to? Empty-nesters or people without children. The sales advantage is to too small a group."
Then there are Michael and Tobi Altholz, who left Brooklyn 23 years ago. They lived 11 years in Kendall, in southwest Dade County, and bought a house six years ago in Weston, a 10,000-acre Arvida/JMB Partners planned community in southwest Broward. Now they have moved to the exclusive Jasmine section of Weston, with houses ranging from $300,000 "to the millions," Mr. Altholz said, declining to disclose what he paid.
"It's not easy to make a profit on a resale," said Mr. Altholz, a 52-year-old sales manager for International Paper. He bought a house with 2,700 square feet of air-conditioned, or under-the-roof, space (and 3,500 square feet if the patio-with-pool and two-car garage are included), while managing to sell a more modest house at Weston for about the $140,000 he paid for it five years ago. Sellers in Florida, as at Weston, are frequently in competition with developers building new houses at the same location, and the preference for the new is pervasive among many Florida buyers.
AT Weston one of the more unusual new models is in the Bay Isles section of Weston Hills, a country-club community within Weston. It utilizes the courtyard approach: The front door opens on a courtyard, in which there is an in-the-ground swimming pool. Visitors can be let in by buzzer in from the house itself, which has 2,650 square feet of air-conditioned space. A 200-square-foot studio apartment occupies the front side of the courtyard, well-suited as a guest apartment. The house with pool sells for $267,000, or $285,000 with the guest house.
A more elaborate use of the courtyard approach is to be seen in the Ballentrae community in Port St. Lucie, which K. Hovnanian Companies of Florida is developing. Dr. Michael Carelli, a 31-year-old optometrist, and his wife, Leah, who relocated to Florida in 1991 from the Grasmere section of Staten Island, bought a $260,000 two-bedroom house with 2,700 square feet of air-conditioned space and a 1,650-square-foot courtyard with a swimming pool and Jacuzzi. A 500-square-foot studio apartment faces the courtyard.
"We'd been living in Florida for six years and never seen anything like it before," Dr. Carelli said.
Real estate consultants often use figures from the Internal Revenue Service as an indicator of where people from other states choose to live when they move to Florida. The I.R.S. data show the changes in residence of taxpayers, by county.
Last year, for example, of the 761,000 returns filed from Dade County, 25,000, or 3 percent, had been filed from a different county the year before. The inmigrants accounted for 7 percent of the 568,000 returns from Broward and 17 percent of the 412,000 filings from Palm Beach County.
It turns out that a substantial share of these new arrivals are from New York City and 10 nearby counties. These 13,400 tax returns, which presumably represent about that many households, accounted for 14 percent of the arrivals to the three counties. About 5,000 went to Broward County, 4,000 to Dade and 4,400 to Palm Beach.
What the statistics fail to show is that many of the arrivals are headed specifically for adult communities. Oriole Homes, based in Delray Beach, is one of the main builders, with seven adult communities in various stages of completion in Palm Beach, Martin and Marion Counties in Florida.
"Older people have become so much more active!" said Mark A. Levy, president of Oriole. "They're living longer and they know they're going to live longer." That means that Oriole has added a racquetball court and more tennis courts in newer communities, provided more clubhouse staffing, added classes in tax planning, investments and health, and is buying computers for residents' use.
At its Coral Lakes development in Boynton Beach -- with 1,300 units planned and 200 already built -- there is to be a 71,000-square-foot clubhouse. Catering to what has been found to be a willingness of many buyers to live in less space for a lower price, it is adding four new models to last year's four, and selling in a price range of $140,000 to $180,000 instead of $160,000 to $180,000. The smallest unit will have 1,250 square feet of air-conditioned space and sell for less than $100,000.
The contrast in housing values dollar-for-dollar in Florida compared with what buyers are accustomed to in the North is striking to many buyers. Bernard Gerson, 70, retired from automotive sales business in Philadelphia, said that he and his wife, Eleanor, had bought a three-bedroom 1,886-square-foot condominium at Coral Lakes from plans last year for $124,000. They had been dividing their time between Philadelphia and a rented condominium in Delray Beach, but now they have sold the Philadelphia apartment.
"Dollar for dollar it's a better value down here," he said, telling of a large master bedroom with three closets and a huge living room, created by making an outdoor patio into an extension of the living room by the removal of doors. An active tennis player, he was also attracted by the development's five Har-Tru-surfaced tennis courts. Eventually there will be 10.
Some of the best values appear to be in the resale market. In the Miami area, for example, there has been about a 10 percent drop in the last 18 or 20 months in the prices of higher-end units, said Ronald A. Suffield, president of the Miami-based Esslinger-Wooten-Maxwell Realtors.
It is now possible to buy a two-bedroom condominium in a mid-80's full-services building on Key Biscayne Island, for example, for $150,000 to $250,000, he said, or a two-bedroom unit in a midrise building in Coral Gables, six miles south of downtown Miami near the University of Miami, for $140,000 to $160,000.
"The inventory of unsold homes is up 16 percent over a year ago," he said.
AMONG the people creating the vacancies are retirees who find their housing is no longer appropriate. "People in Florida retire twice, once in their mid-60's and then in their late-70's," said Terri Cunliffe, executive director of Edgewater Pointe Estates, a continuing-care adult facility in Boca Raton.
New entrants, even those in their 80's or early 90's, may still be in sound health and capable of independent living in their own apartments. But even those residents take two meals a day communally in an attractive dining room. And as their condition requires, personal-care services and nursing care are available to them as they age.
Edgewater Pointe Estates is owned by Adult Communities Total Services Inc., of West Point, Pa. Entrants pay a fee of $100,000 that is described as an "insurance policy," assuring residents of lifetime care at a fixed fee of about $1,000 a month whether they are living independently or in the personal-care or medical-care units.
"State regulations in Florida have made it very difficult to built a new facility," said George R. Gunn Jr., chief executive officer of the company. "The required reserves are very onerous." Reserve requirements are the liquid assets that an operator is required to maintain, currently pegged to the amount needed to carry a year's expenses for debt service, taxes and insurance, and 30 percent of a year's operating costs. There have been numerous financial failures of inadequately financed privately owned facilities for the elderly in Florida, and the state has had to step in to run them temporarily at public expense.
Mr. Gunn predicted that new facilities would not be built in Florida as the law stands. The state already has about 70 continuing-care communities housing an estimated 35,000 people.
THE newer retirees from the North typically still have their health and vigor, however, and are not focusing on the aging issue. After a year or two in Florida, they may be eager for unpressured work.
At the Wycliffe Golf and Country Club in Lake Worth, Max Samakow, who once ran retail stores at the Watergate complex in Washington and elsewhere, has opened a greeting-card shop three years after he and his wife, Shirley, bought at Wycliffe. They lived first in a condominium and later bought a $265,000 house. "We have such a social life here!" said Mrs. Samakow. "I don't have time to breathe."
Another Wycliffe owner, Norman Rubin, describes himself as a pre-retiree. He and his wife, Sandra, still in their late 50's, are in a $142,000 condominium with 2,200 square feet on the golf course, having sold a condominium they had for nine years in Bonaventura. They plan to spend four months a year back home in Randolph, Mass.
"I'm practicing for my full retirement," Mr. Rubin said. "When the time comes I'll play golf six days a week instead of three."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Will Democrats Return To the Fold on Tuesday?

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The Democrats would like this Election Day, when voters will choose the 80 members of the Assembly, to be a referendum on Newt Gingrich and the Republican revolution in Washington. Mr. Gingrich has not specifically accepted the challenge, but being venturesome, he might just be willing to.
There is plenty of evidence that Mr. Gingrich worries a lot of people in this state. Old-line Democrats who abandoned their party for Ronald Reagan and Christine Todd Whitman are drifting back to the fold, prodded by worries about layoffs and the economy. At the polls on Tuesday, we will find out if the prodigal Dems will be joined by any of the 1.1 million New Jerseyans over age 65, who have been voting Republican ever since they started living on Social Security and their pensions, but who may now wonder if a Democratic vote would send a message to Washington for Mr. Gingrich to lay off Medicare. 
 The Speaker was in Plainsboro last month at a big Republican fund-raising event where, far from urging state legislators to stick to local issues, Mr. Gingrich called the Republican anti-tax sweep of the Legislature in 1991 the model he followed in drawing up the Contract With America. He urged New Jerseyans to send a second message to Washington by re-electing Republicans this fall.
Well, a fight over Republican social spending plans is one briar patch that Tom Byrne, chairman of the New Jersey Democrats, would love to be thrown into. The Democrats believe that Mr. Gingrich and the Republicans have read the people wrong, and they believe that those senior citizens living in the piney woods down by the shore will stop worrying about Democratic taxes long enough to start worrying about Republican Medicare cuts.
After seeing Democratic strength in the shore communities dwindle with the shift in political power from cities like Asbury Park to planned communities with names like Breezy Acres Estates, Democrats in the state are hoping to pick up an extra 5 percent or so of the vote among retirees on the strength of their message about Medicare cuts.
"I think senior citizens understand now that Newt is interested in killing Medicare," Mr. Byrne said.
The Governor, however, is not interested in turning her midterm election into a national fight. Nor is she interested in being regarded as the center of focus for the race.
"This is not a referendum on me," she said on Wednesday, "so much as a referendum on the kind of government people have been getting since the Republicans took control of the Legislature in 1991."
Still, as Mr. Gingrich himself noted when the Governor traveled to Atlanta to help the Speaker raise campaign funds, Mrs. Whitman is one of the most popular public figures in the country, and in politics as in high school, popularity is what separates the winners from the rest of us.
The Governor has already won a partial reprieve from Mr. Gingrich in the schedule for reducing the growth of Medicaid payments, a change that lets New Jersey cut back more slowly on the program for poor people and the disabled than Congress had at first planned. The change will save the Governor nearly half a billion dollars over seven years, but it still leaves her facing about $300 million in reduced Federal spending over the same period.
"Does that mean we will be getting less Federal dollars? "Yes," Mrs. Whitman said loyally. "But that is the kind of thing we Republicans have to do to get control over Federal spending."
Then the Governor took a bold step, in answering a question about the impact of Federal and, perforce, state cuts in aid to the poor.
"The presumption that the poor and the elderly are going to be hurt by this is based on the presumption that we, as governors, can't find efficiencies," Mrs. Whitman said. She cited an effort to keep the elderly in their own homes as long as possible, where caring for them is cheaper than in nursing homes.
It is true that Congress is giving governors a freer hand to design and operate Federal programs at the state level, but the idea that hundreds of millions of dollars can be saved by tinkering with the mechanics of social policy is a daunting one. It is also a reminder that Mr. Gingrich may speak of first principles and root causes, but it is the governors like Mrs. Whitman who will have to make the programs work.
The Democrats are betting that she will not be able to do it, not in a way that voters will accept. But then, two years ago, the Democrats and a lot of other people also bet that Mrs. Whitman couldn't tinker more than $1 billion in tax cuts out of state operations, too.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
One County's Transit Decongestant

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK

 BODY:
Chester P. Mattson has a vision. The way he sees it, roadway congestion, commuting time, employment distribution, daytime population (and what he has discovered about these things in the last few years) make the vision not only desirable but also inescapable.
Mr. Mattson, Bergen County's director of planning and economic development, wants to build a $1 billion transit system that would include trolleys, trains and ferries, use existing rail lines, and provide frequent service for the growing number of intra-county commuters, perhaps as early as the year 2000. That's what he told the County Board of Freeholders at a formal presentation last Wednesday. 
 "These are radical plans, but they fit the needs," he said. "We live in an all-day economy that's congested all day."
The plan, known as the Bergen County Year 2000 Rail Transit System, is still largely a dream,tagged with the usual caveats of availability of funds, environmental assessment and possible local opposition. But if even a portion of the system were to become a reality, it would help relieve congestion, and perhaps serve as a model for other areas, both urban and suburban.
"A flexible transit system that can accommodate traditional trips to the region's core and suburb-to-suburb trips to the periphery is something we really need," said Jon Orcutt, associate director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. "Fairly dense urban areas could take a cue from this."
These are key points of the plan Mr. Mattson hopes will offer service seven days a week.
* A nine-mile trolley line using the New York Susquehanna and Western Railway to shuttle passengers from a new garage at the interchange of the Garden State Parkway and Route 80 in Saddle Brook to the Vince Lombardi park-and-ride lot in Ridgefield.
* A 3.5-mile trolley line extending the Saddle Brook line through a refurbished Susquehanna Tunnel into Edgewater, where ferries could deliver passengers to Manhattan.
* A six-mile commuter rail line connecting the Bergen line to the meadowlands sports complex, eventually continuing to the Vince Lombardi park-and-ride lot.
* An eight-mile commuter rail line on Conrail's West Shore right-of-way from the Vince Lombardi park-and-ride to Bergenfield.
* A 10-mile trolley link from Tenafly on the Northern Branch to Edgewater.
"What Bergen County has done is given us an overall framework for how a transportation sytem can be developed long term," said Frank J. Wilson, the State Commissioner of Transportation.
The proposals, which will be presented at public hearings starting in January, culminate five years of engineering and computer studies on work, travel and demographic patterns. The conclusion was that the southern half of the county was mired in an outmoded transit system and in danger of being eclipsed economically by less congested, more accessible areas, Mr. Mattson said.
The best recourse, he said, was a transit hub at the Vince Lombardi park-and-ride to provide links not only to the five pieces, but also to other systems like the Secaucus Transfer. That project, scheduled to be finished in 2001, would enable passengers to transfer to more New Jersey Transit train lines and Amtrak's Northeast Corridor.
So far, the reaction has been guarded but favorable.
"If it's not going to make Edgewater a big parking lot for mass transit, then it would be something good for the community," said Edgewater Mayor Bryan Christiansen, who attended Wednesday's meeting. "But this caught us so off-guard. It's like someone rolled up a brand-new automobile for no reason right in front of my house. If I go in and turn on the ignition, will it blow up, or will it work?"

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Making Music as Business and Art

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN

 BODY:
Once, Robert Tomaro and his Elysian Symphony Orchestra played the "On the Waterfront" film score in a pouring rain. Another time, he rearranged Stravinsky's "Histoire du Soldat" to accompany a screening of Buster Keaton's "Cameraman."
"I am committed to creating a synthesis of musical styles, to bring the new generation into symphony music halls," said Mr. Tomaro, whose eclectic background includes classical conducting and jazz guitar performance and composition. "We should be on the edge and play in some funky places." 
 If that's what it takes to sustain New Jersey's newest symphony orchestra, then that's what Mr. Tomaro will do. So far the group has done better than expected, putting on three concerts a year ahead of schedule and planning several more.
New Jersey has about 18 professional orchestras, professional being defined as paid. (The Elysian players earn about $175 for a concert and rehearsals, Mr. Tomaro said.) But none, except the Elysian, have started in the last five years, said John Peter Holly, president of the Association of New Jersey Orchestras.
Like many orchestras, the Elysian is the offspring of its conductor. Mr. Tomaro, 44, is an enthusiastic, ponytailed leader who feels equally comfortable guest-conducting the London Symphony Orchestra and playing guitar.
Last fall, Mr. Tomaro, who lives in Hoboken, gathered friends to form a board of directors and hired a lawyer and an accountant to file incorporation papers as a not-for-profit organization. They relied on a music contractor, Ralph Farris, who also plays viola, to recruit musicians from New York and New Jersey. Most are freelancers, so finding the right chemistry was crucial.
Board members dipped into their own pockets to print fliers. And the orchestra received a total of $21,700 from the city and private sources for three concerts.
The first, in February, was performed by a seven-piece chamber orchestra that played the Stravinsky. The second, in April, was the "On the Waterfront" concert, at the Erie Lackawanna Plaza on Hoboken's own waterfront with a 55-piece orchestra. The third, in July, featured a 25-piece orchestra playing Italian opera excerpts to celebrate the St. Ann's Italian Festival.
But the board doesn't want to rely on public money, and it has started a "Symphony 600" membership drive to sell 600 memberships, at $100 each. So far, more than 100 people have signed up.
"We all love music, but we really look at it as a business," said Robert W. Avery, a flutist who is vice president of the Elysian Symphony Orchestra and a board member of the Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra. "We're not romanticizing it as a musical, fun adventure."
Next Sunday, at the Demarest School in Hoboken, the Elysian will play works by Tchaikovsky and Barber, and on Dec. 14 it will to play Holst's "Planets," Mozart's "Jupiter" Symphony and Mr. Tomaro's "Celestial Navigation" at the Hayden Planetarium in Manhattan.
Promising, perhaps, but difficult, considering the odds. The popular and acclaimed Hoboken Chamber Orchestra essentially disbanded in 1992 after 10 years because of a lack of support and a stark economy.
Some people are also cautious about Mr. Tomaro's young-generation, hybrid-music approach.
"I'm a firm believer in the repertoire; it has stood the test of time," said Larry Tamburri, executive director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. "There's a misconception that audiences are getting older. Symphony orchestras have basically been the same age because people go to events when they have discretionary time and discretionary income."
Even so, musicians say they are impressed by the Elysian Symphony.
"It sounded excellent, and everything was professional," said Karen Stern, a harpist who played in the "On the Waterfront" concert and performs regularly with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. "Even though he's on a budget, he's still getting top-level people. I think word's getting out that there's a new orchestra in Hoboken."
