HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;
When Ships Come In, Bayonne Wants a Piece of the Action

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: BAYONNE

 BODY:
Sooner or later, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is going to need more port. Though there is still space at Ports Newark and Elizabeth and its ports in New York are underutilized, the agency is projecting steady growth for shipping in the region.
So when one of the best-located shipping ports in the area became available, the Port Authority responded. Last week, it sent a letter to the Federal Government expressing its interest in acquiring the Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne, a 437-acre base that juts two miles out into Upper New York Bay and was marked last spring for shutdown by the Pentagon. 
 "We anticipate increased trade for the port into the next century," the Port Authority chairman, Kathleen Donovan, wrote to the Maritime Administration of the Transportation Department on Oct. 26, "and regard the Bayonne facility as important to the total port's future capacity to accommodate that growth."
The availability of the base may be good news for the Port Authority, but in Bayonne, the agency's request was about as welcome as an earthquake.
Mayor Leonard Kiczek had hoped that the city would be able to acquire the base and sell it to a developer, generating millions of dollars in property taxes. The quasi-governmental Port Authority, Mr. Kiczek noted, does not pay taxes as such; it makes in-lieu-of-tax payment agreements with the cities that house its facilities, but usually much less than if the property were fully taxed. In Bayonne, the Port Authority pays $100,000 a year in lieu of taxes on 100 acres on which it operates an auto terminal. Mr. Kiczek said the taxes would be twice as high if the property were in private hands.
Mr. Kiczek (pronounced KEY-chek) says the chance to make money off a decommissioned base is supposed to be a community's compensation for the economic blow of the closure. The base, which has 2,445 workers, is the city's largest employer.
"The whole scheme of Federal base re-use is to get property productive again," he said.
The Port Authority said it sent the letter merely to keep the door open to maintaining the base as a port, and that the agency itself would not necessarily want to be the port's operator, though it runs all but one of the container ports in the region. "We're just putting it on the table to preserve the port for maritime use."said Gwen Williams, a spokeswoman for the agency.
Mr. Kiczek, noting that the letter states that the Port Authority "is interested in the possible acquisition of surplus Federal real property and . . . . wishes to preserve all possible rights and opportunities for acquisition," remains suspicious. His written request to the Port Authority to "reveal its true intention" had not been answered at week's end.
The future of the base is not expected to be decided for years, though Mr. Kiczek says he is already getting calls from interested developers. The military is not scheduled to vacate the property, a sprawling complex of yellow warehouses, barracks and docks that bring in tanks, cars and personnel carriers, until 1999. But Mr. Kiczek is a firm believer in planning.
He acknowledges that because of environmental damage at the site, which is built on fill, it may make more sense to maintain it as a port than to convert it into an industrial park, even though the latter would generate a lot more revenue.
But if there is to be a port, he wants Bayonne to operate it. He envisions a municipal port authority that would compete head to head with the Port Authority.
The decision on what to do with the base is largely up to the newly formed Base Re-use Commission -- of which Mr. Kiczek is chairman and on which the Port Authority sits -- with final approval from the Federal Government. Bayonne officials and businessmen have 6 seats on the 11-member panel.
"If the local redevelopment authority decides that what they want to do with the property is not consistent with the Port Authority taking it over, it doesn't go into their re-use plan," said Helen Hines, project manager for the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment.
Port battles are not exactly new to Bayonne. In 1917, the city's residents rejected a $10 million bond issue to build a new marine terminal near the site of the base, largely because of fears that it would attract an influx of cheap labor.
Frustration in Trenton with Bayonne's intransigence led to a call for a bi-state committee to develop the harbor.
"It remains to be seen," The New York Times wrote in an editorial at the time, "how much of an obstacle to the greater proposal is the local prejudices of a district which controls so much of the limited total of available water frontage."
The Port Authority was created four years later.

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;
What Does Camden Need? Education, Jobs and Mentors

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
"Let's face it: we need help."
So said Mayor Arnold Webster two weeks ago after Camden's 48th homicide this year, two shy of the city's record of 50 set in 1992 with two full months of 1995 to go. 
 These are not the best times for Camden, a city of 87,000 across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. It has a monopoly on bad breaks, and bad numbers: the murder rate is twice Newark's; one out of every five people is unemployed; more than half the population is under 25, and more than two-thirds receive public assistance.
There are encouraging signs. Since Halloween Eve 1991, when vandals started 133 fires, volunteers have kept the lid on arson and violence; this year, there were only seven building fires. New developments like the Thomas H. Kean New Jersey State Aquarium and Blockbuster-Sony Music Entertainment Center on the waterfront have been popular with visitors.
But Camden needs a lot more to wriggle free of poverty and reclaim its past as a bustling shipyard and manufacturing center. So several people familiar with the city were asked: "What does Camden need?"
 
Hubert Williams
President of the Police Foundation, a nonprofit research group in Washington, and former Newark Police director
"Camden is a city with a lot of urban problems and a diminished resource base. And the fact is, you're not going to get an infusion of money; you have to be savvy as possible about the use of existing resources.
"A city must take a good, hard look at each case to see what kind of patterns emerge. In Newark, we had problems with youths committing crimes, and a lot of kids were school-age kids playing hooky. So we got together with the superintendent of schools and picked up 9,000 kids in the first year, and the crime rate went down.
"If you have people who are selling drugs and their turf is a building, you go after the building: you go after the landlord, you use nuisance laws, whatever it takes. If they're selling drugs on the street corner, take pictures of the people on the corner. The idea is to make it as uncomfortable as possible for them to be in business."
 
Ali Sloan El
Member of the Camden Board of Education and candidate for City Council
"Let the grass-roots community introduce itself to the Police Department. If they put you and me out there, with a badge, a flashlight, and a walkie-talkie, the drug dealers won't do it. We should do it round the clock; people can do it part-time for maybe $10 an hour. It's the presence that counts.
"In the schools, we need to hire teachers from Camden city first, give them the opportunity to teach their children. Not everyone is an Einstein, so we should offer them a vocational complex that should be state-of-the-art. The children that we send out will have to rebuild Camden. They have to be counselors; they have to be teachers; they have to be policemen; they have to be carpenters, nurses.
"I've also been promoting a day curfew, from 9 A.M. to 2:30 P.M., for kids ages 6 to 16. Students are just walking around, chasing business people, robbing them during the daytime. This curfew would put them back in the school."
 
Mary Taylor Previte
Administrator, Camden County Youth Center in Gloucester Township
"Camden needs to feel safe. A lot of kids say they don't feel safe in homes, in streets, even in their schools. If someone feels unsafe, then reading, writing and arithmetic are the last things kids will think about.
"It isn't just government who can help; it's churches, schools, anyone who is a leader in the community. Parents have to spend more time with their children; on average, they spend 30 seconds a day. There's got to be a priority of family: spending time, being a role model, feeding the spirit of their children. Those are just the ABC's of parenting. Grown-ups need to be saying, 'We need more mentors.'
"The most important thing is that people need jobs. As soon as someone sees your address is Camden, they say, 'Don't call us; we'll call you.' We tell the young people to stay in school because getting an education is hard to counteract. Second, a lot of young people need a stable family that includes a very present man in their life.
"Girls will tell me: 'Ain't one house on my street with a dad. My mom gets into drugs, and I have to put food on the table.' "
 
Thomas P. Corcoran
President of Cooper's Ferry Development Association, a nonprofit organization developing the Camden waterfront
"Camden needs to create industrial parks; there are none now, and yet the city is ringed by industrial parks in Pennsauken, Cherry Hill and Bellmar. We could get some infrastructure grants or loans from state and county government to clear underutilized land, put in roads and sewage lines. You play off some businesses already located in Camden: food processing, commercial laundries, printing.
"Most job generation is going to be in the service economy, and we should look for companies that want to have back-office operations, like credit card operations, check processing, with people that can be trained in data entry. We have that labor force.
"We need to have additional restaurants and nightclubs. Next summer, we will open our first year-round restaurants on the waterfront, and we're trying to get one or two hotels to open up in a couple of years."
 
The Rev. Rick Malloy, S.J.
Associate pastor, Holy Name Church
"The main problem is the concentration of poverty. Our kids are caught in a slavery of drug-dealing. Why don't we hire a 20-man drug-seller outreach program to talk to these kids? Why don't we stop the buyer by going to his place of work and embarrassing him? Why don't we designate a certain number of social workers and Big Brothers?
"We need massive parenting programs, teaching parents how to parent kids. We need to get the young kids who go to Rutgers to come back and give to this community. We should have the unemployed rehabilitate the city's 3,000 abandoned houses.
"The frustrating thing is that Camden is doable; it's 87,000 people surrounded by wealth. To save this city would take very little in terms of investment, and you'd reap so many rewards."

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Forging Links With the Past at Long Pond

BYLINE: By ROSALIE STEMER 

 BODY:
In the shadow of the Ramapo Mountains in Passaic County, Long Pond Ironworks provided the American colonies with one of their most basic needs -- iron -- as they broke away from British rule. During the Revolutionary War, Long Pond's charcoal-burning furnaces furnished the iron for stoves, axes and ammunition for George Washington's troops. Iron from Long Pond also helped make the chain blockade strung across the Hudson River at West Point to block British ships.
In 1853, Peter Cooper and Abram S. Hewitt bought the ironworks and installed high-output furnaces that were to supply iron for Union guns in the Civil War. But the advent of furnaces burning anthracite coal limited Long Pond's days. Iron manufacturers found it economical to set up their plants near coal mines, and Long Pond put out its fires in 1882. 
 A hundred years later, Long Pond began to come back to life as Louis West, who grew up on the estate owned by Hewitt's descendants, started a restoration campaign.
Now Long Pond, located in West Milford, is a 140-acre historic park under restoration. A volunteer group, the Friends of Long Pond Ironworks, will offer a two-hour walking tour at no charge on Saturday. Their number is (201) 839-0128.
Mr. West, 82, the former manager of a general store there, talked about the importance of Long Pond.
 Q. Why is this location special?
 A. What I'm standing on here at Long Pond was once under British control. The history is so deep. The iron was the backbone of the nation in the Revolutionary War. People who come here can see how the iron industry helped our country in the War of 1812 and in the Civil War, too.
 Q. What's been done so far?
 A. One water wheel was rebuilt. Two houses where ironworkers lived have been restored externally. My old country store was deteriorating something terrible, but in 1983 orders came through to repair it.
 Q. The ironworks closed in 1882, 31 years before you were born. How is it you know the lore and legend?
 A. Both the ironworks and the mines near it were operated by the Ringwood Company, which was owned by the Hewitt family. I ran the general store for the Ringwood Company from 1935 to 1954. One day in 1953, I saw the company truck going back and forth. I asked, "What are you doing?" They said: "We got orders from the New York office to get rid of all the old records of the Hewitts. We're taking them up to the dump."
That night after work, I climbed around the dump. I got some of the most important papers of the Hewitts about Long Pond that are in existence today.
 Q. When did you meet the Hewitt family?
 A. My father was hired as a superintendent of the private Hewitt estate in 1920. He was in charge of the manor house, the livestock, all the grounds. We moved here when I was almost 7, and I was brought up on the estate. I also worked in their mines.
 Q. When did you do that?
 A. In 1930. But one day when I came up from the shaft, who's standing there but Mr. Ogden B. Hewitt -- the president of the Ringwood Company. He said, "Louie, how old are you?" I said, "I'm 17, going on 18." He told me, "Don't go in the mines again. You're under age."
 Q. What did you do after that?
 A. I went to work in the mine supply house. I furnished the men with helmets, safety shoes, carbide lamps, pipe fittings and so forth. I even issued dynamite to the foreman of the shift. They didn't want me to go in the mines to work, but yet they'd let me handle dynamite. ROSALIE STEMER

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Long Pond Ironworks dates to the Revolutionary War, said Louis West, who is working to restore it. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Bluefish Are Running, So What's Wrong?

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
A CHILL wind whipped off the sea. Fading sunlight streaked the clouds pink as the fishing boats appeared one after the other on the horizon and chugged into port like horses in sight of the stable. On the dock, gulls as fat as Thanksgiving turkeys shrieked in anticipation.
"Late today," commented a young woman who was waiting beside a piling for one of the boats to tie up. Her brother and her uncle were on it and she had to pick them up and drive them home to Trenton. They go out fishing two, sometimes three days a month, she said. It costs about $40 each, including the boat fare, the gas, the incidentals like lunch. The idea is to catch enough fish to cover the cost and put protein on the table of a big extended family. "Coming in late is a good sign," the woman said. 
 "Why is that?"
"Means they caught a lot of fish. They get to pulling up them fish, nobody wants to come home."
By 4 o'clock, boats were nudging into berths at the sprawling Belmar marina with piles of fish glistening on their fantails. The porgies are running great. Blackfish are good. Sea bass, too. Dogfish and conger eels, but who wants them? And from Bradley to Deal, scattered schools of big blues.
The boat with the brother and uncle on it had rumbled in with a haul of big bluefish, 15-pounders and up. Once the boat was secure, a mate on the stern ran his fillet knife across a stone and started slicing thick steaks from the fish. Murmuring in appreciation, the gulls nudged in like gawkers outside a celebrity trial.
The men hauling their gear off the boat had those looks of grubby joy that you see only after a good day fishing. Most of them appeared to be in their 30's, including the small group of New York City cops on an outing with their expensive reels and coolers full of beer. In all, there were about 15 men on the trip, not counting the captain and two mates. The fare for the day was $30.
"You could eat bluefish three times a week," one man said.
It is one sign of the times that more people who take day trips on the 200 or more so-called party boats that sail out of marinas from Highlands to Cape May are now fishing to put food on the table. Despite that, the business is in bad shape -- the worst in anybody's memory.
"You work out the numbers," said Capt. Gary Fagan, owner of Big Mohawk III, a 100-footer that pulled into Belmar, also with about 15 customers on board. Capacity is more than 80. "This is supposed to be the best fishing time of the year. Ten years ago, if we were catching this quantity of fish, we'd have a big crowd. Now it's a struggle for survival. The economy won't let you raise your fare, so you're trying to get more out of less."
Captain Fagan has been running fishing boats off the Jersey coast since the day after he got out of high school 26 years ago. His co-captain, Chris Hueth, said he was amazed by the number of passengers who are also working the numbers now, fishing not for recreation but for food for the table.
"You can spot them right off," he said. "No beer, no Coca-Cola. Supermarket-brand soda. They can't tip the mate much, maybe a dollar. Yesterday, a guy caught 25 sea bass, about two pounds each. You know how many meals that makes?"
Usually, a boat makes enough money in the summer to cover the lean months after Christmas. This year was different. There were an astounding 14 drownings this summer off the North Jersey coast, a result of violent riptides swirling along badly eroded beaches. But the subtleties of coastal geology were lost on the hysterics of New York television news, who screamed alarms for six weeks about hurricane-churned seas and kept people away. In fact, Captain Fagan and others on the docks said, there were only two days the boats couldn't go out.
"I'd get calls from people watching television asking: 'What is going on down there? It sounds like the end of the world!' " said Patty Fagan, his wife, who handles phone bookings for the fishing trips.
Meanwhile, there is something else missing. As boats come in, you scan the faces and realize the geezers are gone, the retired guys who used to crowd the party boats -- the old fishermen who could arbitrate disputes about bait, demonstrate how to tie a sinker, correctly identify any fish hauled in.
Captain Fagan shrugged and hooked a thumb that pointed down the coast. "They're all in Atlantic City," he said. "Those retired guys that fished during the week and off season? The casinos offer them a $10 bus ride and $20 in free quarters plus a meal voucher. How can we compete with that? Those guys are fishing the slot machines now."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Christmas Looks Bad, So Buy Retailers

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
When Wall Street looks at America's shopping centers, it sees little but woe. The big retail chains just ended their worst month in years. The better retailers seem to consistently post disappointing earnings, while the poorer ones go bankrupt. Analysts are competing to identify the next disaster.
There seems to be little hope for a turnaround. The economy seems to be weakening. With consumer debt burdens at record levels, there are signs that Americans are keeping a tighter hold on their wallets. The holiday season is already being written off as the worst in years. 
 Clearly, it is time to buy retail stocks.
At best, this may turn out to be a time like the fall of 1990 for banks, or the spring of 1984 for long-distance telephone companies. In both cases, investors were extremely depressed about industry outlooks. The long-distance companies were involved in a seemingly endless war for market share that was destroying profits. The banks had lost who-knew-how-much money on bad loans, and investors were in no mood to trust anything they said.
On the other hand, neither industry resembled buggy whips just before Henry Ford became famous. Both banks and telephone companies were needed in the economy, and both found ways to make money, rewarding shareholders who had the nerve to buy when the stocks were hated.
Similarly, it is a safe bet that the kids will find something under the Christmas tree next month, not to mention next year. Nor will Americans stop buying clothes. Retailers are going to be around for a long time. On a long-term basis, it is hard to imagine that a diversified group of retail stocks will not show gains from these depressed levels.
The immediate question for investors is not whether all the bad news is out. It probably is not. But prices may already reflect most, if not all, of the bad news to come. One savvy broker suggests that at least some of the weakness in retail stocks last month was caused by tax-induced selling by mutual funds. Many funds have fiscal years that end in October, and have lots of taxable capital gains. Taking some losses in retail stocks helped to reduce the tax their fund holders must pay. That is the kind of selling that can signal market bottoms.
As Christmas approaches, there will be more attention focused on retail stocks. The negative -- and prevalent -- forecast is that nervous retailers will mark down prices well before Santa arrives and destroy earnings. But in such forecasts could be the seed of profit. It appears that retailers will enter the season with restrained inventories. In some cases, that reflects management caution. In others, it is because stores are being kept on a short leash by worried creditors.
That could set the stage for a surprisingly good Christmas for retail profits, even if it is not a particularly good one for sales. Stores might discover that low inventories mean they don't have to go into deep discounting.
Meanwhile, in a market that is otherwise setting records, with the Dow Jones industrial average above 4,800, you can find quality retail stocks such as J. C. Penney and Toys "R" Us trading at reasonable multiples of depressed earnings. Even that one-time growth stock darling, Wal-Mart Stores, is down to less than 20 times earnings. (In its case, the earnings have kept rising, but the stock hasn't.)
In an exuberant stock market where bargains are hard to find, it is as close to a clearance sale as you are likely to find.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi 3000GT VR-4 Spyder;
Razzle-Dazzle From the Top Down

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
IT is unseemly, I guess, for a man of my years to giggle. But when I get behind the wheel of the Mitsubishi 3000GT Spyder, I just can't help it.
The mirth is contagious, too, because the sports coupe's shenanigans with its retractable hardtop -- whirring, gaping, lifting, folding, lowering and latching -- make it a sensation whenever you push the button in public, something else I can't help but do. 
 There are, of course, worse things to do while others watch. And the spontaneous laughs and comments from bystanders make it worthwhile to park at a downtown curb and put the top through its paces. One guy called the Spyder a humdinger, a word I don't think I've heard before in actual conversation.
"That is a real humdinger," he said, ho-hoing and shaking his head.
It is, indeed.
Aside from its novelty, the new model has the tighter, safer and warmer advantages of a closed car, yet a single push of a button can turn it into a convertible. Plus, it shares the virtues of its more mundane brethren.
Mitsubishi's muscular sports car has been around for five years, and the Spyder's futuristic roof adds a touch of youthful whimsy to the 3000GT's maturing warrior image. Paradoxically, it also evokes the past and the efforts by Ford to market a retractable hardtop in the late 1950's.
In fact, a surprising number of otherwise auto-passive folks who stopped to watch and comment on the Spyder's stationary performance seemed to remember the Ford Skyliner of 1957-59. That full-size convertible was an initial hit and is still one of the Fords most prized by collectors.
What killed it, eventually, was the same thing that will be a problem for Mitsubishi. When you put a metal roof into the trunk, which has just 4.4 cubic feet of space, said trunk is full to overflowing. And since the trunk lid has to be hinged at the back, loading even small amounts of cargo over the fender can be awkward.
The Mitsubishi is a different sort of automobile -- a toy instead of a family car, and as such it may fare better. Today's technology should also make repairs less of a hassle than they were with the complex retractables of the past, which actually date to the mid-30's, when prototypes were built by Riley in England and Peugeot in France.
But the '57 Skyliner was the first retractable to make it into mass production. And its top operated in almost exactly the same way as the Mitsubishi's, except for a computer. Ford used 10 power relays, 8 circuit breakers, 10 other switches, 3 drive motors and 610 feet of wiring. With computer controls, the Spyder needs a minimum of wiring and only 7 relays and 4 hydraulic cylinders.
Unfortunately, the technology and today's inflation also jack up the ante for what used to be a sports-car bargain. When Mitsubishi's do-everything 3000GT VR-4, with four-wheel-drive and twin turbochargers, was introduced in 1990, it had a sticker of $31,000. The red Spyder out in the driveway -- a '95 VR-4 with the 320-horsepower V8 and standard niceties like four-wheel steering -- has a take-home tag of $65,424, and even a "basic" hardtop VR-4 will set you back about $45,000. The Spyder can also be had in SL form, with a naturally aspirated 218-horsepower engine and a price of $58,424.
Still, the 3000GT is a strong seller in a weak market. For 1994, the company says, its sales of 15,230 outstripped the combined sales of the Mazda RX-7, Toyota Supra and Nissan 300ZX. Nissan, in fact, will drop the 300ZX after the '96 model year. Chrysler has also taken a new look at the declining market and has decided to stop selling the Dodge Stealth, its version of the 3000GT.
Mitsubishi builds both the Stealth and the 3000GT in Japan, although the Spyder is converted by the ASC Corporation of Southgate, Mich. Annual sales of the flip-top are expected to total 1,000.
No matter the model, the cars are luxurious, capable and fast. With its twin intercooled turbochargers, the "Caracas red" test car is capable of blasting from zero to 60 in about 5.5 seconds, pressing you into the leather seat and taking your breath away. Top speed is said to be 155 miles an hour, at which point the wall of air wins its battle against brute strength.
A six-speed manual is the only transmission available in the VR-4, although the nonturbo car can be had with an automatic. And it should be noted that the VR-4's console-mounted stick requires some muscle, as does the stiff clutch. The car is also hard to get into and out of -- and the confining back seat is just about impossible to use.
It goes without saying that the Spyder belongs to the driver, not the passengers, and at the wheel the comfort is considerable. The suspension and four-wheel steering make it a joy when carving curves or just cruising the open road.
Then, too, there's all that fun at the curb.

INSIDE TRACK: For convertible lovers facing winter, a wondrously silly and sensible solution.

HEADLINE: Let's Look Again at How We Treat Indonesia, China and Cuba

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Real Politics: Why Suharto Is In and Castro Is Out" (news analysis, Oct. 31) highlights failed Administration policies toward disparate authoritarian regimes. Political and economic expediency seems to drive these policies, rather than commitment to any consistent principle, including protection of universal human rights. 
 There is a major difference between clear-eyed engagement faithful to basic human rights and the chilling words of a senior Administration official, who reportedly described President Suharto of Indonesia as "our kind of guy."
In addition to human rights violations within Indonesia proper, President Suharto's Government has presided over the horror story that is East Timor, where some 200,000 East Timorese -- nearly a third of the original population -- have been killed by Indonesian troops.
How many lessons must we learn before we understand that embracing men like Mr. Suharto, who has presided over such events, is not ultimately in our national interest?
As to China, I believe the 1993 decision to delink most-favored-nation trade status from human rights conditions was taken by China as a signal that the United States will place economic self-interest before respect for human rights.
Indeed, even with "commercial engagement" of the past year, China's human rights record has deteriorated, according to the State Department, and prominent activists such as Wei Jingsheng and Chen Zemin have been reincarcerated. Ironically, as you note, United States business is reaping few benefits from what has been sown.
The ill-considered economic and strategic calculations that drive policy on Indonesia and China are underscored by United States treatment of Cuba. Where is the policy of commercial or constructive engagement when it comes to Fidel Castro? Surely that small nation, which poses no threat to the United States but has strong historical and cultural ties to our country, would be receptive to engagement.
There are human rights abuses there as well -- though not on the scale of East Timor or Tibet -- that would presumably be eased by engagement. Certainly Mr. Castro's Government could not do worse than the response given to us by the Chinese. Using diplomatic weapons at our disposal, including economic levers, to encourage fairness and human dignity, we can advance our business interests while remaining true to ourselves.
 
RUSS FEINGOLD
U.S. Senator from Wisconsin
Washington, Nov. 2, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

LENGTH: 1693 words

HEADLINE: The 4-1-1 On Urban Cool: Hype or Hope?

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
SILHOUETTED in the last light of a setting autumn sun, a group of young black men recently strolled along the teeming bazaar that is the Fulton Mall in downtown Brooklyn.
Without a word, without a smile, they walked with a stylized strut -- a graceful sway of shoulders, an easy sling of arms, a slight bob of the head. The bounce of their steps was so buoyant it suggested that Earth's gravity was everybody else's burden. 
 Amid the mall's commotion of open-air commerce, with its sonic soup of reggae, rap and rhythm and blues, these teen-agers, wearing the hip-hop ensemble of oversize clothing, moved like nightfall: smoothly, steadily. In a word, this crew from the nearby Farragut public housing project was cool. In two words: very cool.
"Cool ain't something everybody's got," said one of them, an 18-year-old who answers only to the name of E Z Don. "You know what I'm saying?
"Being cool is like money. Only some people can get it and some people have it. That's just how it is."
Or is it?
Urban cool -- inner-city-honed styles, attitudes and behavior -- has come under increasing scrutiny. This primarily black cultural expression that has rewritten the way America sings, dances and plays is now drawing the attention of more than just fashion designers and music producers. Other outsiders, from cultural anthropologists to sociologists, are examining this infectious force that, for better or worse, transforms almost everything it touches. And while urban cool may prove difficult to define, its presence is instantly recognizable.
From Trenton to Tokyo, from Kansas to Kenya, few people have not bumped into this phenomenon, perhaps in the guise of a baseball cap worn backward.
Yet, scholars are now cautioning that urban cool, especially for the young black men who feel estranged from white culture, is much more than slang, swagger or sagging jeans. Instead, experts like Dr. Richard Majors, a psychologist and senior research associate for the Urban Institute in Washington, say black cool is better understood as a complex system of coping mechanisms. And many say this premise is taking on special relevance now, as black men are becoming more introspective.
Young black women are generally not held to the same standards of urban cool. While there are a growing number of exceptions (the hip-hop singer Mary J. Blige and the rappers Salt N' Pepa, for example), a woman can be "soft" and still be accepted, said Marlene Kim Connor, author of "What is Cool? Understanding Black Manhood in America" (Crown Publishers 1995). A young man can't.
"Women are in some ways immune to the dictates of cool," she added.
Dr. Majors and others say urban cool is a much misunderstood technique for black survival in America, a thread of behavior stretching back from rebellious slaves up to the rapper Snoop Doggy Dog. At the same time, they note that cool can also be just as crippling as it can be liberating.
Being cool -- striking that delicate balance between originality and peer conformity -- is so paramount in the minds of some blacks that a 14-year-old Harlem resident recently confessed he would rather be dead than "wack," a term describing the utter absence of urban cool. But even a modest acceptance of cool's minimum demands may risk alienation from other blacks, stunt mainstream aspirations and generally heighten suspicion of the outside world.
Reef, 18, one of E Z Don's Brooklyn friends, who also identified himself by his street name, said being wack means "you're a sellout, you ain't real" and therefore not worthy of respect. Cool, he explained, is more than a fad; it is a way of life.
Langston Hughes suggested as much some 40 years ago in his poem "Motto."
I play it cool
And dig all jive,
That's the reason
I stay alive.
My motto as I live and learn
is: Dig and be dug inreturn.
"It's not all about clothes," explained Reef, whose 6-foot-3-inch frame was decked out in oversize black pants, a Halley Hansen yachting windbreaker and a pair of $180 Asolo hiking boots. "It's how you present yourself."
Unfortunately, urban cool's disaffection with the mainstream can make the leap to criminality only a short hop for some. It is hardly coincidental, many experts note, that gangster imagery is now considered very cool. And to complete the cycle, many street styles, gestures and expressions are being minted by blacks behind bars.
Cool may represent "one of the richest untapped areas for understanding black male behavior today," Dr. Majors and Janet Mancini Billson wrote in their book, "Cool Pose: The Dilemmas of Black Manhood in America" (Lexington Books, 1992).
Today, Dr. Majors remains convinced that he was right. "There's been a historic lack of opportunities and resources in this country for black men," he said. "Cool becomes his castle, his signature. It's his way to tell society that 'I am here.' "
It can also be a way of making the opposite sex to take notice. "The main reason somebody wants to be cool is for the ladies," said E Z Don, who was dressed from head to boot in the Army surplus chic of camouflage and chin straps. "You know there are a lot of goodies, females, out there that you like. You want to be noticed by them."
"You don't want to be noticed in a bad way," E Z Don added, his voice low, his words dripping like honey. "You rather them look at you as being cool than anything else."
But sometimes, he added, "you might be too cool and the girl gets away."
Long fascinated with what he saw as an almost obsessive drive to be cool by his fellow black friends and classmates -- even when it got them into trouble -- Dr. Majors decidedwhile attending college to study what he termed "cool pose." It has been a long-term exploration.
As the president and chief executive of the National Council of African-American Men, an advocacy group, Dr. Majors said he was frequently reminded that cool is often closely linked to a black man's "self-esteem, to his pride, to his culture, to his blackness." He said this condition was in stark contrast to whites, who tend to use cool more as a personality accessory rather than a source of validation.
While the film maker Spike Lee acknowledged that all black people are not cool, he said that "black and cool, for me, is interchangeable." And when he presents black characters on the screen, he said he tried to make them "interesting and truthful." Along the way, many of them -- from Mars Blackmon in "She's Gotta Have It" to Strike in "Clockers" -- have become profiles in many shades of urban cool.
"I think that coolness is something that is just inherent, just part of our culture, part of our spirituality," Mr. Lee said.
Terry Williams, a sociologist, says that historically, urban cool has been therapeutic. "Cool is a discipline to withhold anger," said Mr. Williams, a professor of community studies and ethnography at the New School for Social Research in New York. "The idea is that black folks have found a way to control their rage in America, and they do it through this rather creative way."
He suggested that an essential component of urban cool was to achieve an almost stoical detachment, or in street parlance, "to chill." For example, Snoop Doggy Dog, who the hip-hop impresario Russell Simmons recently described as the "epitome of cool," is a master of suppressing his emotions. When charged in connection with a killing in Los Angeles two years ago, he popularized the catch phrase: "It's all good, though" (pronounced "dough"). No matter how great the calamity or inconvenience, thousands of young black men shrug it off with the phrase.
"If you have that attitude," Mr. Simmons, 38, said, "when you got it rough and it's not working out, to a degree, it makes the bombs less effective. It protects you from all that."
The mastery of cool, even as its rules shift faster than the wind, also grants black men a degree of power and control in the broader society, Dr. Majors added.
Urban cool becomes the great psychological equalizer for blacks who are vastly underepresented in America's board rooms and country clubs. Beneath its display, Dr. Majors said, is a defiant message: "You can incarcerate me and throw away the key, you can unemploy me, keep away opportunity from me, alienate me, but, baby, I'm going to be here."
In fact, Dr. Majors and Dr. Mancini Billson said that much of urban cool's development was rooted in a belief held by many blacks that "classic American virtues of thrift, perseverance and hard work did not give them the same tangible rewards that accrued to whites."
OTHER experts say this connection is increasingly apparent as more young black men are coming to view mainstream society as foreign, hostile and emasculating. Consequently, the greater their sense of oppression -- real or imagined -- the greater their reliance on the mask of supreme calm, fearlessness and a practiced indifference.
Ms. Connor, the writer, said cool and manhood were synonymous in many black communities today.
"Cool is essentially a way that a young black boy in the streets of America becomes a man," she said. "When they turn to each other and they say, 'Yeah, man, he's cool,' they are giving him the highest compliment."
And cool training often begins early, she said. One of the first lessons a black man is likely to teach a child is to slap five, a gesture of greeting and congratulations. "That's the coolest thing a little kid can do," she said with a chuckle.
But for many blacks, particularly as they navigate their way through society, their measure of urban cool can become a perplexing house of mirrors.
"Cool is real and not real," Ms. Connor said. "It's real as long as you live in the inner cities and people can recognize your level of cool. But when you step outside that, it has very little meaning."
And that, she said, can be a huge problem for many blacks.
Kevin Powell, 29, a senior editor at Vibe magazine, says he is concerned about where all the cool posturing might lead. He sees a connection between the oppression of blacks and their retreat into cool.
He said, "I don't think it bodes well for our future at all."

HEADLINE: VOWS;
Alisa White and Joseph Holland

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY

 BODY:
ALISA WHITE, a correspondent for "American Journal," a television newsmagazine, is athletic, spiritual, ladylike and often jet-lagged. She covered the O. J. Simpson trial for the program, which is syndicated, commuting between New York and Los Angeles for the last year.
She never eats desserts. And when she has a problem, she often fasts and meditates until she feels clearer about it. 
 Until a friend introduced her to Joseph Holland last March, she had dated some men who took her out to dinner and described their ocean-front houses in the Hamptons, powerful Porsches and celebrity friends. She wasn't impressed.
"It was important to me to find a man who was humble, who didn't drop names and talk about what he owned and who he knew," said Ms. White, a graduate of San Francisco State University. "I wanted to meet someone who let his life speak for itself."
By most accounts, there are few people as humble as Mr. Holland, who is the Commissioner of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal and the former co-chairman of Gov. George E. Pataki's election campaign. Friends describe Mr. Holland as a politician for the 1990's: quiet, community-oriented and so spiritual that he has an almost monklike presence.
An All-American football star at Cornell University and a graduate of Harvard Law School, he opened the Beth Hark Crisis Center 13 years ago. It is a shelter for homeless drug-addicted men in Harlem, where he lived until recently, eating meals and sleeping in the same room with the men. He even wrote a play about them, "Home Grown," which is currently being performed at the National Black Theater in Harlem.
He owns a travel agency and also runs a Ben & Jerry's franchise in Harlem, where most of his employees are "graduates" of the shelter.
"Joe is completely selfless," said Barbara Conroy, a friend and a producer for "Inside Edition," the television program. "His father was an ambassador to Sweden; he's Cornell and Harvard educated. But he gave it all up to serve the homeless. How many people do we know who would do something like that?"
Ms. Conroy, who is also a friend of Ms. White's, introduced the couple. At her suggestion, Mr. Holland called Ms. White while she was working in Los Angeles, and for the next three weeks they talked often cross-country about politics, religion, their families, race and Harlem.
When they finally were to meet in person, Ms. White was so nervous she was afraid to open the door. Mr. Holland was not at all apprehensive. "There was a peace and a calm about meeting this woman," he said. "I'd already felt the connection over the phone."
The two are very similar. Both are in their mid-30's; they run, mountain bike, golf, pray and fast together. Just before their wedding, they moved into a brownstone in Harlem together.
On Oct. 28, they were married at Abyssinian Baptist Church on West 138th Street, in a wedding with the Rev. Calvin O. Butts and the Rev. Dr. A. R. Bernard Sr. officiating. The ceremony was like a conversation with the couple -- spiritual, philosophical, probing and unhurried.
But it was not without glamour. "Alisa sparkled all the way down the aisle," said Liz Bruder, a guest, who is a vice president at the Architects and Designers Building in Manhattan. "Her headpiece looked like a giant diamond bracelet wrapped around her hair. It was very poetic."
After the ceremony, 150 guests gathered for dinner at the Union Theological Seminary, at 120th Street. Ken Frydman, who was a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani during his mayoral campaign, said that friends of the groom had wondered for a long time when or if he would ever marry.
"Joe had everything a mate could want," Mr. Frydman said. "It was a conundrum. How does the perfect catch remain at liberty for so many years? Women often tell you there aren't many great ones. He's a great one."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

RETAILING
Half Empty, Half Full
It's November, and the finish line looms, seven weeks away, for the holiday shopping season. The nation's big retailers started by reporting their lowest monthly sales growth in more than four years, raising concerns about whether a grim Christmas looms. Yet investors seemed willing to ignore the report. Shares of Dayton Hudson, the Gap and some other retailers surged; Jeffrey Feiner, Salomon's retail analyst, reasoned that the early warning of weak sales might allow retailers to get their inventories and attendant costs in hand.
 
ACCOUNTABILITY 101
U.S. Expels Daiwa
In what started as a "rogue trader" case, the victimized management has wound up answering criminal charges. Federal and state regulators ordered Daiwa Bank to close its American operations as a Federal grand jury accused the bank of illegally covering up $1.1 billion in trading losses at its New York branch. The indictment asserted that Daiwa's management had communicated at length with Toshihide Iguchi, the trader who has acknowledged creating the losses, and accused Daiwa of conspiracy, fraud, falsification of bank records and the failure to disclose Federal crimes. Daiwa said it would defend itself in court, and the Japanese Government took steps to avert panic and make Daiwa's expulsion from the U.S. as orderly as possible.
 
ACCOUNTABILITY 102
Will the Trader Sing?
Bowing to the inevitable, Nicholas W. Leeson, the former trader, agreed to return to Singapore to face trial for the multibillion-dollar losses that sent Barings P.L.C. to its death. Speculation was rife that he had abandoned his fight against extradition in order to plea bargain, offering to implicate his superiors at Barings. That might play well in Singapore, where a report commissioned by the Government found that Barings managers were "grossly negligent, or willfully blind and reckless to the truth" in the months before the bank collapsed.
 
DEALS
So Happy Together
With two months still to go, American mergers and acquisitions in 1995 have totaled nearly $346 billion, close to last year's record of $347.1 billion. Last week's activities included Praxair offering $2.1 billion for CBI, Comcast paying $1.6 billion for Scripps's cable operations and Softkey International paying $800 million for two educational software companies. Among the spurs to all this activity are the stock market's record levels this year and a growing willingness to undertake hostile offers.
 
CHANGE OF HEART
Delete Text
Not so long ago (1991 to be precise) Wordperfect was the market leader in computer word processors, a cleverly designed, easy-to-use, attractive program. In what might be a caution to today's various best sellers, Wordperfect is now regarded as a "sunset" product, and Novell, which paid hundreds of millions of dollars for it only a year ago, has put it on the block. Who might want it? No one's certain.
 
WAGES
Feeling the Pinch
In between the postings of strong corporate profits and record stock prices, wage increases are providing scant nourishment for American workers. In the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, workers' earnings rose 2.7 percent, the smallest annual increase on record.
 
MEXICO
The Search for Stability
With neither economic balance nor investor confidence fully restored from last year's collapse of the peso, the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo signed a pact with business and labor leaders intended to control prices, cut public spending and limit salary increases. But the agreement did not address a major concern of investors, failing to provide exchange-rate controls. For a day at least, the Mexican stock market rallied on the news, before settling back.
 
PINK SLIPS
Is That a Sucking Sound?
Continuing its drive to shift operations to less expensive plants abroad, Fruit of the Loom said it would trim 3,500 jobs and close six plants in an attempt to increase profits. The nation's largest underwearmaker said the culprits were the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which had led to a flood of cheap imports.
 
THE GLOBAL VILLAGE
Betting on Sports
Gambling that the global appetite for the sweat and thrill of sports competition knows no bounds, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc., the huge cable company, are expected to set up a global sports cable network that would compete with ESPN, which is largely owned by Capital Cities/ABC and soon to be owned by Walt Disney. American sports continue to grow in popularity overseas, but whether the traffic is two-way remains to be seen. Cricket, anyone? Or tossing the caber?

The fountain in the food court at the King of Prussia Mall, in King of Prussia, Pa., typifies the new approach. LENGTH: 953 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
There Are Two Sides To Every Game in Town

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
PERHAPS no American industry this decade, with the possible exception of computer software and on-line technology, has grown as rapidly and pervaded society as thoroughly as legalized gambling.
In 1988 casino gambling was legal in only two states -- Nevada and New Jersey. Today casinos, including those on Indian reservations, operate or are authorized in 23 states. In 1994 gamblers armed with lottery tickets, chips and slot machines wagered a whopping $482 billion in this country, which is more than the gross national product of China and represents a 22 percent increase over the previous year. In the same year consumers spent nearly three times as much on lottery tickets as they did on movie tickets, according to International Gaming and Wagering Business magazine. 
 Yet the first signs of a grassroots backlash also appeared last year, and the nascent revolt is taking hold in state capitals and in Washington. Last week the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee heard testimony on legislation that would establish a national commission to study the economic and social effects of legalized gambling. The House Judiciary Committee held a similar hearing in late September.
It comes as no surprise that such a measure is strongly opposed by the gambling industry, which has become a large contributor to political campaigns. President Clinton, however, announced his support last week. "Too often," Mr. Clinton wrote in a letter to sponsors of the bill, "public officials view gambling as a quick and easy way to raise revenues, without focusing on gambling's hidden social, economic and political costs."
Two Republican Presidential candidates, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Patrick J. Buchanan, a conservative columnist, have taken strong stands against the expansion of gambling. The Christian Coalition, which is devoting more attention to the issue, has pledged resources toward establishing a Washington branch of the National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, a network based in Illinois.
In November 1994, from Florida to Wyoming, an overwhelming majority of state and local referendums to start or expand gambling went down to defeat. In response the gambling industry established a Washington lobbying group, the American Gaming Association, and hired Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, as its president and chief executive officer.
Mr. Fahrenkopf, a Nevada lawyer, rejects the notion that the tide has turned against gambling. "All our polls show that the vast majority of Americans still support gaming and casino gaming," he said. "They've spoken with their feet and with their pocketbooks."
But opponents argue that the rapid proliferation of gambling, from riverboats that ply the Mississippi to Indian casinos in Connecticut and New York, has magnified the industry's shortcomings.
It has become clear, they say, that the benefits of new jobs and growing revenue for states' coffers have been more than offset by a draining of dollars from other industries, by crime, addiction among those gamblers who can least afford it -- especially at a time of economic uncertainty and stagnating wages -- an undermining of the work ethic and corruption of the political system. Casino jobs are often low paying and sometimes temporary. And as the market for gambling has neared saturation, some outlets, riverboats in particular, have started to fail.
 
'An Economic Bust'
 "There's always been moral opposition to it," said Robert Goodman, author of "The Luck Business: The Devastating Consequences and Broken Promises of America's Gambling Explosion." (Free Press 1995). "I think what's new is people realizing that it has been an economic bust, that it's sucking jobs out of cities, that you go to city after city and shops and restaurants are closing while the only things opening are pawn shops." In some states, gambling has revealed its dark yet familiar side: corruption. In Louisiana, a state chronically reeling from disclosures involving shady deals and good old boys, the F.B.I. is investigating a pattern of alleged payoffs to state lawmakers who orchestrated the defeat of legislation that would have allowed a vote on whether to eliminate video poker at truck stops. Voter disgust is playing a significant role in this year's gubernatorial campaign, and leading the candidates to try to outdo each other's anti-gambling proposals.
Mr. Fahrenkopf, who says the latest scandal has more to do with Louisiana than with gambling, stated that in general, "when a little mud splashes up in one corner of this industry, inevitably everybody gets coated."
Regardless of its many pitfalls, gambling may continue to be driven by the same forces that have been driving it for the last seven years -- competition among states and competition between the states and the Indian reservations within their borders.
After Congress passed a 1988 law enabling tribes to open casinos, state officials decided that they wanted a share in the industry. And as the first states began to allow gambling, their neighbors moved quickly to join them in order to stanch the flow of revenue across state lines. That instinct led New York's Legislature this year to begin the process that would allow a vote on a constitutional amendment to permit casino gambling in places other than Indian reservations. Casinos are well established in New Jersey and Connecticut.
 
The End Game
 Tom Grey, executive director of the National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, said he does not underestimate the determination of the gambling industry to expand.
"This is a predatory enterprise," he said, "and it needs new markets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In New York delis, games of chance share the aisles with groceries. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Booming Colorado Weighs Its Future

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo. Nov. 4

 BODY:
Lighting a small, makeshift flamethrower in his cluttered kitchen, Hunter S. Thompson pointed to imaginary Boeing 737's flying overhead and ranted, "Greedheads, greedheads."
Not confining pyrotechnics to his mountainside home, the irascible journalist is rallying Aspenites to vote on Tuesday against a proposal to widen and strengthen this remote resort town's airport runway to accommodate long-haul jets. 
 Executives of the Aspen Skiing Company complain that the number of skiers here has remained flat over the last 20 years. For Mr. Thompson and his fellow slow-growth advocates in this town of 6,000, that is just fine.
It is an attitude that is spreading like a dry pine forest fire in Colorado, one of the fastest-growing states in the Rocky Mountains, the region with the fastest economic and population growth in the nation. On Tuesday, slow-growth initiatives will be on the ballot in Aspen and at least five other Colorado boom towns.
"It's not in my children's interest to have six million people living in Colorado," said Richard A. Lamm, referring to predictions of a population about double that when he was Governor in the early 1980's. "We don't want Denver to become one big Los Angeles of the Rockies."
The slow-growth movement is taking hold as memories fade of the Rockies' bitter recession of a decade ago, a bust triggered by falling oil and gas prices. With Colorado's economy increasingly diversified, many economists believe that the state may be breaking a century-long boom-and-bust cycle.
Today, only 1 percent of Coloradans work in the energy field. More now work in telecommunications than energy. Denver is the capital of nation's cable television industry. Further spurring job growth there are a new international airport and a mutual fund industry whose portfolio has grown tenfold, to $50 billion, in five years.
In the first half of the 1990's, Colorado's annual population growth ran at triple the nation's rate of 1 percent a year, though it has tapered off to only double the national rate today. With quality of life increasingly important for white-collar workers, Denver now offers four major sports teams, a revitalized downtown and easy access to wilderness areas.
In this environment, more and more Colorado communities feel they can give themselves the luxury of shutting the door.
In Boulder, where job growth has run at three times population growth, turnout was light last week for a pro-growth rally billed as "a taste of unemployment."
Stephen M. Pomerance, a City Council candidate who helped found a residents group called Slow Growth, said that unemployment was not a realistic fear for most residents. "In Boulder, we have 85,000 jobs for a city with 95,000 people," he said.
On Tuesday, Boulder residents are to vote on an initiative to cut annual commercial construction in half over the next five years. Sensing a ground swell of support for curbs, Boulder's City Council voted in September to adopt a compromise measure, to cut commercial construction by 30 percent.
Boulder has been so attractive to investors that during the first nine months of this year companies scrambled to win permits for one million square feet of commercial construction, double the annual average of previous years.
To some, Boulder's ballot proposal represents the second shoe dropping. In 1976, Boulder became the first city in Colorado to put caps on housing construction, though it left commercial development untouched.
"The result is that we now have 40,000 people commuting into Boulder every day," said Paul Danish, a Boulder county commissioner, who pushed for the residential curb 20 years ago. Predicting victory for the commercial curb on Tuesday, he said, "You spend your day looking up someone's tailpipe -- and then you say get it out of my life."
The slow-growth movement is strongest in Boulder and other affluent western suburbs of Denver.
In nearby Golden, home to Coors beer, residents are to vote Tuesday on an initiative to limit housing construction to 1 percent of current square footage. Offering views of Rocky Mountain foothills, this onetime territorial capital of 15,000 people saw housing construction growth of 3.2 percent in 1994.
Similar limits are to be voted on Tuesday in three other west Denver suburbs: Broomfield, Lafayette and Longmont.
In Utah, another fast-growing Western state, voters in Midway and St. George on Tuesday will consider limits on building permits.
From 1991 to 1994, Arizona and Colorado each experienced about 11 percent population growth, fastest after Nevada and Idaho.
To some, the West's anti-bulldozer movement is elitist.
"We have a whole generation of people who believe that only worms should move dirt," said Philip M. Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a Denver-based study group. "Growth management can degenerate into enclave development. It backfires because it raises prices, it reduces choice."
For some, Colorado's current economic slowdown and the state's history of boom and bust should be enough for communities to keep doors open to new investment.
"It wasn't that long ago -- in the mid-80's -- that we had a collapse, the bottom fell out of the energy industry, the bottom fell out of the high-tech industry," warned Kenneth N. Hotard, senior vice president of the Boulder Area Board of Realtors. "We already see companies looking elsewhere."
Alexander E. Bracken, a spokesman for Boulder's largest private employer, the Ball Aerospace and Technologies Corporation, said of his city's slow-growth initiative: "We hope that it will be defeated. This initiative would make it very difficult for us to grow."
Coloradans have consistently refused to adopt statewide growth controls or plans.
In Denver today, Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, led a symposium on "smart growth." "It is not realistic to build a wall around your state and to stop growth," he said in an interview on Thursday.
He defined "smart growth" as taking advantage of the population's high level of education to provide well-paying jobs with benefits. Colorado ranks third nationwide in the portion of its population who are high school and college graduates.
Here in the mountain towns of Pitkin County, where unemployment is nearly nonexistent, slow-growth advocates suspect that expansion of Aspen's airport is really a Trojan horse for "industrial tourism."
"They want an industrial, cruise-ship economy here," said Tim Mooney, a realtor and ski instructor, who wore a button showing the black silhouette of a Boeing 737, stamped with a red international stop symbol.
"We're in a box canyon at 7,900 feet -- there are only so many resources here," Mr. Mooney continued, his voice rising. "If the ski company thinks they can ratchet up their business by 10 percent a year, they are going to ratchet down the environment by 10 percent a year."
Down the street, the Aspen Mayor, John S. Bennett, was also skeptical. "One of Aspen's greatest assets has been lack of accessibility," reflected Mr. Bennett, a Yale graduate who owns a French restaurant here, Pour La France. "A bigger airport with heavy, metal jets, flying in from Las Vegas -- I fail to see how it makes Aspen a better community."
Today, newspapers brimmed with advertisements, paid for by the Aspen Skiing Company and other businesses that profit from the ski trade, favoring airport expansion. On Friday, over a breakfast served by a French waiter at a ski company hotel, company executives grumbled that only "elitists" were against permitting landings by Boeing 737's.
"People who oppose this are second-homeowners who come in on private jets -- they are financially bullet-proofed," said Robert A. Maynard, the ski company president. "Why, we even heard someone say, 'Only nerds fly 737's.' "

HEADLINE: Bishops Steer Middle Course On Politics

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
At a time when political conservatives are gearing up to recruit Catholic voters, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops are reaffirming today their longstanding commitment to defend the unborn, the poor and the vulnerable while guarding against attempts to enlist the church in partisan politics.
The bishops have begun the widespread distribution of a 14,000-word statement on political responsibility that sets out familiar positions on issues like abortion, welfare, immigration and arms control, but also declares, "Our moral framework does not easily fit the categories of right or left, Republican or Democrat." 
 Although the Catholic bishops have issued statements on political responsibility before every Presidential campaign since 1976, the statement, a year before November's Presidential election, comes at a time when the role of religion in politics is growing more prominent.
For the first time, the bishops are not only releasing their statement to news organizations but sending copies of the 32-page pamphlet to the nation's 19,000 parishes, with order forms for buying more. In another first, they have condensed key passages into a leaflet designed for mass distribution.
The statement was adopted unanimously at the September meeting of the 54-member Administrative Committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. "The bishops' interest in getting this message out far exceeds what it's been in the past," said John Carr, who oversees the bishops' offices on domestic and international issues.
"What feeds this in part is that the message echoes the Holy Father's call to protect the unborn, reach out to poor and welcome the newcomer," he said, noting that the pamphlet opens with excerpts from the Pope John Paul II's speeches in the United States last month.
But the bishops are also aware of a determined effort by the Christian Coalition, the largely evangelical Protestant political organization headed by Pat Robertson, to set up a Catholic auxiliary claiming to speak for Catholics.
The group, the Catholic Alliance, has produced fliers declaring that it "represents Catholics before the U.S. Congress, state legislatures and local governing bodies." The fliers include a "scorecard" on Congressional voting, rating representatives and senators on what the flier calls the "Catholic Alliance position."
The scorecard is the same one drawn up by its parent organization, the Christian Coalition. Although featuring issues like abortion, the scorecard lists issues like the balanced-budget amendment and term limits on which the bishops take no position, and it makes no mention of some concerns that the bishops emphasize.
For example, the bishops' political responsibility statement expresses support for the earned income tax credit for the working poor, "judiciously administered" affirmative action programs, arms control, foreign assistance, the United Nations, universal access to health care and a "generous U.S. immigration policy."
In some cases, the Catholic Alliance scorecard gives politicians positive ratings for positions that the bishops have actually opposed, like voting for welfare legislation that cuts off benefits for children born out of wedlock to mothers on welfare, or voting for legislation expanding capital punishment.
The bishops' statement also criticized "public attitudes that dismiss the legitimate role of government and ridicule public officials," saying: "Our tradition and experience teach us that markets have both advantages and limitations, that government is neither the solution nor the enemy, that private charities have essential roles, but cannot substitute for just public policies. How these sectors complement and restrain one another is a major issue for 1996."
The bishops warned against political shortcomings that are creating cynicism and disenchantment with politics. "Sound bites and symbols, war rooms and attack ads are replacing civil debate," they said.
"Too much of public life reflects our fears more than hopes, dividing us by age, race, region and class," they said, with the public agenda set by "the politics of money and polarization."
The bishops also warned against "a growing temptation to blame our sense of economic insecurity and moral decline not on cultural disarray or the failures of political and economic leadership, but on too much compassion."
The statement welcomed "the growing discussion of the role of moral values in public life," but it rejected "religious leaders telling people how to vote or religious tests for candidates."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Takes Hand in Bank Merger Talks

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Finance Ministry has summoned Daiwa Bank and two other Japanese institutions for consultations as early as Monday in an attempt to avert a banking crisis days after Daiwa was expelled from the United States by American regulators.
Japanese financial experts said today that Daiwa and Sumitomo Bank were discussing a merger to create the biggest bank in the world, allied with Nomura Securities, the world's largest securities firm. 
 But they cautioned that no deal had been finalized and that there were potential obstacles ahead.
Nevertheless, the discussions of mergers and alliances have captured the imagination of the business world, because the proposals on the table would have repercussions on global financial competition.
A merger with Sumitomo, already one of the world's largest banks, would create a new bank with assets of about $840 billion, according to data compiled by the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily.
"The possible merger could trigger far-reaching restructuring in the Japanese financial sector," said Toru Nakakita, an economics professor at Toyo University.
While some of Daiwa's operations are attractive to Sumitomo, the prospect of a grand alliance with Nomura would seem to be more of an incentive.
Yet it is not clear to what extent the discussions are motivated by business considerations and to what extent by the Japanese Government's desire for a tidy, traditional Japanese-style rescue operation. Nomura and Daiwa started as one institution, and they have remained close since they split in 1948.
Sumitomo and Daiwa had apparently discussed the possibility of combining their operations earlier this year, after the Bank of Tokyo and Mitsubishi Bank announced that they would merge next spring.
The new Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank will become the world's largest bank, with assets of 73 trillion yen, or about $709 billion, unless Sumitomo and Daiwa merge.
Daiwa is somewhat appealing as a takeover target because it is the only big Japanese bank with a trust business and a majority stake in a securities house, Cosmo Securities.
Both Sumitomo and Daiwa are based in Osaka and have somewhat similar styles and cultures, which could make a combination go more smoothly. The corporate culture in Osaka is more aggressive than that in Tokyo; people still sometimes greet each other in Osaka with the saying, "Mokarimakka," or "Have you made money today?"
Working against a merger is that the banks' domestic operations in some ways mirror rather than complement each other.
Another issue that would need to be resolved is how to deal with potential fines by American regulators that could reach $1.3 billion if Daiwa is convicted of all the charges it faces.
Daiwa's troubles started after Toshihide Iguchi, a bond trader in New York, abruptly confessed on July 24 to having hidden $1.1 billion on losses over 11 years. For two months after that, he and Daiwa executives are said to have continued to hide the losses from American authorities. The bank disclosed its losses to the Federal Reserve on Sept. 18.
On Thursday, American regulators ordered Daiwa Bank to shut its American operations, accusing it of conspiracy, fraud, falsification of bank records and failure to disclose Federal crimes.
Both Sumitomo and Nomura have agreed to assist Daiwa in the disposal of its American operations, but Daiwa executives have released few details on Nomura's possible involvement.
The merger, if it goes through, will not necessarily solve all of Daiwa's problems, partly because it would take nearly a year to complete, according to Japanese news reports today. Some financial specialists said that the merger diverts attention away from the real problems of the Japanese banking industry.
"People tend to think that being bigger is synonymous with being stronger," said Yukio Noguchi, an economics professor at Hitotsubashi University. "A merger would in many cases hide the problems or weaknesses of the Japanese banking industry."
Not only is financial disclosure scant and inspection sloppy, but the nation's banking institutions are beleaguered with at least $500 billion in bad loans, of which one-third are probably unrecoverable. Already, foreign banks are raising their charges on loans to Japanese banks, and in some cases they are trimming credit to them.
As for the alliance with Nomura, Kyodo News Service tonight quoted unidentified corporate executives as saying that Daiwa and Nomura had been negotiating to establish a joint financial holding company. That could transform the separate institutions into a large conglomerate.
Kyodo said Nomura and Daiwa had decided to expand their prospective partnership to encompass the new bank that would be created if Daiwa and Sumitomo merged.
Financial specialists cast doubt on this plan because such a holding company is not allowed under current financial regulations.
Still, even if a formal relationship is not established, Sumitomo's ties to Nomura would be greatly strengthened if it combined with Daiwa.
Even if a merger is never achieved, the possibility of one may help calm the markets -- and that may be in the back of the mind of banking executives involved in the negotiations.
