HEADLINE: Some Say a Powell Candidacy Could Make Black Voters Abandon Democrats

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Here inside the Beltway, Republican speculation over whether a Colin Powell candidacy would thwart Newt Gingrich's conservative revolution has all but eclipsed an equally intriguing issue: Were General Powell to seek the Republican Presidential nomination -- and possibly go on to win the Oval Office -- would a significant number of blacks eventually abandon the Democratic Party?
In its most basic form, that issue is currently underlying the sound bites of former Vice President Dan Quayle -- who wants General Powell in the Republican Party -- and is on the minds of politically engaged black academics at both ends of the political spectrum. 
 Like the Republican conservatives' cold war over General Powell, this issue, too, is full of caveats and what if's simply because of two big unknowns.
First, will General Powell, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, announce that he intends to run for the Presidency as a Republican? And if he runs, can he manage the transition from book-tour celebrity to a Presidential candidate whose themes and firm positions will connect with voters, especially Republican primary voters?
Two prominent black academics -- Roger Wilkins, a professor of history at George Mason University whose views are left of center, and Glenn Loury, an economics professor at Boston University whose perspective is right of center -- believe that a Powell candidacy could, under the right conditions, move a sizable number of blacks from the Democratic Party to the Republican side of the ledger.
Though they approach politics from different viewpoints, both agree that such a long-term structural change would be good for the quality of political discourse and could improve the way both parties develop domestic policy.
For Professor Wilkins, General Powell "just happens to fit into something I've yearned for." In an Oct. 9 editorial in The Nation, a liberal weekly, Professor Wilkins wrote: "With about 85 percent of the black Presidential vote crammed into a corner of the Democratic Party, Republicans run on their whiteness and Democrats run away from 'their' blacks. That mixture is toxic. It prevents rational discourse on the broadest range of issues, from our national priorities to education reform to urban reconstruction."
With a substantial number of blacks in both parties, he said in a subsequent interview, Democrats could not take loyal black voters for granted and "Republicans couldn't use racially coded messages they've used so effectively over the years."
Professor Loury, who espouses views on abortion and affirmative action that are to the right of General Powell's, said many blacks would vote for the general if he was the Republican nominee. But whether that would pull blacks into the party in large numbers, he said, "is a longer-term proposition." He added, "It has to do with whether the party gets a soul."
So far, Professor Loury said, the success of the political revolution led by Mr. Gingrich has been fueled by "anger and disgust." What the revolution lacks, and what Powell may be able to supply if he runs and wins, Professor Loury said, is a conservative governing vision that, though differing in philosophy, is as powerful and compelling as was Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.
The possibility of persuading a significant number of blacks to become Republicans figured prominently today in remarks by Mr. Quayle, who is urging the General to join the Republican Party regardless of whether he runs. General Powell has not disclosed his party affiliation.
"I hope that people would view this as a very positive step for black Americans to seriously look at the Republican Party," Mr. Quayle said on the NBC "Today" program. "We're going to continue to reach out to people like Colin Powell and others and say, 'Our party is open, and we're also a party that represents you."
At the moment, not many blacks feel that way. Results of the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, released last week, underscore black voters' loyalty to the Democratic Party. When respondents were asked to cast a hypothetical vote for President Clinton or General Powell, 55 percent of blacks favored the President and 28 percent preferred the retired four-star general. But whites favored General Powell over Mr. Clinton by 51 percent to 31 percent.
The reliability of these soundings and other pro-Powell polls is always an issue, political analysts say, since it is difficult to tell which whites give an honest answer that fits their view of the moment and which give what they consider a socially acceptable answer. "I distrust the high poll numbers right now," said Ron Walters, chairman of Howard University's political science department. "You have to discount those numbers by some factor."
What many have forgotten, says Eddie Mahe, a prominent Republican consultant based in Washington, is that before 1964 and the battle over civil rights legislation, Republican candidates were often able to win up to 40 percent of the black vote. Since then, Mr. Mahe said, Republicans have done poorly because of a presumption that there is a racist message in the party's platform and positions. Mr. Mahe said that as a Presidential candidate "Colin Powell would be able to leap over it like a Superman."
Without the presumption of racism in the way, many blacks could compare their views to Republican positions and values. If that occurred, Mr. Mahe estimated, Republicans could win one-quarter to one-third of black votes.
Yet not everyone who tracks electoral behavior believes that having substantial blocks of black voters in both parties would improve the parties or policy making in Washington. Prof. Ron Walters of Howard University said such a development would splinter black leverage.
While General Powell ponders his choices in seclusion, he remains a vessel that Republicans, Democrats and academics of all stripes pour their hopes, hunches and dreams into. Based on General Powell's own description of himself as as a centrist of the Rockefeller Republican variety, Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, said that the General would be comfortable as a New Democrat. With President Clinton seeking re-election next year, Mr. From said General Powell could set his sights on running in 2000.
But for Mr. From, as for many others, the question remains: how would General Powell perform in Republican primaries? Mr. From said that in the 1994 Congressional elections, in which Republicans wrested control of the House and Senate, 57 percent of Republican voters identified themselves as conservatives and about 20 percent as religious or cultural conservatives. "Those numbers will be magnified in the primaries," he said.

HEADLINE: Chirac Says Deficit Cuts To Come First

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Cutting Government budget deficits is high on the agenda in France, but President Jacques Chirac has told people here to expect their taxes and social security premiums to go up, not down, during the next two years to narrow a $60 billion annual shortfall.
And the conservative majority in Parliament applauded him for it. 
 In 1995 the social security system, which covers old-age pensions and health insurance, will be nearly $13 billion in the red, according to official estimates made public last week. All indications are that Mr. Chirac's conservative Government will raise taxes, possibly by 1 percent, to make up the difference.
"The priority of priorities is to cut deficits," he said in a television interview last week.
In France, which has one of the most comprehensive and expensive welfare states in Europe, the debate is less about scaling back government largess than about how to pay for it, perhaps because so many people collect benefits.
"We started the social security system just after World War II, a period when there was great national solidarity," said Pierre Laroque, 88, who was assigned by Charles de Gaulle in 1945 to give France confidence about the future by establishing comprehensive social security. "There was a period of 30 years when life for most people just got better every year, and the French got used to the idea."
These golden years peaked by the end of the 1980's, when unemployment began to rise.
"We never foresaw that there would come a day when three million people would be without jobs and receiving jobless benefits," Mr. Laroque said.
Mr. Chirac, a political disciple of de Gaulle, did not talk about cutting back benefits, but told his television audience, "France has been spending more than it took in for the past 15 to 20 years."
Mr. Chirac was elected by a 52 percent majority last May promising that his main priority would be reducing the unemployment rate, then more than 12 percent. He attributed it then in part to the high tax burdens imposed on business and individuals here by the comprehensive welfare state. Companies have to pay government-mandated social security, unemployment and other premiums that can add as much as 65 percent to their wage bills.
Now, with his popularity at 14 percent in a public opinion poll by the Ipsos Institute, Mr. Chirac says ambitious job-creation projects and lower taxes will come only after budget cuts reduce deficits and high interest rates.
The remarks by Mr. Chirac last week ended months of uncertainty in international financial markets about whether he would stick with the stringent deficit-cutting policies required by the 1992 European Union Treaty for a common European currency by the end of the century.
French farmers and industrialists, two of Mr. Chirac's most powerful constituencies, argue that a common currency would strengthen French competitiveness, particularly with the United States.
The President is insulated from public opinion ratings because his term runs until 2002, leaving his Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, to take most of the heat if the economic policies fail.

HEADLINE: Friend Says Two Officers Stranded Man Before Killing

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: FORD HEIGHTS, Ill., Nov. 4

 BODY:
On the last day of his life, Richard Will, a 32-year-old white man, begged two black police officers in this dangerous, almost entirely black Chicago suburb to give him a ride to the police station, Mr. Will's friend says.
About 15 minutes later, after walking five blocks in search of a telephone, Mr. Will was attacked by a group of young black males. He was beaten, doused with lighter fluid and set afire. He died a few hours later. 
 Federal and state police authorities have opened investigations into the case. And the family of Mr. Will, a laborer who cleaned stables at a racetrack and who had custody of a 2-year-old daughter, is preparing to file a Federal civil rights suit against the Ford Heights police.
"The police knew the degree of danger in this town," said William Braverman, the family's lawyer. "I don't care if the person passing through is black, Caucasian or Asian. You don't just leave them in a dangerous situation."
The case bears some resemblance to an incident in 1989, in which two white Chicago police officers dropped off two black teen-agers in a rough white neighborhood known as Canaryville. One of the teen-agers was severely beaten. The Canaryville case outraged blacks here, and thousands of demonstrators took part in a three-mile protest march past the home of Mayor Richard M. Daley.
Now, many whites around Chicago are voicing anger. Some are unhappy that the Ford Heights case has not been given more attention by news organizations.
Mike Royko, the Chicago Tribune columnist, asked what the reaction to the case would have been if the police had been white and the victim black: "Would this create much of a public uproar? Demands by community and political leaders for a full investigation? Based on past events, yes, there would be quite an outcry."
Roe Conn, who is host of a morning talk show on WLS, said the radio station had been inundated by "a ton of calls and faxes off the air about this case," with many of them asking, "Why aren't you talking about this?"
Mr. Will was in a car driven by the friend, Cecil McCool, a roofer who is also white, when they were stopped by the two officers in Ford Heights on Oct. 18 at 1 A.M. A computer check found that Mr. McCool had an outstanding warrant for failing to pay child support, and the police arrested him. Mr. Will, who owned the car, did not have a valid driver's license and had been drinking, so the police towed the car and had it impounded.
Mr. McCool told The Southtown Economist, a daily newspaper that covers the South Side of Chicago and the south suburbs, that Mr. Will had begged the police for a ride, that he was so frightened of being left alone in this tough town that he was "shaking like a leaf."
Mr. McCool told the Chicago Sun-Times that after he was taken to the Fords Heights police station, one of the officers told him, "Your buddy got burned." He said the officers were smirking.
The Ford Heights police, who did not return telephone calls, have been quoted saying that they suspected the pair were in Ford Heights to buy drugs. In fact, Mr. Will, who lived in nearby Chicago Heights, did have a police record, according to his lawyer, but for petty theft, not drugs.
One of the arresting officers, Lieut. E. K. Haynie, told The Chicago Sun-Times that Mr. Will did not ask for a ride. He also said he doubted that the young men who attacked Mr. Will were acting out of racial motives.
"They were just doing something stupid," Officer Haynie told the newspaper.
Police initially arrested five people in connection with the killing, but only two have been charged: Wardell McClain, 17, and Michael Armstrong, 16. The other three suspects, two 13-year-olds and a 15-year-old, were released by the Cook County State's Attorney's office for lack of evidence.
Aldon Morris, a sociology professor at Northwestern University, who is black, said the Ford Heights case appeared to be another incident of "the police playing executioner."
As for the brutal slaying itself, Mr. Morris said, it might reflect the "growing level of hostility in poor black neighborhoods that the larger white society sees them as faceless."

HEADLINE: Doctors Seek Clue to Deaths in Nicaragua

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Doctors are struggling to identify a mysterious disease in the dirt-poor backlands of northwestern Nicaragua whose victims die suffocated by their own blood.
According to the World Health Organization, 18 people have died and more than 1,000 suspected cases have been reported in the epidemic, which first appeared in the farming village of Achuapa in rugged hills about 50 miles northwest of Managua, the capital. 
 Researchers in Nicaragua and at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta have determined, based on samples from the victims, that the illness is not hemorrhagic dengue fever, a disease accompanied by agonizing bone pain that is already endemic in Nicaragua. They have also ruled out yellow fever, another disease that, like dengue, is carried by mosquitoes.
Those stricken by the unidentified illness suffer from high fever, severe abdominal pain and body ache, all symptoms of dengue as well. But the patients also develop severe hemorrhaging, which fills their lungs with blood. Without treatment, they suffocate in three or four days, doctors in Nicaragua who are treating the disease said today.
Last week President Violeta Chamorro declared a medical emergency in the country, and the health ministers of the five Central American nations convened on Friday to discuss the epidemic.
Medical investigators do not know what causes the disease or how it is transmitted. But it does not appear to be passed through the air or by personal contact, a spokesman for the Pan American Health Organization, Daniel Epstein, said by telephone from Managua.
Researchers suspect there may be an animal carrier for the disease, which has been tentatively named Achuapa febrile syndrome, but have not ruled out a mutation of some familiar virus.
Achuapa is in a region of dry hardscrabble hills where water and food are scarce. But torrential rains spun off from an unusual series of Caribbean hurricanes in recent months washed rats and cockroaches from their holes and provided new breeding grounds for mosquitoes and countless other tropical insects.
The epidemic has spread to other towns near Achuapa but does not appear to have spread outside the region, Mr. Epstein said. Patients are being treated at the teaching hospital in Leon, the largest city in the area.
"If they come to us right away, we can save them," the hospital director, Dr. Donald Quintana Fajardo, said by telephone from Leon. "But Nicaraguans have a machismo complex where we pretend there is nothing wrong with us. They only come to the hospital at the last minute."
Dr. Quintana said 133 patients suspected of having the disease were under treatment in Leon. With intravenous liquids and blood and treatment to control the fever, doctors have succeeded in stopping the onset of bleeding in the lungs, he said. But blood components needed for treatment are in critically short supply.
A team of physicians from the World Health Organization, the Pan American Health Organization, the Nicaraguan Health Ministry and the Government of Cuba are scouting the Achuapa hills to detect patients and possible carriers.
In the early years of the rule of the Sandinista National Liberation Front in the 1980's, Government health programs were greatly expanded. But years of war with the contra rebels, who were backed by the United States, sapped the public health system. The Government of President Chamorro has not received the aid from the United States or other countries that she expected, and the economy has remained stalled, forcing her to limit public services.
"The living conditions in Achuapa are deplorable," Dr. Quintana said. "None of their basic needs are satisfied."
This year almost 11,000 cases of dengue were reported in Nicaragua, and cholera is also endemic.

HEADLINE: Restructuring of Medicare and Medicaid Will Affect the Low-Income Elderly Twice

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Doris Brisson lives on the outskirts of poverty in Mesquite, Tex. She is 66 years old and gets Social Security payments of $512 a month, food stamps worth $20 a month and she barely makes the rent on a one-room apartment that she says gives cozy a bad name.
When it comes to her health care, Mrs. Brisson relies not only on Medicare, the medical program for people over 65, but also on Medicaid, which covers many of the nation's impoverished. 
 While Congress has grappled with vast overhauls of the nation's two giant health care programs independently, for Mrs. Brisson, and for as many as five million other elderly poor people, the programs are nearly indivisible. To maintain their precarious existences, they depend on both.
Together, the anticipated growth of the programs would be sliced by more than $440 billion in seven years under Republican legislation that passed last month and that President Clinton has threatened to veto.
Republicans maintain that by giving states more flexibility on spending their Medicaid dollars and by directing older people into cost-conscious managed care plans, the Government will save money while improving health care and reducing costs for people like Mrs. Brisson.
But numerous health care experts and advocates for the poor say that the financially pressed and often frail elderly, vulnerable to cuts in both programs, will become the legislation's most pathetic victims. Studies have shown that nearly a million older Americans living in poverty stand to lose some of their health coverage if these changes become law.
"For them it's a double whammy," said Ron Pollack, Executive Director of Families U.S.A., an advocacy group. "They could lose Medicaid eligibility at a time when the Medicare expenses that Medicaid used to cover for them are going up. If they couldn't afford them before, how will they afford them now?"
In Mrs. Brisson's case, Medicare pays for her doctor visits, but her premium, co-payments to her doctor and her annual deductible are now covered under a special Medicaid program. The program, the Qualified Medicare Beneficiary program, or Q.M.B., has required since 1990 that states pay those Medicare costs for beneficiaries who are barely above the poverty line, which is about $7,400 for a single person and about $10,000 for a couple.
But neither program covers medicine. Mrs. Brisson is supposed to be taking medication for high blood pressure, arthritis and depression. She has the prescriptions in her purse, next to the wallet that has too little money to fill them.
"Right now, what I can't get free from the doctor, I do without," said Mrs. Brisson, who has had trouble getting full Medicaid benefits after a recent move from Colorado to Texas. "By the end of the month I'm begging dinner invitations from friends. If anybody asks me to spend one more dollar for my health care, well, I guess I'd just have to quit going to the doctor altogether."
The Republican Medicare plan raises beneficiaries' co-payments, deductibles and premiums and encourages them to join cost-saving managed care plans. By signing on for such a plan, the Republicans argue, older people with limited resources would no longer have to pay a portion of each doctor visit or a minimum amount before their benefits kicked in.
The Medicaid plan, meanwhile, ends mandatory benefits for the very poor and gives states fixed grants that they would decide how to divide among their neediest residents. Whether states would put as much money as the Federal Government now requires into covering gaps in the Medicare coverage for the elderly poor is very much an open question.
"Even if you had a combination of Mother Teresa and Albert Einstein administering these programs, the proposed cuts are so deep that needy people will lose eligibility," said Stan Dorn, managing attorney for the National Health Law Program, a public interest law center in Washington and Los Angeles that focuses on low-income health issues.
Being forced to cut back on the medical attention they get, Mr. Dorn said, will have deadly consequences for the elderly poor. "The death certificate may say 'cause of death: heart attack,' " he said, "but the real cause will be Medicaid and Medicare cuts."
Republicans said that given the spiraling costs of Medicaid and Medicare, they had no choice but to find a way to rein in expenses.
"We are opening up Medicare to the new medicine of the 90's," said Mike Collins, a spokesman for the House Commerce Committee. "States and managed care providers are going to give better care at lower costs to our needy seniors."
But a study by the Urban Institute, a Washington-based research group, found that even assuming that state governments achieve a higher level of cost efficiency in their managed care programs, nearly a million poor older Americans could lose their Medicaid eligibility in the next seven years.
Another report by Project HOPE, a Washington think tank that studies health issues, found that nearly 60 percent of people eligible for Medicaid's Q.M.B. program did not receive benefits because they did not know about the program or did not realize they qualified.
But as the economic situation for poorer older Americans declines, experts warn that more of them will be forced to seek protections, like those now offered under the Q.M.B. program. But while the Republican plan mandates that states set aside a certain portion of their Medicaid block grants to cover premiums for this group, it does not require that all the poor elderly be covered.
Each state would decide who it considers poor within the elderly population and how to distribute money among them. Currently, people with incomes up to 20 percent above the poverty level automatically qualify for Medicaid-subsidized premiums.
Under the Republican plan, states would have to cover only premiums, not deductibles or co-payments. And the amount they would be required to reserve for the premiums is far too little, critics say. It amounts to 90 percent of what they spent on this program from 1993 to 1995, when most of those who were eligible did not participate.
Health care experts also note that managed care plans are not available to more than nine million Medicare recipients because companies have not set up businesses where they live. But Mr. Collins of the House Commerce Committee said that the Republican leadership is "confident that markets will spring up" when the new plan becomes law.
The Republicans, he said, envision a scenario in which Medicare beneficiaries are courted by managed care plans eager for their business. As the competition increases, he said, the plans will recruit good doctors, offer a wide range of services and even give financial incentives to the elderly to join, knowing that if they do not, people will go elsewhere.
But while managed care companies are technically required by law to accept anyone who is eligible for Medicare, companies have a way of skewing their marketing to attract more stable and robust people whose care costs the least and increases profits most, said Lani Sanjek, associate executive director of the New York Statewide Senior Action Council. They hold recruiting seminars, for example, at times and places that are inconvenient or inaccessible to the disabled.
What is more, advocates said, the Republican plan does not provide either a framework or a budget for monitoring the quality of managed care programs.
"No standards have been established, let alone implemented," said Diane Archer, executive director of the Medicare Beneficiaries Defense Fund. "A lot of the elderly are too sick, too frail and too ill-equipped to make an informed choice under these circumstances. As this plan stands, the elderly poor are in danger of higher personal costs or significantly less health care."
Many of these people are already rationing their own health care, doing without medications, like Mrs. Brisson, so that they can afford meals, or are visiting doctors only in an emergency to avoid co-payments they cannot afford.
In Flushing, Queens, Irma Valentine, a former waitress, visits her doctor, because the cost is covered by Medicare. She takes her blood pressure and cholesterol prescriptions because they are covered by Medicaid, for which she is fully eligible because she is below the poverty level. But she does without arthritis pain killers and hemorrhoid medications because neither program covers those.
"I'm 80 years old and I'm barely making it," said Mrs. Valentine, who volunteers time at the Self-Help Senior Center in Latimer Gardens, the public housing project where she lives, in exchange for warm meals. "I'm miserable and I'm scared. If they ask me to give up any more, what would I take it away from? From nothing?"
What Orpha Andrukite hears about the plans debated in Washington has not reassured her that the coverage she now gets is safe. If she does fall off the Medicaid rolls, she says, she might as well "fall off the face of the earth."
She is 70, and after working more than 30 years as a practical nurse, she now lives on $484 a month in Social Security benefits and $17 in food stamps in an apartment in southeast Washington.
Until now, she has been covered by Medicare, with Medicaid picking up her out-of-pocket expenses, including most of the costs of the seven prescriptions she takes for a variety of illnesses, among them diabetes, osteorheumatoid arthritis and spasms. But if she is asked to spend any of her own money, she said, she will have to cut out the pills or the doctor visits.
She already owes money to her daughter and a friend from North Carolina who two years ago slaughtered a cow and brought 100 pounds of meat up to Ms. Andrukite on account. The meat is now gone, she said, but the debt remains.
"I'm already borrowed out, living on the edge," she said. "If they want to get another dollar from me, they may as well just come get me altogether."

When it comes to health care, Mrs. Brisson relies on both Medicare, the medical program for people over 65, and Medicaid, which covers many of the nation's impoverished. (Mark Graham for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Mayoral Election, Race Is Real Issue

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Nov. 3

 BODY:
Tradition and numbers should make the Democratic candidate the odds-on favorite to win Tuesday's mayoral election in this city where Republicans and independents are vastly outnumbered and treated like embarrassing relatives. But unlike past years, the electoral outcome is far less certain.
The Democrat is white. 
 Gary's is only one of more than three dozen mayoral elections in larger cities around the country on Tuesday, including Baltimore, Cincinnati, Hartford, Houston, Philadelphia and San Francisco. But Gary's election is one of the most revealing about the American problem of race, a national heartache that never seems to heal.
The last time this overwhelmingly black city had a white mayor, Lyndon B. Johnson was President and the steel mills on the edge of town were spitting out paychecks in a blizzard of blue-collar prosperity.
But hard times rule the streets now. The mills employ only a fraction of the workers they once did. Drugs and despair crowd the sidewalks and the prospect of a white mayor has apparently so shaken some of Gary's black political establishment that they are willing to forsake their own party and to even make clumsy racial appeals to stop it.
Similar tactics helped turn Chicago, just 30 miles up the toll road from Gary, into "Beriut on the Lake" in the early 1980's when white Democrats abandoned their party in droves and voted Republican because they did not want to support a black Democratic mayoral candidate, Harold Washington, who went on to win two terms.
Last month, Gary's incumbent mayor, Thomas V. Barnes, who is not seeking re-election, wrote a fund-raising letter urging supporters to back a black independent candidate over his fellow Democrat, adding that the Democratic nominee, Scott King, a 44-year-old defense lawyer, "is Caucasian."
In his letter last month, Mr. Barnes asked for $100 to $1,000 contributions to the independent, who entered the race only after Mr. King bested several black opponents in the Democratic primary in May. Mr. King won with about 44 percent of the vote, but only about 30 percent of the Democrats turned out for the primary. In years past, winning the Democratic primary was tantamount to being elected mayor.
But the independent, Marion R. Williams, a high school principal and former city official and longtime Democrat, said he would not play the "race card" and would instead focus on the nuts and bolts of fiscal management and improved city services. His campaign posters and billboards urge people to vote for him "for all the right reasons."
"The media wants me to reach in my back pocket and pull out the race card and lay it on the table," Mr. Williams said. "I'm not going to do that. I'm going to play the credibility card."
The Republican candidate, Diane Ross Boswell, who is black, is not expected to win because recalling the name of the last Republican mayor of Gary is a parlor game for historians.
"Having a white mayor is not news," Mrs. Boswell said. "We've only had two black mayors in Gary. The possibility of having a black woman Republican is news."
Gender, she said, is the forgotten issue of the campaign.
"Being a Republican," the former prosecutor said, "is not as problematic for people as me being a woman."
Still, race never seems far from the calculus of the campaign. Mr. Williams says whites, who rarely bothered to vote in city elections before, have thrown their weight and money behind Mr. King in an effort to seize control of a city making signs of at least a slight economic recovery. Next year, river boat gambling is scheduled to come to town.
On the other hand, Jamelba Johnson, a black volunteer for the King campaign says that Mr. King's black supporters have been called "Uncle Toms" and "sellouts" in an effort to "shame us for voting for a white man."
But the election in Gary also illustrates another side of the racial divide, the bridge builders, the ordinary people who will ultimately decide this election.
Mr. King, with little political experience, could be the next mayor of this 85 percent black city because black voters are willing -- or frustrated enough with the sorry state of their city -- to cross racial lines and give him a chance. They did it in the primary.
"It's not about black or white," said Lugene Braylock, 32, an unemployed store clerk and lifelong resident of the city. "It's about the survival of Gary. It's about, can he do the job? I think King can. If he can't we'll get somebody else in there next time. We're tired of this mess."
In many cases, the "mess" had already started by the time black mayors seized power and pride in Gary and across the United States in the 1960's and 1970's only to see much of it slip away by the 80's as jobs vanished, whites fled, Federal programs were gutted and businesses abandoned urban America.
A victory here on Tuesday by Mr. King would represent yet another reversal of fortune for black mayors who have been replaced by whites in recent years in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, New York and Chicago.
Mr. Barnes, Gary's lame duck mayor, is determined not to allow what he calls "this shameful episode and trend" to continue.
In his letter last month, Mr. Barnes wrote that Mr. King had made few contributions to his adopted city and had won the primary because "of the lack of focus and unity that has existed in Gary as in too many predominately African-American communities across the country."
He added that Mr. King has the backing of the political machine throughout the state and that "as the attorney of choice for accused drug dealers, murderers, carjackers, rapists and racketeers," Mr. King "is considered by many to be part of the public safety problem facing our city."
Indeed, crime is so bad in Gary that when Mr. Barnes requested several weeks ago that 10 Indiana State Troopers be dispatched by the Governor to help patrol the city's streets, 50 were sent in for 30 days. Last week, the troopers extended their stay by at least another month.
Gary is once again on pace to claim the title of "murder capital" of the nation. Two years ago it had the highest number of murders per capita, and so far this year the city of 116,000 has about 100 homicides.
In an interview, Mayor Barnes said that issues of competence, not race, are his major consideration for shunning his party's nominee.
"I choose a highly qualified African-American in a state that has only one African-American mayor over an unqualified white candidate with no record of doing anything for the community," he said. "If the shoes were switched and you had an African-American with a similar record, he'd never make it."
A prosecutor before he became a defense lawyer, Mr. King said he did not think that Mr. Barnes and other black Democrats were motivated by race.
"It's about power," Mr. King said. "It's about patronage. It's about an old political structure trying to survive."
Still, Mr. King, who is married to a black woman and has three children, said that race haunts the campaign.
"There are some African-Americans who are voting for me because I'm white, thinking that a white man can get more out of the white establishment" he said. "There are other African-Americans who wouldn't put me out if I was on fire because I'm white. But the vast majority are making a judgment based on my platform. That's why I love Gary."

But that candidate, Scott King, who campaigned in a mall last week, is white in a city that is 85 percent black. A white mayor was last elected more than 20 years ago. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tokyo Fails To Resolve Bases Impasse

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 4

 BODY:
A last-ditch effort to break an impasse over American bases in Okinawa failed today, landing the dispute squarely in the lap of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama just two weeks before President Clinton arrives in Japan for a summit meeting.
Mr. Murayama met for almost five hours today with Masahide Ota, the Governor of Okinawa, who has refused to sign documents extending leases on land used for American bases. But Mr. Ota again refused to sign and presented the national Government with demands to curb the American military presence. 
 The first of the contested leases does not expire until March, but the Japanese and American Governments want to resolve the crisis before the summit meeting. The meeting had been intended to underscore the close military cooperation between Japan and America, but now it risks showcasing Japanese discontent with American bases.
The discontent is strongest on the sun-drenched southern Japanese island of Okinawa, where 75 percent of American bases are concentrated. Mr. Ota, an American-trained scholar who is an admirer of the United States in many respects, has led a growing movement in Okinawa against the bases, particularly since the arrest in September of three American servicemen on charges of raping a 12-year-old Okinawan girl.
"The Governor reiterated his refusal to sign the documents," Prime Minister Murayama told reporters after the meeting. "I can fully understand his position and his consideration of the people in his prefecture. So I will make a judgment on the matter myself."
Mr. Murayama is expected to override Mr. Ota and sign the documents himself, thereby assuring continuity of the American leases. But that is not certain, and it would be particularly unpleasant for Mr. Murayama, a socialist who spent most of his career opposing the American bases.
Mr. Ota said at a news conference that he was adamant in refusing to force the renewal of the leases, but he suggested that today's meeting was a step toward giving Okinawa's interests a fairer hearing.
"For the first time in history, the Prime Minister seriously listened to my explanations about the actual situation on the American bases in Okinawa," Mr. Ota said.
Mr. Ota presented the Government with 10 demands relating to the bases, few of which are acceptable now to either Tokyo or Washington. For example, Mr. Ota's first demand was that the United States return any bases that stand in the way of economic development.
Other demands included the application of noise limits to the bases; a halt to the use of civilian airports by military planes; application of regular automobile taxes to private cars owned by American soldiers, and the immediate transfer to Japanese custody of all Americans facing criminal proceedings.
Mr. Ota said that Mr. Murayama did seem receptive to one of the demands, that the American-Japanese committee on the bases pay greater attention to local opinions.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry said in Japan a few days ago that the United States was willing to work with Japanese officials in reducing the problems created by the presence of the bases. But he emphasized that the United States opposed any reduction in the present level of 47,000 troops in Japan.
In fact, the United States has only about 44,000 troops in Japan now, although it is authorized to have 47,000. That figure does not include 13,000 American military personnel who are assigned to ships effectively based in Japan.

HEADLINE: California Immigrants Make Fast Economic Gains, Study Finds

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Against the backdrop of California's immigration debate, a study released on Friday shows that many foreign-born residents in the southern part of the state are rapidly acclimating to life here. They are generally learning English and escaping poverty at a quick pace, according to the report.
In the study, which tracked members of various ethnic groups over time, some of the most dramatic results were seen among Hispanic immigrants who were between 5 and 14 years old when they arrived in Southern California in the 1970's. Although only one-third of them could speak English proficiently in 1980, nearly 70 percent could do so 10 years later in 1990. 
 The study also found that the poverty rate of male Asian immigrants between 25 and 34 years old in the 1970's declined significantly. Whereas 16.8 percent had incomes below the poverty level in 1980, only 5.6 percent of the same people had below-poverty incomes in 1990.
"The poor immigrants you see today won't be like that for long," said the author of the report, Dowell Myers, a demography professor at the University of Southern California. "Everybody is moving up at different speeds, but faster than many thought."
The nonpartisan study, paid for by a private foundation, comes at a time when many Californians are calling for stricter immigration laws and measures that would require the use of English in state business. Of Southern California's nearly 17 million residents, about 4.4 million are foreign born.
Mr. Myers culled census data from about 850,000 Southern California residents. He shows a common thread of increasing economic prosperity among immigrants over time, at rates that vary with age, sex and ethnicity.
For example, the average incomes of male European and Middle Eastern immigrants age 25 to 34 grew to $47,700 in 1990 from $23,200 in 1980. During the same period, the income of immigrant Asian men in the same age category doubled to $39,900 from $19,800. However, the earnings of Hispanic men rose only modestly in this 10-year span, to $18,900 from $14,900.
"There is evidence that Latino-Americans are capturing some of the American dream," said Abel Valenzuela, a professor of urban planning and Chicano studies at the University of California at Los Angeles. "But the debate is whether they are rising fast enough."
Nearly half of adult Hispanic immigrants have less than a ninth-grade education when they arrive, Mr. Myers said. The study found that many were not likely to be promoted at their jobs, and were less likely to learn English. In contrast, those who come to the United States at a young age go to school, generally learn English and have a lower poverty rate.
Only 21 percent of Hispanic men who moved to Southern California between the ages of 25 and 34 became proficient in English after 10 years. By comparison, 53 percent of Asian women and almost 80 percent of European and Middle Eastern men in the same age range learned English.
The rates of those obtaining citizenship after 10 years also varies: 67 percent for Asian men, 51 percent for European and Middle Eastern men and 21 percent of Hispanic men. Mr. Myers said that Mexicans and Canadians had a low rate of naturalization because of their proximity to their native countries.
Immigrants out-paced native-born residents in the percentage of those who were self-employed. Mr. Myers called this a "positive" indicator of the region's economic future.

HEADLINE: Javits Convention Center Books Giant Multimedia Expo for '96

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The nation's largest association of companies in the interactive multimedia industry will hold a major trade show next September at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the first new major show at the center in three years, industry officials said yesterday.
The announcement reflects the growing importance of New York City as a national center in the multimedia field, which is a segment of the computer industry that takes animation, video and music and combines them into material for CD-ROM's, on-line applications and virtual reality, among other things. 
 The decision to hold a show at the Javits Center was also hailed by New York State officials as a sign that the overhaul of the center's labor force in July is beginning to attract new business and new tax dollars to the state.
Officials of the trade group, the International Multimedia Association, said their member companies felt that it was time both to consolidate dozens of smaller multimedia trade shows being held around the country and to give the industry a brighter spotlight on the East Coast, especially on Wall Street.
"It's an early playing field right now," said Patrick Ferrell, president and chief executive of Infotainment World, a subsidiary of the International Data Group, which will produce the show, called the IMA Expo, for the association.
The board of the Interactive Multimedia Association determined that the only convention hall on the East Coast large enough and well equipped enough to hold the show was the Javits Center, Mr. Ferrell said, but executives were reluctant to book space because of the center's reputation for cost overruns.
"We have been assured that our costs will be significantly less than other shows held at the Javits," Mr. Ferrell said.
He said the multimedia show, to be held Sept. 17-19, will include about 300 companies and use as much as 250,000 square feet of the center, about a third of the total floor space. It could end up taking as much as 400,000 square feet as more companies agree to participate, he said. Already, Macromedia, Intel, Horizons Technology, I.B.M., Apple and many other major players in the multimedia field have agreed to be represented, he said.
Robert E. Boyle, the center's new president and chief executive, said in a statement that he expects as many as 20,000 participants from 25 countries, pumping as much as $25 million in taxes and other benefits into the state's economy.
Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to announce the new show tomorrow at the Javits Center with industry executives.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Speedway Helps Aid A Town's Recovery

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
In the days following Aug. 24, 1992, it would have been hard to imagine why anyone in Homestead, Fla., would ever again want to see something heading toward them at 200 miles an hour. Hurricane Andrew had roared through that city -- and most of the rest of southern Dade County -- on that day with winds up to 198 m.p.h., carrying away with it 8,000 businesses, 55,000 jobs and 47,000 homes from the area south of Miami.
Shortly before 9 A.M. on Oct. 16, another whirlwind started building momentum on a 344-acre patch of Homestead's east side. This time, city officials were glad to see it. The source of the turbulence, a race car, was safely contained within the concrete walls of Homestead Motorsports Complex, the city-owned $61 million speedway that opens this weekend. 
 All 65,000 seats at the 1.5-mile track -- patterned after the rectangular Indianapolis Motor Speedway -- have been sold for the first big race today, even though the race is part of Nascar's triple-A series, and not a Winston Cup race, which the track eventually hopes to get. Next March, the Indy cars will race at Homestead, followed by major motorcycle and sports-car races.
Today's opening is the start of an 18-month stretch that will see American motor racing undergo an expansion it hasn't experienced in more than 25 years. The Homestead Motorsports Complex, about 30 miles south of Miami, is the first of four new superspeedways that will open between now and the spring of 1997.
Texas Motor Speedway is scheduled to open north of Fort Worth next June, followed by a track near Las Vegas, Nev., next September and Roger Penske's two-mile oval near Los Angeles in spring of 1997. Not since the last wave of speedway construction subsided in the early 1970's have so many tracks opened so soon.
But Homestead's main concern this weekend is its own prosperity, not auto racing's.
"We're still trying to recover from the economic disaster that the hurricane created," said Will Rudd, the Homestead city manager. The city lost about 35 percent of its population, as about 10,000 people moved farther north, and 90 percent of its homes were destroyed.
Although Rudd estimated that the track would create only about 300 full-time jobs at first, the less tangible effects may, in the long run, be more important. "I think it's going to give us name recognition," he said. "It's going to change the way people look at Homestead."
Before the hurricane, he said, the area's economy was equally divided among agriculture, tourism (it is close to Everglades National Park and is the last landfall before the Florida Keys) and Homestead Air Force Base, where Rudd was stationed as a colonel before retiring in 1993.
"The base provided a $430 million annual economic stimulus," Rudd said, "and 80 percent of that stopped on Aug. 25, 1992."
The base has not returned to its post-storm size and, because of Defense Department downsizing, never will, although it is being converted to commercial use, too.
Nonetheless, the base's presence helped ease the approval of the track project in one important area: noise complaints.
"Definitely the hurricane helped us," said Ralph Sanchez, the promoter of events at the track and the man most instrumental in getting it built.
"But the other thing that made us realize this was the spot is that the site is under the approach for Homestead Air Force Base," said Sanchez, who had to drop North Miami as a potential site in early 1992 when residents protested the potential noise and traffic. "When I saw that, I said one F-16 makes more noise than 10 race cars put together."
The track is a rarity among American speedways in that is municipally, rather than privately, owned. About half the money was provided by a Florida hotel tax of 1 percent set aside for construction of sports stadiums, a fund that has also been used to build the Lipton Tennis Stadium in Key Biscayne and to remodel the Orange Bowl.
Most of the rest of the track's financing will come in a bond issue (to be paid off by track revenues) that Homestead will underwrite with a $20 million loan guaranteed by H. Wayne Huizenga, the owner of the Miami Dolphins, Florida Panthers and Joe Robbie Stadium, and the majority shareholder of the Florida Marlins. In a separate deal, Huizenga has a half share of the promotional operation at Homestead, Sanchez the other half.
Sanchez, 47, came to the United States from Cuba in 1961 and spent most of his first five years here in an orphanage, until his parents arrived. He is the founder of Miami Motorsports, which, Rudd said, holds a 37-year contract to promote events at Homestead.
In 1983, Miami Motorsports ran its first race, in the streets of downtown Miami. At the time, the city was also looking for an image boost to counter reports of crime and urban decay. Torrents of rain washed out that first race, and Sanchez says he lost over $1 million. He was back the next year, and every year since.
Homestead's need for a major economic jump-start came just in time for Sanchez. Last March, with the port of Miami about to expand to accommodate a burgeoning cruise market, Sanchez ran his last race downtown. "The handwriting was on the wall long before that," Sanchez said. "The city basically put me on notice that it could evict me at any moment."
Now, Sanchez can unpack his bags in a home as plush as any in the sport. Among the track's amenities are a 32-camera video system and television production center and 20 corporate boxes. In the next few years, he plans to increase seating to 90,000 and add 30 more boxes, trackside condominiums and a shopping center.
Mauricio Gugelmin, a former Formula One driver who now drives Indy cars, did some test runs at Homestead last month and pronounced the facilities first-class. "They spent the money wisely," he said. "It's all pretty well thought out."
Sanchez said he would like to bring the international Formula One circuit to Homestead, to run on the 2.2-mile road-racing track built within the oval. But Gugelmin, who tried out the road course as well as the oval, said: "I think it's too narrow for a Formula One race."
Even if Formula One spurns Homestead, the track won't be empty. At present, Sanchez has booked five major race weekends, plus private test sessions and race-driving schools, making the motorsports complex considerably busier than the $20 million Homestead Baseball Complex, which stands nearby. The Cleveland Indians were supposed to make it their spring training home, but after Hurricane Andrew severely damaged it, the team went elsewhere.
To this day, the stadium has never had a regular tenant, and the city of Homestead, which is already stuck with a bill for the ball park's upkeep, is banking on racing fans to prove that if you build it, they will indeed come.
"We figured that the track would be a success if we sold about 88 to 89 percent of the seats at four events a year," Rudd said. "And now I think we will exceed that."
Rudd's main concern heading into this weekend was traffic: only eight lanes of roadway will connect the track with the nearest highway, about two miles away. "I'm worried about getting everyone out of the place," Rudd said.
Unlike the last exodus from Homestead, though, Rudd would probably like to see a lot more like this one.

HEADLINE: Chasing a Deal on Water With a Few Pitchers of Beer

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Last spring, when Gov. George E. Pataki asked his counsel and close friend, Michael C. Finnegan, to try to mediate a conflict between New York City and the communities around the city's upstate reservoirs, Mr. Finnegan took a drive up to Delaware County to take the temperature of the dispute.
As he spoke with farmers and townsfolk, he felt the heat of their anger at the metropolis to the south that for a century had flooded fields, dug up cemeteries and condemned villages to make way for its expanding water-supply system. 
 "It was kind of like talking to my Irish cousins who lost their lands to the English so many years ago," Mr. Finnegan recalled. "I was shocked to learn that in civics classes in school they were still teaching about the city's condemnation of land. This was not ancient history."
The townsfolk, whose backyards and pastures gather the rain and snow that produce the drinking water for 9 million people in New York and nearby suburbs, were newly inflamed because the city, to avoid having to spend perhaps $8 billion to filter the water drawn from the region, was planning to acquire even more land and enact strict new rules to prevent pollution in the watersheds.
Dozens of economically depressed rural towns, fearing that the city would stifle any chance for development and growth, banded together to fight the plan. The result was a stalemate.
Last week, after orchestrating seven months of confidential talks in venues as varied as an upstate beer garden and the Governor's offices on the 57th floor of the World Trade Center, Mr. Finnegan prevailed. Ending a century of hostility, New York City entered a 10-year, $1.2-billion partnership with 230,000 neighbors to the north to protect the water supply.
Experts in diplomacy and negotiation say the talks are a classic example of an increasingly popular approach to resolving long-festering disputes. Rather than using traditional hard-ball methods, in which each party stakes out an extreme position and battles to some mutually tolerable compromise, Mr. Finnegan created a politics-free climate in which a consensus could be quietly built.
The agreement was all the more significant because the two sides had been separated for decades by everything but bloodshed. More than once, a watershed farmer had threatened to sic his dogs on employees of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection, or D.E.P.
"The D.E.P. up here, with its little white trucks, is viewed like an occupying army," said Allen J. Zerkin, a lawyer from Woodstock who teaches mediation techniques at New York University and in 1992 participated in a failed attempt to end New York's water wars.
But the time was right for an agreement, Mr. Zerkin said, because a Federal deadline was fast approaching that would force the city to pay for filtration if no pollution-control plan was in place.
An important factor was Governor Pataki's background, he said. Besides formerly representing a large swath of the watersheds east of the Hudson in the State Senate, Mr. Pataki also had established a reputation as a conservationist, he said.
In a key move, negotiators were sworn to secrecy to keep both sides focused on goals instead of on how the talks would play in the press, Mr. Finnegan said. "The current disputes in Washington are being negotiated with all the finesse of a 30-second spot," he said. "That's exactly what I feared could happen here."
He added, "I think that's the most important part of this whole story. Not that we resolved the watershed issue, but that we were able to appeal to the best part of everybody who's involved in public service."
In the initial rounds of meetings in May, some representatives from New York City and watershed communities lit into each other, recounting the old war stories of land theft on the city's part or flagrant violations of water-protection rules upstate.
According to a variety of participants, three people -- Mr. Finnegan, Marilyn Gelber, New York City's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, and Daniel A. Ruzow, a lawyer representing a coalition of communities in the watersheds west of the Hudson River -- centered the talks on areas of agreement instead of areas of conflict.
Sometimes in a group of 50 and sometimes breaking into teams of 2 or 3 specialists, the delegations from upstate and downstate, along with Federal and state environmental and health experts, attacked "top 10 lists" of unresolved issues.
Ms. Gelber helped move discussions forward by frequently traveling -- usually alone -- to the watersheds to meet the people there. "I didn't understand until later that this was a stunning change for them," she said. "In the past, D.E.P. always came up with lots of lawyers and advisers, a whole entourage."
When the negotiations bogged down last summer, Ms. Gelber said, she drove out to Trout Creek, in one of the furthest corners of the Delaware River basin, to talk things over with Perry Shelton, the chairman of the Coalition of Watershed Towns.
"Perry's wife had made blueberry muffins that morning," Ms. Gelber said. "Person to person, over the kitchen table, we sat and shared ideas."
Following what Mr. Zerkin, at New York University, said is a classic negotiating rhythm, the participants made slow but steady progress -- "sausage-making," as one participant put it -- and then hit a wall.
"When you get toward the end, the most contentious issues, which have been simmering on a back burner all this time, now come back," he said. "You now have to confront the reality of signing on the dotted line, giving up what you didn't get. You start realizing that you have to sell this back home."
The negotiators were stuck on the size of New York City's payment to watershed towns to offset the economic burdens of pollution controls and the city's refusal to drop an appeal of an old court ruling that favored the upstaters.
In the end, simple civility helped iron things out. During a lunch break in the beer garden at Schneller's, a popular restaurant in Kingston, the New York City delegation bought a pitcher of beer for the upstaters at the next table.
Mr. Finnegan said he noticed at a subsequent lunch meeting at Schneller's that the factions were no longer at separate tables, but had intermingled. "It was at that point I realized we were starting to have some fundamental breakthroughs," he said.
But nothing was resolved easily. The talks almost fell apart four weeks ago, Mr. Ruzow said, when his clients, fearing that New York City was still planning to balk on the payment issue, told him to walk away from the table. Ms. Gelber, eager to prove that the city would meet its financial commitments, brought First Deputy Mayor Peter Powers into the talks. Mr. Powers and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have acknowledged that the small rise in water bills resulting from this deal, an average $7 a month per homeowner, is a bargain in comparison with the cost of building and running a filtration plant that had threatened to triple water rates.
In a final flurry of meetings that forced many participants to miss taking their children trick-or-treating on Halloween, the last details were hashed out. Each side made sacrifices. The city has agreed to spend $350 million to help upstate communities reduce pollution and to spur economic growth, while the watershed towns have dropped their longstanding lawsuits against the city and abide by the rules.
After crowding behind Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani at a 90-minute news conference high in the World Trade Center last Thursday, many of the negotiators prepared to head north to similar events in two watershed towns.
But they were delayed as rain fell all across the region. And in the valleys to the east and west of the Hudson River, the reservoirs, nearly half empty from a summer of drought, began to rise.

HEADLINE: Radically Different

BYLINE: By BRUCE BAWER; Bruce Bawer is the author of "A Place at the Table: The Gay Individual in American Society" and "Prophets and Professors: Essays on the Lives and Works of Modern Poets."

 BODY:

VIRTUAL EQUALITY
The Mainstreaming of Gay and Lesbian Liberation.
By Urvashi Vaid.
440 pp. New York:
Anchor Books/Doubleday. $24.95 
 Before Patrick J. Buchanan's anti-gay philippic at the 1992 Republican National Convention and the religious right's 1993 sabotaging of President Clinton's pledge to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military - which propelled countless infuriated gay Americans out of the closet, many into activism - the gay rights movement was essentially a creature of the political left. Between 1986 and 1992, Urvashi Vaid's successive roles as public information director and executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force put her, a young Vassar graduate and civil rights lawyer, at the center of the action. Noted for her belief that the movement should not only focus on equal rights for gay people but also seek "liberation" for women, people of color and the working class, Ms. Vaid responded to the influx of alarm, denouncing the "mainstreaming" of homosexuality as inimical to revolutionary change and calling for "a full-scale frontal assault" against "the coming of a racist, sexist gay and lesbian right." (There is, incidentally, no such right in sight.)
 "Virtual Equality: The Mainstreaming of Gay and Lesbian Liberation" is the work of a woman in an unusual position. While remaining an ideological extremist (who, for example, still defends the stipulation that half of each state's steering committe members at the 1993 march on Washington had to be people of color), Ms. Vaid manifestly wishes to win over a general audience and re-establish her authority in a movement whose center has moved rapidly toward the nation's political center - and away from her. To this end, she has moderated her formerly strident tone, cut down on the barn-burning rhetoric about the evils of religion, capitalism and the patriarchy, and embraced goals (like the acceptance of gay people by traditional religious institutions and the military) to which she was once at best indifferent. Instead of demanding "full-scale frontal assault" on dissident homosexuals, she speaks of working together.
 At times, indeed, Ms. Vaid sounds strikingly like the Johnny-come-lately liberal, moderate and libertarian activists and writers (this reviewer included) whom she labels "gay conservatives." In stating that gay men and lesbians must "be willing to expose the wildness of our subculture and be prepared to debate it honestly and question it thoroughly," that the gay ghetto can simply be "a more spacious closet" and that the movement should seek to educate straight people instead of ignoring or demonizing them, Ms. Vaid echoes core "gay conservative" concepts.
 Yet "Virtual Equlity" is, essentially, vintage Urvashi Vaid, proffering a vision of a "common, progressive movement" for social, economic and political revolution led by gay people, who, in her view (though not, it seems to me, in the view of most gay people themselves), embody a radical differentness that makes them the natural vanguard for revolution. And we need such revolution, she maintains, in order to transcend what she calls "virtual equlity,' the situation - "at once marginal and mainstream, at once assimilated and irreconcilably queer," and at once accepted and vilified - in which gay Americans now find themselves.
 "Gay conservatives" consider the present state of affairs a transitional stage on the way to full social acceptance, which will be achieved only if the gay movement grows beyond extremism and confrontation and if gay people continue to come out of the closet and to give their straight friends and relatives courses, as it were, in Gay 101 (helping them to understand, among much else, that being gay does not necessarily mean being a revolutionary). According to Ms. Vaid, however, virtual equality has resulted from an excessive focus on "mainstreaming," and can only be overcome through "radical social change." Virtual equality, she says, will give way to real equality only if gay people "develop amovement courageous enough to articulate gay liberation's approaches" to issues like "the deficit, crime, public schools, housing, the role of government, national defense, welfare reform and the shrinkage of the work force." In other words, there are correct gay positions on every issue from Nafta to health cae, and gay people need only to listen obediently when their leaders explain what those positions are.
 Ms. Vaid, then, who at the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force could not even work out a coherent challenge to propaganda from the religious right (and who, in one of many errors in her book, confuses the Bill of Rights with the later amendments to the Constitution, which she dates at 1776), proposes to formulate both the goals and the strategy of a movement for comprehensive and well-nigh utopian "cultural transformantion." She never gets very specific, however, about the nature of that transformation and the means by which she hopes to achive it; she appears to think that in churning out vacuous sentences full of words like "organization," "mobilization" and "empowerment" she is actually saying something. Yet she is clear about who stands in her way: in straight America, her enemy is the white heterosexual overclass oppressor) she ignores the fact that it is in overclass communities that gay people are safest and most accepted); in gay America, her enemy is middle-class white males who, by insisting on "single-issue politics" - that is, on a gay rights stand that for oppressed gay women, blacks and workers, sex, race nd class are also gay issues. Issues, yes - but gay issues?
 To be sure, Ms. Vaid is aware enough of the recent sea change in gy politics to recognize that most readers will not cotton to her radical approach. Hence she proposes compromise - a coordinated two-tiered movement that would enable single-issue types to focus on gay rights while others pursue a "common movement" agenda. All this activity, she suggests, might be subsumed under an "umbrella orgnization" like Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition. This is, of course, basically what the gay movement had in the Age of Vaid: many grass-roots people who did important and effective work toward understanding and acceptance, and a few national leaders who sent out a message of opposition to capitalism, religion and bourgeois values. Ms. Vid is right to assert that "the gay movement needs a fundamental shift." But while more and more gay people realize that the required shift is one toware integration, education and conciliation, Ms. Vaid longs to return to the day of class struggle and liberation fronts. That her rhetoric has come to seem so old so fast is a measure of how gay political discourse outside the academy, anyway - has been profoundly altered in a relatively brief time.

HEADLINE: Executive Suite

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is professor emeritus of economics at Harvard University. His latest book is "A Journey Through Economic Time."

 BODY:

COMPANY MAN
The Rise and Fall of Corporate Life.
By Anthony Sampson.
354 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $27.50. 
 IN economic writing, the distinction of "unquestionably the worst" is a hard competition to win. But the elementary training in awfulness of businesspeople who themselves write about their enterprise has given business prose the edge. Some years back, a leading business school asked me to participate in an effort to see if anything could be done. For a semester I joined some young colleagues in trying to find ways to encourage and guide improvement. The effort was a ghastly failure. The last papers still spoke of "charisma tizing" the product; one budding executive, talking about worker participation, commented on the need for producing "an osmotic upward flow of intelligence." There was more, some of it worse. It is my recollection that the whole attempt was later shelved. In any case, I keep encountering the same kind of meaninglessness on my occasional excursions into business writing.
Most business prose suffers from another, substantive flaw: seeing some particular form of organizational structure as it comes along (strong leadership, team management, carefully cultivated worker loyalty and participation, vigorous downsizing) as the final stage of development. What seems good, or anyhow inevitable, today can in fact be hopelessly archaic tomorrow. Nothing is quite so unstable in structure and form as the modern business enterprise. It survives only with constant adaptation and change.
These are the controlling conditions for Anthony Sampson's new social history of the corporation and the company man. Mr. Sampson is, first of all, an accomplished writer; everything is in clear, unpretentious, jargon-free English. As his past readers know, he shows a wide-ranging knowledge of economic and political life in Britain, the United States and other major industrial countries. And he is committed to change; this principle he accepts.
In "Company Man," Mr. Sampson looks first, in a moderately approving way, at the Boeing and Microsoft corporations, both in the Pacific Northwest, both characterized by worker participation. He then proceeds backward to the East India Company in London and India, and traces the historical development of business management to the present. This takes him to the great capitalist enterprises in the United States in the latter part of the last century -- those of Rockefeller, Morgan, Harriman -- and their European counterparts. He goes on to the heavily bureaucratic enterprises in their varied national forms; to the separate Japanese model, with worker job security and company loyalty; to the corporate raiders; the multinationals and the fears they aroused; and the managerial cutbacks of recent times, with a detailed and compelling account of specifically what this "downsizing" meant in New York State for those who had considered themselves permanent, even beloved, members of the I.B.M. family.
Mr. Sampson deals also with the breakup of the large British combines, the arrival of women in the executive suites and much, much else. He doesn't spare me and my Harvard colleague, Alfred Chandler, for ascribing permanence to corporate structures that were excessive as to the levels of command, vulnerable as to competition and soon in decline. Currently he is impressed with the way the modern executive, free in substantial measure from stockholder control, responsible to a board of directors of his own selection, determines his own compensation in accordance with the established principles of profit maximization.
Few if any authors on this subject matter have so thoroughly covered both the experience and the literature. The last extends not only to the professional but to the literary comment: few if any novels dealing with business or businessmen, from "Dombey and Son" to today, have escaped his attention. He also rediscovers astute earlier comment on business development that many of us either missed or have forgotten. It is good to be reminded that as early as 1904 Thorstein Veblen said: "The heroic role of the captain of industry is that of a deliverer from an excess of business management. It is a casting out of businessmen by the chief of businessmen."
There is one problem. So strong is Mr. Sampson's flow of information and comment that one sometimes gets lost in the current. His stages in business development run together; one struggles a bit to distinguish one change from the next. But this is a detail. "Company Man" is the most luminous history of the business enterprise that we will have this year and, except as imitated, perhaps for a long time to come.

HEADLINE: School Districts Make Contract Gains

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
CONFRONTED with balky taxpayer groups and citizens reluctant to accept teacher salary increases greater than their own, many school districts have come to Spartan terms in agreements with teachers, support staff and other union members.
With the Yonkers Federation of Teachers, which has been working without a contract since June 1994 but voted not to strike last Wednesday night, the status of labor negotiations with teachers in other districts is compelling. 
 Although the current academic year is barely through the first semester, the agreements are having an effect on school budgets, which will be presented next spring.
A reality check, prompted in part by an economic climate in which corporate layoffs, downsizings and wage freezes are the norm rather than the exception, reflects salary increases of 2 to 3 percent. In some cases, there are even givebacks on health care coverage or increased contributions to welfare funds in the newly negotiated settlements.
"In terms of salary increases, these have been far lower than what has been traditional," said Dr. Ronald Valenti, Superintendent of the Harrison School District and president of the Lower Hudson Council of School Superintendents. "You're seeing 2 to 3 percent rather than 5 to 6 percent. In the collective bargaining that has been occurring, obviously it is a reflection of the economy being in such deplorable condition. And, unmistakably, there is a trend toward employees sharing health-care costs. More teacher associations are picking up some of the share."
Successful negotiations, in which both sides leave the bargaining table satisfied with the results, are critical in maintaining positive morale. "Unless you open the school year with a contract, there will be some diminution of employee morale," Dr. Valenti said. Recent negotiations in districts like Harrison, Dobbs Ferry and Chappaqua reveal these changes. "The new contract was at a lesser amount than previous contracts," said Henne Starace, business administrator in the Chappaqua Central School District. The new contract calls for increases of 2.8 percent, 2.9 percent and 3 percent, respectively, in the next three years.
For Dobbs Ferry, whose teachers had been working without a contract since June 30 last year, "We had had lots of discussion about how our salary schedule lines up with other districts," said Mary Cronin, assistant superintendent of the district. The increases, which were recommended by a fact finder for the New York State Public Employment Relations Board, called for 2 percent for the years 1994-95 and 1995-96, and 3 percent for each of the following two years of the contract, which will expire at the end of the academic year in 1998.
"As some board members would say, it is a compromise and a good contract," Mrs. Cronin said. "We think we have a good contract. Teachers understand that the district has been struggling with having higher tax rates. We want to be able to keep the program going without exorbitant increases."
Even districts like Rye, Rye Neck and Eastchester, which are still actively negotiating settlements with their staffs, expect to follow similar trends.
"The general climate is setting a direction for negotiation," said Peter J. Mustich, Superintendent of the Rye Neck School District. "I think that teachers are sensitive to the economic conditions and constraints as they exist. Our goal is to be fair and reasonable with our staff."

HEADLINE: New York Ballot Proposal Makes Debt Loopholes Even Bigger

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New Yorkers will go to the polls Nov. 7 and be asked to vote on constitutional changes to the way the state borrows money. Contrary to "Yes for New York Debt Reform" (editorial, Nov. 1), Ballot Proposal No. 3 offers no improvements to state debt practices. Indeed, it makes matters worse. 
 State debt practices reached scandalous levels during Nelson A. Rockefeller's gubernatorial reign. As required by the state's Constitution, long-term debt must be approved by the voters. However, as Rockefeller moved to expand the size of state government, he not only pushed taxes to destructive levels but sought to saddle taxpayers with added debt as well.
Rockefeller circumvented the voters by establishing state authorities to float debt and implementing state borrowing schemes through local governments. Similar shenanigans have been perpetrated ever since.
Of course, New York taxpayers pay the debt service on all government-related debt -- even public-authority debt -- whether through state taxes, local taxes, tolls or fees. Therefore, true debt reform should require that all long-term debt receive voter approval -- whether floated by the state, public authorities or local governments. True state debt reform should close loopholes.
When all state-related debt is accounted for (as done by the Department of Commerce), the state's total debt outstanding tops $50 billion. The Nov. 7 ballot initiative places no limits on outstanding debt.
Allowing additional borrowing -- free from the prying eyes of voters -- to aid "distressed" municipalities will only increase the number of distressed municipalities. State elected officials will have new means for boosting state debt and bringing home the bacon to their districts.
The natural disaster loophole offers similar temptations. Imagine what Long Island state representatives might offer those with beach homes tumbling into the ocean.
The proposal for debt reform allows for the incurrence of more debt without voter approval and, therefore, potentially higher taxes down the road.
 
RAYMOND J. KEATING
Center Moriches, L.I., Nov. 1, 1995
 
The writer is chief economist of the Small Business Survival Committee in Washington.
