HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
HOMELESS PROGRAM IS REVAMPED
Battered by accusations of strong-arm tactics, the Grand Central Partnership has revamped its field program for the homeless and reduced its size after a major loss of financial support. The program's workers, ostensibly hired to guide the homeless to shelter and services, served instead as quasi-security guards at up to 80 locations, mostly cash machine lobbies in Manhattan. Scores of the field workers were themselves untrained homeless people paid $10 a day. Now the program has just 18 sites, and the field workers have been replaced by a core of a dozen full-time staff members. [B3.]
 
CITY HALL'S INFLUENCE OVER THE SCHOOLS
In the Blue Room of City Hall on Saturday, the Mayor of New York demonstrated how much control he really does exercise over the school system, despite his complaints to the contrary. He did so by producing a new five-year contract with the United Federation of Teachers, a generous pact that gives union members an 11 percent increase over five years and demands no major work-rule or productivity concessions in return. The agreement was worked out by the Mayor's labor commissioner, analyzed by the Mayor's budget director and concluded with virtually no contribution from the Board of Education's labor negotiators. No wonder the Mayor found it "historic." Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B3.]
 
BRONX GIRL IS SLAIN IN BASEMENT
A Bronx girl's trip to a dingy basement to fetch a load of freshly washed laundry for her mother cost her her life, the police said. Detectives said that the girl died of a single gunshot wound to the head. Police Inspector William Gardella said that detectives had no suspects and no motive in the killing. [B3.]
 
REGION
 
VOTERS TO GET DEBT QUESTION
Few things are more complicated than government borrowing practices, but on Tuesday voters will be asked to decide, on the basis of reading a 128-word question, whether to support a constitutional amendment that would significantly change how New York State pays its debts.
 
MOLINARI GIVEN POLICE PROTECTION
Two days before the election in which Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, is trying to unseat District Attorney William L. Murphy, a spokesman for Mr. Molinari's campaign complained that a car thief who had threatened the Borough President's life had been sentenced to only weekends in jail. Ed Burke, a spokesman for Mr. Molinari, said that the Borough President had been given 24-hour protection from the New York Police Department after learning that there was "a hit" on his life.
 
YONKERS RACE REKINDLES AN OLD FEUD
When Terence M. Zaleski was elected Mayor in 1991, he took on broad governing powers that his predecessors had not possessed since World War II. But for all the authority a revision in the Yonkers charter gave him, critics in both major political parties say city government has often seemed mired in partisan conflict during his four years in office. The debate over where the fault lies has shaped the mayoral race in Yonkers. [B4.]
 
STRIFE-TORN PEQUOTS RE-ELECT CHAIRMAN
In two decades as tribal chairman, Richard Hayward has seen the Mashantucket Pequots rise from the edge of extinction to economic and political power as owners of the nation's most profitable casino, the Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard, Conn. But with their new-found wealth has come new internal struggles and strife, as tribal elections have demonstrated. The tribe, which has more than 300 members, voted to re-elect Mr. Hayward, known to many as Skip. But he did not face much opposition: a leading challenger, Michael Goodwin, the tribe's assistant director of cultural resources, was disqualified from the race two days before the election. [B2.]
 
WALLACHS'S PARENT FILES BANKRUPTCY
Wallachs clothing stores, a New York institution for more than 100 years, is conducting a going-out-of-business sale at its 12 stores in New York, New Jersey and New Hampshire. Also joining in the sale are Roots, J. R. Tripler and other retail stores that, together with Wallachs, make up the 19-state chain of 50 stores owned and operated by the Hastings Group. [D10.]

HEADLINE: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: PERES;
For New Leader Shouldering the Job, Huge Task and an Uneasy Mandate

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 5

 BODY:
After Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's historic handshake with Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization in September 1993, some Israelis suggested that next Mr. Rabin might actually shake hands with Foreign Minister Shimon Peres.
The point of the joke was the celebrated rivalry of the two men who took turns leading the Labor Party through the 1970's and 1980's and who finally joined forces to achieve the historic breakthrough in Israeli-Palestinian relations. 
 Now Mr. Peres, who took over somberly last night as the Acting Prime Minister, has the task of shouldering the peace forward while working to heal a nation in shock over Mr. Rabin's assassination and the divisions and passions it underscored.
It is too early to tell whether he will lead his party to the elections currently scheduled for next November -- but there is a consensus among politicians that at this point, at least, there is nobody in the Labor Party of his stature.
Yet he must meet the onslaught from the conservative Likud Party and quell nagging doubts about the wisdom of handing more lands and power to the Palestinians, without the broad public faith that Mr. Rabin enjoyed as a military man who personified the nation's ambivalence about the concessions it was making.
Though they belonged to the same political generation and followed roughly parallel political paths, Mr. Peres and Mr. Rabin were totally different in style and appeal. Mr. Rabin was the model of the sabra -- the tough, native-born Israeli; Mr. Peres is an immigrant from Eastern Europe. Mr. Rabin was a warrior and war hero; Mr. Peres, though the architect of the modern Israeli military industry, comes across to many as a dovish elitist.
Where the chain-smoking Mr. Rabin was gruff, candid and quick to anger, Mr. Peres is the smooth, eloquent cosmopolitan. If Mr. Rabin felt at home in America, Mr. Peres favors the intellectual salons of Paris. Mr. Rabin did not conceal his distaste at meeting with Mr. Arafat, while Mr. Peres spent long hours negotiating with him.
In the end, it was these complementary qualities that enabled the two men to reach the historic peace with the Palestinians, a fact recognized by the Nobel committee when it awarded the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize collectively to Mr. Rabin, Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat.
It was Mr. Peres the visionary who initiated the secret contacts with the P.L.O. in Oslo and followed them through to agreement, and it was Mr. Rabin, the trusted leader, who gave the deal a political credibility. Despite decades of often-bitter rivalry, each acknowledged the critical contribution of the other.
In the end, Mr. Peres stood in the Cabinet's meeting room with tears in his eyes before the empty seat of his long-time rival, a seat he now had to fill, and paid him tribute: "He was a rare leader in Jewish history."
Referring to the three years he had served in Mr. Rabin's Cabinet, he continued: "These three years were for me also a revelation of friendship, the likes of which I had never seen -- just as there had been between us a rivalry on a level I had never known before."
Mr. Peres likes to present his own political vision in terms of a river. "Rivers are in constant flux, their steady flow forever creating a new reality," he wrote in his 1993 book, "The New Middle East" (Henry Holt, New York).
"A man might drown in their waters, but he cannot turn them back," he wrote. "The same holds true for history. We cannot build a future on the ruins of an old order."
From that basic premise, he developed his vision that Israel's future lay in reaching peace with the Palestinians and in building a strong economy. "Quality cannot be obtained through military conquest," he wrote in an article in 1989. "It is a matter for creative achievement," And he continued, "The major conflicts in the future will be waged more in R. & D. laboratories than on the battlefield."
That sort of thinking, however, often put Mr. Peres ahead of his countrymen, and he was perceived by the public as ready to strike deals behind his country's back. Where Mr. Rabin, the awkward old soldier, could inspire love, the elegant Mr. Peres never inspired more than respect.
Born Shimon Persky in 1923 in Vishneva, then a center of Jewish life in Poland (now in Belarus), Mr. Peres arrived in Palestine with his family in 1934. He studied in Tel Aviv, then in an agricultural school.
By age 20, Mr. Peres was secretary of the Labor Youth Movement, and soon after he went to work with David Ben-Gurion and Levi Eshkol, two of the founding fathers of the Jewish state.
In the first years after the establishment of the Israeli state, Mr. Peres led a military delegation to the United States, where he did advanced studies at New York University and Harvard. He returned to Israel in 1952 and, at age 29, was appointed by Prime Minister Ben-Gurion as Director General of the Defense Ministry. In that capacity, he built up the armaments industry, introducing electronics and aircraft industries and bringing Israel a nuclear reactor.
In subsequent years, Mr. Peres, who is married with two sons and a daughter, was elected to the Parliament and helped to unify the Labor movement into the Israel Labor Party. He held a progression of Government offices, including Deputy Defense Minister, Minister of Immigrant Absorption, Minister of Transport and Communications, Minister of Information, and, in 1974, Minister of Defense.
When Mr. Rabin resigned as Prime Minister in 1977 over a minor scandal, Mr. Peres replaced him as Acting Prime Minister and as chairman of the Labor Party.
After the 1984 elections, Mr. Peres served as Prime Minister for two years in a Government of national unity with the conservative Likud. He began Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon and was credited with taming runaway inflation. After the leadership passed through rotation to Likud's Yitzhak Shamir, Mr. Peres became Vice Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, and after the 1988 elections he served as Minister of Finance.
When Mr. Rabin was elected Prime Minister in 1992, he offered the position of Foreign Minister to Mr. Peres, and before long he initiated the secret contacts with the P.L.O. that led to the historic peace agreement. In recent months, Mr. Peres plunged into the second-stage negotiations on transferring control over major Palestinian-population areas of the West Bank to the Palestinians.
He personally met for many hours with Mr. Arafat and spent a tense final week with the P.L.O. leader in September ironing out the last obstacles. The agreement was signed in Washington on Sept. 28, launching a process of disengagement that Mr. Peres will now be charged with sustaining.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres, who succeeded Yitzhak Rabin, comforted Leah Rabin, Mr. Rabin's widow, yesterday at the Parliament building in Jerusalem, where Mr. Rabin's body lay in state. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In 128 Words, a Question on State Borrowing

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Few things are more complicated than government borrowing practices, but on Tuesday voters will be asked to decide, on the basis of reading a 128-word question, whether to support a constitutional amendment that would significantly change how New York State pays its debts.
To supporters of the amendment, the issue is simple enough. They say New York has had an egregious history of gimmicky borrowing that has resulted in the lowest bond rating of any state. The proposed amendment, which would restrict borrowing by quasi-governmental agencies and cap debt not approved by voters, will enforce fiscal discipline, they say. 
 Critics of the amendment agree that the state's borrowing practices have been unsound. But their analysis of the amendment couldn't be more different: They contend it will allow excessive borrowing without voter approval, which they believe is prohibited by the Constitution.
The issue has created some odd political alliances. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, have joined in endorsing the amendment. Last week, the two men, who have frequently clashed and are seen as potential gubernatorial rivals in 1998, appeared together to call for the amendment's passage.
On the other side, the state Conservative Party, upstate Democrats, supporters of Ross Perot and anti-tax groups have united strongly against the amendment. The Conservatives have been running radio ads in communities outside New York City that warn that the amendment "means more welfare for New York City and higher taxes for us."
Because the opposition has been outspoken and well-organized, even supporters of the measure say it is in danger of failing. Moreover, the opposition is strongest upstate and in New York City's suburbs, where turnout is expected to be highest. The city itself, where support for the amendment is thought to be strongest, has few important races and turnout is likely to be very low.
"There's no question it's an uphill battle," said Mr. McCall, who has been by far the strongest voice among public officials in advocating the amendment.
Mr. McCall and other supporters of the measure, which was approved twice by the Legislature, say it does not go as far as they would like. But they insist that it will end the worst of the state's bad borrowing habits, improve its low credit rating and reduce its interest costs.
Under the State Constitution, the voters are supposed to authorize long-term borrowing by the state. In recent years, voters have been unwilling to approve bond acts. So the state has increasingly circumnavigated the ballot box by having public authorities -- quasi-governmental agencies -- borrow money to help pay state capital and operating expenses. As a result of that practice -- which has been upheld by the state's highest court -- only $5 billion of the state's $28 billion in long-term debt has been approved by voters.
The proposed amendment would ban such back-door borrowing. But its critics say it is chock full of loopholes that will invite abuse, such as a provision that would allow borrowing for jobs programs during severe economic downturns.
Because of that and other provisions, "the state would never have to come back to voters for approval if it wanted to borrow money,' said Robert L. Schulz, the leader of an anti-tax group, All-County Taxpayers Association. "This does not offer restrictions. It opens the back door wider, it opens the front door, it takes the roof off."

HEADLINE: Wallachs's Parent Files For Chapter 11 Protection

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Wallachs clothing stores, a New York institution for more than 100 years, is conducting a "going out of business" sale at its 12 stores in New York, New Jersey and New Hampshire. Also joining in the sale are Roots, F. R. Tripler and other retail stores that, with Wallachs, make up the 19-state chain of 50 stores owned and operated by the Hastings Group.
As recently as three years ago, before demand plummeted for the tailored suits and other clothing in which it specialized, the group owned almost 200 stores. 
 According to the Chapter 11 filing by Hastings, the company intends to liquidate the business or sell its "small core" of profitable locations. The papers were filed Oct. 23 in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where the Hastings Group is incorporated.
Either way, it could spell the end for most of the group's stores -- including the venerable Wallachs chain, which in the mid-1970's offered classes in how to tie a scarf, and which at one time invited customers and passers-by alike to stop in and have loose buttons sewn on or missing buttons replaced at no cost.
With annual sales of about $100 million, the Hastings Group -- including Hastings (USA) Inc. and West Belt Distributors -- estimated its assets at the time of the filing at approximately $34.6 million and liabilities at about $38.3 million. The liquidation sales, which include store equipment, fixtures and furniture, are intended to stem what Hastings described as "losses that are occurring on a daily basis."
In recent weeks, vendors have stopped shipments of merchandise. But a hint of the group's financial difficulties appeared this spring when Wallachs, which carries men's suits priced at about $375 to more than $1,000, closed its 20,000-square-foot store in lower Manhattan and opened a 9,000-square-foot store four blocks away, at 52 Broadway, at Exchange Place. The other Wallachs store in Manhattan is at 555 Fifth Avenue, at 46th Street.
Specialty apparel stores have struggled for most of this decade, except for that relative handful of stores frequented by the carriage trade. Most of the suffering was caused by America's trend toward more casual attire, particularly in the workplace, by widespread layoffs among white-collar workers, and by customers who were skittish about the economy and switched to department stores or discount stores. Even when the economy improved, many former customers did not return to the specialty stores.
The Hastings Group, based in Chicago, acquired the stores in August 1994 from the HSSA investment group, which had been operating under Chapter 11 proceedings for nine months. After HSSA had bought the stores in October 1992 from the Hartmarx Corporation for a $43 million note due in two years, it closed about 100 of the 187 stores by year's end. These included the Raleighs stores in the Washington area, Hanny's in Phoenix, Arthur Frank in Salt Lake City, Peer Gordon in Cleveland and Kleinhans in Buffalo.
But those measures were not enough. Hastings said that before its purchase the business had suffered several years of contraction and a deeper erosion of its customer base than Hastings had anticipated.
Representatives of Hastings could not be reached for comment on closings or layoffs.

HEADLINE: I.B.M.'s Robotic Army of Computer-Chip Soldiers

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Most owners of personal computers know the type of microprocessor that acts as the electronic brain inside their desktop or notebook machines. But do they know what kind of chip is in their dishwashers or new telephone-answering machines?
Not likely. Yet as the semiconductor industry continues its explosive growth, a surge that the industry estimates will see worldwide sales jump 79 percent, to $261 billion in 1998 from $146 billion this year, these hidden chips have become robotic foot soldiers of the digital revolution. 
 And I.B.M. is eager to enlist. The company, sensing an opportunity to expand deeper into the world of commercial chip manufacturing, is expected to announce today that one of its new specialized chips has been chosen by Thomson Consumer Electronics for a new interactive television set-top box that Thomson will manufacture. It would be the biggest push yet by the International Business Machines Corporation into the market for so-called embedded controllers -- computer chips that make their way into non-computer devices.
Embedded controllers are specialized microprocessors that are responsible for most of the neat new functions found in everything from video-game players to microwave ovens. Most cars already contain about a dozen of the chips, and analysts predict that the wholesale value of electronics in all cars built in North America will increase to $15 billion by the year 2000, from $4.5 billion in 1987.
As sales of dedicated microprocessors soar, a more powerful generation of controllers promises to drive down the prices and make commonplace such items as color laser printers, digital cameras and personal digital assistants.
"The personal computer business is just one marketplace," said Tom Starnes of Dataquest in San Jose, Calif. "The nice thing about embedded controllers is that they appear in all aspects of your life."
In aiming for a bigger presence in the embedded-controller business, I.B.M. will find itself competing in a market long dominated by Motorola, Intel and Japanese semiconductor makers like Hitachi and NEC.
Today, I.B.M. is expected to announce that Thomson Consumer Electronics will place its chips in the set-top boxes Thomson is making for Tele-TV, a joint venture of Nynex, Pacific Telesis and Bell Atlantic.
Tele-TV plans to offer a multichannel television service using satellite and microwave distribution before its planned fiber optic network is completed. In the meantime, it will buy three million of the I.B.M.-equipped boxes from Thompson starting next year, said Elliott H. Newcombe 3d, marketing manager for I.B.M.'s new line of controllers.
Thomson is I.B.M.'s first major customer since the company announced its first commercial embedded controller in September 1994. Since then, the I.B.M. chips have begun to appear in a few pieces of hardware that direct data across computer networks, and Mr. Newcombe said they had been included in designs by other customers who have yet to bring their products to market. I.B.M. is also using the chips in developing half a dozen products.
I.B.M., which will report virtually no revenue from embedded controllers this year, expects to collect as much as $50 million next year from the sales of its three types of controller chips. That would still be minuscule compared with the $1.4 billion in sales that Motorola's controller-chip business had last year.
I.B.M.'s effort is part of a three-year-old strategy to realize a profit from its huge investment and expertise in semiconductor manufacturing. Until 1992, all of I.B.M.'s semiconductor production was used internally, making the microelectronics division, which pioneered much of the cutting-edge technology now used by its competitors, a multibillion-dollar expense.
The company, while still finding its way in embedded controllers, already supplies memory, logic and microprocessor chips to a number of outside customers, including competitors like Hewlett-Packard and Silicon Graphics. Outside revenue for the division jumped to $1.75 billion in 1994 from $325 million in 1992 and is expected to reach $2.5 billion this year, according to Daniel Mandresh of Merrill Lynch & Company.
Like the overall industry, the bulk of I.B.M.'s semiconductor revenue comes from selling memory chips that store information used by microprocessors. The company recently announced plans to build a $1.2 billion memory-chip plant in Manassas, Va., with Toshiba of Japan. Last week, it said it would spend $1 billion more to expand memory-chip production at its plant in Corbeil-Essonnes, France.
But while it expects its overall memory sales to rise, I.B.M. is planning to make this area a smaller part of its overall semiconductor revenue, shielding itself against the ups and downs of the cyclical memory-chip market. As part of last week's announcement, another $400 million was earmarked to expand production of microprocessors at the company's plant in Burlington, Vt.
Included in those plans are the new controller chips, which are based on the PowerPC microprocessor developed by I.B.M., Motorola and Apple Computer. While the three companies jointly own the design for the PowerPC processor used in personal computers and work stations, I.B.M. and Motorola have each developed their own PowerPC-based controllers.
In addition to providing a new source of revenue for I.B.M.'s microelectronics division, the controllers would provide needed volume for the PowerPC design. Unlike Intel, which dominates the market for personal computer microprocessors and can therefore spread the high cost of production over tens of millions of units each year, I.B.M.produces only a few million Power PC units a year in Burlington, the bulk of which are sold to Apple for its PC's.
"It's great to have great technology but we have to have economies of scale," said Douglas A. Grose, I.B.M.'s Burlington manager.
Because controllers do not have to perform the same complex functions needed by a microprocessor designed for a personal computer, they are usually a generation or two behind the PC chips. Consequently, the prices of embedded controllers range from $1 to $80, compared with an Intel Pentium chip in a personal computer, which costs about $350.
But the PowerPC represents one of the most advanced controllers, based on the reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, design favored for many of today's most powerful computer work stations. These attributes suit the PowerPC for a growing number of advanced new products like set-top boxes, laser printers and video-game players.
As the newcomer to the game, I.B.M. has focused its efforts in this high-end arena, which also includes products like faxes, telephones and networking equipment. Though the number of such controllers now sold is small, this area is expected to grow rapidly in the next few years.
"I think they are targeting exactly the right customers," said Susan Mason, an analyst with Information Architects, a research firm that closely follows the embedded-controller market. The customers they focus on "may not be shipping a lot today but will be shipping a lot in the future," she said.
And by sharing the same basic PowerPC design with Motorola, I.B.M. is well positioned to take business away from the industry leader in the future, Ms. Mason added.
The question remaining is whether I.B.M., which is relatively new to the world of selling chips commercially, can market its technology and service its customers as effectively as its more established competitors.
Unsurprisingly, Mr. Newcombe thinks it can. He plans to insure that the Burlington plant is churning out PowerPC chips for years to come. "The embedded world is slow to migrate to these upper levels of performance," he said, "but the good news is that when they do, they stay there for a long time."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Diagram: "Highway Information"
 One of the many uses for dedicated computer chips is controlling the increasingly complicated electrical systems in cars. According to Ford Motor, the current cost of electronics in a car is $1,500 to $1,750, more than twice the cost of the steel used to make the auto. Here: a look at the Lincoln Continental, Ford's most electronically complicated car, and its underlying electronic systems.
 
The chip set in the car comes primarily from off-the-shelf parts that have been re-engineered to perform different tasks.
 
A set of twisted-pair wires form a sort of local-area computer network in the car.
 
The car uses multiplexing technology so that sensors scattered throughout the car can send information to different control centers.
 
An optional satellite location system allows mororists to signal a rescue center when the car breaks down. The center uses catellite technology to direct the repair vehicle.
 
Ride control controls the car's air suspension system and -- shock absorbers and variably alters the power-steering system through altering sensors and controls at each wheel. The driver can select "plush" for a floating-on-air, no-handling type of drive, or "firm" for something more solid.
 
Cell phone control controls calls including whether or not comversation takes place on handset or through stereo system.
 
Virtual image cluster -- The speedometer, odomoeter and gas guage have a three-dimensional look to them.

HEADLINE: Reinventing the Neon Jungle

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Times Square has long been a magnet for the good, the bad, the ugly, the zany and the downright weird. No, not the people, but the overhead signs -- a vast, chaotic tableau of visual media of every variety.
The roll-call of giant commercial displays over the years includes winking penguins, smoke-puffing billboards, ersatz waterfalls, even a Mona Lisa rendered at 250 times the size of the original. Often, Times Square has been a showcase for the cutting-edge technology of its day. So it seems fitting that the Internet, the media of the moment, has recently secured a beachhead of sorts amid the neon of Times Square. 
 The Joe Boxer Corporation, a San Francisco marketer of oddball underwear (gag prints and detachable tails), leased a sign on 42d Street two months ago with an electric-light strip on the bottom for displaying E-mail messages from around the world. Mostly, they are personal messages: a birthday greeting to a 92-year-old grandmother, a writer's pitch for her unpublished short stories, a marriage proposal -- "Lee, I love you and want to ask you to be my husband. Hey this is the 90's. Rachel."
The billboard is displaying the most private of media, E-mail, which is typically written or received alone by someone hunched in front of a personal computer, in the most public of places, Times Square. Nicholas Graham, the 37-year-old president of Joe Boxer, calls his innovation "E-mail broadcasting."
The E-mail billboard is the latest evidence that as a center of state-of-the-art outdoor media, Times Square is regaining a breadth and vitality not seen since the golden age of signage in the 1950's and early 1960's, when the district was alight with flashy neon animations.
The comeback of Times Square as an outdoor emporium of commerical display is the result of economic regeneration and shrewd public policy. Times Square's recent history also shows the evolution of curiously appropriate technology -- a pastiche of everything from art-deco neon to fiber optics and computer graphics.
Advertisers justify their multimillion-dollar signs and the spending of hundreds of thousands a year to lease space in Times Square by talking about the million people who trudge through the district each day, and all those few-second "impressions." But those passers-by may or may not gaze up. For the companies, it is mostly about the image-burnishing prestige of having a presence in Times Square, one of the world's great crossroads.
Scholars and civic groups, led by the Municipal Art
 
Society, a former pioneer of anti-billboard activism dating back to the turn of the century, pushed hard for a 1986 zoning ordinance that actually mandated big signs and bright lights on new buildings in Times Square. They prevailed over many in the state and local government, and elsewhere, who wanted to do away with the area's garish commercialism, and remake Times Square in the image of Wall Street or Rockefeller Center, a sober office distict.
"It now appears that Times Square, with its aesthetic chaos and its finger-snapping vitality, may well survive the best intentions of the misguided," said Kent Barwick, a trustee of the Municipal Art Society.
These days, the intelligentsia waxes absolutely poetic on the subject of the neon sign, once regarded as a symbol of low-brow commercialism. Kenneth T. Jackson, editor in chief of "The Encyclopedia of New York" and a history professor at Columbia University, recently led 200 students on a midnight bicycle tour of Times Square. "There's no experience like it -- that sea of neon," he said. "If you took away the neon, it wouldn't be Times Square."
The view that big, flashy signs are vital to Times Square's distinctive character was the basis for the 1986 law encouraging their construction. By all accounts, it was a crucial step toward creating the look of Times Square today.
"The zoning ordinance was the catalyst," said Jason Perline, who is the chairman of Van Wagner Communications Inc., a sign design and marketing agent. "Imagine a municipality passing a law requiring commercial signs."
This odd yet enlightened act of urban preservation has secured Times Square's stature. London may have Picadilly Circus, and Tokyo the Ginza, but "no other city has such a concentrated place, a great outdoor space filled with powerful signs, like Times Square," said Paul Marantz, an architectural lighting consultant in New York.
The sign population of Times Square is rising, and set to go higher. At the start of the 1980's, sign company executives say, there were fewer than two dozen of the jumbo sign faces, which can cover thousands of square feet each, above Broadway and Seventh Avenue, from 42d Street to 49th Street. Today, they say, there are some 60 such big signs. For advertisers, the leasing cost for big billboards ranges from $180,000 to $1.2 million a year, depending on the display space and its location.
The signs range from Morgan Stanley's new electronic tickers, made with three million light-emitting diodes, spitting out financial headlines and stock quotes in 10-foot-high lettering, to giant computer-printed likenesses of everyone from Rush Limbaugh, advertising himself, to a seemingly naked Claudia Schiffer, coyly covered with hay, advertising Kenar apparel.
The other notable trend in Times Square's commercial display recently is the increasing diversity of signs, both by nationality and by industries represented. The Japanese electronics companies, like Sony, Panasonic, JVC and Aiwa, began the return of big signs by major consumer-products makers. Sony led the march in 1979 and others followed, all wanting "electronic calling cards" in Times Square.
The big American companies followed, like Kodak, Hertz, Maxwell House, Bloomberg and others. The Coca-Cola Company, the doyen of Times Square advertisers with a 75-year presence, unveiled a new, $3.5-million sign at the end of 1991. The four-story Coke bottle, at 47th and Broadway, fills and refills thanks to a mile of neon tubing, 60 miles of optical fiber and 13,000 light bulbs, all controlled by computer.
A wider range of industries are represented on Times Square signs these days. In particular, companies accustomed to pictorial ads like fashion, apparel and cosmetics makers have billboards everywhere -- mostly blown-up versions of magazine ads for Calvin Klein, Kenar, Jantzen, Banana Republic, Hanes, Hugo Boss, Tommy Hilfiger and others. But even the billboard, a prehistoric technology, has a new computerized gloss.
In the late 1970's, when Brooke Shields was creating a stir in Times Square with ads for Calvin Klein jeans, her suggestive likeness was hand-painted on the billboard. Painters using four-inch brushes mounted scaffolding. Often, an art director stood on the street with a two-way radio, directing their efforts. It could take months to complete a sign, and its quality depended on the painters' skill.
Today, with digital technology, the production process can take just hours. An image can be scanned from a magazine page, for example, manipulated in a personal computer, and then printed on rolls of vinyl in a machine that resembles a giant version of a desktop printer. The process was developed by the Metromedia Corporation, and later emulated by others. In the last few years, sign painters have become an endangered species.
Yet has all the advanced technology, from computer-rendered portraits to Sony's high-resolution Jumbotron screen, really improved the medium of outdoor display? Tama Starr, president of Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, which has made many of Times Square's signs since 1897, believes the most effective ingredients have not changed much over the years.
"The great signs are stunning, kinetic light sculptures," Ms. Starr said. "And through that artistic image, the company's message comes through."
Times Square historians tend to agree that the best signs were the mechanical ones dating back to the 1930's and 1940's. There was the Camel ad, which blew smoke rings of steam, and the Pepsi-Cola waterfall, which used a vacuum system to keep the falling water hugging the sign face. Most of these were built by Ms. Starr's grandfather, Jacob Starr, and designed by Douglas Leigh.
Today, at 88, Mr. Leigh confesses that he misses the old mechanical signs, which he believes were a unique medium. Of the Sony Jumbotron, he said, "It's great technology, but it's just a big version of what you can see in your living room."
Still, he says that the ascendancy of electronic technology over simpler forms of human inventiveness is only to be expected. "That's the electronic age, pal," Mr. Leigh said.

 Times Square has always been known for advertising, but recent and not-so-recent technological advances have made it a center for multimedia ads. And a center for ads about underwear, strangely enough.
 Map of Times Square shows locations of large billboards.
 
Financial News
 Owner -- Morgan Stanley
 Type -- Five screens and multitime zone clocks at a cost of several million dollars.
 Audience -- East side of the Square. The screens show information from stock markets and financial news from Reuters and others.
 Technology -- Light-emitting-diode screen. The ticker concept goes back to the 195h century. The 2d generation diodes have been around for the last year, and are brighter.
 Effective? -- Offers intelligent information, but any serious trader really should be on the floor. The multiple ticker screens, all moving at differnt speeds, can be dizzying.
 
8 O'Clock Coffee Mug
 Type -- Old-fashioned mechanical billboard with steaming cup.
 Audience -- West side of TImes Square and caffiene addicts.
 Technology -- Three-dimensional coffee cup with a slit at the top for steam release.
 Effective? -- Possibly the lowest-tech gimmick billboard, also one of the most appealing in its simplicity and lack of glitz.
 
Calvin Klein
 Type -- Vinyl billboard with surly urban youths.
 Audience -- West side of Times Square and commuters who use 43d Street.
 Technology -- Large sheets of computer-colored vinyl, a technique that became possible in 1986, has been refined in the last three years. The billboard cost more than $15,000.
 Effective? -- Mr. Klein's ads have always been a hot topic of discussion, and the recent campaign featuring teen-agers in provocative poses remined in Times Square long after similar ads were pulled eleswhere.
 
Coca-Cola Sign
 Type -- 55 tons of fiber optics (pliable strands that transmit light), neon, glass, aluminum, light bulbs and steel with strolling ticker at cost of $3.5 million.
 Audience -- The entire Square.
 Technology -- The fiber optics make it appeqar as if the bottle empties and refills.
 Effective? -- Sits high up but extremely complex in its activity. It gets lost in the column of signs above it.
 
Jumbotron TV
 Owner -- Sony
Type -- Outsized television set.
 Audience -- All of Times Square. The screen carries ads for Sony items, news and public service announcements.
 Technology -- Enormous (32 feet by 23.5 feet) TV screen based on sports stadium screen technology.
 Effective? -- One of thge most dynamic installations in Times Square.
 
Joe Boxer Ad
 Type -- Underwear billboard with a ticker wired to Internet.
 Audience -- New surfers and tourists who happen to look up from the north side of 42d Street.
 Technology -- Users can seen messages through http://www.joeboxer.com. and have them posted to ticker after the rigors of editing.
 Effective? -- The sign is not in the most visible spot in the square, and advertisements for the company run more frequently than E-mail. (pg. D1)

 At King Graphics Technologies in New York, computers are used to generate outsized vinal sheets that are strung up to billboards. The printing cost can run from $2,000 to $25,000. Ads that are lit from the back are printed on both sides so they do not wash out -- making them more expensive.
 1. The ad is scanned into a Power Macintosh or created from scratch on the computer using photo editing programs such as Adobe's Photoshop.
 2. The printer outputs several 20-foot wide strips of vinyl.
 3. The vinyl is melted together and can be strung up on less than three hours. Ads that were painted by hand could take two months. (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Bill and Note Sales This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Government's quarterly refunding tentatively scheduled this week includes the auctions of 3- and 10-year notes, beginning tomorrow for the 3-year maturity and Wednesday for the 10-year maturity. On Thursday, a tentative auction of one-year bills is also scheduled.
The auctions of both the notes and the one-year bills may be postponed, because they are contingent on an agreement being reached on a Federal budget and a raising of the Federal debt ceiling. 
 By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.30 percent and on a six-month bill 5.24 percent. The current rate for a one-year bill is 5.12 percent, a three-year note is trading at a price to yield 5.55 percent and a 10-year note at a price to yield 5.92 percent.
Government financings expected this week include a $400 million Fannie Mae debenture issue due in 2005, which is to be priced tomorrow.
The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

HEADLINE: Savings Bond Rates Fall

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
With interest rates falling, buyers of United States savings bonds in the next six months will be earning less. The Treasury Department said last week that interest rates on short-term bonds issued from November through April would be 4.75 percent, down from 5.25 percent, and for long-term bonds, 5.16 percent instead of 6.31 percent.

HEADLINE: In America;
Asleep At the Revolution

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Marian Wright Edelman was seething.
"I have been so frustrated trying to get the message out," she said. "It is immoral what is going on in Washington today. The country is sleeping through this revolution." 
 Ms. Edelman is president of the Children's Defense Fund and she is outraged by the Republican-led assault on the poor and the young and the sick and the disabled.
What we are witnessing, she said, "is an unbelievable budget massacre of the weakest. It is absolutely wrong."
Ms. Edelman seemed awed by the magnitude of the assault. "I have never seen anything like it. The budget cuts are many times the size of those in the Reagan years. I very seldom use the word evil, but what I am seeing . . ." She stopped and shook her head.
Ms. Edelman is convinced that most Americans are unaware of the amount of harm that will result from the G.O.P. budget policies. She emphasized that it is not just the fact that funding for social programs is being cut. What is more important is that the Federal Government is abandoning its responsibility to provide even the most minimal level of assistance to Americans left without any other resources.
That is a radical and deeply regrettable change at the core of the American value system.
"Until now," said Ms. Edelman, "our Government has said to a child or to a poor person or to the elderly or the disabled that, you know, if there is a recession or a disaster, and regardless of where you live, we are going to be there for you. The fundamental principle that our national Government is the protector of last resort is what is at stake as we give these block grants to the states and tell them to go ahead and do whatever they want.
Ms. Edelman denounced the politicians who have "succeeded in making 'entitlements' a dirty word." The entitlement issue is the safety net issue, she said, and it is essential that people who care about the country's most vulnerable individuals fight for it. Without the guarantee of help, many people in desperate need will not get help, and many of them will be children.
The existence of Federal entitlements means that "there is a floor," said Ms. Edelman. "There is a national guarantee of some decency. No 7-year-old will have to sit in class without eating all day, his attention wholly distracted from learning by his hungry belly. No 5-year-old will have to grow up on the streets or in an orphanage simply because her father left and our patience with her mother's inability to find and keep a job has run out."
Ms. Edelman addressed the entitlement issue directly in an open letter to President Clinton published in Friday's Washington Post. "We do not want to codify a policy of national child abandonment," she wrote. "Franklin Delano Roosevelt correctly stated: 'Better the occasional faults of a government that lives in a spirit of charity than the constant omissions of a government frozen in the ice of its own indifference.'
"Every president since FDR -- Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter, Reagan, and Bush -- preserved the minimal national guarantee of income assistance for poor children. It is a precedent I hope and trust you will uphold."
Ms. Edelman argues that the welfare and Medicaid bills fashioned by Congress in the name of "reform" will in fact make more families poor and deprive many more Americans of desperately needed health care.
That is unquestionably true, but it has not slowed the rush to get the bills enacted into law. A study by the Department of Health and Human Services concluded that the Senate welfare bill, which is less harsh than the House bill, would push 1.1 million children into poverty and would worsen the condition of families already in poverty.
That did not stop President Clinton from announcing his strong support for the Senate bill.
Ms. Edelman said she was "disturbed" by the President's position and hoped he would change his mind. She said any legislation that weakens the health or income safety net should be vetoed.
"The President of the United States and everybody else ought to be saying: 'This is not who we are. This is wrong and we won't do it. We are not going to hurt children.' "

HEADLINE: Strife-Torn Pequots Re-elect Chairman

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
In two decades as tribal chairman, Richard Hayward has seen the Mashantucket Pequots rise from the edge of extinction to economic and political power as owners of the nation's most profitable casino, the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, Conn. But with their new-found wealth has come new internal strife, as yesterday's tribal elections demonstrated.
The tribe, which has more than 300 members, voted to re-elect Mr. Hayward, known to many as Skip. But he did not face much opposition: a leading challenger, Michael Goodwin, the tribe's assistant director of cultural resources, was disqualified from the race two days before the election. 
 The Pequots -- who employ 10,000 people, took in $800 million last year at their Foxwoods casino and are planning to open another in Bridgeport -- are governed by a seven-member tribal council, headed by the chairman. Only members of the council can run for chairman, said Charles Duffy, a lobbyist for the Pequots. Since Mr. Goodwin was not on the council, he could not run for chairman, Mr. Duffy said.
But Mr. Goodwin charged that he had been barred from the election because of his controversial political viewpoints. He told The Day of New London that he had planned to question how the tribe distributed its vast new wealth.
"There are some folks out there so scared of an honest election they'd be willing to do anything to shut me out of the vote," he told the newspaper. "It doesn't look right, though, and I think the membership will smell a rat."
Neither Mr. Hayward nor Mr. Goodwin returned telephone calls last night.
The Pequots had nearly died out as a tribe in the 1970's, to the point that Connecticut considered turning their reservation into a state park. Then in 1983, the Pequots won Federal recognition, which qualified them to enter the gambling business, and in 1992 Foxwoods was opened.
The Pequots now offer their members jobs with an average salary of $50,000 to $60,000, housing and fully subsidized education from nursery school through graduate school.
And the small tribe suddenly finds itself with plenty of money to argue over. Tribal issues are discussed at monthly meetings in the community center and decided by the tribal council. Two council members are elected each year, and the chairman is elected every three years. Half of the tribe's members are old enough to vote.
In recent years, race has sometimes proved a point of contention. Some tribal members married into white families, others into black families. Mr. Goodwin, the disqualified challenger, charged that the tribe had been discriminatory in the way it distributed housing to its membership. And The Day of New London reported that seven other tribal members who were found ineligible to run for office were black.
Mr. Duffy, the lobbyist, said: "The tribe is wholly integrated and the council reflects that."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about tribal elections held by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians in Connecticut referred incorrectly to the status of some participants. Michael Goodwin, who criticized the tribe's leaders, ran unsuccessfully for the tribal council. He was not disqualified, nor were any tribal members ruled ineligible to run.
The article's headline characterized the elections incorrectly. The tribe's chairman, Richard Hayward, was re-elected by the tribal council without opposition. The annual election was not strife-torn.

HEADLINE: Competition and Cutbacks Hurt Foreign Doctors in U.S.

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
At Woodhull Hospital in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Dr. Yusuf Afacan takes care of poor patients sick with AIDS, drawing their blood, juggling their medications, finding them homes.
After graduating from medical school in his native Turkey, Dr. Afacan did a residency in New Jersey and a fellowship in infectious diseases at the University of Rochester. He landed his job in Brooklyn through a program that allows foreign-born and foreign-trained doctors to remain in the United States if they practice in underserved areas. Four of the five senior doctors at his clinic are also foreign graduates -- the others from Belgium, Haiti and Pakistan. 
 But if legislators have their way, Dr. Afacan and his colleagues, who work where many American doctors refuse to go, may be an endangered species. Facing an oversupply of doctors, the Clinton Administration and Congress, in separate measures, are scaling back the Government programs that have long allowed graduates of overseas medical schools to practice in the United States, providing crucial care in the sickest, poorest neighborhoods.
At the same time, medical groups, which have long officially embraced foreign doctors, are becoming less welcoming toward them as competition for medical jobs increases in an industry that has been thrown into turmoil by budget cuts and the growth of managed care.
Physicians like Dr. Afacan are at the center of a political maelstrom that threatens to topple the fragile infrastructure that provides care in America's AIDS clinics, city hospitals and rural emergency rooms.
Public hospital administrators are in a near panic at the prospect of losing a huge chunk of their work force.
"There is this myth that if we cut off the supply of international graduates, somehow there are going to be American doctors who are going to want these jobs," said Kalman Resnick, a Chicago lawyer who has helped Cook County Hospital find foreign-trained doctors. "And that is just not the case."
Of the 1,261 doctors in training who dispense care full time at New York's public hospitals, nearly 70 percent are foreign-born graduates of overseas medical schools, and the percentage is even higher at some private hospitals in poor neighborhoods. At Bronx Lebanon, it is 71 percent; at North General Hospital in Harlem, it is 91 percent.
The international medical graduates, many of whom were recruited by hospitals in need of their labor, feel betrayed.
"When this country needed a lot of physicians to help the health care system, international graduates were very welcome -- wined and dined," said Dr. Busharat Ahmad, a Pakastani-born ophthalmologist, who practices in Monroe, Mich. "And now when they don't need so many they are thrown by the wayside, and no one cares."
 
Purse Snapped Shut By Medicare Bill
 The House Medicare bill that passed last month will cut Federal subsidies for doctors in training who are international medical school graduates and neither citizens nor permanent residents. More than 50 percent of doctors in training fall into this category at many inner-city hospitals, where such doctors dispense the bulk of front-line care.
At the same time, the Department of Health and Human Services is seeking to curtail a visa program that has allowed foreign doctors who have finished training to remain in the United States if they practice in poor areas.
Within the profession, graduates of foreign medical schools say they are facing new levels of bias, with groups like the American Association of Medical Colleges lobbying to restrict opportunities for foreign physicians.
And as H.M.O.'s sweep across the nation, foreign-trained physicians say they are being shut out of plans by managed-care companies who promise customers American doctors.
It is the latest phase in this country's ambivalent relationship with foreign medical graduates, who are at once deemed inferior in training but critical to the delivery of health care to the poor. And some immigration critics say the proposals are racist as well since they do no affect U.S. citizens who are graduates of foreign medical schools.
"There is a color line and also an accent line in American medicine," Mr. Resnick said.
Central to the debate about the proper role of foreign-trained doctors are a couple of facts: First, that there are now too many doctors in the United States, particularly specialists, and health economists say this surplus breeds inefficiency and drives up costs. And second, there are 149,000 international medical graduates now practicing in the United States, which amounts to 20 percent of the nation's physicians -- a number that has been accelerating fast. Virtually all of these doctors enter the country for medical training but remain for years afterward.
To groups as diverse as the American Association of Medical Colleges, an industry group, and the Center for the Health Professions at the University of California at San Francisco, a research group, the proper course is a matter of simple math.
"We have just got to stop the pipeline of foreign medical graduates," Dr. Ed O'Neil, director of the center, said. "They are a big chunk of physician oversupply. This very quickly gets into racial issues, but I don't think that's it. We're just trying to be rational."
 
A Promise to Leave, A Reason to Stay
 Officially, most foreign doctors who obtain visas to train in this country do so with the explicit understanding that they will leave once that training is finished. But more than 75 percent, and perhaps as many as 90 percent, of these doctors end up practicing here, both because of poor job prospects in their native countries -- most are from poor nations -- and because the technology-based training they receive here is irrelevant at home. Although they come initially for primary-care training, in the end most specialize.
At the end of 1994, there were 23,499 international medical graduates pursuing medical training in the United States, a number that has doubled in the last five years. Forty-two percent of doctors in training in New York and 52 percent in New Jersey are international medical graduates. In Illinois, the percentage is 32; in Michigan, 29. Just over 8 percent nationwide are American-born citizens who traveled overseas to attend medical school.
"We take the brightest students in foreign medical schools and give them a set of skills that are not needed in their own country, and so they stay here and add to the physician glut," Dr. O'Neil said.
But a process that sounds so irrational has burgeoned because it makes sense from another perspective: As they travel the circuitous route that begins with medical school in Guadalajara or New Delhi, international graduates often spend more than a decade training and working in medically underserved areas, performing a crucial role in American health care.
Virtually all foreign doctors who enter the country on temporary training visas stay on indefinitely through Federal programs that grant them visa waivers in exchange for a commitment to practice for three years in a medically underserved neighborhood.
The Department of Veterans Affairs, the Appalachian Regional Commission and, more recently, the Department of Housing and Urban Development as well as the Department of Agriculture, issued visa waivers to help staff inner-city and rural hospitals.
In many cases, that three-year stopover, even if it is en route to specialties or fancier practices, has been invaluable. "The HUD waiver program has been a real boon for us, and let me tell you there are few boons when you're dealing with an inner-city population with AIDS," said Dr. Victoria Sharp, medical director of the Spellman Center of St. Clare's Hospital, a designated AIDS treatment center in New York City.
But if the Congress and the Department of Health and Human Services have their way, foreign-born graduates of foreign medical schools will be largely barred from this country in the future.
Although the House Medicare bill does not prohibit hospitals from admitting foreign graduates as medical residents, it largely eliminates subsidies to help pay for their training, which would discourage hospitals from hiring them.
 
Cheap Labor, Where Labor Is Needed
 Hospitals now receive about $150,000 a year for each doctor in training, regardless of nationality, to compensate for the costs of medical education. So for better and worse, inner-city hospitals have gotten both cheap labor and extra Federal dollars when they hire foreign graduates.
"This subsidy has fueled the expansion of training programs in the inner cities where the shortage of fully trained doctors is great," said Dr. Jordan Cohen, president of the American Association of Medical Colleges. "But we've ended up with an educational system that's been terribly distorted by service requirements of institutions."
While Congress moves to shut the pipeline for residents, the Department of Health and Human Services under the leadership of Secretary Donna E. Shalala is moving to curtail physician immigration programs. This summer, Ms. Shalala wrote to her counterparts at the Department of Agriculture and Housing and Urban Development to request that they no longer issue immigration waivers to foreign physicians, citing a national surplus of doctors. For the moment, the HUD program is on hold.
But health-care advocates fear that such proposals will leave poor people without doctors.
This week St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark had three waiver requests turned down for experienced foreign medical graduates who were to be full-time doctors for patients on Medicaid.
"What are we supposed to do?" said Dominick Calgi, an administrator at the hospital, "We are going to have to try to get other physicians, but there are not many who are willing to commit to the inner city, and never of this quality." In the meantime, the hospital pieces together a staff using residents and doctors who commit to a few hours here and there.
The issue of international graduates has been divisive for organized medicine.
Recently, the American Medical Association recommended that the number of training slots in the United States be limited to 110 percent of the number of graduates of American medical schools each year; it is now 145 percent. The restriction would largely affect foreign doctors, who get the slots that graduates of United States medical schools leave unfilled. The association's medical-student division went further, suggesting that graduates of the American schools be awarded preference over international medical graduates.
That proposal was ultimately rejected but set off a ferocious debate in which foreign graduates complained that they were being treated as second-class citizens and Americans fretted about jobs.
 
A Shoulder Cold And Shrugged
 Foreign-trained doctors say their employment prospects have already dimmed. Carlos Roldan, who went to medical school in Colombia and passed the test required of foreign-trained doctors on his first try, assumed he would have no trouble landing a residency slot in New York. He wrote to 90 hospitals and received 45 applications in response. He filled them all out, got only two interviews, and no job. Many hospitals wrote back that foreign-trained doctors need not apply.
Even senior doctors, who are now citizens, say they are being squeezed out of jobs, as H.M.O.'s sweep the country, favoring American-trained doctors in hiring.
When one hospital in suburban Detroit was taken over by a large H.M.O. this year, the new owners promptly dismissed the hospital's anesthesiologists -- six foreign-trained doctors and one American graduate, according to a physician who would not identify the H.M.O because he is seeking an affiliation with it. The H.M.O. invited the former doctors to apply for jobs, and all did, but only the United States-trained doctor was hired.
"These people are all in their 40's and 50's, their children were born in the U.S., so this is a big deal for them," he said. He said he knew of 16 experienced doctors from abroad who had been forced out of practice because they were not admitted to H.M.O.'s.
Inner-city and rural hospitals are busily devising contingency plans if the role of foreign doctors is restricted, hiring more nurse practitioners and physician's assistants.
In the long run, health-care planners hope that American-trained doctors will trickle down into today's inner cities as the job market gets tighter. But many have suggested that the Government needs to resurrect a National Health Service Corps, allowing doctors to practice in underserved areas in exchange for a reduction of medical school loans.
"If the problem is a shortage of primary-care doctors in poor neighborhoods why not face that directly," Dr. O'Neil said, "instead of subsidizing the training of someone we don't need, who is going to stay here, become a neurosurgeon and drive up costs?"

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Japanese Prefer Blondes (In Their Ads, That Is)

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Brian G. Banowetz, a 28-year-old former Army intelligence trainee in Oregon, flew here this year with empty pockets and big dreams.
With a smattering of Japanese, dark good looks and a bit of acting experience, Mr. Banowetz hopes he is on his way. He has already helped sell KitKat chocolate bars, Toyota cars and other products in five Japanese commercials. 
 "Japan was a 10-year dream," said Mr. Banowetz, confident as he began an audition with a Japanese company. "Here you can be in the thick of it all in a bigger way."
Japanese seem to tuck away their wallets when it comes to buying American cars and other products, but they still harbor a fascination with the West. As a result, the faces that beam from advertisements, billboards and commercials often have blue eyes and blond hair.
Tokyo streets and television screens have been sprinkled with the giant images of Madonna and Takara liquor, Harrison Ford and Kirin beer, Peter Falk and Suntory whisky, Eddie Murphy and Sapporo canned coffee, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Arinamin vitamins, and thousands of aspiring actors like Mr. Banowetz. Big stars come for the big money, and also because doing a commercial in Japan does not sully a reputation in America.
One in five commercials used to feature foreigners, and even unknown actors could earn a nice living by filming just commercials.
The recession here has dampened the business a bit. But foreign models are still paid 50 percent more than Japanese, and so Japan remains a fertile training ground for young Americans trying to make a name in the sparkling, dazzling world of modeling and television.
"This means a lot to me," Howard C. R. Franklin said as he walked out of an audition after his day job at an American securities company. "I like the exhibitionism. My modeling friends think I'm nuts. I'm straddling two worlds, the normal and the exhibitionist worlds."
In some cases, Japanese advertisers use foreigners to add cachet to their products. At other times, the foreigner is the focus of a certain comedy. Maureen L. Card is often on camera swathed in the 1950's look, her hair in curlers, cold cream covering her face.
A large woman, she appeared in one commercial vacuuming. Her on-stage scrawny husband was sitting in the way, so she picked him up with the tip of her vacuum and scooped him out of the room.
"I was very overweight and they wanted a fat woman to do a commercial," said Ms. Card, who with her husband and three children comes from San Diego. "They're getting a silly foreigner and I'm getting paid. I've never felt I've been used."
Sometimes Japanese companies seem to enjoy poking fun of foreigners, perhaps because it is even more amusing to see a humiliated American than a humiliated Japanese. When Akio Shizume, a creative director at Dentsu Inc., an advertising company, wanted to show a sleepy, slumping man fall flat into a mushy cake, he chose to use foreign actors, not Japanese.
If a Japanese actor appeared messy on screen, Japanese viewers might identify with him and feel awkward and so they would not want to buy the wet tissues the company sells, Mr. Shimuze said.
"Foreigners are neutral, like people from another world, so the audience does not identify with the dirtiness of the actions and instead feels only the humor in the commercial," Mr. Shizume said.
Last year a 3 1/2-year-old blond girl from an American military family pocketed about $6,000 for a session's work filming a car commercial in which she sipped a glass of milk and then spilled it.
The commercial ran for a year and won a top award and she became a poster child for the Mercedes-Benz car all over Japan. Spurred on by stories like this, parents shuffle their children to photo sessions, register their names with several different modeling agencies, and then drag their young hopefuls around the city from audition to audition.
"When Japanese look at an Asian kid, they look at the face first," said Masako Saito, president of K & M Promotions, a modeling agency. "But all foreign faces look the same, and so they don't look at the face of the model, but focus their eyes more on the clothes."
Even the Japanese directors often do not scrutinize the faces too closely. Once when a Japanese company wanted a certain style of young boy, Mrs. Saito brought in nearly 40 boys to an audition. All were turned down because they did not have the right aura.
Then Mrs. Saito spotted someone she liked -- a young short-haired model with a healthy look. She conferred with the American mother, and together they brought in the young child. The director smiled, a contract was drawn up and the commercial was filmed. It was not until two years later that Mrs. Saito told him the young model was a girl.
Not all Japanese are happy watching foreigners take the spotlight so often in their own commercials.
That came up recently when Jaacs, a credit card company, wanted a genuine American gas station with a bathroom, and the advertising managers approved a decision to fly to Hollywood to film.
In the commercial, an American man pulls into the station and gets out of his car, clearly in great need of a toilet, but when he looks over to the bathroom, he sees a line of five or six men, who are also waiting impatiently. He finds a Jaacs card and turns it over to the gas attendant, who calls out, "Whose Jaacs card?"
Checking their pockets and fiddling with their wallets, the men walk stiffly, uncomfortably, over to the gas attendant, while the lone man scurries into the empty bathroom.
"Most of the top executives like it now," said Toshiyasu Nakamura, who approved the commercial, which ultimately won an award. "But in the beginning, they kept asking, 'Why do we need foreigners in commercials?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Japanese may resist American goods, but not American models. Faces on posters in a department store were distinctly un-Japanese. (Fumiyo Asahi for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Talk of a Sumitomo Merger Lifts Price of Daiwa Stock

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The shares of Daiwa Bank continued to rise today on expectations of a merger, but Japanese Finance Ministry officials were quiet about the progress of discussions.
Late last week, the ministry summoned officials of Sumitomo Bank to discuss a potential merger with Daiwa, a union that would create the world's largest bank. The discussions followed losses by Daiwa of $1.1 billion in unauthorized bond trading in New York, the expulsion of the bank from the United States, and its indictment on a variety of fraud and conspiracy charges. Daiwa is facing the threat of American fines as high as $1.3 billion. 
 Speculation about a merger sent Daiwa's shares soaring 100 yen, or 15.6 percent, on Monday. By early afternoon in Tokyo today, Daiwa's shares were up another 12 yen, at 751 yen, after trading up as much as 40 yen, or 5.4 percent, this morning.
Financial-industry executives here have been looking for clues on a possible merger from the Finance Ministry.
Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura, while not commenting specifically on the progress of talks, said Monday that Sumitomo's cooperation with Daiwa was necessary to avoid confusion in the financial markets, according to a report by the Kyodo news service.
Tatsuya Tamura, executive director of the Bank of Japan, echoed Mr. Takemura's remarks, saying that Sumitomo's support would have a "positive impact on maintaining stability in the financial system in Japan."
The central bank is considering extending loans to Daiwa to avert a possible cash shortage, Japan's leading economic daily, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, said. Japanese bankers said Daiwa has had some trouble raising funds recently.
In addition, the Bank of Japan said Monday that it would be watching Daiwa much more closely, making monthly inspections of the bank.
Some bankers remain skeptical that a merger of Daiwa and Sumitomo would take place at all, or at least soon. The chairmen of Sumitomo and Daiwa are reportedly close friends, and that friendship may have brought the two institutions together in the first place.
But Sumitomo and Daiwa need to work out the transfer of operations in the United States before they examine the broader dimensions of how a merger would take place, a Japanese banker familiar with the institutions said. The banker added: "Everyone is getting excited. But there are many obstacles."
The Nomura Securities Company, which owns 3.3 percent of Daiwa, has said that it will help Daiwa dispose of its United States operations.
For a merger, Sumitomo would need the blessing of Japanese tax authorities, as well as that of the Fair Trade Commission, the nation's weak anti-monopoly watchdog. It would also have to deal with various Daiwa executives, who might not favor having their bank disappear.
Deputy Finance Minister Kyosuke Shinozawa on Monday acknowledged some responsibility for the $1.1 billion fraud at Daiwa. He also said that the ministry would strengthen its inspection and supervisory systems for overseas branches of Japanese banks to prevent other scandals.

HEADLINE: Teacher Contract Faces Uphill Ratification Battle

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Now that the leaders of the teachers' union have reached a tentative agreement with New York City on a new contract, they must begin their campaign to win the support of rank-and-file members like Paul Arcidiacono.
Mr. Arcidiacono, a guidance counselor at Lincoln Academy on West 60th Street in Manhattan, is disappointed that the five-year agreement provides for no raises until October 1997. As an employee for 29 years, he is also dismayed that the pact gives individual schools the option to overlook an applicant's seniority when filling a teaching vacancy. He is troubled that the contract authorizes the Board of Education to defer 5 percent of every new teacher's annual salary for four years, an incentive for new teachers to remain in the system. 
 "As it stands now, I'll vote against it," said Mr. Arcidiacono, who splits his time between Lincoln and another experimental middle school, New Direction in Harlem. "I'd have to see more of the details."
In its 35-year history, the membership of the United Federation of Teachers has never rejected a contract deal that its leaders have struck with the city. But as a vote looms later this month, the union president, Sandra Feldman, is taking nothing for granted, particularly since the early reactions she received yesterday was decidedly mixed.
"Of course, there is a great deal of disappointment, even anger, among some members about the level of the pay increase," Ms. Feldman's spokeswoman, Susan Amlung, said. "But the more we explain the other provisions in the contract, the more they like it. It is a question of information."
The dissemination of that information began last night, as Ms. Feldman met with the union's 80-member, elected executive board, to begin outlining the agreement's most attractive facets: a pledge that no member will be laid off before 1998; raises totaling 11 percent over the last three years; the elevation of the top salary in the system to $70,000 by 1999, and the abolition of administration periods, in which teachers in middle schools and high schools were tapped to patrol hallways and cafeterias.
"Considering these tough times for the city, the outcome of these talks is a positive one," Ms. Feldman said on Saturday. It is a message she is sure to repeat tomorrow, when the union's 3,000-member delegate assembly, with representatives from every school in the city, will meet in midtown Manhattan to vote on whether to recommend the contract to the rank and file.
Peter Hannon, a science teacher who is the union chapter chairman at Public School 199 on West 70th Street, said he intended to vote in favor of the contract at the meeting.
"It's a knowing trade-off," he said, adding that the two-year wage freeze was balanced by the three-year no-layoff pledge. He added that he viewed the contract's unusual length, 59 months, as an asset, "an insurance policy if the economy goes down the tubes."
That, however, is not what Bob Dehler heard as he walked the hallways yesterday at Seward Park High School on Grand Street in Manhattan.
"The money issue is the major issue teachers will have with the contract," said Mr. Dehler, an English teacher for nearly two decades who is the school's chapter chairman. "People are just saying overwhelmingly to me, 'I hope you vote against this.' "
Mr. Dehler said he planned to take their advice, in part because he was concerned that the Mayor might be unable to find the money to pay for the wage increases by the time they are scheduled to begin in 1997.
As she patrolled the cafeteria yesterday at Seward Park High, Daisy Besterman, a biology teacher, said she was eager to make better use of the one period she has spent roaming the lunchroom each day this term.
"I'm not in security," she said. "I'm a scientist."
Under the contract, Ms. Besterman would be relieved of cafeteria duty, making time for her to advise students preparing to enter projects in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search.
But as much as she said she relished such contact with budding scientists, she said was saddened that the new contract failed to raise her current annual salary, $39,600, to a level she considered equitable.
"I have two master's degrees," she said, "and there are people out there with just a B.A. making more than I am."
