HEADLINE: Fred Hechinger, Education Editor and Advocate, Dies at 75

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Fred M. Hechinger, the former education editor of The New York Times whose articles, columns and books reflected his abiding concern for the impact of education on shaping individuals and the nation, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 75.
The cause was cardiac arrest, said his wife, Grace, who often joined him in his writing, editing and research. 
 After retiring in 1990 from The Times, where he had been president of The New York Times Company Foundation and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since 1977, he was named a senior adviser to the Carnegie Corporation of New York. He worked at the philanthropic foundation until his death, focusing on education and youth programs.
In a career in journalism that began not long after World War II, the soft-spoken, good-humored Mr. Hechinger, who was often seen puffing on a pipe, was not only an education writer for The Times of London, The New York Herald Tribune, The Washington Post and Harper's Magazine but was also the associate publisher and executive editor of The Bridgeport (Conn.) Sunday Herald and education editor of Parents Magazine.
At The New York Times, which he joined in 1959, he originated the newspaper's special education sections, wrote on a vast spectrum of educational issues, served on the editorial board and became an assistant editor of the editorial page before heading The Times Foundation and the Neediest Cases Fund.
In one of his reports on the activities of the foundation, which supports education, journalism, the arts, community services and environmental concerns, he said the test of its success "is the impact on human lives of the dollars we are able selectively to allocate."
Summing up the foundation's mission at a time when government support was shrinking, he wrote:
"To teach children to read and the elderly to continue to learn; to provide interpreters for deaf students; to improve the condition of poor youngsters or to expand opportunities for those who have suffered discrimination; to fight against censorship; to help tiny or giant stages to let the show go on or to provide a forum for poets; to further the restoration of urban parks or the redevelopment of decaying city blocks."
Mr. Hechinger's writings covered a range of topics, from school integration and Federal school legislation to merit pay for teachers, after-school programs, teen-age delinquency, sex, free speech for students, college admissions standards, black studies programs, cram courses and overseas studies.
He was the author of "An Adventure in Education: Connecticut Points the Way" (Macmillan, 1956), "The Big Red Schoolhouse" (Doubleday, 1959) and, with his wife, "Teen-Age Tyranny" (Morrow, 1963), "The New York Times Guide to New York City Private Schools" (Simon & Schuster, 1968) and "Growing Up in America" (McGraw-Hill, 1975).
Mr. Hechinger was a founder of the Education Writers Association; twice a winner of the George Polk Memorial Award (1950 and 1951), a journalism award, and a recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal of Teachers College of Columbia University.
Fred Hechinger was born on July 7, 1920, in Nuremberg, Germany, and left the country in 1936. Arriving in the United States, he completed high school and studied nights at City College, from which he received a bachelor of arts degree. During World War II, he served in the Army in military intelligence, attached mainly to the British War Office in London.
After his discharge in 1946 as a master sergeant, he studied at the University of London before embarking on a career as a foreign correspondent, covering Europe and the Middle East for the Overseas News Agency. In 1948, he was a special consultant to the education and cultural relations division of the United States military government in Germany.
Explaining his interest in education reporting, he said, "I began to realize that a country's approach to education in general, and especially to its children, could tell more about its social, political and economic background than a whole battery of interviews with politicians."
Mr. Hechinger joined The Herald Tribune in 1950 as education editor, simultaneously serving as American correspondent for the Educational Supplement of The Times of London. In 1959, after spending three years in Bridgeport, he joined The Times.
Arthur Gelb, who worked closely with Mr. Hechinger for more than 20 years as metropolitan editor and managing editor of The Times and as Mr. Hechinger's successor as president of The Times Foundation and Neediest Cases Fund, said: "During his vigorous tenure at The Times, Fred Hechinger was the voice of wisdom, reason and conscience in the often-volatile world of education. His influence extended beyond his many articles and books, for he also served informally as a trusted adviser to public school chancellors, as well as deans and presidents of our leading universities."
In his farewell "About Education" column, written in December 1990 after three decades of assessing the good and bad in American education, Mr. Hechinger recalled his very first column in The Times, in 1959. Then he had called the nation's schoolchildren "earthbound," bemoaned the neglect of mathematics and science and called for national educational goals.
"My report of 31 years ago might suggest that little has changed," he wrote. "Americans have landed on the moon, but schools are still mired in earthbound problems, such as mastery of math and science. Junior high schools still await reform.
"Some things have grown worse, poverty, disintegrating families, drugs, violence."
He recalled, though, that he had visited many classrooms where great teachers infused their students with the joy of learning.
"But after leaving such good-news classrooms, I would think about hundreds of thousands of youngsters who are never allowed to taste such pleasures," Mr. Hechinger wrote. "Should I have ignored the bad news -- about a system that deprives the many of joy reserved for the few?
"I tried to celebrate the islands of excellence, but I could not overlook the sea of neglect and apathy that threatened to wash over them."
In addition to his wife, the former Grace Bernstein, Mr. Hechinger is survived by two sons, Paul D. Hechinger of Manhattan and John E. Hechinger of Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
With No Data to Digest, Prices of Treasuries Slip

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Without any fresh economic data to give traders direction, Treasury prices slipped in light trading yesterday.
While some market participants sold yesterday to take profits on last week's gain, others declined to buy before knowing whether the Treasury would go ahead with a series of note auctions this week. 
 Late yesterday afternoon, the Treasury announced that it had postponed the sales of new three-year notes and 10-year notes for an indefinite period or until an agreement on the national debt limit was reached. The news of the postponement had little impact on the market. Many in the market said that Congress would have little opportunity to make progress on the debt ceiling with many Congressional leaders in Israel for the funeral of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
The uncertainty surrounding the debt limit bolstered demand at the Treasury's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, traders said. The average rate at auction for a three-month bill was 5.36 percent, up from 5.29 percent last week, while a six-month bill was 5.29 percent, down from 5.31 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 8/32 , to 10726/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its prices, rose to 6.29 percent, from 6.27 percent on Friday.
The turmoil in Washington is having little impact on the bond market over all, some traders and analysts said.
"The perception in the fixed-income market," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management of Washington, "is that the fundamentals of sagging growth and waning inflation both domestically and internationally could not support for long any substantial increase in bond yields that might be linked with a budget-deficit impasse."
Mr. Carpenter also said that many in the market believed that the President and Congress were not that far apart and that there would be a budget before the end of the year.
In the futures market, trading was fairly lackluster yesterday, said Robin Mesch, a market analyst with Technical Data of Boston. "We probably will see range-trading for the early part of this week," she said.
In the municipal market, prices were slightly lower early in the session, with two of the week's largest deals priced at the outset.
Bear, Stearns & Company tentatively priced $251 million of New York State Urban Development bonds with a maximum yield of 6 percent for an issue due in 2020.
Michael S. Appelbaum, senior vice president of investment at Paine Webber, said confusion about changes in the tax laws had cheapened the municipal market to the point where tax-free bonds offered attractive yields.
"Many investors in the upper tax bracket," Mr. Appelbaum said, "may not be aware that some long-term triple-A-rated municipal issues are currently offering a 9 to 9.5 percent taxable equivalent yield."

HEADLINE: Stocks Down in Quiet Trading, With Dow Off 11.56

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market fell yesterday in quiet trading, ending a three-session advance to record highs.
Technology stocks, which had surged recently, were in the forefront of the retreat, after Goldman, Sachs & Company removed Microsoft from its list of recommended stocks. 
 "Stocks didn't get a follow-through from last week," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist of Salomon Brothers. "Stocks have been running with bonds and bonds were weak." Last week, the stock market had its biggest weekly percentage gain in about four months.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 11.56 points, to 4,814.01, after setting a high of 4,825.57 on Friday. Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.11 points, to 588.46, and the Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, dropped 3.52 points, to 1,062.14.
Declines exceeded advances on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,162 t0 1,071. Big Board trading was thin, with 309.1 million shares changing hands, compared with 345.5 million shares Friday.
Unusually heavy daily merger and acquisition activity caught the market's attention yesterday. International Paper agreed to buy Federal Paper Board. Shares of Federal Paper jumped 6 1/2, to 52. International Paper shares dropped 1, to 36 1/8.
Sherwin-Williams said that it would buy Pratt & Lambert, sending Pratt & Lambert's stock up 67 percent, or, 13 7/8. to 34 3/4. Sherwin-Williams slipped 1/8, to 37 1/2.
And First Interstate spurned a bid from Wells Fargo to announce a merger with First Bank Systems. First Interstate slipped 1, to 126 7/8, after earlier rising as much as 2, to 129 3/4.
Technology stocks followed Microsoft lower. Microsoft dropped 2 1/8, to 97 3/8; Intel fell 111/16 , to 7013/16 ; I.B.M. declined 1, to 100 1/2; Micron gave up 3 3/4, to 64 1/2, and Texas In-struments plunged 3, to 62 1/2.
With the uncertainty over the Federal budget, utility issues were soft. Con Edison closed at 29 7/8, down 1/2; Pacific Gas and Electric closed at 29 1/2, down 1/8, and Unicom closed at 32 7/8, down 5/8.
The Dow Jones transportation averge rallied 19.50 points to a new high of 2,010.45, spurred by an announcement by Roadway Services that it plans to sell its money-losing air-freight unit. Roadway increased 4, to 50 1/4, while Delta Air Lines advanced 5/8, to 70 1/8, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 1 1/4, to 72.
A number of retail stocks also gained amid reports that their shares were oversold. May Department Stores closed at 41 3/4, up 1 3/8; Toys "R" Us closed at 24 1/8, up 1 1/8, and Dillard closed at 29 1/4, up 5/8. However, Circuit City fell 2 1/4, to 30 1/2, and CompUSA dropped 2 1/4, to 36 7/8.
Two of the Big Three auto makers pushed higher on what some analysts said were expectations of stronger economic growth. General Motors advanced 1, to 44 7/8, and Ford Motor rose 1/8, to 28 3/4. But Chrysler dropped 1/2, to 50 1/4.
McAfee Associates, which introduced a virus protection program that stops users from downloading infected software from the Internet, jumped 3 3/4, to 46 3/4. And McDonnell Douglas, which received an $18 billion order for C-17 military transport planes, surged 1 3/8, to 86 1/8.

HEADLINE: Citing Debt Impasse, Treasury Drops Plan For Selling Securities

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The Government today postponed the $31.5 billion in borrowing it had planned for this week because President Clinton and Congressional Republicans failed to agree on raising the $4.9 trillion debt limit.
The Treasury Department had announced tentative plans last week to sell $18 billion in three-year notes on Tuesday and $13.5 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday to pay off maturing securities and replenish Government coffers. 
 But the deputy assistant Treasury secretary, Darcy E. Bradbury, had warned that the schedule would have to be changed if there was no assurance of final action on the debt limit by today.
The Government must pay about $25 billion in interest to holders of securities by mid-November. If the debt ceiling impasse is not settled by then, the United States could default on its obligations for the first time in history.
But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said on Sunday that he believed that Congress would increase the ceiling. And the House Republican leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, predicted action by Congress by the end of the week.
Before raising the limit, Republicans want the President to accept their blueprint for balancing the budget in seven years. The Administration wants Congress to increase the limit to $5.5 trillion while negotiations over broader tax and spending issues continue.
Republicans contend that a default would pose no serious risk to the nation's finances. They dismiss warnings that interest rates on Treasury securities would soar.

HEADLINE: ASSASINATION IN ISRAEL;
Words of Grief and Resolve From Friends and World Leaders

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by foreign leaders and friends at Yitzhak Rabin's funeral in Jerusalem yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times and the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The speeches by Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Eitan Haber were translated from the Hebrew by The Times and by official translators.
 
PRESIDENT CLINTON
To all the people of Israel, the American people mourn with you in the loss of your leader. And I mourn with you, for he was my partner and friend. 
 Every moment we shared was a joy because he was a good man, and an inspiration because he was also a great man.
Leah, I know that too many times in the life of this country, you were called upon to comfort and console the mothers and the fathers, the husbands and the wives, the sons and the daughters who lost their loved ones to violence and vengeance. You gave them strength. Now, we here and millions of people all around the world, in all humility and honor, offer you our strength. May God comfort you among all the mourners of Zion and to Israel.
Yitzhak Rabin lived the history of Israel through every trial and triumph, the struggle for independence, the wars for survival, the pursuit of peace and all he served on the front lines. This son of David and of Solomon took up arms to defend Israel's freedom and laid down his life to secure Israel's future. He was a man completely without pretense, as all of his friends knew.
I read that in 1949, after the War of Independence, David Ben-Gurion sent him to represent Israel at the armistice talks at Rhodes, and he had never before worn a necktie and did not know how to tie the knot. So, the problem was solved by a friend who tied it for him before he left and showed him how to preserve the knot simply by loosening the tie and pullin it over his head.
Well, the last time we were together, not two weeks ago, he showed up for a black tie event on time, but without the black tie.
And so, he borrowed a tie. And I was privileged to straighten it for him. It is a moment I will cherish as long as I live.
To him, ceremonies and words were less important than actions and deeds. Six weeks ago, the King and President Mubarak will remember, we were at the White House for signing the Israel-Palestinian agreement and a lot of people spoke. I spoke. The King spoke. Chairman Arafat spoke. President Mubarak spoke. Our Foreign Ministers all spoke. And finally, Prime Minister Rabin gotup to speak and he said, "First, the good news. I am the last speaker."
But he also understood the power of words and symbolism. Take a look at the stage he set in Washington -- the King of Jordan, the President of Egypt, Chairman Arafat, and us, the Prime Minister, and Foreign Minister of Israel on one platform.
"Please take a good hard look. The sight you see before you was impossible, was unthinkable just three years ago. Only poets dreamt of it and to our great pain, soldier and civilian went to their deaths to make this moment possible" -- those were his words.
Today, my fellow citizens of the world, I ask all of you to take a good hard look at this picture. Look at the leaders from all over the Middle East and around the world who have journeyed here today for Yitzhak Rabin and for peace. Though we no longer hear his deep and booming voice, it is he who has brought us together again here, in word and deed, for peace.
Now it falls to all of us who love peace and all of us who loved him to carry on the struggle to which he gave life and for which he gave his life. He cleared the path. And his spirit continues to light the way. His spirit lives on in the growing peace between Israel and her neighbors. It lives in the eyes of the children, the Jewish and the Arab children, who are leaving behind a past of fear for a future of hope. It lives on in the promise of true security.
So, let me say to the people of Israel: Even in your hour of darkness, his spirit lives on, and so you must not lose your spirit. Look at what you have accomplished making a once barren desert bloom, building a thriving democracy in a hostile terrain, winning battles and wars and now winning the peace, which is the only enduring victory.
Your Prime Minister was a martyr for peace, but he was a victim of hate. Surely, we must learn from his martyrdom that if people cannot let go of the hatred of their enemies, they risk sowing the seeds of hatred among themselves.
I ask you, the people of Israel, on behalf of my nation that knows its own long litany of loss -- from Abraham Lincoln to President Kennedy to Martin Luther King -- do not let that happen to you. In the Knesset, in your homes, in your places of worship, stay the righteous course.
As Moses said to the children of Israel when he knew he would not cross over into the Promised Land: "Be strong and of good courage. Fear not, for God will go with you. He will not fail you. He will not forsake you."
President Weizman, Acting Prime Minister Peres, to all the people of Israel, as you stay the course of peace, I make this pledge: Neither will America forsake you.
Legend has it that in every generation of Jews from time immemorial, a just leader emerged to protect his people and show them the way to safety. Prime Minister Rabin was such a leader.
He knew, as he declared to the world on the White House lawn two years ago, that the time had come, in his words, "to begin a new reckoning in the relations between people, between parents tired of war, between children who will not know war."
Here in Jerusalem, I believe with perfect faith that he was leading his people to that Promised Land.
This week, Jews all around the world are studying the Torah portion in which God tests the faith of Abraham, Patriarch of the Jews and the Arabs. He commands Abraham to sacrifice Yitzhak, "Take your son, the one you love, Yitzhak."
As we all know, as Abraham in loyalty to God was about to kill his son, God spared Yitzhak. Now, God tests our faith even more terribly, for he has taken our Yitzhak.
But Israel's covenant with God -- for freedom, for tolerance, for security, for peace -- that covenant must hold. That covenant was Prime Minister Rabin's life's work, now we must make it his lasting legacy. His spirit must live on in us.
 
SHIMON PERES OF ISRAEL
 We have not come to seal this tomb, we have come to salute you, Yitzhak, for what you were. You were a courageous fighter who brought victories for your people, a great dreamer who forged a new reality in our region. Last Saturday night, we joined hands and sang the song of peace together and I could feel your uplifted spirits.
You told me that there were warnings of a planned attempt against your life during this large rally. We did not know who would attack. We did not anticipate that the damage would be so great. But we knew that we could not fear death and that we could not hesitate in our effort to achieve peace.
One day earlier we met, as was our custom, face to face. For the first time you pointed out to me that the work was exhausting, but that the peace was overriding.
I was aware of your tremendous restraint and therefore also of your refusal to be caught up in the fanfare, even in that of peace. I was also aware of your great wisdom and from that stemmed your cautiousness about not revealing things before their time. These are characteristics of a leader, and that is what you were from the time you reached adulthood, a daring leader in the forward command posts of Israel's battlefields, and a great leader in the struggle for peace in the Middle East. Being a leader is not amusing, and you weren't necessarily a person who was easily amused. Seriousness became your second nature and responsibility was your first nature. That combination made you into a rare leader, able to move mountains and to pave roads, able to set a goal and to achieve it.
I did not know that these were the last hours of the cooperation between us -- a cooperation that knew no limits. I felt as if some distant grace fell upon you and you were suddenly able to breathe easily at the sight of the sea of friends who came to support the path you had chosen and congratulate you for it. The summit to which you led us broadened, and from it we could view the new tomorrow, the vision of the future promised to the new generation of Israeli youth.
Yitzhak, the youngest among Israel's generals, Yitzhak the greatest of Israel's peacemakers, the suddenness of your departure shed light on your many deeds. You were unlike anyone else, nor did you want to imitate anyone. You were not a jolly sort. You demanded a lot, first of all from yourself and therefore also from your fellow men.
You did not accept failure, nor were you afraid of successes. You knew every detail, and you saw the big picture. And each of the details remained beside you throughout the entire process, and that led to great decisions and intense activity.
You promised to change the orders of priority, and indeed a new order emerged. Priorities encouraging development were adopted. Junctions were opened, roads were paved. Unemployment dropped, waves of immigration were absorbed. Production grew, investments increased. The education budget doubled and science was promoted.
 Above all, perhaps as the basis for it all, strong winds of peace began to blow. Two agreements with our Palestinian neighbors were achieved. I saw how much the Palestinian people and their leaders -- who are represented here -- were moved. These two agreements will enable them to hold democratic elections and they will enable us to free ourselves from the necessity of ruling another nation, just as you promised...
Leah is at this time without you, but the entire nation is with her and the family. I see our people very distressed, a nation with tears in their eyes. The nation also knows that the bullet that murdered you cannot and will not kill the ideas you advocated.
You did not leave us a will, but you left us a path which we will follow with determination and faith. The nation is crying. I hope these will be tears for unity, tears for peace among us, and peace with our neighbors.
I see our Arab neighbors, and I would like to say to them that the peace is irreversible for both of us. None of us can stop, postpone or hesitate about peace, which must be comprehensive and inclusive of old and young.
From here, Yitzhak, in Jerusalem where you were born, where the three greatest religions in history were founded, let us quote the words of our matriarch Rachel, whose death occurred on the same date on which you fell: Keep thy voice from weeping, and thy eyes from tears, for thy work shall be rewarded and there is hope for thy future, said the Lord.
 Goodbye, my eldest brother, the bringer of peace. We will add and continue to carry this peace, for near and far, that you wanted and expected in your life and death.
 
EITAN HABER, SPEECHWRITER
 Yitzhak, this is the final speech. There will not be another one. For a whole generation, more than 35 years, you were my teacher, counselor, and leader. You were my father. You were asked to sing a song of peace just five minutes before this inhuman person shot you; and you were given a piece of paper with the words of the song written down on it.
Once again, you sang off key. Afterward, you folded the paper carefully in four, and at the end of the rally inserted it, as always, into the pocket of your jacket.
Your blood oozed onto that piece of paper and covered the words of the song of peace on that lyric sheet.
Your blood cries out to us from that sheet. I ask to read the lyrics of a song that could have been written yesterday, after you sang there and after they shot you. This is that sheet of paper:
Let the sun rise, the morning shine,
 The most righteous prayer will not bring us back.
 Who is the one whose light has been extinguished,
 And buried in the earth;
 Bitter tears will not wake him, will not bring him back.
 No song of praise or victory will avail us.
 Therefore, sing only a song of peace.
 Don't whisper a prayer --
sing aloud a song of peace.
Yitzhak we miss you.
 
KING HUSSEIN OF JORDAN
 My friends, I had never thought that the moment would come, like this, when I would grieve the loss of a brother, a colleague and a friend, a man, a soldier, whom I trust on the opposite side of a divide, whom I respected as he respected us -- a man I came to know because I realized as he did, that we have to cross over the divide, establish a dialogue, get to know each other and strive to leave for those who follow us a legacy that is worthy of them. And so we did. And so we became brethren and friends.
I've never been used to standing, except with you next to me, speaking of peace, speaking of our dreams and the hopes of generations to come that must live in peace, enjoy human dignity, come together, work together to build a better future, which is our right.
Never in all my thoughts did it occur to me that my first visit to Jerusalem in response to your invitation, and the invitation of the Speaker of the Knesset, at the invitation of the President of Israel, would be on such an occasion.
You lived as a soldier, you died as a soldier for peace.
And I believe it is time for all of us to come out openly and to speak of peace. Not here today, but for all the times to come. We belong to the camp of peace. We believe in peace. We believe that our one God wishes us to live in peace, and wishes peace upon us, for these are his teachings to all the followers of the three great monotheistic religions, the children of Abraham.
Let's not keep silent. Let our voices rise high to speak of our commitment to peace for all times to come. And let us tell those who live in darkness, who are the enemies of life, and through faith and religion and the teachings of our one God, this is where we stand. This is our camp. Maybe God will bless you with the realization that you must join it, and we'll pray that He will. But otherwise, we are not ashamed, nor are we afraid, nor are we anything but determined to continue the legacy for which my friend fell, as did my grandfather in this very city when I was with him and but a boy.
He was man of courage ... and he was endowed with one of the greatest virtues that any man can have. He was endowed with humility. He felt, with those around him, an evolution of responsibility. He placed himself, as I do, and have done often, in the place of the other partner to achieve a worthy goal. And we achieved peace, an honorable peace and a lasting peace.
He had courage, he had vision and he had a commitment to peace. And standing here, I commit before you, before my people in Jordan, before the world, myself to continue to do my utmost to insure that we leave a similar legacy. And when my time comes, I hope it will be like my grandfather's and like Yitzhak Rabin's.
For his spirit -- and I try and make sense for the people of Jordan, my family, the people of Israel -- decent people throughout the world feel today. So many live and so many inevitably die. This is the will of God, this is the way of all, but those are fortunate and lucky in life, those who are great are those who leave something behind and you are such a man, my friend.
The places in my country, among the majority of our people, and our armed forces and people who once were your enemies are somber today and their hearts are heavy. Let's hope and pray that God will give us all guidance, each in his respective position, to do what he can for the better future that Yitzhak Rabin sought with determination and courage.
 
PRESIDENT MUBARAK OF EGYPT
 It is with deep regret that we assemble here today to pay our last respects to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, a courageous leader and a recognized statesman. His earnest efforts to achieve peace in the Middle East are a testament to his vision -- which we share -- to end the suffering of all the peoples of our region.
He defied the prejudices of the past to tackle the most complicated of problems, namely, the Palestinian problem, in a forthright manner. The success he achieved in this regard has firmly laid the foundations of peaceful coexistence between Palestinians and the Israelis in a climate of trust and mutual respect. These achievements have undoubtedly established him as a true hero of peace.
The untimely loss of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin at this important juncture in the history of the Middle East has dealt a severe blow to our noble cause. We must, therefore, redouble our efforts and reaffirm our obligation to continue the sacred mission to achieve a just and lasting peace.
We must deprive those treacherous hands, hostile toward our goal, from reaping the rewards of their vile actions. Only through our unwavering commitment to this objective can we truly honor the memory of this fallen hero of peace.
And I could say that the best memorial for Yitzhak Rabin is to continue what he started, which is the peace process. For as we mentioned several times, peace is so precious for the whole people all over the world.
On this sad occasion, ladies and gentlemen, I extend the condolences of the people and the Government of Egypt and my personal condolences to the Government and the people of Israel and the family of Mr. Yitzhak Rabin.

HEADLINE: A U.S. Role In Bosnia May Hinder Recruiters

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: OTTUMWA, Iowa

 BODY:
Sgt. Charlie Pomykaj, burly in his khaki shirt and blue trousers with a red stripe down the legs, looks every ounce the Marine Corps recruiter as he works a crowd of high school students on lunch break outside class here, offering college tuition, technical skills and exotic foreign adventures to anyone who enlists.
But one adventure Sergeant Pomykaj is not mentioning is Bosnia. 
 Most people here are opposed to President Clinton's proposal to send 20,000 American troops to help keep peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and recruiters say they fear that their sales pitches may fall on deaf ears if teen-agers or their parents think a recruit will end up in the middle of ethnic bloodshed that seems to go on forever.
"If it's seen as senseless, like Somalia, and if it's not supported in the community, then, of course, it'll trickle down to the kids," said Sergeant Pomykaj, 28, who was a weather technician in the Persian Gulf war.
The prospect of American troops in Bosnia has not hurt recruiting so far, military officials say. But recruiting is a volatile business in the best of times. Success depends on elusive perceptions about the vitality of the armed forces as well as their missions.
In the gulf war, young men and women flocked to recruiting centers. But the debacle in Somalia, where 18 American soldiers were killed while fighting in Mogadishu, the Somali capital, on Oct. 3, 1993, had the opposite effect. And of late, recruiters have had a hard enough time persuading the public that the shrinking Pentagon budget does not translate into fewer new openings or opportunities for advancement in the armed forces.
It is not just Marine Corps recruiters who express concern over a potential mission in Bosnia.
"If we go over there and there are casualties, we'll be hurting in recruiting," said Capt. Harry Meyer, who heads the Army's recruiting efforts in south-central Iowa. "We'll have to overcome objections from parents who will ask, 'Will my son or daughter have to go to Bosnia?' "
Residents of this city of 25,000 people 75 miles southeast of Des Moines, once one of the biggest meat-packing centers in Iowa, say they favor the military and are very patriotic.
The military has not had a visible presence here since 1947, when the Navy closed an air station on the edge of town where a young lieutenant named Richard M. Nixon served briefly in World War II. But memories of yellow ribbons and prayers for sons and daughters in the gulf war remain vivid.
Bosnia, though, is different.
"The calls are 95 percent against our going into Bosnia," said Dave Michaels, the program director of radio station KLEE-AM. "Lots of people are comparing it to Vietnam."
To be sure, many people here have not focused on Bosnia. In the malls, high schools and community colleges where Sergeant Pomykaj scours every day for potential marines, other matters are more important.
"Right now, the fact that the girls' volleyball team is in the state tournament is a greater news item than Bosnia," said Cliff Vande Wall, a guidance counselor at Oskaloosa High School, just up the road from Ottumwa.
But recruiters fear that Bosnia lies just beneath the surface.
The last few years have been hard for military recruiters. Military surveys show that the percentage of 16- to 21-year-old men who are inclined to enlist is steadily dropping. The Air Force barely made its recruiting requirement this year, reaching the mark only on Sept. 30, the last day of the 1995 fiscal year. About 96 percent of the new recruits are high school graduates, but that is down from 99 percent in 1992.
And the armed forces are still fighting the perception that they are no longer hiring. While the Defense Department thins its middle and higher ranks, it still needs to sign up tens of thousands of new troops each year to maintain the proper proportion. This is even more important as the military's drawdown nears an end. The Army alone has to recruit 68,000 people for its enlisted ranks this year.
To help remedy these problems, the Pentagon has increased its advertising budget for recruiting this year to $207 million from $112.5 million in 1993, and is assigning more people to recruiting duty.
"A lot of people don't know that the drawdown is over," said Staff Sgt. Jim Bonynge, Sergeant Pomykaj's supervisor who oversees Marine recruiting in 20 counties in south-central Iowa from his office in Des Moines.
Even without Bosnia, the Midwest is a tough sell for the Marines. The 11-state Marine Corps district, based in Kansas City, ranked last out of six Marine recruiting districts nationwide, signing up only 74 percent of its goal in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.
Marine officials say the district's location, landlocked and 850 miles from the nearest Marine base, at Quantico, Va., does not help. Low unemployment and the tendency for many high school graduates to sign up for college instead of the military also pose challenges.
Another hurdle lies in the rolling fields of corn and soybeans. Most farms have been in families for generations, and many fathers are not about to let their strapping young sons join what the Marines call "America's 911 force" when the annual harvest is at stake.
New American military missions in places like Haiti, Somalia and Rwanda also give pause to parents whose consent is required for recruits under 18 years of age.
"Parents ask, 'Will Johnny or Suzy go to war?' " said Sergeant Bonynge, who served in Beirut and was a helicopter mechanic in the gulf war. "They think the Marine Corps and the first to fight, but we have jobs in administration and accounting, too."
One angry parent or a hostile high school guidance counselor can ruin Sergeant Pomykaj's yearly goal to sign up at least 24 new marines.
At Indian Hills Community College, Sergeant Pomykaj strikes up a conversation with anyone who meets his recruiting standard: physically fit, decent grades and no problems with drugs or the law. And at Ottumwa High School, he sets his sights on the school's 180 male seniors. But he will talk to any of the school's 1,410 students -- by phone, at home or in his office at a nearby shopping mall.
Potential recruits have mixed feelings about Bosnia. "A lot of us think we should go in and help stop the killing," said David Gordy, 16, a member of Ottumwa High's Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps, "but others are opposed to it altogether because Americans will die."
Older recruiters remember other unpopular missions -- like Beirut, where 241 marines, members of a multinational peacekeeping force in Lebanon, were killed when their barracks were destroyed by a terrorist's bomb on Oct. 23, 1983.
"As Beirut dragged on, the parents just said, 'No,' " said Col. Pat Donahue, executive officer of the Midwest recruiting district that includes Iowa. "Those kind of political things started showing up on the evening news and pulled the parents away. That's what Bosnia would do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Looking for a few good men, Sgt. Charlie Pomykaj, a Marine Corps recruiter, strolled outside Ottumwa High School in Iowa last month as he tried to fill his annual goal of signing up at least 24 new marines. But the prospect of the recruits' serving as peacekeepers in Bosnia may make his job more difficult. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Move to Improve Relations With Exiles in U.S., Cuba Eases the Way for Investment

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Seeking to improve relations with Cuban exiles it once derided as "worms" and "counterrevolutionaries," the Cuban Government announced measures today that could make it easier for them to invest on the island.
Under the new regulations, announced by Roberto Robaina, Cuba's Foreign Minister, the 1.2 million Cubans living abroad will be able to apply for travel documents, renewable every two years, that will allow them to enter and leave the country as many times as they like. 
 While details remain to be worked out, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said that all persons of Cuban descent would presumably be eligible for the new system, including those traveling on foreign passports and those who left the country "illegally."
The measures were announced at the end of a Government-sponsored conference, "The Nation and Migration," with 357 invited members of the emigre community, increasingly being courted as a source of capital and investment.
Cuban-Americans returning to visit relatives have long criticized cumbersome and costly bureaucratic procedures that ignore their American citizenship and treat them as Cuban nationals. The issue had been raised repeatedly at an earlier meeting last year, and Cuban officials describe the changes as an effort to advance the "normalization" of their relationship with the emigre community.
Many participants also complained of efforts by the Clinton Administration to prevent them from attending the conference, scheduled to end tonight with a reception at the Palace of the Revolution. Washington, they said, has refused to authorize the special license that would have exempted them from the longstanding American embargo on trade and travel to Cuba.
The Clinton Administration in recent months has endorsed "people-to-people" contact between Americans and Cubans as a way of fomenting political changes here, and many of those attending the conference said they were here with just that intention. Though denied the license, they were still able to take advantage of new regulations that allow Cuban-Americans to visit the island once a year for emergency humanitarian reasons, such as a family illness.
No conferee has drawn more attention than Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, founder of the Miami-based exile group Cambio Cubano, or Cuban Change. A former guerrilla leader who helped overthrow the Batista dictatorship in 1959, Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo later broke with Mr. Castro, spent 22 years in prison here, and now argues that dialogue between exiles and the Cuban Government offers the only peaceful solution to the country's crisis.
Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo visited here in June and met with Mr. Castro, the two men talked again in New York last month. Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo identified himself openly here as an opponent of Mr. Castro, and has used the conference as a platform to press for political reforms and to criticize official Cuban Government positions on human rights.
Reacting, for example, to the emphasis that Mr. Robaina, the Foreign Minister, placed on the United States' economic embargo of Cuba in the opening speech of the conference, Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo told reporters that actually "there are two embargoes, one American and one Cuban." An important factor that "contributes to the distance" between Cubans in the United States and those on the island, he said, is "the lack of information and freedom of expression" here.
In a speech delivered in the presence of Cuban officials, but which has not yet been reported by the Government-run television or in the newspapers, Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo urged the Cuban Government not to fear "the possibility of a multiparty scenario." He also called for a national assembly to write a new constitution, noting that "under the pretext of defending the nation from external aggression, a citizen today can turn to no organism to denounce an abuse of which he has been the victim."

HEADLINE: Election Day Choices

 BODY:
Here is a summary of our recommendations for noteworthy local races and ballot proposals in today's elections. Poll hours in New York State are from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. and in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.
Staten Island
DISTRICT ATTORNEY
William Murphy
 
Suffolk County
COUNTY EXECUTIVE
Robert Gaffney
 
New York State
PROPOSALS
1. Vote Yes. To adjust for the impact of inflation on lawsuits by increasing to $50,000 the maximum amount of damages that can be sought in cases before the Civil Court of New York City and the District Court of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. 
 2. Vote Yes. To conform state law to new Federal rules for voter registration, and to make it clear that a voter who moves within the same county, or within New York City, need not re-register.
3. Vote Yes. To reform the state's borrowing practices by permitting it to issue bonds without voter approval but placing a cap on the amount, while sharply curbing the ability of state agencies to incur their own debt. The amendment would also prohibit borrowing for day-to-day expenses and require the state to produce a long-range capital investment plan for public review.
4. Vote Yes. To authorize a worthwhile swap supported by environmentalists in which the state would convey to the upstate town of Keene 12 acres from Adirondack State Park for public use as a cemetery in return for 144 acres surrounding a nearby trout stream.
 
New Jersey
PROPOSALS
1. Vote Yes. To provide for the appointment at the beginning of each decade of a bipartisan New Jersey Redistricting Commission to redraw Congressional districts for that decade.
2. Vote No. To dedicate an additional portion of the existing state gasoline tax for the funding of the state transportation system exclusively, as opposed to using it for education or any other purpose.
3. Vote No. To amend the State Constitution to prohibit the Legislature and executive branch from imposing requirements on local governments without providing the money to pay for them, and to establish a bipartisan Council on Local Mandates with the power to nullify any such mandates determined to be unfunded, with limited exceptions.
4. Vote Yes. To authorize the sale of $340 million in state general obligation bonds to acquire and develop lands for recreation and conservation.

HEADLINE: SNAPSHOT;
On the Ballot Today

 BODY:
A roundup of the most important elections taking place today.
 
GOVERNOR
 
KENTUCKY: The Republican candidate for governor, Larry Forgy, is a conservative, wealthy lawyer. He has campaigned against abortion, for lower taxes and for a revision of the Kentucky Education Reform Law of 1990, which changed schools to put greater emphasis on writing and group work.
The Democrat, Lieut. Gov. Paul Patton, is a former operator of a coal mine. The issues on which he has based his campaign include a policy of fostering economic development and modest changes in taxes and education.
 
MISSISSIPPI: Gov. Kirk Fordice, a Republican, is seeking reelection, campaigning on the addition of 115,000 jobs in the state during his administration. He is also seeking a 10 percent cut in the state income tax over three years.
The Democrat, Dick Molpus, has been Secretary of State for 12 years. He has also raised tax cuts as an issue, pusch for a 50 percent cut in taxes on groceries. The other major campaign issue has a dispute with Mr. Fordice over his mockery of Mr. Molpus's wife.
 
STATE LEGISLATURES
 
MAINE: Two special elections to fill vacancies in the state House will determine whether Republicans gain control in the lower chamber for the first time in two decades. Because of the two House vacancies, they have a temporary majority. In the Senate, Republicans hold a slight majority, which they are expected to keep.
 
MISSISSIPPIANS: Mississippians, who have increasingly voted Republican in national and Congressional elections, continue to favor the Democratic Party for the state legislature. Republicans are hoping to narrow the 34-to-18 Democratic edge in the state Senate by winning four open seats and upsetting several longtime incumbents. But they are not expected to win control of the Senate and face even larger odds in the House, which is overwhelmingly Democratic.
 
NEW JERSEY: Residents will vote on candidates for all 80 seats in the General Assembly, and Republicans are hoping to expand on their current 53-to-27 majority. The race has attracted much interest in Washington, since national Republicans regard the state Republicans' sweep of the Assembly and Senate in 1991 - followed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's victory in 1993 - as forerunners of the Gingrich revolution of 1994.
 
VIRIGINA: After electing a Republican governor in 1993, Virginia could be the first state in the old South to elect a Republican Legislature since Reconstruction. While the Democrats still hold majorities in both the 40-seat Senate and the 100-member House of Delegates, Republicans need to gain only three seats in each house to have a majority.
 
STATE PROPOSALS
 
MAINE: An anti-gay-rights measure and a requirementing that adults wear seat belts.
 
MINNESOTA: A St. Paul requirement that companies getting government aid to favor city residents in hiring and pay them hourly "living wage" of $7.21.
 
MISSISSIPPI: A limit of two consecutive terms for most elected and appointed state and local offices.
 
OHIO: A requirement that the governor consult the parole board before cutting prison sentences.
 
PENNSYLVANIA: Whether children can testify by videotape or television at trials.
 
TEXAS: Abolition of the state treasurer's office and give duties to comptroller.
 
WASHINGTON: Allowing slot machines and video poker at American Indian-run casinos and share profits annually with registered voters.

HEADLINE: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE POLITICS;
Israel's Leader Declines to Call Early Elections

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Israel's Acting Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, said today that he would not call national elections quickly, a step that would have taken advantage of the wave of sympathy aroused by the assassination of his predecessor Yitzhak Rabin.
In so doing he insured that the furious maneuvering and mutual recriminations that began as soon as Mr. Rabin's body was laid to rest would continue until the elections scheduled for next November. 
 Some Labor Party politicians had urged Mr. Peres to hold elections as early as possible -- while the conservative Likud bloc was under fire from a public repelled by the killing of Mr. Rabin by a right-wing militant and while the Government's policies benefited from the aura of Mr. Rabin's martyrdom.
Israeli law requires 100 days notice, so an election could be held in late February. But Mr. Peres said he would wait until the current term runs out next November, as Mr. Rabin had intended to do.
Although Mr. Peres gave no immediate explanation for his decision, members of his party said he wanted to use the next year to guide the already planned Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, to establish his own credentials as a worthy successor to Mr. Rabin and to broaden the Labor coalition's political base.
Colleagues also said that Mr. Peres did not want to win an election under the mantle of his old rival, Mr. Rabin.
For now, his main opponent, Binyamin Netanyahu, leader of the rightist Likud bloc, is on the defensive. In the immediate aftermath of the shooting, the sharpest accusations against the right, and especially against Mr. Netanyahu, came from no less than Mr. Rabin's widow, Leah. She demonstratively snubbed Mr. Netanyahu at the funeral and, in interview after interview, blamed the right for creating the climate of division and hate that inspired Mr. Rabin's killer.
"Yes, surely I blame, surely I blame them," she said on the ABC News program "Good Morning America." "If you ever heard their speeches at the Knesset, you would understand what I mean. They were very, very violent in their expressions -- 'We are selling the country down the drain, there will be no Israel after this peace agreement.' I mean this was wild."
Mrs. Rabin's charges, during the traditional weeklong period of mourning, were striking proof that the bitterness over the fundamental issue of Mr. Rabin's peace with the Palestinians had not been soothed by his death.
On the left, even those who did not go as far as Mrs. Rabin in accusing the right still said that the huge turnout of mourners was proof of wide national support for his policy of making peace with the Palestinians. "This was the real referendum," declared Shevach Weiss, the Speaker of Parliament, countering Likud demands for a national referendum on the agreements.
For the time being, Mr. Netanyahu could do little but issue statements rejecting what he called "cynical incitement," while his lieutenants countered that the left was no less responsible for the bitterness of the division than the right. Putting the blame on the Likud for the murder, Mr. Netanyahu said, "was like asking whether Lee Harvey Oswald was a Republican or a Democrat and then blaming that party."
There was no doubt that the accusations would pursue him throughout the campaign, and that Likud's main political weapon, its opposition to Mr. Rabin's policies, was badly blunted.
Still, politicians on both sides agreed that Mr. Netanyahu was down, but far from out. For one thing, the passions aroused by the assassination would fade over a year's time, or could be supplanted by others.
"How long can this defensiveness last?" asked a Western diplomat. "It sounds cynical, but it could be to the next suicide bombing."
Such terrorist attacks in the past have all been followed by calls for tough measures against the Palestinians and a suspension of peace talks.
There was also Mr. Netanyahu himself, a tough and savvy politician who gained global exposure as Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations during the Persian Gulf war and is regarded as a master of the television sound bite.
"A year is a very long time," said Zalman Shoval, former Ambassador to Washington and head of foreign relations in the Likud. "People will not go back to normal, but hopefully Israelis will get back to what decisions should be based on."
In Israel, that means the disposition of the West Bank and the Golan Heights, areas that Israel occupied in 1967 and that Mr. Rabin was prepared to cede, at least in part, in exchange for peace.
The dispute is at the heart of the rift in Israeli society, pitting those who believe that the West Bank is an inherent and indivisible part of the Land of Israel, the biblical provinces of Judea and Samaria, against those who believe that Israel can only become secure and whole when it ends the occupation.
It is this issue, above all others, that determines the political spectrum in Israel: to be against ceding the lands is to be on the right, to seek a rapid withdrawal from all the lands is to be on the left.
The 1993 agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization turned the national debate into a national conflict. Jewish settlers in the West Bank turned to increasingly violent protests, and their supporters in Israel intensified their invective.
Mr. Rabin was the military commander in the 1967 war when the West Bank was seized, and Prime Minister in 1993 when he shook hands with the P.L.O. leader, Yasir Arafat, and agreed to a phased lifting of Israeli control over the Palestinians.
His 1967 exploits gave him the credibility to launch a process that many Israelis opposed, and many more feared. That was what turned the extreme right against him so bitterly and, many now say, led to his death. And that was what brought so many world leaders to his funeral, and prompted so many, from President Clinton to King Hussein of Jordan, to urge the Israelis not to abandon the course that Mr. Rabin set.
There was no chance that the course would change quickly. The primary architect of the peace agreements on the Israeli side had been Mr. Peres, who immediately made clear he would keep the course.
The immediate political challenge was to Mr. Netanyahu and his Likud, damaged by the accusations of having incited the assassination. But the battle in the next election, as always here, would be for the wavering center and there Mr. Peres had his own problems. Many commentators say it would be Mr. Peres's success in reaching into that center that would determine the outcome.
The perceived martyrdom of Mr. Rabin in the cause of peace seemed certain to sway many undecided Israelis toward Labor.
"In his death, Rabin's purpose and vision have taken on a much greater meaning and significance for Israeli people than in his life," the diplomat said. "What he was doing was controversial in life, but in his death the response is that this was a peace worth pursuing."
The smoothness of the transition and the general acceptance that Mr. Peres, who shared much of Mr. Rabin's liberal ideology, was the undisputed successor to Mr. Rabin, gave the new Prime Minister a clear legitimacy to lead the left wing in the next election. The challenge for Mr. Peres was to harness those feelings while avoiding the perception that he was trying to cash in on tragedy.
Mr. Peres's greatest handicap was that although he was respected for his intellect and his achievements, he never enjoyed Mr. Rabin's popularity as a war hero and plainspoken politician, and he was generally seen to be far more conciliatory to the Arabs than the Prime Minister. So one challenge facing him over the next 12 months will be to solidify his standing with the center.
The first sign of Mr. Peres's intentions will be revealed when he chooses a new Cabinet. Under Israeli law, the current Government automatically resigned with Mr. Rabin's death, but all factions in the Parliament have agreed not to oppose Mr. Peres as successor.
The wild cards in the Labor lineup are three younger politicians widely regarded as the next generation. First among them is Ehud Barak, 53, the Interior Minister, who until 10 months ago was the Army Chief of Staff. Mr. Barak combines charisma and a military background, which is highly esteemed in Israel, and he is considered tougher on defense issues than Mr. Peres.
Mr. Peres is expected to appoint him Defense Minister, a post Mr. Rabin held. Such a choice would make the Government more acceptable to the center, but the disadvantage is that it would effectively proclaim Mr. Barak as the heir apparent to the Labor party leadership, a move that would antagonize many members of the generation between Mr. Peres and Mr. Barak, men in their late 50's and early 60's who believe their turn is next.
Also in the wings is Haim Ramon, 45, the leader of the Histadrut labor movement. Attractive and popular, Mr. Ramon broke with Labor last year, but he is widely thought to be awaiting an opening to return, albeit with his own conditions. One of them would be a visible post, which could be the Interior Ministry if Mr. Barak is moved to Defense.
Finally there is Yossi Beilin, the Economics Minister, a protege of Mr. Peres who is close to him in outlook. Mr. Peres may put Mr. Beilin in the Foreign Ministry, where he was once Mr. Peres's deputy. But Mr. Beilin is regarded as one of the most liberal of Cabinet members, and his promotion would not serve to broaden the Government's appeal.
Mr. Peres is also expected to try to broaden his government by bringing in two small religious parties that Mr. Rabin had kept out, Shas and Agudat Yisrael. Unlike Mr. Rabin, who had few contacts with religious politicians, Mr. Peres has maintained good ties with them. That would help free him from the handicap Mr. Rabin had in the Parliament, where his peace deal with the P.L.O. was approved by a single vote.

ELECTING PARLIAMENT, PROPORTIONALLY
People vote for a party not a candidate. Each party fields a list of candidates and and receives the number of seats in proportion to the number of votes it receives above the required threshold of 20,000 votes.
 
". . . And the Road Ahead for the Government"
 
1 -- Mandatory Cabinet resignations
Under Israeli law, immediately on Prime Minister Yizhak Rabin's death, his Cabinet was automatically deemed to have resigned, and stayed on as interim Government. As the senior Cabinet member, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres assumed the duties of Prime Minster until the Cabinet met to confirm him as Acting Prime Minster.
 
2 -- President asks a member to form a new government
To form the next government, President Ezer Weizman, after consulting with Parliament representatives, is to ask a member of Parliament to form a new government Labor Party and the opposition Likud in agreement, Mr. Weizman is expected to approach Mr. Peres soon after the seven-day period of official mourning.
 
3 -- Choosing the new government
Mr. Peres will then have 21 days to form a new Cabinet. If he needs it, he can ask for another 21 days. He then presents his slate of ministers to parliament, which is likely to approve them. If it does not, the process starts fro the beginning, with Mr. Weizman asking another member to try to form a government.
 
4 -- The option: a new election
Parliament also has the option of passing a law allowing for early elections, in which case the transitional government would continue in office until a new Prime Minster and a new Parliament were elected. Under new election procedures, in the next national elections Israeli's will elect the Prime Minister and Parliament separately, and it will be the elected Prime Minster's task to forge a majority in Parliament. The next scheduled election is in November 1996.

HEADLINE: One Pleads Guilty to Okinawa Rape; 2 Others Admit Role

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Three American servicemen pleaded guilty today to conspiring to abduct and rape a 12-year-old Okinawa schoolgirl in a case that has caused an uproar throughout Japan. One admitted beating and raping the girl, but the others insisted that they did not actually go through with the rape.
The pleas came in a hushed Japanese courtroom on the opening day of the trial for the men accused of a crime that has galvanized opposition to the presence of American military bases in Okinawa and the rest of Japan and has threatened the security alliance between the Washington and Tokyo. 
 In a two-hour hearing today, prosecutors gave a detailed account of the crime. They said the suspects had planned the attack, going to a store to buy condoms and adhesive tape, which they used to cover the victim's eyes and mouth and bind her hands and feet.
In a show of contrition, the lawyers for the three defendants said their clients planned to compensate the victim monetarily. The lawyers said the amount has not yet been decided, but one of them estimated in an interview that the combined total from the three servicemen would be between $10,000 and $20,000.
The three men, who are being tried under Japanese law, are accused of snatching the sixth grader off the street on the evening of Sept. 4 and of raping her in the back seat of their rented car. They are also accused of beating her in the face and stomach to subdue her, causing injuries that required two weeks of medical treatment. If convicted, they face from three years to life in a Japanese prison.
Today, each defendant, in turn, stood before the three judges in a military-looking posture, feet spread apart and hands behind his back, to enter his plea.
Seaman Marcus D. Gill, 22, of Woodville, Texas, who has been portrayed by both the prosecutors and the other defendants as the ringleader, quickly admitted guilt on all counts.
But Pfc. Kendrick M. Ledet, 20, of Waycross, Ga., denied raping and beating the victim. "All three of us did not beat her," he said. "I did not rape her and beat her."
Pfc. Rodrico Harp, 21, from Griffin, Ga., said he did not rape the girl either and said he hit her only once in the process of abducting her off the street. "I did hit her, but I didn't hit her in the back seat of the car," he said.
The servicemen did not say anything beyond entering their pleas. But lawyers for Private Ledet and Private Harp said after today's hearing that after entering the back seat of the car for their turns with the girl, Private Ledet and Private Harp did not go through with sexual intercourse when they saw how young she was, something they had not realized when they abducted her.
Prosecutors seemed to agree that Private Ledet did not actually achieve penetration. But they said they had a statement from Private Harp admitting that he did. But Private Harp's lawyer, Mitsunobu Matsunaga, said the statement was made to United States military authorities under great pressure and he would challenge it.
Even if the two men did not rape the girl, they can still be convicted of rape if they are judged to have been part of a conspiracy, just as the driver of a getaway car can be convicted of robbery even if he does not physically take the money. And evidence presented today, including statements by the two marines, showed they played big roles in the abduction and preparation for rape.
In one of the most dramatic moments today, prosecutors read excerpts from the victim's statement in which she described how, while walking home, she was hit in the face and grabbed around the neck from behind. She said she is now scared whenever she sees a foreigner. "I hope that they will be kept in jail as long as they live," she was quoted as saying.
Her father, in his statement, went even further saying, "If the existing laws permit, I would like to kill those three American soldiers."
Regardless of its outcome, the trial has already had a major effect on relations between the United States and Japan. The focus of attention has moved beyond this incident to the issue of whether the United States military bases and 47,000 American troops should be in Japan at all, now that the cold war has ended.
President Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan are scheduled to reaffirm the alliance when they meet in Japan later this month, and United States officials are scrambling to put the genie unleashed by the rape case back in the bottle.
For Okinawans, the rape aroused pent-up anger over the crime, noise and economic dislocation they are exposed to because their small island is home to three-fifths of the American troops in Japan.
The United States military, which is paying for the defense of the servicemen, sent an observer, Capt. William Ferrell, a marine whose job is to monitor trials.
The indictment was read and the defendants entered their pleas. Then the prosecutor outlined the case and announced a list of 79 separate documents that would be offered as evidence, including numerous statements by the defendants.
Today's description of the crime lacked any discussion of what led the men, who had no criminal records in Japan and apparently good military records, to commit the crime.
Mr. Matsunaga, Private Harp's lawyer, said in an interview that the three men had discussed hiring prostitutes but that Seaman Gill had said he had no money and proposed the rape instead. At first, the others thought he was joking, but then the discussion grew more serious. He said Private Harp "didn't do anything to stop it. He just let things go."
According to the case outlined by prosecutors, four servicemen rented a car. At some point, Seaman Gill, who was driving, began proposing a rape. The men went to a grocery store and Privates Harp and Ledet went in to buy tape and condoms. At that point, the fourth serviceman realized that his colleagues were serious about the rape and left. According to military officials, this fourth person later helped identify the three defendants.
The men then drove around looking for a victim, according to a statement by Seaman Gill that was read by the prosecutor. At about 8 P.M., they found the girl, stopped the car, and Private Ledet and Private Harp got out.
Private Harp acted as if he was going to ask directions. Private Ledet put his arm around the girl's neck from behind and Private Harp hit her in the face. Private Ledet shoved her into the car, the two marines taped her eyes and mouth and tied her hands and feet. Seaman Gill drove to a remote farm road surrounded by sugar cane fields.
Seaman Gill went into the back seat and hit the girl and raped her. Then Private Ledet went into the back seat to rape her but "was not able" to penetrate, according to part of his statement read by prosecutors. Then Private Harp went into the back seat and raped her, prosecutors said. The rape was over at about 8:20. The men drove away and left the girl, who went to a nearby home to call for help.
The next hearing is scheduled for Dec. 4. Trials in Japan generally take place a day here and day there rather than running continuously.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Tax Cuts Would Evade Majority of Americans
The Republican tax cuts now making their way through Congress would not affect what most Americans owe, a computer analysis shows. Under the big budget bill passed by the Senate last month, 68 million taxpayers, or 55 percent of all households, would see no change.
But middle-class families with several children and wealthy investors can expect a windfall. And about 13 million people would face tax increases or would get a smaller payment from the Government under the earned-income tax credit than they would otherwise receive. [Page A1.]
 
First Interstate Holders Restive
First Interstate Bancorp's agreement to be bought by First Bank System of Minneapolis could run into trouble. Several large shareholders said they would vote down the First Bank deal if Wells Fargo proceeded with its hostile bid. [D2.]
 
Funds Considered To Stabilize Peso
Mexican business leaders are negotiating with the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo on a proposal by export-oriented companies to create funds of perhaps $5 billion to shield the battered peso from abrupt drops on the currency markets. Even so, the peso fell to 7.475 to the dollar, a low for the year. [D4.]
 
New Anti-AIDS Drug Backed
An F.D.A. advisory panel recommended swift approval of the first of a new, potent class of drugs to fight the virus that causes AIDS. The drug, saquinavir, produced by Hoffmann-La Roche, is known as a protease inhibitor and apparently greatly reduces the virus levels in a patient's body. [A20.]
 
Opposition Seen to Daiwa Merger
Daiwa Bank's largest shareholder, Nomura Securities, is reported to oppose the idea of merging the troubled bank into Sumitomo Bank. Nomura's stake is 3.3 percent. [D4.]
 
Michelin in Pension Settlement
Michelin North America agreed to pay $380 million into the eight underfinanced pension plans of its Uniroyal Goodrich Tire unit, in the largest cash settlement ever with the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. [D3.]
 
MCI to Offer Dial-a-Record
MCI Communications plans to open a "record store" using toll-free "800" phone lines. Customers will be able to hear snippets of any of 20,000 different songs and order albums, by pressing telephone buttons. MCI has arranged promotional alliances with radio stations in more than 100 cities. [D10.]
 
Turner Shows a Profit
Turner Broadcasting reported a profit of $39.8 million, or 14 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $4.6 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. It cited the strength of its cable networks and syndication of "Seinfeld." [D10.]
 
A Welcome Mat At U.S. Gateways
Foreign business and leisure travelers would find it easier to enter the United States under a policy favored by business executives at last week's White House Conference on Travel and Tourism. They also called for developing a reliable economic analysis of the travel and tourism industry, now valued at $417 billion. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D8.]
 
N.A.S.D. Fines Arkansas Brokerage
The N.A.S.D. fined Worthen Investments, a Little Rock, Ark., brokerage, its former president and other employees $258,400 after they agreed to settle charges of misleading customers on the risks of mutual funds. [D5.]
 
Technology Companies Oppose U.S.
A group of 37 technology companies rejected a Clinton Administration plan to set new standards on data encryption. The group plans to write its own proposal. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Group Strikes Deal for Rockefeller Center

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
An investor group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and including David Rockefeller struck a deal yesterday to buy Rockefeller Center from Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is preparing to take ownership of the trophy property.
The deal appears to have ended the pitched months-long battle for Rockefeller Center. Moreover, it means that Mr. Rockefeller has apparently succeeded in his fight to restore his family's interest in the Manhattan landmark that his father, John D. Rockefeller Jr., built in the middle of the Great Depression. 
The Goldman group will pay $8 a share, or $306.1 million, to buy out the shareholders of the real estate investment trust, or REIT. The group will also assume roughly $845 million in debt and other liabilities.
By raising its original offer of $7.75 a share, the Goldman group beat a proposal by Gotham Partners L.P., a large Rockefeller Center Properties shareholder, that would have kept the property in the hands of the REIT's shareholders.
And it scotched a previous deal the REIT had reached with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, which would have allowed shareholders to retain an interest in Rockefeller Center.
Both Gotham and the Zell group declined to comment, saying they had not had time to evaluate the Goldman deal.
Mr. Rockefeller vowed that the Goldman investors would "assure that the center remains a treasured asset of our city and our nation."
That view was echoed by Jerry I. Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer Properties Inc., the large New York real estate company that is part of the Goldman group and will operate the property when the group takes control. "The property has been standing almost 65 years, and for almost that entire time, it has been a leader worldwide in terms of location and position in the office market," Mr. Speyer said. "When you say Rockefeller Center, it means something, whether you say it in the Ginza in Tokyo or in the Place Vendome."
The Goldman investors, Gotham and Mr. Zell's group have been competing for control of the property since its owners, two partnerships owned by Rockefeller Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May.
In September, the Mitsubishi Estate Company, which owned an 80 percent stake in the Rockefeller Group, stunned the real estate world when it decided to walk away from its almost $2 billion investment in the center and transfer ownership to the REIT, which held the $1.3 billion mortgage on the original 12-acre piece of midtown Manhattan known as Rockefeller Center. The Rockefeller family trusts own the other 20 percent of Rockefeller Group.
The REIT was then forced to recapitalize so that it would have the financing to operate the property.
Yesterday, the two bankrupt partnerships filed a reorganization plan for turning the property over to the REIT. The terms of that plan -- including who will assume liabilities like $68 million in slip-and-fall claims against the property's owners -- still have to be negotiated.
Mr. Speyer said the Goldman group would begin discussing those issues with Rockefeller Group and hoped for a quick settlement.
Assuming the Goldman group's deal goes through, the REIT will have to pay an $11 million breakup fee to Mr. Zell to end its agreement with his group, which includes the General Electric Company and the Walt Disney Company.
The other hurdle facing the Goldman group is the REIT's shareholders, who must approve the deal. Several shareholders have suggested that the REIT should seek new financing on its own. Gotham made a proposal that would have refinanced the REIT's debt at a lower interest rate and raised at least $150 million through a rights offering.
If shareholders do not approve the deal, the Goldman group has agreed to participate in a rights offering with the REIT that would raise $200 million.
But people familiar with the terms of that rights offering said it presented an unattractive alternative for shareholders. Goldman, which already has the right to buy up to a 19.9 percent stake in the REIT, would be protected from dilution of its stake and would get the right to buy $50 million of stock at $7 to $7.50 a share for three years.
"It's an interesting development, and we are currently evaluating it," said David K. Sherman, a vice president at the Leucadia National Corporation, a large real estate and insurance company that holds a 7.1 percent stake in the REIT and has supported the Gotham proposal.
Another shareholder, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "I think this means this fight is over."
Peter D. Linneman, chairman of the REIT's board, declined to comment on the precise terms of the rights offering because the REIT had not filed its deal with the Securities and Exchange Commission. But he described it as "reasonably straightforward" and emphasized that the offering was presented only as an option in the event that shareholders rejected the all-cash deal.
"I am confident that the agreement we have made will get complete shareholder support," he said. "We believe our shareholders should and will take a straightforward $8 in cash."
Mr. Linneman stressed that the $8-a-share figure was twice what the REIT's shares were trading for late last year. "It's pretty fully priced at $8," he said. "Beyond that, I think any additional value comes at a higher risk than the typical REIT shareholder would want to take."
But the Goldman group obviously believes it can increase the value of the property. It promised its fellow investors, which include affiliates of the Agnelli family of Italy and the Niarchos family of Greece, a 20-plus percent return on their investments. And Gotham estimated that the property would be worth as much as $12 a share in three to five years.
"This is a very sophisticated investor group, and I don't think we'd be making the investment if we didn't feel this was an economically feasible deal," Mr. Speyer said. "But there is going to be a three- to four-year haul in turning this property around, with enormous capital expenditures and huge operating and management challenges."
