HEADLINE: Some Big Holders Hesitant About First Interstate Deal

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
First Interstate Bancorp's agreement to be bought by First Bank System Inc., announced on Monday, may run into problems with shareholders if Wells Fargo & Company chooses to proceed with its hostile bid.
Several large shareholders said yesterday that they would vote against the First Bank deal if given the alternative of a higher offer by Wells Fargo. 
 If Wells makes a new bid, "it would be hard to look at both offers and come out on the side of First Bank System," said Denis Laplaige, president of the MacKay-Shields Financial Corporation, an investment firm that owns about 1.9 percent of First Interstate's stock.
"We think that a combination of First Interstate and First Bank System will make a fine bank, but Wells Fargo has the best shot of combining operations and realizing the greatest synergies," he said.
On Monday, First Bank, based in Minneapolis, agreed to buy the much larger First Interstate, based in Los Angeles, for stock valued at $10 billion, at yesterday's stock price. The deal, which would preserve First Interstate's name and much of its management, is worth less than the surprise hostile bid made by Wells Fargo on Oct. 19.
Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, initially offered stock worth about $10.1 billion, but raised its bid on Monday to $10.7 billion, valued on yesterday's stock price. The increased offer from Wells is worth $136.66 a share, about $5 more a share than the First Bank bid.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the shares of First Interstate rose 50 cents, to $127.375; First Bank was up 75 cents, to $50.625, and Wells Fargo was down 37.5 cents, to $210.25.
Executives at Wells Fargo were debating yesterday whether to go ahead with a hostile tender offer for First Interstate shares, people familiar with the bank said. While such a course would be expensive and could distract management for up to a year, analysts and investment bankers expect Wells Fargo to proceed because of the enormous financial returns the bank foresees from the acquisition.
First Interstate has agreed to pay penalties of up to $200 million to First Bank if the merger is not consummated, but analysts said this would not be enough of a deterrent to block a new offer by Wells Fargo.
Thomas K. Brown, an analyst of regional banks for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, predicted that Wells Fargo would proceed with a hostile bid valued at about $147 a share, increasing the total price to $11.7 billion. Such an offer, he said, would be attractive to shareholders who are dissatisfied by the First Bank bid.
"First Interstate shareholders are not at all happy," Mr. Brown said. "I have talked to four of the five largest holders and the reaction ranges from modestly negative to violently negative."
"Investors are most upset about the process," Mr. Brown said. "They feel that the management and the board decided they would sell the company to anybody except Wells Fargo." Mr. Brown said First Interstate executives also offended investors by saying that the decision was based in part on the effect of the deal on the California economy and other nonfinancial considerations.
"The shareholders are saying they have no obligation to the state of California and that should not be part of the process," he said.
First Interstate's chairman, William E. B. Siart, spent much of the day meeting with investors to win support for the deal.
"It's clear that in the beginning a lot of people will have questions about our deal," said Shirley T. Hosoi, First Interstate's spokeswoman. "Wells has a leg up because they have been out in the marketplace for three weeks to explain their deal. As people begin to understand us over the next few weeks, they will support us."
First Interstate's largest shareholder, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the investment fund, remained silent on the First Bank deal yesterday. "K.K.R. is supportive of the process that the First Interstate board has conducted, but they decline to comment on any specific merger plan or transaction," a spokeswoman said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Growth Rate Slows Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
In another sign of increasingly pinched household budgets, consumers sharply curtailed new installment debt in September, Federal Reserve figures showed today, adding to a number of recent indications that consumer spending may be running out of steam.
The amount of outstanding installment credit rose $5.4 billion during the month, barely half as much as the August increase. Credit-card balances increased by $2.8 billion, the slimmest rise of the year. At the same time, lenders have become more reluctant to make loans. 
 "This is telling us the windows are now open and the cold air's rushing in," said James H. Chessen, economist for the American Bankers Association, pointing to indications of distress among a still small, but growing, group of consumers. Credit-card delinquencies, he said, are as high as they were at the end of the latest recession, which ended in early 1991.
Although analysts generally minimize the importance of one month's installment report, which provides only a net change in the amount outstanding, not the underlying extensions and repayments from which that figure is derived, some saw the September figures as part of a pattern.
"The slowing has been under way since May," said Stuart Sclater-Booth, a researcher at Paine Webber. "Consumers are more financially strapped." In fact, at 18.83 percent of disposable income, installment debt edged to a record in September, Mr. Sclater-Booth said.
Analysts said that the Fed's monthly report did not include home-equity loans and could have been muddied by the increased use of credit cards for convenience rather than for borrowing or for obtaining such benefits as frequent-flier miles. Still, they said it was hard to avoid the conclusion that more household budgets were stretched thin.
"Consumer debt has been really piling up," said David Lereah, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, which reported a rise in mortgage delinquencies for the second quarter and said it expects another increase for the third period. "It's reaching a point where you just can't take on more."
Mr. Lereah added, however, that interest rates on many credit cards have tumbled in recent years, reducing the burden of a given volume of debt. He called this a largely unrecognized "refinancing revolution" in credit cards, similar to the 1993 scramble to replace high-rate home mortgages with cheaper ones when long-term rates fell sharply.
James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, was skeptical about today's report even as he termed it "consistent with the notion that consumers, having overextended themselves, may be pulling back a bit."
Mr. Annable said that consumers may be spending significantly more than the installment figures showed. He said that sales of new and used homes surged at a 67 percent annual pace during the summer quarter, and that when a home changes hands, about 2 percent of its price is spent on repairs and furnishings. He said that little of this might show up as installment debt. Roof repairs or furniture may wind up being paid out of savings or be included in the mortgage.
So while some consumers "are falling over the cliff," he said that he would not worry about the economy as long as the unemployment rate, 5.5 percent in October, remained low.
Mr. Chessen noted, however, that banks were already taking protective action. "Lenders are being much more cautious," he said. "It is going to be more difficult to get credit" as banks impose what he called "extra layering" of credit evaluation and delay increasing credit lines to their customers.
The Fed's report found that outstanding debt rose more slowly for all three of its major categories of installment debt. Automobile loans increased $1.8 billion following a $2 billion rise in August; revolving loans climbed $2.8 billion, compared with $4.4 billion the previous month, and other loans increased $826 million compared with $3.9 billion.
The "other" category includes loans, secured or unsecured, for mobile homes, education, boats and vacations.
September's 6.6 percent annual rate of change for installment debt followed a 12.7 percent pace in August, which was the 16th month in the last 18 months in which the advance in outstanding debt increased at a double-digit pace.
For the 12 months through September, the outstanding credit debt rose 13.9 percent. That continued a slowdown that began after a peak of 15.3 percent for the 12 months ended in May, Mr. Sclater-Booth of Paine Webber said.
Separately, the Labor Department said that productivity grew at a slower pace than expected in the third quarter, though the manufacturing sector posted the largest gain in eight years.
 Nonfarm business productivity grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2 percent in the third quarter, less than the 2.8 percent increase expected by economists.
 Second-quarter productivity was revised upward slightly, to a 4.9 percent gain from 4.8 percent.
 Productivity in manufacturing grew 6.2 percent in the third quarter, the largest gain since a 10.6 percent increase in the second quarter of 1987, the department said.
 Productivity gauges efficiency by measuring the amount of goods and services produced per hour by all workers, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations.

HEADLINE: Death Penalty Case Lures Top Legal Help

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Had Lawrence Whitehurst been arrested three weeks earlier for the murder and kidnapping of a 7-year-old girl in Kingston, N.Y., he probably would have ended up with a single court-appointed lawyer.
But Mr. Whitehurst was arrested after New York State's death penalty law took effect on Sept. 1. As a result, Mr. Whitehurst, an unemployed 25-year-old grocery clerk, has four lawyers, a paralegal, an investigator and a social worker. And his legal team is not just made up of recent law school graduates making an idealistic detour on their way to lucrative legal careers. It includes lawyers who were seasoned in states that have the death penalty and who enlisted in New York out of either opposition to capital punishment or a feeling that capital defendants deserve vigorous representation. 
 "Death is different," said Mark B. Harris, Mr. Whitehurst's lead counsel and the deputy chief of the new Capital Defender Office created by the death-penalty statute. "The better attorneys we can get involved, the less possibility that innocent people will be executed."
The legal talent that has gravitated to the Whitehurst case -- the first in the state in which the prosecution has said it will seek the death penalty -- reflects the breadth of representation that capital defendants are getting as a result of a bill carefully drafted to win broad support in the State Legislature.
The Capital Defender Office has 17 lawyers in bureaus in Manhattan, Rochester and Albany, and roughly half come with experience handling death-penalty cases outside New York, according to the office's administrator. The office, with a budget this year of $3.2 million, can multiply its force by contracting with legal aid societies or private lawyers. It also sponsors seminars on the death penalty for criminal lawyers, and roughly 160 have enrolled.
As of Oct. 31, the Capital Defender Office was notified of 102 murder cases that could potentially qualify for the death penalty, 74 of them in New York City. The office has taken on only eight cases and it has assigned seven of them to outside lawyers because in the remainder, there were indications that capital charges would not be pursued. In the Bronx, for example, the District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, appended notes to the 22 murder cases he referred, saying he would not seek execution because of his doctrinal opposition to capital punishment.
On Monday, a Manhattan grand jury handed up the state's first capital murder indictment in the case of two men accused of slaying three family members in Harlem last month. One of those slain, Arelis Batista, 18, was said by the police to have enlisted the suspects in a plot to kill her father but ended up a victim herself. The father has insisted the police are mistaken.
The two suspects, however, may not face the death penalty. In Manhattan, too, the District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, is an opponent of the death penalty. He has named a committee of prosecutors to help him decide whether to seek capital punishment in some cases.
If he does, he, like other district attorneys, will face a more spirited, adroit defense than in more routine murder cases because of the depth of talent these cases are attracting.
For example, Mr. Harris, 45, the lawyer in the Kingston case, said he gave up an 18-year private practice that earned him a lot more than the $80,000 his state job pays because he wanted the chance to create precedents on a frontier of state law. Death penalty cases will include procedures that have not been tested in New York State, like separate trial phases for guilt and punishment and the cloistered questioning of individual jury panelists about their attitudes toward the death penalty.
Passage of the law, which guarantees every capital defendant at least two lawyers, drew Mr. Harris's co-counsel, Barry Fisher, 32, back to his home state from Atlanta. A magna cum laude graduate of Harvard Law School, he had been representing capital defendants through the Southern Center for Human Rights.
As a result of this gathering tide, local prosecutors like E. Michael Kavanagh, the District Attorney for Ulster County, which includes Kingston, are bracing for tougher courtroom fights. Mr. Kavanagh said he is sometimes struck by the fact that "if you're charged with murdering someone you get a barrage of attorneys, but if you're charged with maiming or raping someone or doing something less serious you get a lesser defense."
But in the end, he said, even though the challenge will be tougher, "it should be, given what's at stake."
"If there's an adjudication of guilt, people need to be satisfied with the outcome," Mr. Kavanagh said.
The Whitehurst case was the state's first in which the local District Attorney announced he would seek the death penalty. Mr. Kavanagh's statement put the case under the provisions of the new law, which provides for execution by lethal injection for specific categories of murder, including those committed in the course of grave felonies like rape or kidnapping.
But in contrast to the defendants in the Manhattan case, Mr. Whitehurst was arraigned on the lesser charge of second-degree murder, with Mr. Kavanagh explaining that he would elevate the case to first-degree murder in the indictment he sought from a grand jury, which is still hearing the case.
Mr. Whitehurst is accused of beckoning 7-year-old Rickel Knox into his car and bludgeoning her in the woods outside Kingston. The girl's mother, Margaret Marable, told the police she believes Mr. Whitehurst took revenge on Rickel because the mother had resisted his advances.
A key element in Mr. Whitehurst's defense strategy is the ploy used by prosecutors to find the body. Mr. Whitehurst was questioned for two days after the girl disappeared, then charged only with kidnapping. Prosecutors, eager to locate Rickel, told him that if he led them to her they would arrange a relatively lenient sentence. Mr. Whitehurst, prosecutors say, then showed them where the body was hidden.
Defense lawyers contend that what the prosecutors did was renege on a plea bargain. As a result, the lawyers argue, prosecutors have so tainted the case that it should be shifted to another district attorney's office. Mr. Kavanagh has denied any misconduct. "I would have done anything the guy wanted us to do to get the girl alive," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Because the prosecution has said it will seek the death penalty against Lawrence Whitehurst, left (Spencer Ainsley/The Poughkeepsie Journal), charged in the death of a 7-year-old girl, his lawyers reflect the breadth of representation capital defendants are receiving. Co-counsels are Barry Fisher, who represented capital defendants for the Southern Center for Human Rights, and Mark B. Harris, with beard. "Death is different," Mr. Harris said. (Alan E. Solomon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Wait for Debt Limit Deal Keeps Bond Traders Quiet

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices moved lower within a narrow range in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants continued to watch the talks in Congress about the Federal budget and the debt ceiling and showed scant reaction to economic data and comments made by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.
Traders noted continuing consolidation within the market, as some participants locked in gains made last week, with only modest buying from those taking advantage of dips in prices to pick up bargains. 
 On Monday, the Treasury postponed indefinitely, or at least until Congress passed authorization for raising the Federal debt limit, the auction of new three-year notes that had been scheduled for yesterday and one of 10-year notes that had been scheduled for today.
Yesterday, the 30-year bond was down 6/32, to a price of 107 20/32 to yield 6.30 percent, up from 6.29 percent on Monday.
Debt futures also ended on a softer note, with investors buying at the lows. The December Treasury bond futures contract closed at 117 14/32. "My technicals are calling for about a half-point more decline," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, "which should be a good buying opportunity."
There was little response to the 2.3 percent increase in the Johnson Redbook report about weekly chain-store sales, a trader said, because the market had already priced in the increase. In another report yesterday, the Fed said that consumer credit expanded by $5.42 billion in September, well short of the $8.5 billion that economists had anticipated and indicating that consumers are less willing to take on more debt.
Even statements by Mr. Greenspan failed to stir the market. Addressing the Gerald R. Ford Foundation in Grand Rapids, Mich., he called financial stability in general and price stability in particular the keys to long-term economic success, and said that the central bank had had "considerable success" in the fight against inflation in recent years. Some traders interpreted this to mean that the Fed was not prepared to ease rates any time soon, though others dismissed the comments as not suggestive of any particular sentiment.
The House Ways and Means Committee said yesterday that a draft version of a House bill would raise the debt ceiling by $50 billion until mid-December. Republicans said that the added $50 billion would be enough to finance Government operations until they forward final legislation to the President for approval.
"Assuming there is a near-term agreement on the debt-ceiling limit," Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data of Boston, said, "traders will have to take on over $50 billion of three-year, ten-year and one-year auction paper all within a very short time span. This is on top of the expected $29.25 billion in two-year and five-year notes, along with a larger $29.2 billion weekly bill auction."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said that the Treasury market "is currently in a state of suspended animation while waiting for passage of debt-ceiling legislation. As soon as the debt ceiling is lifted," he noted, there would be a spate of Treasury offerings.
"Another continuing resolution will be needed next week to keep the Government operational until a budget accord is reached," Mr. Fine continued. "While all of this is temporary, it is nonetheless distracting, and creates potential headaches for the Fed in its role of market stabilizer."
Meanwhile, Mr. Fine said, the October Producer Price Index on Thursday is the only major economic statistic the market will face this week, with forecasts for the index ranging from minus a half percent to plus two-tenths of 1 percent.
"Even the high end of the range still suggests a subdued, benign and nonthreatening pace of inflation," he said. "Indeed, not only does the inflation picture give the Fed latitude to ease further, but a number of recently released economic statistics suggest a possible further slowing of the economy over the near term, which could, if continued, give the Fed some inducement on the output side of the equation as well."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Moves in Paris Bolster Franc, Helping Dollar Rise vs. Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday after a Government reshuffling in France bolstered the French franc against the mark.
The Cabinet shake-up indicated to currency traders that the Government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe and President Jacques Chirac would make trimming the $58 billion budget deficit a priority over reducing the 11.5 percent unemployment rate. 
 "Juppe and Chirac have dropped the idea that they can create jobs at the same time they cut spending," said Ken Nixon, currency adviser at Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in New York.
The Cabinet changes, which left Jean Arthuis as Finance Minister, bolstered expectations that the Government would remain committed to a strong franc and that it would move forward on European monetary union.
The news helped drive the mark down to 3.4461 francs, from 3.4625 francs on Monday, in New York.
When the mark falls against European currencies, it typically depreciates against the dollar as well , as speculators seek all opportunities to sell marks.
But the Japanese yen also rose strongly against the mark, which left the dollar slightly weaker against the yen.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar slipped to 103 yen from 103.33 yen on Monday. But the dollar rose to 1.4160 marks from 1.4128 marks and to 1.1389 Swiss francs from 1.1380 Swiss francs.
In other trading, the dollar fell to 4.8825 French francs from 4.8911 French francs. The British pound edged up to $1.5809 from $1.5799.
The dollar's gains were restrained by the battle between President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress over efforts to cut the budget deficit and raise the debt limit, currency traders said.
"I don't think there'll be any major action on the dollar until we see some developments in the budget talks," said Frank Hanson, a trader at Unibank in Copenhagen. "It's difficult to know what will happen there, as we're talking about politicians, so people are staying on the sidelines for the moment."
Without an increase in the debt limit, the Treasury cannot sell more debt and will not be able to make interest payments due Nov. 15. A default would undermine confidence in American assets and weaken the dollar.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Biggest Stockholder in Daiwa Frowns on a Sumitomo Merger

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Daiwa Bank's largest shareholder has reportedly thrown cold water on the idea of a merger between the troubled bank and Sumitomo Bank.
The shareholder, Nomura Securities, which owns 3.3 percent of Daiwa, did not make its reasons clear. But in a meeting on Monday between Hideo Sakamaki, Nomura's president, and Takashi Kaiho, his counterpart at Daiwa, Nomura expressed reservations about a merger, according to a report in a Japanese daily, Mainichi Shimbun. 
 "As a leading shareholder, we cannot assent to the merger with Sumitomo Bank," Mainichi quoted Mr. Sakamaki as saying. "We cannot give support to Daiwa if it will merge with Sumitomo Bank."
Other reports agreed that Nomura might disapprove of a merger, although it was not clear whether Nomura could block a deal if the Japanese Finance Ministry insisted on one.
A Nomura spokesman would not say much about the matter. "We are not in the position to comment about the reported merger because neither bank has said the two will merge," the spokesman said on Tuesday. "It has just been media talk."
Newspaper reports did not offer explanations of why Nomura would not support a merger. Last week, Daiwa announced that Nomura had offered to help it dispose of its operations in the United States, and there was no suggestion that Nomura was withdrawing such an offer.
In Washington, the House planned hearings into the Daiwa case. Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, who heads the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions, said on Tuesday that the hearings on Dec. 5 would review the case and overall American regulation of international financial institutions. Witnesses were expected to include officials from the Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and New York State Banking Department.
Some analysts here sought to explain Nomura's stance by saying that the securities company wanted to negotiate a stronger tie-in with Daiwa to expand into the banking business. This would be hard if Sumitomo absorbed Daiwa.
"They've always wanted to be a bank," David Atkinson, a financial analyst at Goldman, Sachs Japan, said of Nomura. About a merger between Sumitomo and Daiwa, he added, "I'm not sure it's going to happen."
Another big Japanese daily, Asahi Shimbun, suggested that Nomura had not been consulted on the possibility of a merger and might have felt left out of the decision-making.
Several Japanese bankers said the merger could be unpopular with other banks here, which would have to compete with a mammoth new institution. A union of Sumitomo and Daiwa would create the world's largest bank, with assets of 87.7 trillion yen -- about $850 billion -- and would significantly broaden Sumitomo's business activities.
Sumitomo would gain access to Daiwa's trust operation, which is the nation's largest pension-fund manager. Moreover, Daiwa has a controlling interest in Cosmo Securities, a business in which Sumitomo is reportedly interested.
The uncertainty led Daiwa's stock to pull back sharply today after soaring Monday on hopes for a merger. The shares fell by 60 yen in trading today, to close at 670 yen, after edging down slightly on Tuesday. The stock had spurted on Monday, gaining 100 yen.
In another development affecting Daiwa, Japan's top economic planner expressed concern that the bank's expulsion from the United States could hamper broad economic recovery. Isamu Miyazaki, head of the Economic Planning Agency, said Daiwa's expulsion could have a "very bad psychological impact" on the economy, the Kyodo news service quoted Mr. Miyazaki as saying.

Trader Denied Bail in U.S.
 By Reuters
A Federal judge denied bail yesterday to a former Daiwa Bank trader in New York who has pleaded guilty to concealing $1.1 billion in losses. United States District Judge Lewis Kaplan refused to release Toshihide Iguchi, 44, former senior vice president at Daiwa's New York branch, citing a risk that Mr. Iguchi might flee. Judge Kaplan noted that Mr. Iguchi's property was subject to forfeiture and that he faced up to 90 years in prison, and added, "A person in his situation might well be be tempted to disappear." The judge also noted that others could be charged in the case.

HEADLINE: H.M.O. Quality Called Equal, at Less Cost

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
A broad new study asserts that patients treated by health maintenance organizations and those treated by doctors in traditional medical practices had similar results, even though the H.M.O.'s cost substantially less.
The study, by the New England Medical Center in Boston and the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., is the first comprehensive case-by-case comparison of the treatment and cost of the two kinds of health care systems. It was published yesterday in The Journal of the American Medical Association. 
 The researchers also reported that the studies patients, who were moderately sick with high blood pressure or adult diabetes, had similar results whether they were treated by primary-care doctors, like internists or family practitioners, or by specialists in cardiology and endocrinology.
The study comes as experts debate whether H.M.O.'s sacrifice quality of care for lower costs, and as a Congressional conference committee takes up House and Senate bills that, as part of a Medicare overhaul, encourage greater use of H.M.O.'s. More Americans are turning to H.M.O.'s for their medical care; about 50 million Americans now use these organizations.
The study also comes in the midst of Congressional efforts to cut projected spending on Medicare, the Federal health care program for the elderly, by $270 billion over the next seven years, and similar efforts to squeeze $170 billion from Medicaid, the health care program for the poor. Those cuts are being considered by the conference committee as well.
Some experts warned against drawing too sweeping a conclusion from the results of the new study, which was conducted in Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles from 1986 to 1993.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said that many H.M.O.'s paid far too much attention to the bottom line and that one study of two diseases in three cities was "not enough to disprove that."
He added that the cost data in the new study, analyzed in 1992, were already outdated in view of the recent increases in the use of H.M.O.'s.
But he said the A.M.A. had long taken the position that H.M.O.'s can provide high-quality medical care and said the group was concerned "not about managed care but managed profiteering."
The A.M.A. has, in fact, been a frequent opponent of H.M.O.'s, seeing them, among other things, as interfering with the doctor's ability to make appropriate medical decisions and maintain traditional doctor-patient relationships.
Others reacted to the study by cautioning that much more detailed work should be done.
"It's very well to have this good study started nearly 10 years ago, but we need more work now," said Dr. David Lansky, regional director of clinical information for Providence Health System, a group of doctors and hospitals in Portland, Ore.
But Dr. Lansky added: "It's important stuff they've done. They have shown that it is possible to look at the overall patterns of care provided by our major systems and evaluate quality of care systematically." He called the study a "milestone."
Others in the health profession called the research very important to assessing the quality of American health care. Earlier projects -- like a 1986 study by the University of California at San Francisco -- reached similar conclusions but studied fewer patients and did not analyze costs. The California research compared rheumatoid arthritis patients treated by Kaiser Permanente, an H.M.O., with those treated by traditional fee-for-service doctors.
H.M.O.'s have been successful in holding down health care costs by urging the doctors on their staffs to spend less money on treatments; by heavily using preset fees, under which doctors get paid a set amount per month per patient, regardless of how often they see the patient or whether they see the patient at all, and by their less frequent use of specialists.
But the study's authors emphasized that more research was needed to learn how much cost cutting can be done without endangering the quality of care and to determine how much the effectiveness of treatment varies among health plans, diseases and patients.
"The equivalent outcomes observed in this study do not necessarily mean that cutbacks in services currently being considered will lead to good outcomes for all patients," said Alan R. Tarlov, director of the Health Institute at the New England center, referring to the proposed cuts in Medicare and Medicaid.
He added, "There might be some aspects of care that affect outcomes adversely, particularly for vulnerable subgroups," like the elderly and poor.
The 1,720 patients in the study were treated by 354 doctors and 13 nurse practitioners, and were followed up and interviewed over the seven years of the project. The doctors and nurses practiced in H.M.O.'s, large multi-specialty group practices, solo practices or single-specialty groups.
The researchers found that the type of health care insurance system the patients had chosen -- prepaid in an H.M.O. or fee-for-service in a traditional plan -- had no bearing on whether their blood pressure or blood-sugar levels were under control, or whether other consequences of their illnesses developed after two years. The kind of plan selected also did not affect the patients' ability to function in everyday life after four years, or their mortality rate after seven years.
The researchers said the H.M.O. doctors hospitalized 40 percent fewer patients than the fee-for-service doctors, and ordered 12 percent fewer drugs.
The study also found that primary-care doctors spent less money than the specialists. For example, cardiologists hospitalized twice the number of patients and ordered 24 percent more drugs and 19 percent more laboratory tests. Endocrinologists sent one and a half times more patients to hospitals and ordered 48 percent more laboratory tests and 10 percent more drugs.
But Dr. Philip E. Cryer, president-elect of the American Diabetes Association, said the conclusions of the study were not always supported by the data, pointing out that endocrinologists did better, for example, in treating diabetics' foot problems.
The researchers acknowledged Dr. Cryer's point but said those problems did not show up in the four-year and seven-year follow-up observations.
Dr. Sheldon Greenfield of the New England Medical Center, the principal author of the study, said the researchers picked adult diabetes to study because of its prevalence; because its many complications make it one of the most expensive of chronic diseases, and because the right treatments often prevent such complications. Hypertension was chosen, in part, because it is treated by doctors in all specialties and systems of care, Dr. Greenfield said.

HEADLINE: A Report Criticizes Improvement Zones In New York City

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
In the first government review of the self-taxing business districts that have proliferated in New York City in the last decade, a City Council inquiry has concluded that some have abused their power and failed to deliver promised services.
The Council's inquiry, to be released today, found that a lack of oversight has allowed some of these business improvement districts to pay their executives excessive salaries and spend too much money on their operations. That contradicts the original notion that the districts would deliver better services at lower cost than the government precisely because they would be more efficient. 
 The inquiry also found managerial problems and abuses in several districts, ranging from the large Grand Central Partnership to the tiny East Brooklyn Business Improvement District: conflicts of interest, illegal loans, use of illegal immigrants at less than minimum wage. At least one district is close to bankruptcy, the report said.
At a time when the city is cutting back on services and increasingly relying on the districts to provide them instead, the City Council's report calls for greater regulation of these quasi-governmental groups in the interest of keeping them alive.
"Requiring the BID's to be accountable to the public is revolutionary -- right now BID's can do whatever they want," said Herbert Berman, chairman of the Council's Finance Committee. "BID's are a significant reality, especially at a time of fiscal restraint. I've always encouraged them. A majority do an effective job and in an honest way, but some have raised substantial questions."
By levying special taxes on property owners, the business improvement districts supplement the city's delivery of sanitation, security and social services and promote local businesses. An outgrowth of the special assessment districts created by the State Legislature in the 1970's, the BID's were authorized by the City Council in 1982. There are now 34, large and small, covering 550 blocks across the city from Harlem to Brighton Beach; business owners in 39 more areas are considering creating districts.
The districts' leaders, who have not seen the report, had little comment. Tom Cusick, president of the Fifth Avenue improvement district and chairman of the new New York City BID Managers Association, said it was unfair to release the report without giving the district's a chance to respond. Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, also reserved comment.
The districts were meant to be streamlined operations, but many spend considerable amounts of money in administrative overhead, according to the inquiry. The small Columbus/Amsterdam BID spends half its budget on administration. And the Church Avenue district in Brooklyn spends 29 percent of its budget to pay the $35,000 salary of its director -- but only $6,000 for the sanitation services that are one of its central obligations to property owners.
Six districts pay their managers at least $100,000 in salary. Daniel Biederman, who runs the Grand Central, 34th Street and Bryant Park BID's, makes $315,000. His security chief, at $144,999, and his sanitation chief, at $114,530, make more than the city's Police and Sanitation Commissioners, who earn $110,000 each.
At the same time, the inquiry found, several BID's hired illegal immigrants, paid less than minimum wage and paid salaries in cash. One company in particular that is said to use illegal immigrants had multiple contracts with business districts.
Several districts did not properly supervise their contractors, sometimes failing to execute written contracts, the inquiry found. The Church Avenue district, for instance, hired a company to sweep streets and sidewalks, but the workers swept only the streets and solicited additional payments from merchants to do the sidewalks.
The City Council inquiry, which was conducted by the Council's Office of Oversight and Investigation and the staff of its Finance Committee, was prompted partly by controversies involving Mr. Biederman's joint management of three of the city's most prominent BID's.
The report recommends that Mr. Biederman not be allowed to take on any more districts -- he has expressed interest in creating or running several others -- and that no one else be allowed to run more than one BID.
Some BID's are not performing proper audits of their finances, the report said. At the Jamaica Mall district in Queens, the budget committee did not meet for two years, and the board did not get minutes of executive committee meetings. The East Brooklyn BID is so mismanaged that it is near bankruptcy, the report said.
Many improvement districts have tangled relationships with local business groups that pose potential conflicts, the report said. Some district officials also work for other groups with different boundaries and goals, and it is not always clear how the officials' time and loyalties are divided. Some of those groups have contracts with the districts, raising questions about the equity of those arrangements, whose costs are borne by the districts' taxpayers.
The most extreme example of a potential for conflicts involved the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce, which ran both the Jamaica Mall and 165th Street districts. The chamber president was the manager of the mall district, and the organizations shared several board members.
Eventually, disaffected property owners at Jamaica Mall forced a court-supervised election that installed a new district board. It sued the chamber for $1 million, claiming fraud, misappropriation of funds and violation of fiduciary trust. The chamber countersued for $10 million, and both cases are still pending.
Among other issues, the 165th Street and Jamaica Mall districts gave or loaned nearly $20,000 to the Jamaica Economic Growth Corporation, transfers that the report said state law prohibits.
The report calls for new performance standards and stricter oversight by individual BID boards, by the city's Department of Business Services, by the State Legislature and by the Council itself. Mr. Berman, the Finance Committee chairman, said, "We're not going to blindly approve BID's and their assessment increase."
Dissatisfaction with the improvement districts emerged in a poll of 404 property owners and managers conducted by the council's staff. About a third could not name their BID and did not know what it did.
Although sanitation was widely rated as improved, other services got mixed reviews in the survey. Business promotions like flyers and directories are a major BID theme, but only 57 percent said they were aware of such efforts.
While the law creating the districts grants them only five-year contracts, no district with outstanding debt can be dissolved. And so the districts have the potential to survive forever regardless of the feelings of the owners who are taxed -- and the inquiry found that only 45 percent of owners surveyed feel that their investment is paying off.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The White House Conference on Travel and Tourism produces a series of recommendations.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
THE many business executives who attended last week's White House Conference on Travel and Tourism are back at their usual haunts, after having voted to carry out a series of recommendations.
The recommendations include include making it easier for foreign business and leisure travelers to enter the United States, and developing a reliable economic analysis of the travel and tourism industry, which is currently valued at $417 billion. 
 Unlike past White House conferences, private industry contributed most of the cost. Contributions ranged from less than $500, given by 20 contributors, to at least $500,000 from American Express. Many airlines, hotels, rental car concerns, tour operators and travel agencies also made donations, individually or as members of trade associations.
With America's share of foreign visitors headed for its fourth consecutive decline, delegates at the conference agonized over how to reverse that trend -- a trend that Greg Farmer, Under Secretary of Commerce, attributes to growing competition from other countries and to the United States spending less than 32 other countries to promote foreign tourism.
Delegates recommended that Congress enact legislation for a national tourism office chartered by the Federal Government but managed by the private sector. Representative Toby Roth, a Republican from Wisconsin, has since introduced a bill calling for a panel that would devise a strategy to attract foreign visitors, and calling for a private tourism agency to carry out the campaign.
With Congress in an anti-spending mood, it may not be easy raising the $100 million budget thought necessary by the year 2000 to run the tourism office. And the private sector has been unable to agree on how to raise its contribution. A suggested $3 departure tax did not sit well with the airline industry, whose passengers already pay as many as six different taxes and fees, while a suggested $3 surcharge on passports also ran into opposition.
But a totally unscientific survey by this column found delegates and travel industry executives optimistic that financing will be found. Not because of any laxity over public or private purse strings, but because both sides recognize that more tourists translate into more jobs, higher tax receipts and increased revenues.
 
Help in Latin America
The growing competition between United States and Latin American airlines may not be good for the balance sheet of individual carriers, but the lower fares generated by the competition have increased traffic along many of those routes. Many southbound passengers include business travelers looking to invest and sell in the region.
As it happens "Investing and Selling In Latin America" is the first title from Hemisphere Business Books in Shawnee Mission, Kan. (913 677-4116). Its 358 pages contain chapters on individual Latin American nations by financial writers who either live in the region or have lived there and still pay frequent visits.
The book covers economic policies, political stability, bureaucracy and corruption, sometimes in less-than-flattering terms. People who have established businesses in Latin America relate their experiences, including a businessman who spent a night in jail while trying to modernize Venezuela's telephone system. The book also tells what to expect from a nation's labor force and how to find sales reps and local partners.
"This is the first of several books we have planned for doing business in Latin America," said Shirley Christian, the publisher of Hemisphere Business Books. While "Investing and Selling in Latin America" contains a reading list, Ms. Christian, a former Latin American correspondent for The New York Times, The Miami Herald and The Associated Press, said that Hemisphere was also considering publishing important out-of-print books about Latin America.
 
Low Fares, and Leg Room
Dozens of low-fare airlines have come and gone since deregulation of the industry in 1978. No sooner did Alaska-based Mark Air suspend flights and file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection two weeks ago, than an airline with the incongruous name of Jet Train announced plans to begin service on Dec. 11, pending final Government approval.
Based in Aliquippa, Pa., Jet Train (800 359-4968) plans a daily nonstop flight between Newark and Pittsburgh and between Newark and Orlando, Fla., with one-stop flights between Pittsburgh and Orlando. Citing low fares -- $129 one way between Newark and Orlando, with an introductory rate of $69 from Dec. 11 through Dec. 17 -- with few restrictions, Jet Train also boasts that every seat on the two DC9-31's that make up its fleet have a 34-inch pitch -- that is, there are 34 inches between rows measured front-to-back.
Although 34-inch pitch was common in economy class not long ago, Jet Train may still be on to something in ballyhooing it as a luxury amenity -- especially when the intent of many airlines these days seems to be to see which passenger in economy class cries "uncle" first.

HEADLINE: In Wake of Disaster, Opportunity

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma sat by a sun-bathed window in the lobby of the luxurious St. Regis Hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan one recent morning, autographing photos of himself for constituents back home and recalling the party given the night before in his honor.
With the financier Henry R. Kravis as host at his Manhattan apartment, the affair was attended by corporate icons and celebrities who saluted the Republican Governor's leadership during the difficult days last spring after the Oklahoma City bombing, and discussed what could be done to create jobs and wealth for the people of his state. 
 "The question was," Mr. Keating said, "How do we make Oklahoma rich?"
To find an answer to that ambitious proposition, he is taking full advantage of the national platform that the bombing provided. In an all-out effort to advance the economic development agenda in his state -- which in per-capita income ranks as the seventh poorest in the United States -- Mr. Keating is crisscrossing the country, raising his profile through local media appearances, calling on corporations, and reaching out to people like Mr. Kravis.
The efforts appear to be paying off. Since the summer, several corporations, including the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, have announced plans to expand factories or locate offices in Oklahoma.
Mr. Kravis, the co-founder of the corporate buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and an Oklahoma native, said he spoke by telephone with the Governor right after the April 19 bombing.
"I said, 'Look, you've got a window of opportunity,' " Mr. Kravis recalled. "You should take advantage of this opportunity to get the word out of what Oklahoma is all about."
Mr. Keating has been following that advice.
"Since April 19, the height of interest in Oklahoma has increased," the Governor said. "I am doing just what I would have done with or without the tragedy. The tragedy just provided an excellent platform. I'm not embarrassed by that."
A former F.B.I. agent and Justice Department official in the Reagan and Bush Administrations, Mr. Keating was three months into his first term as Governor when the blast destroyed the Federal Building in downtown Oklahoma City, killing 168 people. Projecting a sense of calm, the Governor coordinated the efforts of the many rescue and investigation teams. He appeared on the news practically around the clock, overshadowing everyone else.
Mr. Keating's steadiness and the spirit that the people of Oklahoma displayed helped to dispel the state's image in the business community as a backwater. Herb Kelleher, chief executive of Southwest Airlines, said he was impressed with the "can-do attitude" and "sense of community" that Oklahomans demonstrated. In June, Southwest opened a reservations center in Oklahoma City, employing 1,000 people, a deal that was struck before the bombing.
Mr. Keating, 51, has become Oklahoma's star salesman. An energetic man who jogs three miles every other day, he is suddenly finding himself on the A-list of rich and powerful people. He has traveled to Omaha to play golf with the billionaire Warren E. Buffett and vacationed with Mr. Kravis at the financier's Aspen hideaway. Last month, the Governor joined about 45 leaders of major corporations for a daylong outing aboard a yacht owned by the publishing company Forbes Inc.
The level of activity has led to speculation that the Governor might have his sights on national office. He denies this, and insists that his purpose is to thank people for their support after the bombing and to drum up interest in Oklahoma.
Making Oklahoma wealthy, as he intends, will not be easy. Since the 80's, when oil prices dropped and the farm economy receded, the state's fortunes have lagged.
While major corporations like AT&T and General Motors have large operations in Oklahoma, many other companies have decided against moving to the state, citing impediments like a shortage of direct airline flights from the coasts and the absence of a law banning labor contracts that require workers to belong to a union.
Although corporate relocation executives are attracted by the state's vocational and technical education system and the resulting high level of productivity of its work force, these factors have not been enough. The state has been a runner-up for several big economic development projects in recent years, like in 1991, when United Airlines decided to locate a maintenance facility, with 7,000 jobs, in Indiana.
"Being runner-up means you're the first-place loser," said Rick Moore, assistant to Mayor Ronald Norick of Oklahoma City.
The loss that scorched Mr. Keating came right before the bombing, when Micron Technology decided to build a $1.3 billion microchip processing plant, to employ 3,500 people, in Utah instead of Oklahoma. Mr. Keating decided to mount a full-scale offensive.
On April 4, two weeks before the bombing, the Governor's office hired Development Counselors International, a New York public relations firm that specializes in business development.
"The irony is they felt they weren't known for anything," said Robert E. DeRocker, a vice president at the firm. "They wanted us to look for speaking forums for the Governor, to help them with expansion."
The bombing made Mr. De Rocker's task easier. After April 19, he said, Mr. Keating's "placeability" soared, and it has remained high. "People from TV stations are calling us, saying they want him on," Mr. DeRocker said.
While calling on companies that might create jobs at home is not uncommon for any Governor, the volume of activity and the access provided Mr. Keating is striking. By December, he will have made 16 economic development trips in five months, visiting more than 35 companies around the nation.
"This Governor will run you ragged," said Bill Moss, who has served under five Governors as director of corporate site location for the Oklahoma Department of Commerce.
Normally, government officials who are trying to attract big businesses to their area are referred to corporate real estate managers, or site-selection consultants hired by the companies. But Mr. Keating and his economic development team receive red carpet treatment at most companies they visit.
In Chicago last summer, the Governor was scheduled to meet with the real estate manager of a Fortune 500 company that is considering opening a plant in Oklahoma. But when he walked into the lobby of the company's headquarters, the chairman of the board and the chief executive were there to greet him.
During the same trip, while the Oklahoma team was meeting in Chicago with executives at Viskase, a food processor that has operations in Oklahoma, indictments in the bombing were announced back home. Viskase officials turned their corporate boardroom over to the Governor and his staff to use as a satellite press office. And last summer in Toronto, when Oklahoma sponsored a hospitality suite at a convention of economic-development professionals, more than 1,200 people showed up.
"We were overwhelmed," said W. Andrew Burke, senior vice president for economic development in Oklahoma City.
It is too soon to tell what kind of long-term effect all of the attention will have on development in Oklahoma, but the early signs are promising. In addition to Goodyear, which announced a $25 million expansion of its plant in Lawton, First Data Resources, a consumer finance company in Omaha, recently announced plans to open an office in Tulsa, employing 3,000 people. And Viskase has agreed to expand its Pauls Valley plant, adding 250 jobs.
Development experts in the state believe they are on the verge of some other major deals that should put an end to Oklahoma's days as an economic development also-ran.
And Mr. Keating, despite his new-found fame, seems to be keeping things in perspective. He recently joked about an Omaha television interviewer who did not know who he was when he arrived at the station. "I'm Frank Keating, the Governor from Oklahoma," he said he told the interviewer, as he extended his hand. "Oh, hi Frank," he said she snapped back. "I'm from Florida, and I'm running for President."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
George Wallace as a Founding Father

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

THE POLITICS OF RAGE
George Wallace, the Origins of the New Conservatism and the Transformation of American Politics
By Dan T. Carter
Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.
Dan T. Carter ends this voyage through the heart of the American political darkness with an epigram: George C. Wallace, he writes, was "the most influential loser in 20th-century American politics." 
 Mr. Carter's point is that the race-baiting former Alabama Governor, though he failed in his four "whirlwind campaigns" for the Presidency, was the central and indispensable ingredient in the rise of a new American conservatism inaugurated with the successful "Southern strategy" of Richard M. Nixon and continuing with the anti-welfare state populism of Newt Gingrich. He was the "alchemist of the new social conservatism," Mr. Carter says, and hence of the transformation of American politics.
Biographers are not usually prone to minimize the historical importance of their subjects, and Mr. Carter, who is the Kenan Professor of History at Emory University in Atlanta and the author of prize-winning books on Southern history, certainly makes a large claim for his. In one respect it is too large. Mr. Carter builds a compelling, well-documented argument to the effect that Wallace's presence catalyzed the emergence in the late 1960's of a " 'New American Majority' on the solid foundation of the conservative South." His argument that conservatism today has succeeded because it has been able to encode Wallace's demagogic appeal is less persuasive.
That failing aside, however, "The Politics of Rage" is a stimulating political biography, solidly researched and vividly presented. One reads it with many thoughts: about, for example, the boundless cynicism of certain members of the American political class. Mr. Carter, though not absolutely certain about this, is doubtful that Wallace actually believed all those things he said about the civil rights movement and a Communist conspiracy or, for that matter, about the supposed dread danger to the white race that would ensue if black people registered for the vote. (One campaign aide summed up the Wallace electoral strategy in the 1970 gubernatorial race as, "Promise them the moon and holler, 'Nigger.' " ).
Most of all, however, "The Politics of Rage" makes one think about how different America was when Wallace made his famous, media-wise stand at the schoolhouse door as he battled in 1963 to prevent the integration of the University of Alabama. His single most famous statement, "Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever," would simply not be heard today in Southern elections. Three decades ago, to express a cynical, overtly racist contempt for the civil rights of black people was often vital to winning public office in the South.
"The Politics of Rage" weaves together two complementary purposes. In part it is high quality, if conventional, biography. It covers all the stages of Wallace's life, from his humble origins, to the years of pugnacious oratory and demagogic agitation, to the 1972 assassination attempt that left him in a wheelchair. Mr. Carter covers Wallace's several wives, especially Lurleen Wallace, who stood in for him as Governor in 1966, when the Alabama Constitution prohibited any Governor from serving two consecutive terms. Mr. Carter's narration of the major episodes of the civil rights movement in Alabama is gripping and sobering, even when he traces events familiar to readers of other recent accounts, like Taylor Branch's "Parting the Waves."
Mr. Carter gets to his second purpose in his final three chapters, in which he spins a dark, complicated tale of win-at-all-costs political warfare that is decidedly not the most glorious moment in the history of the American democracy. The story here has as much to do with Richard M. Nixon as with George Wallace, especially in the years 1968 to 1972, when Wallace's strong showing in the Democratic primaries pushed Nixon to compete for the white-conservative Wallace constituency, and to inherit it after Wallace was shot. What emerged, in Mr. Carter's view, was not just Nixon's Southern strategy, but the whole current political majority, built on a symbolic politics of backlash among whites.
"The Alabama governor," Mr. Carter declares, "compounded racial fear, anti-communism, cultural nostalgia and traditional right-wing economics into a movement that laid the foundation for the conservative counterrevolution that reshaped American politics in the 1970's and 1980's."
Certainly, Wallace's ability to capture, in what Mr. Carter calls "earthy language," a traditionalist despair at post-60's American turmoil helped to galvanize the new Republican majority in the early 1970's. But Mr. Carter simply tosses out his further argument -- that Wallace created the framework for present-day conservatism -- almost as though nothing has happened since he won the Michigan and Maryland Democratic primaries in 1972, or as though nothing had happened before.
The social conservatism that Mr. Carter sees aborning in the late 1960's was always present in America, which suggests that Mr. Wallace effected less of a "transformation" than Mr. Carter suggests. Absent from his argument is the possibility that the Democrats lost the majority by veering too far from grass-roots values, which is very different from saying that a decisive majority was created on the basis of white racial fears. Most of all, Mr. Carter makes too little of the way in which the national rhetoric and even the beliefs about civil rights have changed, becoming more distant from the Wallace legacy rather than carrying it on in coded form.
Still, whether or not one agrees with all of Mr. Carter's thesis, this biography is a very good one, likely to stand for a long time as the definitive work on one of the country's most interesting and disturbing recent historical actors.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A book review yesterday about "The Politics of Rage," a biography of George Wallace, misstated the title of a book about the civil rights movement by Taylor Branch. It is "Parting the Waters," not "Parting the Waves."

Bridge C15
 
Chronicle D24

HEADLINE: Learning Accepts New Offer From Broderbund Software

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Learning Company accepted a sweetened merger offer from Broderbund Software Inc. today and rejected a competing offer from Softkey International Inc. But it was still not clear which bidder will prevail.
Under the revised terms, Broderbund's offer is valued at $555 million, representing a 13 percent increase from the previous offer. Broderbund would pay 0.92 of a share of its common for each share of the Learning Company, valuing the Learning shares at $59.685, based on Broderbund's closing price today. 
 Under the previous offer, Broderbund would have paid 0.8125 share for each Learning share.
The new offer remains below the cash and stock offer from Softkey. That is valued at about $64 a share.
Analysts said Broderbund's offer had the advantages of board approval from the Learning Company, and of being tax-free. But some said arbitragers and other short-term holders of Learning might opt for the higher cash value offer.
"We still have the superior economic offer and it's up to the market to decide what the future of the Learning Company will be," Kevin O'Leary, Softkey's president, said in a telephone interview. He said Learning's premium-priced products were out of step with trends in the market. "They're working on the economics of yesterday," he said. "Softkey says that's changing. I'm confident we're going to win this."
Pressing its campaign, Softkey said it delivered demands to Learning today from holders of more than 10 percent of its common stock for a special meeting of stockholders to vote for a new board of directors.
The Learning Company, based in Fremont, Calif., is best known for Reader Rabbit and other educational programs. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., is the producer of the Carmen San Diego series and other educational programs.
Softkey, based in Cambridge, Mass., produces primarily budget-priced software sold from racks, but has decided to move aggressively into educational software with this proposed deal as well as the recently planned acquisition of the Minnesota Educational Computing Corporation.
Learning's shares closed at $60 today, down $1 in Nasdaq trading. Broderbund closed at $64.875, down 62.5 cents, and Softkey shares closed at $34, up 6.25 cents.
Learning said its board believed the resources and business philosophies of Softkey would not enable Learning to realize its market potential. It said the board "views the Softkey business model as unlikely to achieve long-term business or financial success."
While Softkey's executives blasted Learning's board and management in statements today, under the terms of the Broderbund offer, Learning management would remain in place, and be given two seats on Broderbund's board.
"We believe that the management of the Learning Company is one of its key assets," said Broderbund's president, William McDonagh, in a telephone interview. "We're looking at a merger with a successful company that is doing a lot of things right. The last thing we want to do is alter that chemistry."
Mr. McDonagh said that the relative cash value of the two deals was open to interpretation, and in any case, changed every day with shifting prices of the stocks involved. But he said the combination of Broderbund and the Learning Company was a better fit. "The important consideration is what is the long-term value to the shareholders of the two companies together," he said. The Learning Company agreed.
"The merger with Broderbund represents a compelling opportunity for us to achieve our strategic objectives and enhance long-term stockholder value," said Bill Dinsmore, Learning's president and chief executive. "The odds are Broderbund will persevere if the situation remains about where it is," said Vince Turzo, an analyst with Jeffries & Company in San Francisco, noting that the difference between the offers was only about 7 percent. "As long as the spread is less than 10 percent, the outside directors can make the case that Broderbund's offer is a cleaner, simpler offer, non-taxable, and that Broderbund's shares are a higher quality piece of paper than Softkey's," he said.
But Keith Benjamin, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company, thought Broderbund's sweetened offer might still not be high enough, particularly if more than half of Learning's stockholders were arbitragers. "I don't think we've seen the end of it," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Markets Skeptical, the Peso Falls Again

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The peso slid again today to a record low against the dollar, signaling stubborn skepticism in the markets about the Mexican Government's economic management and recovery program.
At the close of trading, the peso stood at 7.80 to the dollar, down from 7.475 on Tuesday. It reached its previous lows in March, 7.4 at the close and 7.75 intraday in the midst of acute financial turmoil. 
 Today, the peso continued to slip in spite of a series of Government measures in the last two weeks intended to confront chronic weaknesses in the Mexican economy. The stock market declined as well, with the main stock index here falling 21.53 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 2,234.47.
Wall Street had clamored for some of the Government's steps, yet they did not appear sufficient to rebuild the confidence of investors who remember the burning they took in the botched devaluation of the peso last December.
The Government's growing credibility problem, largely based on doubts in the financial markets that it has a realistic outlook for the economy, puts Mexico in a bind. Any move to shore up the peso could only signal to speculators that the Government recognizes some underlying weakness in the economy and might further encourage a selloff in the currency.
Another problem is that volume on the peso market has been extremely low, with relatively few buyers seeking dollars, but virtually no one buying pesos. This lack of liquidity magnifies peso fluctuations against the dollar because the peso is vulnerable to nervous investors and speculators, analysts said.
In Washington, Treasury officials declined today to comment on Mexico's latest economic problems. But the peso's fall puts them in a difficult position, because the last rescue of the Mexican currency was deeply unpopular in Congress and provoked some Republicans to start investigating how Mexico's financial problems became so severe last year while the Clinton Administration was reassuring the public that the economy was sound.
Administration officials have consistently urged Mexico this year to follow the sort of free-market policies that it employed this week. In particular, Mexico raised interest rates to prop up the peso.
On Tuesday night the Mexican Government, in an indirect slap at speculators, increased short-term interest rates to 54 percent. American analysts had been calling for the rate rise to discipline the peso market. But the increase did not induce peso buying today, and might have raised fears of exacerbating this country's recession. Indeed, cries of pain rose from Mexican business leaders who have been crushed by the high cost of credit.
Perplexed officials said the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo had not been able to fight its way out of a hangover of market perceptions based on its handling of the financial crisis last December and early this year. But the Government has also failed, some analysts said, to forcefully rebuff challenges to the peso by traders.
"There is no reason or economic basis to explain what we are seeing. The only thing we can do is keep our blood cool," the spokesman for the economic recovery program, Alejandro Valenzuela, said today.
Since Oct. 31 the Government has announced a new pact with business and the unions to stimulate growth, an overhaul of the pension system to promote domestic savings -- a step considered crucial to build Mexico's currency reserves, and a program of incentives for agriculture. A budget to be unveiled by Nov. 15 is expected to include cuts in public spending.
"What's going on is different from what you would expect, judging from the economic plan. It all seems to be lost in the market turbulence," said Mauricio Gonzalez, director of Grupo Economistas Asociados, a consulting firm here.
Every week since the peso began to fall anew early last month, tugging Mexican stocks with it, a new explanation has emerged from the pits -- worries about third-quarter corporate earnings, political fretting about the Zaptista rebels, whacky rumors about official resignations and military unrest.
At least one common denominator has been widespread disbelief in the Government's projections of 3 percent growth in the gross domestic product and only 20 percent inflation in 1996, which Mr. Valenzuela reiterated today. Many private economists do not believe that Mexico will show sustained growth before the end of next year.
"It is not that the Government omitted the obvious; it's that there is no obvious," one economist, Jonathan Heath, said. "The markets have seen that there is no magic solution around to give us growth right away, and we're stuck with a muddling-through policy."
This week, conservative critics in the United States warned that the Mexican central bank was expanding the money supply too quickly and further undermining the peso. The bank was obliged to respond with a statement showing that the increase it initiated on Oct. 27 was a long-planned move to anticipate regular year-end increases in demand.
Official reserves dipped late in October, prompting market jitters, but recovered by last Friday, increasing $593 million in one week, to $14.1 billion -- more than enough to cover Government obligations.
Last spring, President Clinton arranged nearly $50 billion of international credit for Mexico to prop up the peso, of which $20 billion came from the United States. The Mexican Government has borrowed $12.5 billion of the American credit line, and repaid $700 million of it, meaning that it still has the right under the agreement to borrow up to $8.2 billion more. The Mexican authorities are widely believed to have borrowed relatively little of the remaining lines totaling nearly $30 billion.
Mexico and its foreign investors have become used to forceful leaders like former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a master at constructing an image of strength around his economic programs. But both President Zedillo and Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz have elected to deal with currency instability by ignoring it, at least in public. Neither has referred to it, and both have chosen instead to soldier on with political and economic reforms.
"Apparently, the market needs an even larger injection of general confidence-building measures," said Luis R. Luis, head of emerging-market debt research at Scudder, Stevens & Clark in Boston.

HEADLINE: Court Panel Says Foreigners Share Rights of Free Speech

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8

 BODY:
In a case fraught with implications for international relations as well as constitutional law, a three-judge Federal panel ruled today that foreigners in this country have the same right to free speech as American citizens.
Civil liberties lawyers called the ruling perhaps the most significant challenge to date of the 43-year-old McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, which was nurtured by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and passed at a time of great public concern over communism. Over the years the law has been used to bar several prominent Marxist authors and intellectual dissidents from visiting the United States. 
 "It's a landmark decision," Mark Rosenbaum, legal director of the Los Angeles office of the American Civil Liberties Union, said of today's ruling by the panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco. "It means that when the Constitution talks about rights for all people, it means what it says. There's not a visa check on the First Amendment."
David Cole, a professor at Georgetown University Law Center and a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights, who argued the case on appeal, said: "This is a great day for all immigrants in this country. The court's decision means that immigrants can speak and associate as freely as citizens and that they need not fear deportation for their political views."
A spokesman for the Justice Department said tonight that the department had not yet been notified of the court's decision and could not comment on it.
Today's ruling arose from the case of seven Palestinians and a Kenyan who were arrested at gunpoint in 1987 in Southern California and ordered deported by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The defendants, who became known as the L.A. 8, were originally charged with subversion under a section of the McCarran-Walter act that prohibits foreigners in the United States from promoting world communism.
The immigration service based its decision on the grounds that the eight supported the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Marxist faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization that has claimed responsibility for airline hijackings in the 1970's. All eight are avowed Palestinian nationalists but deny being members of the Popular Front.
Most of the eight were admitted to the United States on student visas. After their arrest, they were taken into custody by the immigration service and held in maximum security for nearly three weeks.
Civil liberties groups protested the arrests and said the Reagan Administration was using the guise of national security and employing the McCarthy-era law to deport people with no personal history of violent acts. Among the organizations defending the eight immigrants' right to free speech were the civil liberties union and the American Jewish Committee.
In its original complaint, the Government argued that each defendant belonged to "an organization that causes to be written, circulated, distributed, published or displayed, written or printed matter advocating or teaching economic, international and governmental doctrines of world Communism."
The defendants argued that they were being selectively prosecuted. In court documents, they noted, that the Government did not seek to deport other similarly situated aliens aligned with organizations that the United States supported.
The ruling today rejected in the broadest terms the immigration services' efforts to deport the eight, saying "because we are a nation founded by immigrants," the First Amendment free speech provisions are "especially relevant to our attitude toward current immigrants who are a part of our community."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1995

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about an appeals court ruling on the free speech rights of foreigners in this country included a Jewish organization incorrectly among defenders of the rights of eight immigrants who were ordered deported because of their support for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. A detailed account of the immigrants' case was published in 1987 in Present Tense magazine, formerly published by the American Jewish Committee; the committee did not come to the defense of the eight.
