HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Frugality that could backfire: cutting U.S. research subsidies.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
CONGRESSIONAL Republicans are putting Government on a diet. But how much of the weight to be lost will be fat?
Take the case of science and technology. Few areas of Federal spending can be as easily justified as basic research, where investments are too risky for most companies and the fruits of their efforts cannot be protected by patents. Yet according to President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, the Republican budget resolution would cut research financing by 30 percent over the next seven years. 
 Nothing would be lost, of course, if that 30 percent would otherwise have gone to what Roger Noll, an economist at Stanford University, dismisses as "pyramid building" -- Big Science projects with little social value. But that is not how the system seems to work. More likely, Mr. Noll suggests, the money will come from programs with the weakest political constituents -- typically the ones that generate the highest returns for the economy.
Of the $173 billion the National Science Foundation estimates was spent on research and development in 1994, $62 billion came from the Federal Government. And of the $62 billion, 58 percent went to what the foundation classified as basic research and 35 percent to applied research as opposed to development.
The categories are a bit arbitrary: research and development can range from the abstract (what is the weight of a neutrino?) to the practical (what lubricant will keep a machine gun from jamming in a sandstorm?). But the underlying logic seems quite sensible to most economists.
In general it pays Government to support research and development because, as a half-dozen studies have confirmed, the total return to the investment averages 50 percent annually. And since the economic spillovers are very large -- one's invention will almost inevitably produce windfalls for others -- private businesses lack adequate incentives to create productivity-enhancing technology unless they are subsidized.
More specifically, economists suggest, it pays to put a disproportionate amount of the Federal effort into basic research, where there is little chance of an appropriable commercial payoff and the difference between the social rate of return and the return to a private business is likely to be greatest. Expecting AT&T to invent the transistor was a stretch; asking it to spend stockholder money to investigate the origins of the universe would be a joke.
Despite the enthusiasm for research and development in the past, Zvi Griliches, an economist at Harvard, says that the consensus for spending huge sums on basic and applied research (in contrast to commercial development) is fragile.
With the end of an era in which every expenditure could be justified in the name of competition with the Soviet Union, the coalition of businesses, government labs and university-based scientists that had supported a big Federal research budget fell to squabbling over thinner slices from a shrinking pie. Meanwhile, Mr. Griliches says, companies have become less willing to pick up the slack in their own labs: competition has driven once-fat companies like AT&T and I.B.M. out of research unlikely to generate quick profits.
To bolster support for holding the line on Government R & D, the Clinton Administration has evoked the specter of Japanese competition. While America is cutting basic research, Japan is increasing it: nonmilitary research financed by the Japanese Government is expected to exceed American spending for the first time in 1997. And if the Republicans have their way, Japanese spending will be two-thirds greater in 2000.
That does not impress Mr. Griliches, who sees the potential for "free riding" on Japan's scientific endeavors in the next decade, just as Japan has ridden on America's efforts in the past. "We'd be better off if someone else did it," he said.
But America is going to keep spending money on research. And there is broad concern that politics will cut the quality of the research and development financed by Washington along with the dollars going into it. Mr. Noll offers the example of NASA's space station, which will apparently survive the budget cuts albeit with reduced financing. "All the money will end up in hardware," he predicted, with little or nothing left for the research that was the rationale for putting hundreds of tons of equipment into orbit.
Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has yet another worry. The Administration is proud of its record in supporting pre-commercial development, as it did with the Internet. And Mr. Stiglitz fears that lessons in how to get a bang for a buck will be lost in the rush to shrink the research role. The better the Government is at allocating subsidies, he suggests, the harder it is to sustain support for them. "Nobody has a guarantee of subsidies in the new world of competition for subsidies," he said.

HEADLINE: Chip Makers Bolstered by Strong Report On Orders

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry displayed surprising strength in a report today, with its leading indicator rebounding beyond analyst expectations and easing Wall Street's fears that the technology boom might be crumbling.
The Semiconductor Industry Association reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.18 in October, reversing a brief decline to 1.15 in September from August's 1.17 and from July's record of 1.23. 
 The book-to-bill ratio compares orders with shipments: a number more than one indicates positive growth, and a ratio of 1.18 indicates that for each $100 of chips shipped during the month, $118 of chips were ordered.
The carefully watched book-to-bill ratio was reported after the stock market closed, but it pleasantly surprised Wall Street, which had been unnerved on Tuesday by news that Cirrus Logic Inc., a maker of customized chips, had lost a big order from the Intel Corporation.
The news sent technology stocks reeling Tuesday. Though many technology issues rebounded today, adding fuel to a strong stock-market rally, semiconductor stocks continued to fall. [Page D12.]
"There's going to be a little bit of sunshine in technology markets tomorrow," said Charles Bouchet, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment bank. "We thought that this was a one-company perturbation, and this book-to-bill number vindicates us."
The one company appears to be Intel's client, Packard Bell Electronics, the nation's fourth-largest maker of personal computers. Packard Bell rushed to prominence last fall after it picked up a decisive edge over other computer makers by slicing its prices on PC's used in homes.
Now with PC makers like Compaq Computer and AST Research sharpening their emphasis on lower-priced products, it appears that Packard Bell may be in danger of giving up some market share from the last Christmas season. Such competition means that the demand for chips for the personal computer industry is at least likely to remain stable.
Most analysts said today that the stock market had overreacted to the Cirrus Logic news, but they also said they were impressed by the breadth of the strength in the semiconductor industry that the latest month's book-to-bill number represents.
The latest report also revised upward the September ratio, to 1.15 from an earlier estimate of 1.11.
The association, a trade group based in San Jose, Calif., forecast that the North American market would grow 40.2 percent, to $47.1 billion, by the end of the year. Moreover, the group's forecast indicates that seasonally adjusted bookings for chips had surged 55.7 percent, to $4.90 billion, from October 1994 bookings of $3.15 billion.
"We were looking to high the 40's and we got 55.7 percent," said Thomas Thornhill 3d, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "It was a little more strength than we had been expecting."
Not only does there seem to be continued strength in PC markets going into the Christmas selling season, but there also seems to be resilience beyond the sector, he said.
"A lot of the electronics companies we talk to that are not tightly tied to the PC market are doing very well in areas as diverse as data communications, telecommunications, consumer electronics and automotive," Mr. Thornhill said. He noted that there are also indications that the PC business is poised to have a solid Christmas season.
The semiconductor industry has been among the most sharply cyclical. In recent years, however, as new markets for microelectronic consumer products have opened, the industry has been sheltered from downturns. The semiconductor industry has recorded book-to-bill ratios exceeding 1.10 every month this year.
Mr. Bouchet of Hambrecht & Quist said that a rich variety of consumer markets were emerging which could create fresh demand for chips.
"The Internet is going to create a tremendous demand for higher-speed communications in the home," he said. "We're looking forward to I.S.D.N. digital telephone communications and cable modems going into the home. There's a lot of pent-up demand that has yet to surface." I.S.D.N. refers to integrated services digital network technology, which allows voice and computer data to be transmitted over the same phone line simultaneously.
A wild card affecting forecasts of future demand for personal computers has been the different assessments of how quickly Windows 95, the Microsoft Corporation's new PC operating system, will be adopted and whether it will lead to a wave of purchases of the new hardware needed to provide more horsepower to run the program.
Analysts said the inventory of computers pre-loaded with Windows 95 was relatively lean going into the Christmas season.

HEADLINE: W. M. Rountree, 78, A U.S. Ambassador From 1959 to 1973

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
William M. Rountree, who served as a United States ambassador in Asia, Africa and Latin America from 1959 to 1973, died on Friday in Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 78 and lived in Gainesville.
He had been under treatment for cancer, family members said. 
 Mr. Rountree came to diplomacy by way of the Treasury Department, which lent him as a budget specialist in 1941 to the Lend-Lease Administration, a vital component of President Roosevelt's efforts to sustain Britain, and later the Soviet Union, against Hitler's onslaught.
He was then chosen by Ambassador Loy Henderson as his principal assistant in Cairo directing United States economic operations in the Middle East. Ambassador Henderson sponsored Mr. Rountree's entry into the Foreign Service, where he soon was given responsibilities for economic and political affairs in the Middle East, South Asia and Africa.
Mr. Rountree became a close aide of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. As an Assistant Secretary of State, Mr. Rountree was deeply involved in the 1956 Suez crisis and in the 1958 unrest in Lebanon.
He was appointed Ambassador to Pakistan in 1959, to the Sudan in 1962, to South Africa in 1965 and to Brazil in 1970. He retired in 1973.
Mr. Rountree was born in Swainsboro, Ga. He earned a bachelor's degree and then a law degree by attending night classes at Columbus University in Washington. Columbus later became the Catholic University Law School.
He is survived by his wife of 49 years, the former Suzanne McDowall; a daughter, Susan Hanes of Chicago; two sisters, Mary Roberts of Decatur, Ga., and Sara Thomason of New Orleans, and two grandsons.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William M. Rountree. (Associated Press, 1956)

HEADLINE: A Voyage to Bedlam and Part Way Back;
Yale law Graduate, a Schizophrenic, Is Encumbered by an Invisible Wheelchair

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The most interesting feature of Michael B. Laudor's resume can only be glimpsed between the lines. Sprinkled among the stellar nuggets of his life, from graduating summa cum laude from Yale University in three years to being awarded a coveted postdoctoral associateship at Yale Law School, are references to his work as a mental-health advocate and a consultant on ethics in psychiatric research.
Mr. Laudor, 32 and by all accounts a genius, is a schizophrenic who emerged from eight months in a psychiatric unit at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center to go to Yale Law School. His success is about many things: the efficacy of new drugs in treating mental illness, the support of family, friends and colleagues and the steely refusal of a young man who became very sick at age 24 to be capsized by his disease. 
 But shadowing his progress is always the question whether to reveal himself as a person with schizophrenia, the most common major mental illness -- afflicting 1 in 100 people -- and the most disabling.
"Some people at Yale Law School told me not to tell anyone because mental illness is a career killer," he said. "They won't let you work in law firms, they won't let you work as a professor."
Mr. Laudor is now looking for a job as a law professor in the New York area. After finishing his postdoctoral work last year, he avoided saying why he never clerked for a judge or worked in a big law firm. The truth was that he could not handle the pressure and long hours. But he told interviewers such work would not offer him enough intellectual stimulation, an answer he concedes was "incredibly arrogant-sounding." He got no offers.
This year, he is telling schools about his illness, even highlighting his involvement in mental health. The reaction is mixed. One interviewer asked if he was violent, which Mr. Laudor said reflected a common and painful stereotype. Another said, only half-jokingly, that Mr. Laudor's self-awareness would be refreshing, since a half dozen faculty members should probably be treated for a mental disorder.
On the outside, Mr. Laudor, who divides his time between his apartment in Riverdale in the Bronx and his mother's house in New Rochelle, N.Y., seems composed. Tall, with fine features and big round glasses, he is charming and well dressed and makes the right amount of eye contact. As he quotes from Virgil's "Aeneid" and talks about synapses and dendrites with the ease of a neurologist, the pyrotechnics of his intellect are on full display.
Yet underneath, the schizophrenia and the side effects from the risperidone, the medication he takes to keep the psychosis in check, are percolating. "I feel that I'm pawing through walls of cotton and gauze when I talk to you now," he said. "I'm using 60 or 70 percent of my effort just to maintain the proper reality contact with the world."
Dubbing himself a "flaming schizophrenic," Mr. Laudor said that his decision to make his illness public and work closely with others with mental disabilities was a political and religious one. He is chairman of the Westchester Consumer Empowerment Center, part of the nonprofit Westchester Independent Living Center in White Plains, and a consultant to the New York State Psychiatric Institute in Manhattan.
 
'I Can Be A Role Model'
"I am a religious person, and there is a notion in Judaism of tikkun olam, or to heal the world, and we are all, as a nation of priests, called upon to do our part to heal the world," he said. "People with schizophrenia are negated constantly, and I can be a role model. I can stand up and say I am a person with schizophrenia who has been a senior editor of The Yale Law Review, who is a reasonable candidate to be a law professor.
"And if I am not doing that, I will be doing something else of value to society."
Schizophrenia is often marked by a break with reality, paranoia, hallucinations, agitation, withdrawal, blunted emotions and diminished functioning. Some people do not respond to medication, and many do not have the constancy of support that Mr. Laudor has had from friends, relatives and a talented psychiatrist.
Yet others do recover, or struggle through their symptoms to live independently and hold jobs.
"If somebody in a white coat tells you you have a terrible disorder and you're never going to get better, chances are a whole group of people are going to buy off on that and it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy," said Dr. Courtenay M. Harding, a psychologist who is associate director of programs for public psychiatry at the University of Colorado School of Medicine.
Dr. Harding has studied 269 severely ill patients discharged from the back wards of a Vermont mental hospital in the late 1950's. In the community, the patients, half of them schizophrenic, were given therapy, social support and job opportunities. Two-thirds of the patients "improved considerably or had fully recovered" 25 years after discharge, according to the study, published in 1987 in The American Journal of Psychiatry.
Growing up in New Rochelle, Mr. Laudor was a standout from an early age. He often cut classes to play jazz guitar but got A's anyway. He read "Ulysses" and "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich." He scored so high on the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test that he was chosen to take part in the prestigious summer program of the Telluride Association in Ithaca, N.Y.
Mr. Laudor breezed through Yale in three years, using the credits the university gave him for the advanced placement courses he took in high school. He had never been happier. The creativity and intelligence that made him different in high school let him fit right in at Yale.
His first job after college was with Bain & Company, a management consulting firm in Boston. His dream was to make enough money in 10 years so he could support himself writing fiction. But after several months, he experienced what he now thinks was his first brush with illness. He thought his phone lines at work were tapped.
He left abruptly and moved to an apartment in his hometown overlooking Long Island Sound to begin writing. For a while, things seemed to get better. But in 1987, his first psychotic break occurred after a confluence of traumas: his grandfather's death, a breakup with a woman and rejections of his short stories.
He began to imagine that some musicians he jammed with once a week were part of a cult. Then he began to hear bells in the night, and embellishing a line from Psalm 130 about "watchmen for the morning," thought his neighbors were ringing bells to keep watch for the dawn outside his bedroom window.
Schizophrenia usually hits in late adolescence or early adulthood and can retard social development. In Mr. Laudor's case, onset of the disease in his mid-20's probably worked to his advantage, since he had already acquired knowledge and skills and reached emotional maturity. Mental illness runs deep on his father's side of the family.
After seeing a series of psychiatrists, he was hospitalized at Columbia-Presbyterian in upper Manhattan, where he received a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, a type of schizophrenia that also involves depression. It was a harrowing eight months filled with torturous hallucinations, but it was also the beginning of his recovery, thanks in part to antipsychotic medication.
 
A 26th Birthday 'Crying on My Bed'
"Everyone around me was screaming lunacy, and at first I got worse and worse," he said. "My reality was that at any moment they would surgically cut me to death without any anesthesia. I spent my 26th birthday there crying on my bed."
But he had visitors: friends, cousins, parents, rabbis. "I was afraid of them because I was so paranoid," he said, "but it was still a link with reality that filtered through to the subconscious mind."
The next stop was Futura House, a halfway house for the mentally ill in White Plains, where Mr. Laudor went to a day program at St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison. He received one-on-one, family, group and art therapy. His hallucinations and paranoia became manageable.
The people at St. Vincent's said he was well enough to handle a job and suggested Macy's.
"They saw me as a very high-functioning schizophrenic but not a very high-functioning person, and what high-functioning schizophrenics can do is limited," he said bitterly. "I could aspire to working a register at Macy's."
His father, Charles, accompanied him to Macy's at Herald Square to observe a cashier in action. She was besieged by snippy customers, and Mr. Laudor's father predicted that he would be back in the hospital in six months if he took the job. Instead, his father urged Michael to go to Yale Law School, where he had applied just before becoming ill.
Guido Calabresi, dean of the law school, set the tone for the next three years. The dean told him that he was in a sort of invisible wheelchair and that he would place ramps wherever needed.
 
Few Classmates Knew of His Illness
He told only a small number of classmates that he had schizophrenia. When his fingers stiffened from the medication, they typed for him, and when his vision blurred, another side effect, they read to him. "I went to the most supportive mental health care facility that exists in America: the Yale Law School," he said.
Far from knowing that Mr. Laudor had a severe mental illness, the other students were somewhat in awe. "There were two people in our class who were far and away much more brilliant than everyone else, and Michael was one of them," said Diana Jarvis, a corporate lawyer in Manhattan who went to law school with Mr. Laudor.
By the end of law school, Mr. Laudor had so impressed his professors that they asked him to join the school as an associate. For two years, he did research, published articles and attended faculty workshops. When it was over, in spring 1994, he applied for teaching jobs at law schools in the New York area, wanting to stay close to his family and doctor.
But lacking experience, he got no nibbles. He sank into a depression, which coincided with his father's entering the hospital with prostate cancer. The depression was treated, and Mr. Laudor devoted the next year to his father, an economics professor at Adelphi University who died six weeks ago.
Now, he is once again sending out resumes. Those who know him well are guardedly optimistic.
"I think somebody who has the abilities Michael does should have an easier time than many because he is so talented," said Mr. Calabresi, now a United States circuit judge in New Haven. "He is a brilliant young person who has conquered what is always difficult -- an illness -- but has conquered it extraordinarily well."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael B. Laudor, a schizophrenic, at Yale Law School. He said he uses "60 or 70 percent of my effort just to maintain the proper reality contact with the world." (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Both Sides Stiffen Lines In Showdown On U.S. Debt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration and Congress danced toward the deadline for national default, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin always knew he had a few tricks up his sleeve to keep the finances of the United States afloat.
Even if the Republicans in Congress failed to act, he could tinker with the way the Government invests in two huge trust funds, and play other accounting games that could keep the Government from defaulting for the first time in 200 years. 
 Now, Republicans have come up with a plan Mr. Rubin finds even more unthinkable than default: the House is on the verge of passing a bill that would briefly raise the debt limit, but only if President Clinton agrees to strip away the Treasury department's ability to maneuver after that extension expires in mid-December. The political motive is clear: the Republicans want to force Mr. Clinton to sign their budget, or eventually be the man who pulls the trigger on sending the country into default.
It is a game that Mr. Clinton's aides insist he will not play. Mr. Rubin, who has been at the center of the arguments with Speaker Newt Gingrich over the issue, has said repeatedly in recent days that he will advise Mr. Clinton to veto a debt extension now -- before the Republican budget is ready -- rather than tie his hands in a fight over a veto next month.
A senior Treasury official, told reporters today that the Republicans were "greasing the skids toward default" by denying the Treasury the ability to maneuver.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said: "There is no backdoor way for them to write a budget that's unacceptable for the President."
But the Republicans, too, are holding firm."Our members believe they came here as a majority to balance the budget and quit borrowing from our children and grandchildren," Mr. Gingrich said. "And they are seeing a White House which refuses to negotiate."
Sorting out the bluster from the reality over this issue has never been easy, and even now Republicans seem divided over how far to push their effort to tie Mr. Clinton's hands. On the one hand, they want every negotiating advantage they can get; on the other, they do not want to be blamed for a default, which many experts believe could send interest rates up and roil the financial markets.
The markets themselves have, so far at least, viewed all this as a familiar game of chicken. There is a widespread assumption that the issue will be resolved before Nov. 15, when nearly $25 billion in interest payments must be made to holders of United States securities. The next day, more than $40 billion more in interest and principal comes due.
But the market's assumption is based on past experience, before a Republican majority took control of Congress for the first time in 40 years, and before the debt limit became a symbolic issue for Republican freshmen determined to diminish Government.
There are hints that the game has changed considerably. The question is whether both sides will refuse to blink and send the United States into what would presumably be a brief default on its obligations. Some Republican supporters on Wall Street have said that such a default might be acceptable, particularly if it forced the White House to agree to greater deficit reduction.
The main impetus for the restrictions on the debt has come from the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Bill Archer. Under a debt-limit extension he pushed through on Tuesday night, the Government could borrow an extra $67 billion, enough to take it through early December. But the bill, in its current form, would require the Treasury to lower the debt limit to $4.8 trillion, or $100 billion less than the current level, in mid-December.
The bill goes to the House floor tomorrow, and other conservatives are hoping to put additional items on it there, perhaps including the elimination of the Commerce Department. President Clinton has already vowed to veto any bill that eliminates the department.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Is Selling Vista Hotel

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Stepping up efforts to turn over some assets to private companies, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has reached a deal to sell the New York Vista Hotel in the World Trade Center to the Host Marriott Corporation, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
The agreement, which the authority's board is to vote on today, is the latest and biggest move in recent years by the authority to shed businesses that are not related to its core areas: transportation and commerce. The authority is overseen by two Republican Governors, George E. Pataki and Christine Todd Whitman, who have cut its budget, causing large-scale layoffs. 
 Senior officials at the authority declined to comment yesterday on the sale of the Vista, but one person familiar with the deal said the price was about $140 million. Nick Hill, a spokesman for Host Marriott, which owns 88 hotels, mostly in the United States, also declined to comment.
Governor Pataki's office yesterday released a copy of a letter he had sent to the authority's board, urging it to approve the sale of the Vista at its meeting today. "It is my belief that the people of New Jersey and New York will benefit from the port divesting itself of ancillary activities," Mr. Pataki wrote.
The sale comes at a favorable time for the authority. The hotel industry in New York City is recovering from a prolonged slump and hotels are being snapped up at the highest prices in years.
The authority began exploring whether to put the 820-room Vista on the market last year after it had spent $65 million on renovations and repairs to the hotel from the terrorist bombing at the World Trade Center in February 1993. The attack closed the hotel for more than 20 months.
The Port Authority bought the Vista from the Kuo Corporation for $78 million in 1989, when it was also expanding into such economic-development ventures as industrial parks. But in recent years, authority officials have begun to question such projects, arguing that government should not be dabbling in real estate or hotels.
That includes the World Trade Center itself, which the authority built in the early 1970's. The authority will soon receive a report from an investment bank on whether it should sell all or part of the trade center. And it recently sold parts of its industrial parks in Yonkers and Elizabeth, N.J.
The authority's new executive director, George J. Marlin, has repeatedly vowed to concentrate on improving service at its core holdings, including the region's three major airports, the PATH commuter railway, six bridges and tunnels and marine terminals on New York Harbor.
Kathleen A. Donovan, the chairwoman of the authority, would not discuss the pending sale of the Vista specifically, but she emphasized that the authority no longer had any interest in operating hotels.
"The Port Authority has some wonderful opportunities, but running a hotel doesn't have to be one of them," she said.
Anthony E. Shorris, who resigned earlier this year as first deputy executive director of the authority, said that even before the bombing at the trade center, the authority considered selling the hotel.
"The port took over the hotel when there was a business dispute going on between the then-current owner and the management company," he said. "The port stepped into the breach at that time, whether wisely or unwisely in retrospect, but certainly it became clear over time that the right thing to do was fix it up and make it ready for sale."

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Banks Again On Risks of Lax Lending

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Repeating his warnings against lax lending practices, the Clinton Administration's top bank regulator issued a new study today that suggested that the offers of credit cards and home equity loans pouring into the nation's mailboxes may indicate a worrisome willingness to ignore risks.
The figures show that banks have relaxed their credit standards for some consumer lending, said the regulator, Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency. 
 While there have been a few signs in recent days of a slowing in consumer borrowing, heavy spending financed with loans has underpinned much of the current economic expansion. Economists have been divided over whether to worry about how many of these loans will be repaid or about what happens if the lending stops.
Bank regulators have been more worried about the effect on bank balance sheets if many risky loans are not repaid the next time the economy goes into a slump. Banks are allowing borrowers to post less collateral, pay smaller initial fees and spread their repayments over more years, particularly for home equity loans, according to a survey of the Federal examiners for the nation's 40 largest federally chartered banks.
"I continue to be concerned that in their efforts to be competitive banks should not lose sight of the effect of new lending on the risk in their portfolios," Mr. Ludwig said in his warning to the chief executives of the nation's 3,000 federally chartered banks, which was dated Nov. 7 and released today with the survey.
Mr. Ludwig ordered the study of bank lending practices last April, when he issued his first strong warning to bankers against making loans to risky applicants. Today's review covered lending during the 12-month period ended last May; aides to Mr. Ludwig said they did not have more recent information.
But private analysts said that there was considerable evidence that banks continued to pursue low credit risks with zeal as they strive to make as many loans as possible.
"More banks are making it easier for the less creditworthy to borrow," said Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, a weekly newsletter based in North Palm Beach, Fla. "There is internal pressure within institutions to drive up their loans and increase their revenues."
Mr. Heady said that Mr. Ludwig's warning to bankers last April had showed little effect. "If anything, we've seen a loosening of lending standards thus far this year," he said.
But today's survey and comments by other regulators suggested that banks had avoided lowering their standards for large loans to companies and other big borrowers. "Credit quality has been holding up very well, and in fact is somewhat improving," said William McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a telephone interview this afternoon.
Analysts and politicians alike played down the possibility that risky loans would cause bank failures in the next economic downturn, in turn draining the industry's deposit insurance fund and forcing another bailout by taxpayers. The concerns that Mr. Ludwig expressed today "must be understood in the context of the positive news that American banks are in an unprecedentedly strong position to provide capital to American business, and the Bank Insurance Fund has never been better capitalized," said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the House Banking Committee.
Today's survey found that Federal examiners believed 19 of the 40 big banks had "eased somewhat" their lending standards for home equity loans.
By contrast, only nine banks appeared to have eased their credit standards for commercial and industrial loans, while 15 banks were exposed to less risk in that category.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Mark, But Slips Back in Yen Trading

 BODY:
Despite another tumble in the Mexican peso, the dollar advanced against the German mark yesterday, which weakened because of a stronger French franc and hints of lower interest rates in Germany.
But the dollar fell against the Japanese yen. Currency traders sold dollars after a report from Japan showed that investors there were not sending as much money overseas as was thought, thus indicating less of a demand for dollars. 
 In New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 102.58 yen from 103 on Tuesday. It rose to 1.4216 marks from 1.4160 marks and to 1.1465 Swiss francs from 1.1389 francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5794 from $1.5801.
The Mexican peso fell as low as 7.82 to the dollar yesterday, surpassing a previous intraday low of 7.750 to the dollar on March 9. It settled at 7.80 pesos to the dollar, compared with 7.475 late Tuesday.
Indications of further cuts in German interest rates hurt the mark. A key short-term rate on two-week repurchase agreements dropped yesterday, and Hans-Jurgen Krupp, a Bundesbank policy maker, said further rate cuts were possible.
Also yesterday, the French franc continued to strengthen against the mark after a shake-up in the French Cabinet.
The currency markets received more details yesterday about the United States' purchases of dollars last summer. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that American monetary authorities had bought a total of $1.53 billion, paying in Japanese yen and German marks.
At its quarterly press briefing yesterday and in a separate report on the period to Congress, the New York Fed said the interventions took place on July 7, Aug. 2 and Aug. 15.
On July 7, the New York Fed's foreign-exchange trading desk bought $333.3 million with yen, in coordination with the Japanese central bank. On Aug. 2, again in concert with Japan's monetary authorities, the United States bought $500 million with yen.
On Aug. 15, the New York Fed said its trading desk bought $300 million with yen and $400 million with marks in an operation in the London, Frankfurt and New York markets. This operation was coordinated with both the Japanese and German monetary authorities, the New York Fed said.
All three operations were confirmed at the time by the Treasury Department.
"At the start of the period, the mood of the market seemed to be that the dollar was undervalued," Peter R. Fisher, executive vice president of the New York Fed, said at the press briefing.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Rise On Optimism Over Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices moved sharply higher yesterday, bolstered by optimism that an agreement on the Federal budget and debt limit could soon be reached.
The rally was also fueled by technical factors, including short-covering. 
 Yesterday was the first time in four sessions that prices rose. Buying was prompted in part after the House Ways and Means Committee late Tuesday adopted a plan to raise the debt limit from $4.9 trillion to $4.967 trillion, but only until Dec. 12.
While the Republican-controlled Congress and the Clinton Administration are still far apart on a debt limit agreement, the fact that Congress was taking some action on the issue raised expectations in the market that an accord would soon be reached, which could set the stage for another cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 25/32 to 10813/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.25 percent, from 6.30 percent on Tuesday.
Prices were also bolstered by purchases by the Federal Reserve, which was in the market to buy bills of all maturities. The operation, known as a bill pass, injects reserves permanently into the banking system, but does not signal any change in interest rate policy. The last pass was on May 31, when the central bank bought about $4.5 billion of bills.
Shorter-maturity bills, particularly the six-month and one-year bills, were up substantially because of the Fed's activity.
Traders noted other factors supporting Treasury prices, including a steady dollar and demand from European buyers amid speculation about a cut in German interest rates, which would make American securities more attractive in comparison.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International of San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm, said market participants were reluctant to take large positions yesterday ahead of the Government's report on producer prices, which is due out today.
Expectations that the Producer Price Index would show encouraging news on inflation also forced some investors to cover their short positions, which are in essence bets that prices will fall.
While concerns eased over the budget battle in Washington, the lack of an agreement continued to affect Treasury auctions. The Treasury announced yesterday that it was postponing the one-year bill auction that had tentatively been scheduled for today. The Treasury has already postponed sales of new 3-year notes and 10-year notes.
Few investors expect a default by the Treasury, traders said, which is why the market has shown so much resiliency amid the political fracas.
In other trading, the futures market remained bullish yesterday, said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston. She said the market could support a rally pushing the price of the December bond contract to118 15/32 . "If the market pulls back before reaching this target, it would be a buying opportunity," she said. The December contract closed yesterday at 1187/32 .

HEADLINE: Few to Pursue Claims Against New York Life

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that the vast majority of its three million policyholders who were offered a settlement arising from claims of improper sales practices had decided not to fight the company. An agreement was reached in August by the company and lawyers who had filed class-action lawsuits contending that New York Life had used improper sales activities. Customers who bought life insurance policies with investment features between 1984 and 1992 were offered a choice: They could do nothing, which meant accepting the company's offer, or they could tell the company that they wanted to pursue their grievances before arbitrators hired by the company, or, if they wanted, in court.
Under the settlement, customers who accepted the company's offer can choose between receiving loans with low interest rates or buying additional amounts of life insurance or annuities at prices the company said were lower than its ordinary offerings. Customers who wanted an arbitration hearing or a day in court were required to tell the company by Oct. 31 that they did not want to participate in the agreement. 
 Only about 6,000 customers told the company they wanted to pursue their grievances, while about 450 wrote to object to the terms of the settlement. But many of the objections will be disallowed, said Walter Shur, a consultant to the company, because they were filed by people who did not accept the settlement.
Although the settlement was praised by some regulators and consumer advocates as a reasonable alternative to class-action lawsuits, it was criticized by others, including some customers who said they did not understand their policies and had an equally hard time understanding the company's offer.
Joseph Belth, a professor emeritus of insurance at Indiana University and the author of "Life Insurance: A Consumer's Handbook," was critical of the agreement because the Oct. 31 deadline was not disclosed in the three-page letter announcing the offer and did not appear in the 14-page description of the offer until page 11. He added that it was unfortunate that the court hearing to approve the settlement was set for next Wednesday, or more than two weeks after the deadline for deciding whether to participate.
New York Life officials said the value of their offer to consumers who did not choose to seek arbitration could be as little as $50, and they estimated the total cost of the settlement, including arbitration awards, at $65 million. Law firms handling the class-action lawsuits, led by Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in New York and Arnzen, Parry & Wentz in Covington, Ky., may collect another $22 million if the plan is approved by a judge in New York next week.
"For people who think they were improperly sold a policy, that is what the A.D.R. process is for," Mr. Shur said, referring to alternative dispute resolution, or arbitration, hearings.
For others, who did not feel misled but were upset because the investment returns on the policies fell from double digits in the mid-1980's to 7 percent or lower now, he said the company was making the offer to maintain good will.
The settlement also covers customers who contend that they were improperly sold life insurance as an investment product or that they were persuaded to replace an existing policy with a new one when that was not in their best interest.

HEADLINE: Unwitting in California

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a Californian, I read with interest in your Nov. 7 front-page article that my state is leading the nation in building prisons, and paying prison guards more than schoolteachers. The irony here is obvious. Not only are prison guards now making more than many University of California professors, they will eventually put those professors out of work. 
 Rand Corporation studies show that over the next 25 years, implementing the state's three-strikes law -- heavily supported by the prison guards' union -- will cost the state an outrageous $5.5 billion a year. The money must come from somewhere, and because much of California's budget is tied up in entitlements or other mandated spending, higher education is going to suffer the most.
Californians may have unwittingly replaced the university system with the prison system when they voted for the three-strikes law last year.
 
LORI DORFMAN
Oakland, Calif., Nov. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dow Chemical Gets Go-Ahead In East Germany

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Giving the green light to one of the largest state subsidies in Europe for a collapsing enterprise, the European Commission approved a plan today to allow the German Government to give the Dow Chemical Company $6.77 billion to rejuvenate a giant eastern German petrochemical complex.
The subsidy, approved earlier in the year by Bonn, is by far the largest bailout engineered under the vast privatization program for the former East Germany. 
 But the ultimate fate of the deal to revive the Buna plant in the eastern German city of Schkopau is uncertain, since the commission reduced the amount of the bailout that the German Government could give the American chemical company by $1.08 billion. Dow and the German Government agreed in April to a $7.8 billion bailout package.
The news produced a chilly response from Dow's European headquarters in Zurich, where officials said they had not seen any documents on the decision from the European Commission in Brussels.
The deal is the second biggest ever approved by Brussels, after the $9.3 billion French Government bailout earlier this year of Europe's largest bank, Credit Lyonnais. Substantial aid packages to private industry are subject to commission approval to insure that no government gives undue competitive advantages to any one company.
Dow, based in Midland, Mich., has a big operation in Europe and wants to expand eastward. "This is a very important investment for Dow, since it gives them assets at below replacement cost in the area they are working very hard to build up -- Eastern European commodity chemicals," said Paul Raman, chemicals analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York.
Mr. Raman calculated that the acquisition could add up to 11 percent to Dow's profits, lifting the company's earnings by $1 a share. He also said that Dow was acquiring assets at about $550 million less than it would have cost to build a new plant.
"We are not in a position yet to comment on the specifics or what impact this would have on the privatization plan," said Marina Ashanin, a Dow spokeswoman. "Until we see the details and see the specific conditions that have been included in the approval, it is difficult to know whether it is on balance a positive or a negative."
However, Mr. Raman said he did not think that the changes imposed by the European Commission would kill the transaction, especially factoring in the lucrative market that could open up for Dow.
"It will make it not as attractive, but I still think they will do the deal," he said.
In many ways the Buna privatization is a landmark, since it represents not only the last huge privatization that the German Government will undertake in what was the German Democratic Republic, but also one of the costliest efforts by Bonn to preserve jobs and a viable industry in the area that previously had the largest chemical center of the Communist bloc.
Although the plant is commonly referred to as Buna, its official name is BSL Polyolefinverbund G.m.b.H., and includes the giant Buna chemical complex at Schkopau, a steam cracker at Bohlen some 30 miles south, and the Leune polyethylene plant in Merseburg, 20 miles to the west.
The Buna plant was originally a key factory of the I. G. Farben chemical complex, an industrial and research pillar of Hitler's Third Reich. The German Government's plan to spend billions on the bailout has not been without controversy. For example, Dow has agreed to maintain 2,200 jobs at the three sites and will pay heavy penalties if employment falls below 1,800. But that is below current employment levels, and only a tiny fraction of employment during Communist times, when it reached as high as 30,000.
The plan has upset tens of thousands of former workers who have lost jobs in an area where unemployment approaches 30 percent. Given the bleak outlook for new jobs, workers often say they long for the old days when all were guaranteed work despite punishing levels of pollution and grim working conditions. Indeed, the poor condition of the eastern German plants and their environmental problems have deterred many chemical companies from acquiring them.
Another contentious issue is the generous terms of the deal, which were kept secret during the negotiations with the German privatization officials. The magnitude of the bailout -- and thus the ultimate cost to the German taxpayer -- was not known until earlier this year when it was made public by the European Commission.
Under the the agreement, Dow will buy an 80 percent stake in the Buna complex, with the promised investment of $700 million in plant expansion by 2000, and an additional $880 million after that.
The German Government will keep a 20 percent stake, but Dow has the option to buy that stake by 2000.
Dow officials say they see the investment as opening a huge potential market. It gives the chemical giant a large plant close to the Eastern European markets as well as close to the Russian market, which they predict will expand in their demand for petrochemical products, particularly chlorine and ethylene products.
In taking over Buna, Dow also gets employees who are familiar with the business ways of the former Communist countries and who have a wide network of business associates there, as well as the ability to speak Russian and other Eastern European languages.
"They know the people who we want to have as our customers tomorrow," Ms. Ashanin said.

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
Briton, 34, Is Running For Money, Not Love

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
If he wins the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Paul Evans of Britain will have made an astounding progression from the unemployment line to the finish line. Seven years ago, he was working in a shoe factory outside of Norwich, England. His running career began, not out of an obsession, but out of economic necessity. He got laid off.
"What am I good at?" he asked himself when the Bally shoe factory closed in 1988. 
 Evans had played soccer in a semi-professional league, and while he said he could run effortlessly for 90 minutes, "My problem began when someone gave me the ball."
So soccer was out of the question. But running was an intriguing idea. He was 27 at the time and had jogged to get in shape for soccer. There was money to be made in road races. Why not give it a shot?
Two years after he began training seriously, Evans entered the 1990 New York City Marathon but suffered from dehydration and dropped out after 18 miles. In 1993, he finished seventh in 2 hours 13 minutes 36 seconds. Last April, he placed fifth in the London Marathon, lowering his personal best by five seconds to 2:10.31 -- among the 20 fastest times in the world this year.
On Sunday, Evans will attempt to become the first Briton -- and non-African or Mexican -- to win New York since Steve Jones in 1988. And if the rest of his body is 34, Evans feels his legs are younger in racing years.
"The registration on the car is quite old, but the engine doesn't have many miles," he said yesterday.
Something else Evans feels may be in his favor is the weather. Race organizers are preparing for what could be the coldest New York City Marathon in the race's 26-year history, with the possibility that temperatures will descend into the 40's with a northwest wind of 15 to 20 miles an hour. A cool day, Evans said, may insulate him from dehydration and the warm-weather-thriving Mexicans and Kenyans.
"The colder the better," Evans said. "Just as long as it's not hot."
Until a month ago, he had not planned to run a fall marathon. But he won a 30-kilometer (18.6-mile) cross-country race in Sweden, breaking the course record set by Douglas Wakiihuri of Kenya. After the race, Evans learned that Wakiihuri had set the course record only a month before winning the 1990 New York City Marathon. A seed was planted.
"It got my mind to thinking, if he can do it . . . ," Evans said.
His coach, John Bicourt, contacted New York race officials, and Evans joined the field that includes the 1994 champion, German Silva of Mexico. Already this year, Evans has set personal records from 3,000 meters to the half-marathon. In January, he shaved 50 seconds off Jones's British record for the half-marathon by running 60.09 in Marrakesh, Morocco. He said he would like to run under 2:10 on Sunday.
Thin and blond, Evans spoke with reporters yesterday while wearing sensible penny loafers instead of the standard running shoes. Once a cobbler, always a cobbler.
"It's funny how life works," Evans said. "Losing my job was probably the best thing that ever happened to me. If the factory was still open, I'd probably still be there, making shoes."
He had been an average runner in high school, Evans said, but at 16 or 17, he left to get a job in the shoe factory. Running required two things he didn't possess -- willpower and discipline.
"I had a little money in my pocket, and running looked too much like hard work," Evans said. "Like any youngster, hard work was something I didn't want to know."
After 10 years in the factory, however, Evans was laid off. Or in classic British understatement, his job was made "redundant" when the factory closed. He had a wife and two young sons to support, so Evans took to running.
But training 100 miles a week or more on pavement eventually left him with back pain. Now, he runs through the countryside of rural eastern England and avoids the roads except for racing. He has learned to train the way the Kenyans train, he said, where "your body is your coach and you run according to how you feel."
"It was the best apprenticeship I ever served," Evans said of his days in the shoe factory. "It made me realize how lucky I am. I've seen virtually all the world. I'm making a living doing something I love to do. Ten years in the factory was hard work. The pay wasn't great. I've seen the other side of the coin. When it's raining out and I don't want to run, I think of the factory, and I'm right out the front door."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); KENYA (92%); ENGLAND (91%); UNITED KINGDOM (88%); SWEDEN (79%);

HEADLINE: Cuba's Problem Is Castro, Not U.S. Embargo;
A Week in Havana

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Carl Rosenstein's Nov. 1 letter is a good example of how United States propaganda about Cuba can distort thinking. After a one-week trip to Havana, Mr. Rosenstein concludes there is prostitution everywhere, there is nothing to buy, there is a food shortage and the architecture "is returning to its original state -- sand -- from years of neglect." What's more, he knows about "the state of the society." 
 In coming up with these conclusions after one week, and in saying that the 35-year United States embargo has nothing to do with Cuba's economic crisis, Mr. Rosenstein is mouthing the distortions of the Torricelli-Helms-Mas Canosa troika. He could have written the letter before going to Cuba.
 
SANDRA LEVINSON
Exec. Dir., Center for Cuban Studies
New York, Nov. 3, 1995

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Intervening, Mexico Halts Slide in Peso

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Mexico's central bank stepped in today to stop the plunge of the peso, signaling that it would not allow a speculative frenzy to erode the currency further.
Officials confirmed that the bank had made a peso purchase in the final hour of trading, but did not specify the amount. Traders estimated its value at $200 million, large enough to halt the peso's downward momentum and to turn it around, amid very low volume on the market. The central bank intervened after the peso plunged early in the session below 8 to the dollar, another record low and a psychological threshold. 
 Its move strengthened the peso, pushing it back up to a rate of 7.55 to the dollar at the close of trading here, from 7.80 late Wednesday. The peso has lost more than 15 percent of its value against the dollar since the end of September.
[The rebound bolstered hopes in Washington that the peso's difficulties would not intensify into another international financial crisis. Page D2.]
The Mexican bank's decision to intervene today in the currency market followed its move on Tuesday night to raise interest rates more than 10 percent to make investments in pesos more attractive to buyers. But that did not quell a surge of speculative selling, nor did it attract new buyers, officials said.
"We have to send a message that the exchange rate should not be that high," a Government finance official said. "A desirable byproduct is to punish some speculators. The rate is totally unjustified."
And President Ernesto Zedillo, referring to the peso's current weakness, said, "Sooner or later, those markets will have to give in to the evidence that our economy is on solid ground."
The intervention marked the first time the central bank had entered the market since February. The bank had stayed away to show its determination to let the peso float freely, honoring free-market forces. In recent days, though, the bank has been criticized by economists and investors, who said it had raised interest rates too late to counteract increases in the money supply and a sinking currency.
The Mexican stock market also rebounded today, with the leading index climbing steadily throughout the day to close at 2,311.09, up 3.43 percent.
The currency market was jarred somewhat in the morning by an announcement from a group of private exporting companies that a plan they put forward for a $5 billion joint fund with the Government to stabilize the peso would not be carried out. Both executives and finance officials said the Government was eager to take advantage of the good will and the funds offered by private industry to steady the currency, but needed more time to work out a viable plan.
Mexican business's proposal had been received with dismay by some bankers here and from the United States, who feared that it might lead to veiled Government control of the currency market.
Separately, the Government introduced its bill in Congress today to reform the pension system and promote development by increasing savings. The bill would allow private managers to invest pension savings funds that, for the first time, would be controlled by individual workers.
But officials acknowledged that in the midst of a paralyzing recession, the peso's losses were derailing their statistical calculations for economic recovery programs and for the 1996 budget, which Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz is preparing for announcement by next Wednesday.
Mr. Ortiz gave a preview of the budget at a closed breakfast today with legislators from the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. The Finance Minister insisted that Mexico could expect as much as 6 percent growth by the second half of 1996. Based on that report, the majority leader of the lower house of Congress, Humberto Roque Villanueva, said the proposed budget was balanced and "absolutely austere," equivalent to 17 percent of the gross domestic product and with a spending cut of about 1 percent.
No new taxes were proposed, and increases were for modernization of the state oil company Pemex, important public projects like highways, worker training and other programs to rekindle economic growth.

HEADLINE: Drug Makers' Managed-Care Ties Questioned

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Congressional investigators focusing on competition in the drug industry said yesterday that Merck & Company had profited from the relationship with its Medco drug distribution and managed-care unit in ways that merited close attention from the Federal Trade Commission.
Merck, as well as SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and Eli Lilly & Company, paid billions of dollars over the last two years to acquire managed-care businesses, and securities analysts said the drug makers would have to increase sales of their own products to justify their investments. 
 The F.T.C., prodded by other drug companies, consumer advocates, pharmacists and the National Association of Chain Drugstores, has warned against using the managed-care companies, called pharmaceutical benefits managers, to gain unfair advantages in the market.
The General Accounting Office, in its report released yesterday, said that Medco Containment Services, and in one instance SmithKline's Diversified Pharmaceutical Services unit, had dropped some products that compete with top drugs of the parent companies from the lists of preferred drugs that health plans push their members to use.
G.A.O. officials said they were unable to obtain pricing and marketing information from Medco that would enable the agency to determine whether antitrust violations had occurred.
But the G.A.O., the investigative arm of Congress, said that "the extent to which Medco gave preference to Merck products" was good reason for the Federal Trade Commission to continue to monitor the Merck-Medco merger and similar relationships between manufacturers and the managed care units.
Consumer groups said they hoped that the report would strengthen the resolve of the F.T.C. to examine links such as the Merck-Medco relationship and SmithKline's ties to Diversified. As a condition of approving the merger of Lilly and PCS Health Systems, another big managed-care drug unit, in November 1994, the commission had said it would maintain close scrutiny over that relationship.
The G.A.O. report followed a consent agreement that Merck made last month with 17 state attorneys general, which requires Medco pharmacists to disclose their affiliation with Merck when they telephone physicians to urge them to switch patients to Merck drugs. PCS and Diversified said they would make the same kinds of disclosures.
Kevin Colgan, a Medco spokesman, said, "Our customers understand that we will give preferential status to drugs, including Merck drugs, when it is medically appropriate and when those drugs help our customers reduce their overall costs."
Drug makers whose products were dropped were guarded in their comments, noting that they had other drugs they wanted to sell to the powerful managed-care drug units.
The G.A.O. said 100 million people in the United States were in health plans served by at least 40 pharmaceutical benefits manager companies in 1993. Five big pharmaceutical benefit managers -- Medco, Diversified, PCS, Value Rx and the Prescription Service unit of Caremark International -- had an estimated 80 percent of the business.
While Congress is considered unlikely to act on the G.A.O. report, the Food and Drug Administration is considering whether to make new rules to regulate pharmaceutical benefit managers, known as P.B.M.'s. At a Food and Drug Administration hearing last month, Stephen Stefano, a senior executive of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's biggest drug maker, testified that "manufacturer-owned P.B.M. companies" had issued letters to doctors containing "unsupportable claims" that disparaged Glaxo products.
He said the drug companies, which he did not name, could not make such statements themselves under F.D.A. rules. Mr. Stefano added that Glaxo did not, however, want the F.D.A. to issue new regulations for P.B.M.'s.
In the enormous United States market for cholesterol-lowering drugs, Medco added two Merck products, Mevacor and Zocor, to its list in May 1993, two months before the Merck-Medco merger was announced. This year, Merck-Medco dropped Pravachol -- a competing Bristol-Myers Squibb drug -- which is in the same class of drugs as Mevacor and Zocor.
A fourth entry in that class, Lescol, made by Sandoz Ltd., was never allowed on the Medco list, a Sandoz spokeswoman said. Analysts said Sandoz had introduced Lescol last year at a price that was 49 percent below the prices of the Merck and Bristol-Myers drugs.
Helped by the publication of Merck-sponsored research that showed that Zocor helped reduce mortality rates, Zocor's sales rose 80 percent, to $460 million, in the first nine months of this year, Neil B. Sweig, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman, said. He said combined sales of the four drugs would be $1.94 billion in 1995.
Mr. Colgan said Medco's independent advisory committee determined that Lescol did not offer a "clinical advantage" over Mevacor and Zocor, and that rebates that rewarded customers who used a "bundle" of Medco drugs would eliminate the Lescol price advantage.
He said Pravachol had been dropped from the preferred list because Medco could no longer buy it at a price that offered "economic advantage to Medco's clients" who, he said, could still get Pravachol from Medco if they insisted on doing so.
Last year, Medco also dropped Zestril, a cardiovascular drug that Zeneca Pharmaceuticals, a company based in Britain, sells under license from Merck. Mr. Colgan said that because Zestril was identical to Merck's Prinivil, there was no reason to offer both drugs.
Joel H. Tau, a spokesman for Zeneca, said: "We are well aware that P.B.M.'s have the ability to move market share, either through the exclusion or inclusion of products. And those P.B.M.'s that are owned by drug companies, especially those that operate mail-order divisions, usually have preferred drug programs, which inevitably include the owners' drugs."

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico: Absent From the White House Crisis List

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Peso? What peso? 
 Last winter, a plunge in Mexico's currency threw the Treasury Department into weeks of emergency meetings and crisis planning. This week, the peso has seen its most serious slump since then, but Clinton Administration officials are saying little and doing nothing.
"I haven't been in a room where it has been discussed at all," a senior Administration political operative said.
The inactivity contrasts with the dire warnings issued by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin as President Clinton was pushing a bailout package early this year. But there are good reasons for this autumn's policy -- political and practical.
Listen to any number of Republicans, particularly Patrick J. Buchanan, and it is clear that they think the Mexican bailout is an issue on which the Administration is vulnerable. Mr. Buchanan has based a good bit of his Presidential campaign on attacking the bailout, and is running radio ads in New Hampshire contending that the billions in assistance to Mexico should have been used to offset cuts in Medicare instead.
And in practical terms, there is not much more American officials can do for Mexico. They have already set up lines of credit. Mexico does not appear to be in the same danger of default on its foreign debts that it was last year. Beyond that, there is a domestic budget battle that has lights burning late at the Treasury.
The result has been a policy of benign neglect, and a hope that the problem will go away without becoming any more serious. There was a small sign this afternoon that Mexico might be in control of its latest peso problem, when intervention by the Mexican central bank halted a 4.8 percent drop in the peso and turned it into a 3.4 percent increase by the end of trading.
In several important ways, Mexico's plight is not as dire as it was a year ago. Its reserves of foreign currency, which are needed to prop up the peso's value in international markets, are nearly three times as high as they were when the country was forced to devalue last December. Mexico did not have big lines of credit in place last year and had cut itself off from the International Monetary Fund. And Mexico was faced then with imminent default on nearly $30 billion worth of short-term bonds payable in foreign currencies within a few months.
With international help, Mexico has now paid off all but $2 billion of the short-term bonds. It has replaced them with debts to the United States, the International Monetary Fund and European bond buyers that will not mature for several years. So Mexico can make ends meet with a lot less foreign currency than it needed last year.
There is still some help in reserve. Mexico still has $8.2 billion it can borrow at any time from a Treasury line of credit set up last winter, and an additional $7 billion that it can borrow from a line of credit set up by the International Monetary Fund.
Mexico has also sharply reduced its trade deficit, which was bleeding the country of dollars at a rapid pace last year. As a share of the economy, the Mexican deficit, broadly measured to include investment royalties, was three times as large last year as the United States trade deficit. The peso's steep plunge since then has made foreign goods so expensive in Mexico that imports have slowed to a trickle and the Mexican trade deficit has largely disappeared.
But there are a couple of reasons why the latest drop in the peso could prove more serious than last winter's drop.
The Mexican Government has been forced again to push interest rates above 50 percent to attract investors. That was a heavy blow last winter, when the economy had been growing for several years. It is a heavier burden this year, when the economy is deep in a recession thatsome analysts fear could eventually lead to social unrest.
Mexico has also disappointed investors with its inability to maintain a steady value for the peso. Each sudden plunge makes it all the more difficult to restore foreign investors' faith in the currency.
A senior Treasury official said in an interview tonight that the best hope for Mexico was to keep to its current policies. "In the face of volatility, Mexican officials have re-emphasized the importance of sticking with their monetary and fiscal policies," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. "They have an excellent record maintaining tough economic policies. This is what they need to do."
But even if the peso does not collapse, there could be bad political news for the Clinton Administration. By making American goods more expensive in Mexico, the falling peso widens the American trade deficit there. That will make it still harder for the Administration to cite the North American Free Trade Agreement as a success during next year's election campaign.
Most Congressional Republicans have been reluctant to take advantage of the Administration's predicament, for fear of making Mexico's problems worse and being blamed for them. The exception is Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who said tonight that both countries should stop trying to keep the peso from falling.
"The social fabric of the country is coming apart under the austere conditions," he said of Mexico, adding, "You have the seeds of social turmoil and revolution in place -- now you want to invest money in that system?"

LENGTH: 617 words

HEADLINE: Weakness Shows in Producer Prices and the Job Market

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The fifth straight decline in energy costs helped push producer prices lower in October, and another report released today suggested weakness in the job market. Some analysts said the combination would give the Federal Reserve the latitude to cut interest rates, if needed, to stimulate the economy.
The Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the third drop in five months. The decline was led by energy prices, but even excluding the volatile food and energy categories, the core index showed no increase in prices. 
 In the second report, the department said the number of new claims for unemployment benefits shot up by 9,000 last week, to the highest level since the summer. New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 375,000, the highest level since they totaled 416,000 in the week ended July 15.
Some analysts said the Fed could act at its meeting next week, although others believe it will wait for the resolution of the Federal budget impasse and more economic data later this year.
Many believe that the central bank has achieved its objective of a "soft landing" for the economy -- slow growth without inflation.
"One day soon, the Fed might have to stand back and declare victory," said Eugene Sherman, an economist at M. A. Schapiro & Company in New York.
Prices of finished goods fell in October, and those that contribute to so-called pipeline inflation -- price increases in earlier stages of production -- remained muted.
"At least at the producer level, there are no price pressures in place or materializing," Mr. Sherman said. "Inflation is just not a concern at this time."
Analysts predicted that the Government's report on prices at the consumer level, to be released Wednesday, would show that they also remained under control last month.
"Consumers are still value conscious and selective," said Richard Berner, an economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "They are always shopping for bargains, meaning the retailer has to lure them with incentives."
Consumer prices rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in September, and for the first nine months of 1995, they were rising at a modest annual rate of 2.8 percent.
For the year so far, producer prices have risen even less. They have increased at an annual rate of just 1.4 percent, compared with a 1.7 percent advance in 1994.
Although producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September, the increase was driven by a 1 percent jump in food prices, the result of a summer drought that wilted vegetable harvests. Producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in August.
The Labor Department said food prices held steady in October as vegetable costs fell 19.1 percent, retreating from their 38.6 percent increase a month earlier.
Energy prices dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent, even more than the decline of five-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier. Energy costs have fallen each month since rising six-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Heating oil costs fell 11.1 percent, the steepest drop since a 12.1 percent decline in January. Gasoline prices were down 2.7 percent and natural gas prices were down six-tenths of 1 percent. Electricity costs, however, rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Prices for finished consumer goods other than food and energy increased one-tenth of 1 percent after an advance of three-tenths of 1 percent in September. Household appliances rose four-tenths of 1 percent, and the cost of furniture was up one-tenth of 1 percent.
Automobile prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the department said, reflecting 1996 "quality changes" that added an average of $167.06 to the cost of a car.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Prices" tracks index of finished goods prices, seasonally adjusted, form May 1994 through October 1995. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Early Peso Loss and Budget Fear Drag Down Dollar Against Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen and other currencies, dragged down by early losses of the Mexican peso.
The dollar began to slide against the yen in Tokyo trading overnight, and the resumption this morning of the peso's recent losses hastened the fall. 
 "Anyone with an interest in marks or yen versus the dollar either accelerated their dollar sales or postponed their dollar purchases," said Hubert Pedroli, a foreign-exchange manager at Credit Suisse.
The persistent weakness of Mexico's currency has been slow to affect the dollar, in contrast to last winter when the peso's plunge sideswiped the dollar. A weak peso affects the dollar because of the close economic ties between the two nations.
Yesterday, however, "the peso began having an effect on the dollar in general," Mr. Pedroli said. "The dollar had been weak versus the yen, but not the mark, and this morning it was weaker versus both."
The peso fell as low as 8.2 to the dollar in New York yesterday before the Mexican central bank started buying pesos to push its currency higher. By the end of the day, the peso had rebounded to 7.55 to the dollar, up from 7.80 late Wednesday.
Currency traders in the United States reported that the central bank had spent $200 million to buy pesos at a rate of 7.60 to the dollar. The bank confirmed that it was supporting the currency, but gave few details.
In other trading, the dollar settled at 100.40 yen in New York late yesterday, down from 102.58 yen on Wednesday. It fell to 1.4104 German marks from 1.4216 marks and to 1.1361 Swiss francs from 1.1465 francs. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5794.
The continued battle in Washington over the Federal budget also weighed on the dollar yesterday. Warnings of a debt default by the United States have rattled nerves, mostly among foreign dollar holders, and many are dumping dollars.
One result has been a swing back into yen, which had been shunned by many investors because of Japan's banking crisis and economic slump.
In Asian trading, the yen began to rally against the mark, the Australian dollar and the American dollar.
"It started as unwinding of yen trades put on a few weeks ago," said Paul Farrell, a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank. "There's been a change in perception about where the yen should be trading." That was underscored by a quick plunge in the Australian dollar, which had recently soared against the yen.
