HEADLINE: Price Data Help to Push Stocks Higher

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock indexes set record highs for a second consecutive session yesterday, as stocks were spurred by a slip in the Producer Price Index and a resurgence in technology shares.
"The combination was a real bright spot for stocks," said Barbara G. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "The weakness in producer prices confirmed the scenario of low inflation. And since technology has been leading the stock market, the strength in the group was good for stocks." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.56 points, to close at 4,864.23, surpassing the record set on Wednesday. Among broader market indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.55 points, to 593.26 -- its 66th record high of the year.
And the Nasdaq composite index, which did not participate significantly in Wednesday's surge, soared 17.65 points, to 1,065.59, bolstered by the surge in technology stocks.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange, though, narrowly topped declines, 1,173 to 1,066. Big Board volume totaled 380.8 million shares, up from 366 million shares Wednesday and the recent average daily trading of 347 million shares.
Traders were encouraged at the start of the session by the Government's report on October producer prices, which indicated that inflation remained in check. Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers eased one-tenth of 1 percent for the third time in five months. That report, and another showing a rise in new claims for unemployment benefits, reinforced the hope of some investors that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates again this year.
But such optimism was overshadowed in the bond market by growing worries about the fight in Washington concerning the Federal debt ceiling and the risk of a default. The 30-year Treasury bond dropped 15/32 in price; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.28 percent from 6.25 percent.
Technology stocks posted sharp gains, led by semiconductor issues bouncing back from their recent retreat. Fueling the rally was a semiconductor industry report, released late Wednesday, that showed orders for computer chips were stronger than expected. Shares of Micron Technology Inc. soared 3, to 65; those of the Intel Corporation rose 3 1/16, to 69; Applied Materials Inc. gained 4 1/4, to 52, and the Oracle Corporation advanced 2 3/8, to 47 1/8.
Financial-industry issues also moved higher as the prospects for lower interest rates brightened. Shares of Merrill Lynch & Company rose 3, to 60 1/2; those of Morgan Stanley Group closed at 89 5/8, up 2 1/4; J. P. Morgan closed at 77 7/8, up 3/8, and the Nationsbank Corporation closed at 69 3/8, up 1 1/2.
In contrast, oil stocks were weak, reflecting the fall in the price of crude oil shown in the producer price report. Shares of Texaco Inc. declined 3/4, to 68 3/4; the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company eased 3/8, to 123 1/2; ARCO dropped 1 3/8, to 108 5/8, and the Chevron Corporation fell 3/8 a share, to 47 3/4.
The Kmart Corporation, which said that it would delay the release of its third-quarter earnings by three days to Thursday, sunk to its lowest level in nearly 13 years. The stock of the discount retailer fell 3/8, to 7 7/8; it was the day's most active issue, withtrading of more than 15 million shares.
Shares of Hamburger Hamlet Restaurants Inc. plunged 1 3/4, to 1 3/16, after the company said it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Kulicke & Soffa Industries advanced 3 1/4, to 32, after the company resumed normal production of its semiconductor assembly equipment.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Concern Over U.S. Default Trims Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday after a White House statement on a possible default by the Government unnerved the market.
The selloff came even after a report on producer prices showed moderate inflation growth, which ordinarily would have heartened the market. 
 Prices declined early in the session after the White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, said he saw no chance that the Government would avoid a shutdown next week. Mr. McCurry's comments came as Republicans put the final touches on a stopgap spending measure that the President has promised to veto. And while the spokesman stopped short of saying a default was inevitable, he called it increasingly likely.
Few traders and analysts say they believe the Government will shut down because of the impasse over the Federal budget. But the talk of default from the White House yesterday was enough to deflate the market's optimism that an agreement between President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress on the budget and debt limit could soon be reached. On Wednesday, that optimism lifted the price of the 30-year bond by 25/32.
Yesterday, it appeared that "both sides in Washington will attempt to use the capital markets as a battering ram as either an indicator or validator of their respective positions on the issue," said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and manging director at ASB Capital Management, a Washington firm with about $6 billion of bonds under management.
After Mr. McCurry's comments, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell a half-point and remained near that level throughout the session. The 30-year bond settled at 107 30/32, down 15/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.28 percent from 6.25 percent.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the market's reaction yesterday was fairly restrained given the pessimistic signals from Washington. "It looked more like tech correction than a deep-rooted concern that the debt ceiling will not be lifted," he said.
Mr. Dwyer and other analysts said yesterday's report on producer prices showed that inflation remained contained. The Labor Department said that the Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent in October, in line with economists' expectations and the third drop in five months.
But the bullish data failed to move the market.
"While the market certainly feels heavy, and the rejection of today's friendly data is a red flag, the fact is key levels have not been violated and retail has not been selling," said David Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data. "It looks like we're going to experience contained sideways volatility, with a downward bias, until Washington gets something together."
Still, some economists saw hints of inflation in the producer prices report. Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities Company International, said the index's components showed that the weakness in prices was easing and called the Producer Price Index data "a report with a forked tongue."
In futures trading, the December bond contract settled at 117 19/32. "I like the way bonds withstood the test of fire at 117 13/32 for the December bond futures contract today," said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston. "I now think they are headed back up."

HEADLINE: Greater Poverty Tolls Is Seen in Wefare Bill

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration acknowledged in a new report to Congress today that a Senate bill to restructure the nation's welfare system could push as many as 1.2 million more children into poverty.
But White House officials still held out the possibility that President Clinton could sign the Senate bill if it were somehow to emerge intact from a House and Senate conference committee. 
 "He may have to accept that bill," said the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry. Despite the findings on the bill's effect on children, Mr. McCurry said, the legislation is "within striking distance of something that's going to be acceptable to the President."
The report, which was requested by Congressional Democrats opposed to the welfare legislation, was done by the President's Office of Management and Budget. It comes close to duplicating earlier draft findings that the President received in September from his Health and Human Services Secretary but declined to release.
The Administration's position underscores the dilemma in which Mr. Clinton finds himself as he tries to make good on his 1992 pledge to "end welfare as we know it" but also tries to appease important elements of his base of support going into the election year.
In September, Mr. Clinton virtually endorsed the Senate version of a welfare overhaul. But since then, he has been under growing pressure from liberal Democrats in Congress and officials inside his Administration, as well as from women's groups and advocacy groups for children, to reconsider his position.
Initially today, some liberals said they were pleased that the Administration had documented the poverty that could result from the Senate legislation.
But their praise for the President faded when they heard that the White House was holding out the possibility that Mr. Clinton could still approve the Senate measure despite the findings.
"I don't think it took a genius to tell us the Senate bill would make more children poor," said Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund and a longtime friend and supporter of the Clintons. "But now that you document it, how in the world could you support it? It's just unconscionable, and it's a failure of moral leadership on the part of the President."
But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said he thought House and Senate negotiators might be able to accommodate some of the Administration's recommendations. "We're going to have a good welfare reform bill, one that has and maintains the strong bipartisan support it had in the Senate," Mr. Dole said, "and one I believe President Clinton will sign."
But Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, was far less accommodating. "This new report by the Administration is a road map to another Clinton Administration flip-flop," he said. "He wants to hold on to the failed methods of our current welfare system and throw even more money at it."
The budget office study was released as House and Senate Republicans were pushing to complete a compromise welfare bill. Both the House and Senate measures would replace an array of Federal antipoverty programs with limited lump-sum payments that states could use as they wished to help the poor.
The House measure is more stringent and includes several provisions that are favored by conservatives to fight illegitimacy but have been rejected in the Senate and opposed by the President. Those proposals include one to deny additional benefits to women who had children while on the welfare rolls and one to deny cash benefits to teen-agers who had children out of wedlock.
In its study, the budget office analyzed the Senate measure, the House measure and a Senate Democratic alternative that fell by the wayside. It found that the House welfare proposal could move 2.1 million children into poverty, that the Senate bill could move 1.2 million more children into poverty and that the Senate Democrats' alternative would move 100,000 to 500,000 children into poverty.
The budget analysts said they had used an expansive definition of what counts as a poor person's income to reach their findings, including grants, like food stamps and housing programs, and the effects of taxes in calculating family income. The report noted that if the analysts had used the Census Bureau's definition of poverty, 300,000 children would be pushed into poverty by the Senate plan and 500,000 children into poverty under the House plan.
The budget report recommended some changes that could be made in the Senate welfare legislation to make it less onerous to poor children, including the following:
*Financing for child care for poor mothers could be permanently increased. The House version of the bill cuts child care financing, and the Senate's includes a $3 billion increase for child care, but only for a period of five years.
*States could be required to maintain their spending on welfare at a certain level and to maintain an adequate contingency fund so they could meet the growing need for welfare during recessions.
*More money could be provided to give bonuses to states that successfully moved people from welfare to work.
*States could be required to give parents vouchers for their children's portion of welfare benefits if the parents are cut off from benefits because they hit the five-year time limit without finding work.
The budget office also renewed calls for Congress to raise the minimum wage and to modify a number of its planned deficit-reduction measures that strike at the poor.
"What it adds up to in our view is that there's a great deal of room for improving the welfare bill as it moves through the conference process," said Alice M. Rivlin, the President's budget director. But she also would not say that Mr. Clinton would veto a measure that resembled the original Senate plan without such changes.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who was one of the Senators who requested the study of the welfare bill, said the Administration was unlikely to be able to moderate the Senate bill now because the conference committee would seek a compromise between the House and Senate bills, producing a more stringent measure than the Senate bill.
"Through 11 Presidents and 31 Congresses, we have tried to help dependent children and never, until now, have we undertaken to do them harm," Mr. Moynihan said.

Rivlin, head of the budget office, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, met to discuss the report's findings. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Energy Secretary Used Fund to Monitor Reporters

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary faced a storm of criticism today and the possibility she could lose her job after it was disclosed that she had spent thousands of dollars in Government money for a consulting firm to monitor the reporters who cover her department and to rank them as to how favorable they were.
Senior Clinton Administration officials said they were appalled by what they called her lack of judgment in paying $43,500 to Carma International, a Washington firm, to identify unfriendly press outlets. 
 Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said that Mrs. O'Leary's action, reported today in The Wall Street Journal, was "unacceptable." One senior White House official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mrs. O'Leary might be asked to resign.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, told reporters that he was greatly concerned by The Journal's disclosures and had asked Mrs. O'Leary to give him a full report by the end of the day. He turned away questions as to whether she might lose her job.
Another senior official said that Mrs. O'Leary was in deep trouble but that the White House would wait to see if she could ride out the storm. She was providing the White House a written explanation tonight and was expected on Friday to make her case in person to remain on the job.
Mrs. O'Leary, a former utility company executive, was traveling today in Louisiana, where she told The Associated Press that she had not asked for an evaluation of reporters but for an analysis of news coverage. She said it would have cost the department $170,000 to do the same job itself.
"There's no enemies list, no gumshoes, no investigators," she said.
Her Washington office had earlier arranged a conference call with dozens of reporters to answer questions. But she abruptly postponed the call after White House officials leveled their public criticisms.
But she was quoted later today by The Associated Press as saying the contract had been mischaracterized. "This was a simple effort to analyze the way the department disseminated its messages. Nothing more," she said.
Asked whether she considered resigning, the Secretary replied, "Of course not."
Mrs. O'Leary said the decision to conduct the media study was made in the department's public affairs office without her direct knowledge.
Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat from Nevada, a state with extensive and sometimes contentious dealings with the Energy Department, demanded on the Senate floor today that Mrs. O'Leary herself reimburse the Treasury for the full amount of the consulting contract.
"I have very serious reservations about the judgment of Secretary O'Leary," he said. "Spending tax dollars to investigate and evaluate reporters and media coverage, complete with charts, is completely inappropriate. As Energy Secretary, she should be concerned with energy policy and not her image."
According to documents released with no hesitation today by chagrined department officials eager to show their openness with the press, Carma provided an evaluation of articles and news broadcasts about the department from December through July.
The study also ranked the top 25 favorable and top 25 unfavorable sources quoted in news articles about the department.
The documents showed that Carma had evaluated articles about the department and assigned scores -- on a scale of 1 to 100, with 50 being neutral -- to the reporters who wrote them. The research assistants at Carma tallied the number of references they deemed to be either favorable or unfavorable to assign a score to that reporter's work.
In the July report, H. Joseph Hebert of The Associated Press scored lowest with a 30.8 rating. "As far as I'm concerned, if you have too good a rating, you aren't doing your job," Mr. Hebert said today.
Scoring next-lowest was Matthew L. Wald of The New York Times, with a rating of 46.7.
Adding to the notion that the study was to be used to identify and work to change reporters who wrote unfavorably, Barbara Semedo, the department's press secretary, was quoted by The Journal as saying that the lower ratings "meant we weren't getting our message across, that we needed to work on this person a little."
The Carma analysis evaluated reporting on subjects as diverse as cleaning up nuclear waste, as well as perceptions of Mrs. O'Leary.
Joe Gaither, a senior vice president for research at Carma, said in an interview that under its approach, if a journalist scored an unfavorable rating, it did not necessarily mean the journalist was unfavorably disposed to a client. It might mean that the event was unfavorable. But he said Carma's research could tell a client how that reporter portrayed that event, compared with other reporters.
"All we're trying to do is analyze the news coverage and let our client know what's said being said about them and then to put it into a context for them with regard to other reporters," Mr. Gaither said.
He said the company, which was founded in 1984 and has offices in London, Toronto and in Sydney, Australia, in addition to Washington, does $3.5 million to $4 million in business a year. Most clients, he said, are large corporations.
Carma has also worked as a news-clipping service for Government agencies like the United States Postal Service.
In one sense, the work Carma did for Mrs. O'Leary is similar to what a Government press office does regularly, albeit in an informal manner -- evaluate how its agency is being covered. It is unusual, if not unprecedented, to have an outside consultant charged with that task and to have specific rankings for media outlets.
Mrs. O'Leary won praise early in her tenure for her willingness to disclose information on how the Atomic Energy Commission had conducted radiation experiments on unwitting human subjects. She said such secrecy was no longer needed, and moreover it was improper for a government to withhold such information from its citizens.

HEADLINE: TRIBUNAL INDICTS 3 SERBIA OFFICERS

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
A United Nations tribunal indicted three senior officers in Serbia's Army today, bringing its investigations into war crimes in the former Yugoslavia closer than ever before to the Serbian political leadership and President Slobodan Milosevic.
The indictments, the first handed down for officials in Serbia rather than Bosnian Serbs, were announced by the International Criminal Tribunal in The Hague as the Clinton Administration said a trade embargo on Serbia would be slightly eased. 
 The easing -- officially described by the State Department as a "humanitarian" gesture -- will allow natural gas into Serbia for an initial period of two months to heat homes and help offset the effects of a winter that has come early to the Balkans.
Since Bosnian peace talks began in Dayton, Ohio, eight days ago, Mr. Milosevic has insistently argued for some relaxation of the three-year-old sanctions on Serbia, officials close to the negotiations said. This preoccupation has tended to make progress on other issues difficult.
The fact that the indictments of Serbian officers came on the same day as a gesture was made to Mr. Milosevic that may improve the atmosphere at the peace talks illustrates the growing tension between the international tribunal's quest for justice and the West's determination to secure a peace deal to end the 42-month-old Bosnian war.
The tribunal indicted Gen. Mile Mrksic, Maj. Veselin Sljivancanin and Capt. Miroslav Radic on charges related to the killing of 260 men from the Croatian town of Vukovar after a brutal three-month siege of the town ended with its surrender on Nov. 19, 1991. They were then officers in the old Yugoslav Federal Army. They are now believed to be in Serbia.
On the day the town surrendered, soldiers and officers from the Serbian-dominated force entered Vukovar hospital, where at least 1,000 people had taken shelter in the hope of being rescued by international relief organizations. Men of fighting age were led away, never to be seen again. Most of them are now believed to be buried in a mass grave at Ovcara, near Vukovar.
At the time, the old state of Yugoslavia was still formally in existence, although Croatia and Slovenia had seceded in June 1991. Thus supreme command of the army attacking Vukovar lay constitutionally with the Federal Presidency, where Serbia's influence -- and thus Mr. Milosevic's -- had become completely dominant.
"These indictments will automatically take us further up the line," Graham Blewitt, the tribunal's deputy prosecutor, said in a telephone interview.
"We do assume in an army that a chain of command exists," he said. "Either we will find that specific direct orders did come down the line for what happened in Vukovar. Or, if these officers were acting independently, then those further up had a responsibility to stop or punish the illegal activity."
Over the last year, 43 people, most of them Bosnian Serbs but also a few Bosnian Croats, have been indicted by the court. But only one suspect, Dusan Tadic, a Serb from the northwestern Bosnian town of Prijedor accused of crimes against Muslims at the Omarska camp, is in custody in The Hague.
The most prominent among the accused are the Bosnian Serb political and military leaders, Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic. Dr. Karadzic did not come to the peace talks in Ohio because he would face arrest.
The tribunal's powers to bring those indicted to trial have proved limited up to now. But it appears that countries in the area that refuse to cooperate with the court may suffer economic and political sanction under any peace agreement. Moreover, any international forces policing a peace -- including American troops -- would be under an obligation to arrest indicted suspects if they encounter them.
Mr. Milosevic has consistently denied any responsibility for any war crimes committed during the Croatian war of 1991 or the Bosnian war that began in April 1992. The siege of Vukovar set the tone for the Bosnian war both in the brutality of the attack there on civilians and in the summary execution of many non-Serbs that followed its fall.
Both conflicts have centered on the Serbian minorities in Croatia and Bosnia who rejected inclusion in the two new states and wanted to retain their ties to Belgrade.
The Serbian President initially armed and backed these minorities, using the Yugoslav Army overtly in Croatia and acting in a more disguised way in Bosnia through the widespread use of Serbian militia groups and the creation of a Bosnian Serb army.
As early as March 1991, as Yugoslavia headed toward disintegration, Mr. Milosevic announced that he had "ordered the mobilization of special reservists and the formation of additional Serbian militia units."
The indictments today were the first handed down for officials in Serbia. Other indictments have involved Bosnian Serbs and have thus allowed Mr. Milosevic to say he could do little to secure the arrest of those concerned because Bosnia is another country.
The Serbian President will thus be faced with a delicate decision. Refusal to hand over the three men could mean that any economic aid promised under the terms of an eventual peace accord would not go to Serbia pending the arrest of the officers. Moreover, the lifting of all sanctions on Serbia could be delayed.
General Mrksic, who was a colonel at the time of the Vukovar siege, was sent from Belgrade last May to command the Serb-held area of Croatia known as Krajina. In August, when Croatia attacked, he led a hasty evacuation that left close to 200,000 Serbs as refugees.
By that time, it was clear to Western officials that Mr. Milosevic's desire to support Serbs outside Serbia had given way to an overriding desire for a peace that would secure his power. General Mrksic's actions in Krajina appeared to reflect this quest.
"The indictments today put direct pressure on Mr. Milosevic," Mr. Blewitt, the deputy prosecutor, said. "In the past Belgrade has been able to say that Bosnian Serbs were separate units and inquiries should be made in Pale. That's not possible now. Noncompliance will ultimately result in our informing the Security Council and could bring further consequences for Serbia."
Administration officials said that if Mr. Milosevic were ultimately indicted by the tribunal, he would be treated in the same way as Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic, who were indicted earlier this year. Since the peace talks in Ohio began, it has become clear that the Administration is determined to oust these two men as soon as possible.
But the Administration is now so deeply engaged with Mr. Milosevic as the most effective single vehicle in the Balkans for securing a peace that any eventual indictment would clearly be a very delicate political issue.
Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said the decision to allow gas supplies into Serbia for two months was made on "humanitarian" grounds given the extreme cold in Serbia. Because it is such a measure, the United Nations sanctions committee can make the decision without a meeting of the Security Council. The formal decision is expected on Friday or Saturday.
It is clear, however, that Mr. Milosevic's deep preoccupation with sanctions relief has hindered progress in the peace talks. Up to now, little real headway on the most difficult issues of territory and governance in Bosnia has been made. "They only really got stuck into the thick of it in the past 24 hours," a senior official said.
To try to push the talks along, Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to visit Dayton on Friday. An announcement is expected on reinforcing the Muslim-Croatian federation, which has been under extreme strain. American officials hope that the consolidation of the federation will insure that a united front is presented to the Serbs in the more difficult phase of negotiations that will now begin.
The announcement will center on the formation of a federation customs union, the reunification of the divided city of Mostar, the return of refugees and other issues. Similar commitments have been made in the past and announced with some fanfare, only to make little or no difference on the ground where suspicions between Croats and Muslims are still virulent.

HEADLINE: Senate Joins House in Voting to Raise Medicare Premiums

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Senate followed the House tonight in voting, largely along party lines, to increase Medicare premiums. In doing so, both chambers forged ahead without waiting for an overall agreement on how to redesign the Medicare program, which provides health insurance for 37 million people who are elderly or disabled.
It appears likely, but not certain, that Medicare premiums will actually increase in January. The issue is one of many tangled up in a huge confrontation between President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress. 
 By a vote of 52 to 44, the Senate rejected efforts by Democrats to block the proposed increase in Medicare premiums. On Wednesday, the House, by a vote of 230 to 197, approved the increase in premiums as part of a stopgap spending bill.
The proposed increase in the monthly premium, to $53.50 from $46.10, is one of the most contentious parts of the Republican plan to cut projected spending on Medicare by $270 billion in the next seven years. Republicans said the change must be approved soon to take effect on Jan. 1, when the premium would otherwise drop to $42.50 a month.
The timing is important for several reasons. If the premium increases in January, it will be covered by a cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits, which takes effect at the same time. Medicare premiums are deducted from monthly Social Security checks.
But if the premium increased later in 1996, the change would be more noticeable, and it might become a political issue in the Presidential election and in Congressional elections.
Republicans met today behind closed doors to iron out differences in the overall Medicare legislation passed last month by the House and the Senate. Social Security officials said they must have a decision on the level of Medicare premiums by Wednesday so they can write computer programs for the Social Security checks to be sent to millions of people in January. The premium will then be locked in place through April 1996, they said.
Republicans want to raise the premiums for all of 1996 as part of a stopgap spending bill that will finance Government operations through the remainder of this month. The bill is known as a continuing resolution because it provides "continuing appropriations."
Republicans said it was absurd to let premiums decline at a time when Medicare costs were growing more than 10 percent a year. Democrats said the Republicans were trying to sneak the higher premiums through Congress on the stopgap spending bill with inadequate debate.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said: "Cuts in payments to doctors are not included in the continuing resolution. Cuts in payments to hospitals are not included. The only Medicare cut in this bill is a proposal to impose a new tax on the elderly and disabled," in the form of higher premiums.
President Clinton cited the increased premiums as one reason he would probably veto the stopgap spending bill.
Republicans said that their proposal did not represent a radical change in Medicare because beneficiaries, overall, would still pay 31.5 percent of the cost of Part B of the program, which covers doctors' services and laboratory tests. For several years, Congress specified the dollar amount of the premiums. If there is no change in the current law the premium will be set to equal 25 percent of Part B and beneficiaries will pay $42.50 a month.
Representative Bill Thomas, a California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said that Democrats were "pandering to seniors" in demanding that the premium be allowed to decline.
Under current law, states must pay the premiums and certain other health care costs for Medicare beneficiaries with incomes below the official poverty level ($8,967 a year for an elderly couple). Martin A. Corry, director of Federal affairs at the American Association of Retired Persons, said there was no guarantee of such protection for elderly people in the stopgap spending bill.
"Any increase in premiums should be coupled with protections for low-income Medicare beneficiaries, just as in current law," Mr. Corry said.
Democrats said the proposed increase in the Medicare premium would reduce or wipe out the annual inflation adjustment in Social Security checks for many people.
Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that Republicans from the House and the Senate were close to agreement on many provisions of the overall Medicare bill. But they have not even begun negotiations with the White House.
The conferees said they were likely to drop a Senate proposal to increase the $100 deductible that beneficiaries must pay each year before Medicare will help pay doctors' bills.
The negotiators said they had also agreed to create a new trust fund to help pay the costs of training doctors, though many teaching hospitals would still face substantial cuts in Federal aid.
Mr. Archer said the House and Senate negotiators had agreed to make it easier for doctors and hospitals to establish their own health plans, which could then sell coverage to Medicare beneficiaries. These "provider-sponsored organizations" would compete with commercial insurance companies and Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
The conferees are also expected to create incentives for elderly people to establish special savings accounts that would be used to pay medical expenses. But lawmakers said they had not agreed on whether to accept provisions of the House bill that would limit payments to victims of medical malpractice. Doctors have sought such limits, but consumer advocates oppose them.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Casino Plan May Not Be a Pipe Dream

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J.

 BODY:
IT looks like a regular parking lot. Two and a half acres of blacktop, a few weeds and the remnants of a beer bottle or two behind Phil & Eddie's Bar and the Rusty Rudder Restaurant off the boardwalk.
But to many people here, the lot could be, should be, sacred territory.
They said so on Election Day. By more than 2 to 1 -- 1,081 to 491 -- Wildwood residents want the city to deed the unused municipal parking lot to the Delaware tribe of western Oklahoma for a casino. And although the referendum was nonbinding, city officials said they consider it binding. 
 "We put in an application for a binding referendum," said William Mitchell, the city's public works commissioner. But the Cape May County Clerk's office made a mistake, he said, and labeled it nonbinding. "It doesn't really matter. The voters are serious. We can now go ahead and try to get this to work."
Try being the operative word, of course. Of all the casino proposals floating around the country (Idea of the Week: gaming cruises off Staten Island's Navy home port), Wildwood's plan for an Indian casino at the parking lot sounds like one of the most farfetched.
Ever since Chief Larry Snake of the Delaware tribe came to town in August and declared the parking lot ancestral Indian land, state officials have practically laughed off the notion as a pipe dream.
Mr. Mitchell said the city has remained undeterred, despite Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's "serious concerns" about gambling outside Atlantic City. Even despite Congressman Robert G. Torricelli's bill to ban Indian casinos outside of reservations. And especially despite the 12 casinos gloating on the landscape just 30 miles away.
MANY people here consider Atlantic City the root of Wildwood's evils. They say Atlantic City stole Wildwood's tourists, and now they want them back.
"The gradual decline started after three or four casinos opened up," said John Nickels, who owns Nickels' Midway Pier, an array of arcades, shops and food stands. "Wildwood was the most successful resort on the East Coast. Now, you can shoot a cannon down the middle of the city and not hit anyone."
He was not kidding. After Labor Day, the city's street lights start blinking and the boardwalk that so many teen-agers have considered the reason for summer stands unamused, empty. The eight-block business district looks like a set for a Rod Serling fantasy. It's one boarded-up building after another, with hardly a place open to get breakfast.
Ten years ago, if you were a teen-ager from Pennsylvania, Delaware or New Jersey looking for a beach, Wildwood was it. Next to this blue-collar Riviera, the famous Victorian inns of Cape May seemed so prissy. But there aren't as many teen-agers as there used to be; even at the height of summer, the motels are only 80 percent full.
And Wildwood is tired of hibernating nine months a year. It hurts in obvious ways. Unemployment hovers at about 30 percent. The city, with about 5,000 year-round residents, is saddled with foreclosed properties. It plans to auction 40 lots and buildings next weekend.
Wildwood has the same rationale as other towns betting on a casino for revival: it is worth a try. The city began scouting for an Indian tribe to call its very own three years ago. It found it in the Delawares of Anadarko, Okla., which Chief Snake said had been driven from New Jersey more than a century ago.
ON paper, the pact the city signed with the tribe sounds as exciting as any. The tribe would guarantee $8 million a year to Wildwood. The gaming hall would be alcohol-free, which would keep the 100 or so pubs in town happy; no casino hotel would be built to compete with the city's 10,000 hotel and motel rooms. First choice of jobs would go to Indians, but backers estimate that the casino would provide 2,000 jobs on the grounds and 8,000 in related services.
With all the hurdles, Mr. Mitchell sounds optimistic. (The state cannot prevent the building of a casino on a reservation, but whether it can stop one on land deeded to a tribe is a central question in a case in Federal court in Oregon.) "If we had one big thing -- a casino -- it could turn everything around," he said. "Determination often pays off."
The way he describes it, a casino does not seem so farfetched after all. He and others like to believe the rest of New Jersey is jealous of the plan. After all, when Wildwood first announced the idea, a councilman from Phillipsburg, clear on the opposite end of the state, announced that the Delaware Indians and their casino did not belong in Wildwood. With Phillipsburg right on the Delaware River, he said, the Delawares of Anadarko, Okla., have a much closer tie to ancestral land in his town.

HEADLINE: Home Values Are Higher in All Regions

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Helped by lower mortgage rates that spurred demand, the value of most homes rose sharply in the third quarter in all regions of the country, the National Association of Realtors said today.
The median price of existing single-family homes rose 4.6 percent in the third quarter to $116,200, from $111,100 in the second quarter. The third-quarter price was 4.3 percent higher than the third quarter of 1994, when the median price was $111,400. The median is the midpoint; half the homes sell for more and half for less than that price. 
 Regionally, the median price rose 1.4 percent in the Northeast over the third quarter a year ago, 2.7 percent in the Midwest, 6.3 percent in the South and 4.2 percent in the West.

HEADLINE: Vestiges of Dictatorship

 BODY:
The Latin American delegation at the recent United Nations anniversary consisted of Fidel Castro and the representatives of 16 freely elected governments. That Latin America is home to only one clear dictatorship is a real success story. But as in former Communist Europe, elections in Latin America do not mean that true democracy is here to stay or even, in many places, here at all.
The democratization of Latin America is a sad song, and an old one. The end of the dictators was first heralded in the 1940's with elections in three nations. By the next decade, two of those had fallen to military dictatorship. In 1960 Paraguay was South America's only dictatorship. By 1976, in all of Latin America, there were only four democracies. Today military officials have made coup threats in Honduras, Guatemala, Chile, Peru and Venezuela. 
 A less visible but more common problem is that elected government has not brought an end to the abuses associated with dictatorship. Civilian government is no guarantee of respect for human rights. In four years in the mid-1980's, 6,000 people were killed or abducted by security forces in democratic Peru, the vast majority unarmed civilians. That is twice the number of murders and disappearances during the 17-year dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet in neighboring Chile.
In many countries, military leaders tolerate civilian rule only as long as they retain the power they held as dictators. Many armed forces still own networks of banks and businesses, and control civilian agencies, such as the customs service, that provide opportunity for corruption. In most nations, officers are still tried for human rights abuse in military courts, where they are routinely acquitted.
Civilian governments violate human rights as well. One egregious example is the so-called "faceless" courts of Colombia and Peru, where the identity of judges is disguised. Defendants face Draconian sentences, including life imprisonment, in trials where they are often not confronted with the evidence against them. Although the United States Agency for International Development encouraged the creation of these courts in Colombia to protect judicial authorities in cases involving terrorists and drug traffickers, they have also been used to prosecute peaceful leftists.
The Clinton emphasis on trade is a vast improvement over the policies of past Administrations, which often openly backed dictatorship and military rule. But America still has an important role beyond that of buyer and seller. Washington remains the most important outside influence on the Latin sectors most likely to block democracy: military, business and agricultural leaders.
America should use its influence to support civilian leaders seeking to control their militaries. It should push governments to respect human rights, and encourage the growth of an already impressive array of independent organizations, such as human rights groups and peasant associations, that hold their governments accountable.
With the end of the cold war and reflexive American support of Latin military rule, prospects for lasting democracy in Latin America have never been better. But democracy in Latin America is a work in progress, and its courageous advocates still need American and worldwide support.
